rank_250.title: London bid another step forward
rank_250.text:
Sport in this country has come a long way since hilarity was the loudest response to the idea of a London Olympic bid. In those early days, people imagined one long fiasco of missed deadlines and signal failures on the tube. The Games would suffer death by committee, death by engineering works. Non-believers cried: " Look at the Dome, look at Wembley, look at us! " Were the British not the gold medallists in chaos?

This black comedy of self-deprecation had its uses. It gave London a reason to look into the cracked mirror of the Thames. Like America these past 25 years, Britain has tended to put private consumption before public investment. This has turned us into a nation which drinks caffe lattes and eats rocket salads but can't get to work on time because of the trains. Health, education, transport: these are the three great anxieties of modern British life. So along comes a proposal for a London Olympic bid and we all have to decide what we think: not about the Games so much as our capital city - our deepening culture of self-doubt.

The best bet was to keep it simple. Would London be a better or worse place to live after the Olympic circus had left town? The city's mayor, Ken Livingstone, was the most impressive performer at yesterday's official announcement. He preached the gospel of regeneration. "Not since Queen Victoria was on the throne will a single decision have had such an effect on London," he said while assuring ratepayers that he would play to win.

It ought to be obvious that the crew on British sport's old ship of fools should be kept away from the delicate bidding process. This is not another free ride for the gin and tonic brigade. The best sporting administrators should be led to the fore and the worst told to spend more time at the allotment. Internationally, the 2006 World Cup bid showed the Football Association (and by implication the English) to be hopelessly misguided in their belief that votes could be won by parading Sir Bobby Charlton around the world.

The more the FA rammed tradition down the world game's throat the more it gagged. So the best foundation for London's Olympic campaign is not the old mother country rhetoric but humility: an acceptance that London needs the Games more than the Games need London. Bringing them to this country will leave an infrastructure legacy to compare with the advances made in Barcelona, Sydney and Athens.

London is routinely referred to as one of the world's great cities, which it is. More accurately, though, it's a mosaic of small towns rammed together into a steaming, slow-moving metropolis of abundant creativity and energy but no real civic sense. By 2012, at both extremes of the District Line, Londoners may have discovered a new reason to regard each other as neighbours and participants in a single, consuming urban drama. They will pay for it, sure, but there may be a fresh light in London's eye, a better appreciation of what the city is capable of beyond the old imperatives of getting and spending.

The objections that were raised like street barricades by the antis have been crushed. The first was that it's immoral to spend £2.6 billion of public money on a three-week fiesta when the Government are still acquiescing in the sale of school playing fields and under-investing in physical education. That needed to be said. But this was never an either/or scenario. It's not as if those billions were piled high on a Westminster table and the Cabinet had to decide whether to spend them on athletic equipment in London comprehensives or splurge it all on one of the two biggest shows on earth (the other one being football's World Cup).

Another firm protestation was that we shouldn't need the Games to sort out our tube network, the East End and our dismal tradition of leaving health-improving sports to their own devices. Who could argue against such moral logic? Never mind the A-Z. Some days in London you're doing well if you get from A to B. The hard truth, though, is that governments achieve change quicker when they have an imposed timetable or an excuse. There is no greater incentive for a politician than protecting his place in history. Perversely, the Tony Blair-Jacques Chirac rivalry is good news for the organisers of London's bid. It keeps No 10's mind on the job.

The sporting argument is strong, but nothing persuades quite like the possibility that London will advance 40 years in 10, and achieve in seven years of frantic investment a better balance between East and West. Better trains, more venues and facilities - the long-term benefit of which must be universal access - moisture for the grass roots. One only has to step off the rattler at Manchester's Piccadilly station to appreciate the effect of last summer's Commonwealth Games. Aside from the new stadiums and the new look for Piccadilly Gardens, there is a noticeable increase in Manchester's confidence, its self-esteem.

Ironically, it was Manchester which played the victim in Britain's last, and almost entirely shambolic, Olympic bid, almost a decade ago. Sydney blew them away. But we've come a long way since a senior British Olympic administrator suggested an athletes' village could be built under canvas in Hyde Park - a kind of Glastonbury of wrestlers and javelin throwers.

We can throw all sorts of abstractions around: unity, strong leadership, vision. But what will really bring the Games to London is clever horse-trading among the 127 International Olympic Committee members whose votes will determine the venue for 2012. Rhetoric and grand plans for the East End will not by themselves turn heads. Sad this, but persuasion is the cold reality of the piano bar in the five-star hotel.

Today, and for one day only, the architects of the bid can reflect on how far New Labour thinking has come since the House of Commons listlessly debated the British Olympic Association's proposal. Yesterday Tessa Jowell, Secretary of State at the Department for Culture, Media and Sport, went through an astonishing conversion. She promised that the Games "will put sport - from the school-yard to the medal podium - at the heart of government thinking." We should hold her to that.

rank_236.title: London's Valley of hope
rank_236.text:
With an 80,000 capacity stadium as its centrepiece and a promise not to include any white elephant developments, the London bid for the 2012 Olympics finally took shape yesterday.

Plans unveiled by the bid team show how 14 of the 35 sports will be located in a 500-acre Olympic zone contained within 1,500 acres of the Lower Lea Valley.

From Hackney Marshes in the north to the River Thames in the south, the regeneration of this part of London will mark the biggest urban park development seen in Europe for 200 years.

The Olympics will also mean that the redevelopment already planned for this part of London could take just eight years instead of 20.

The bid may have been slow to start but six months' work has gone into a plan of the Olympic park and sporting venues that will be presented to East End communities at a series of public meetings over the next two weeks.

On the face of it, the 2012 team have come up with something none of the other bidding cities can match: a compact Olympic site offering half of the athletes taking part only a 15-minute journey to their events.

Keith Mills, the chief executive of London 2012, said: "The plan shows our preferred options for the Olympic bid but with the public consultation process starting this week, nothing is set in stone."

The Olympic zone, lying between the boroughs of Hackney, Waltham Forest, Tower Hamlets and Newham, contains the BMX cycling courses and velodrome, indoor arenas for basketball, volleyball and handball, the aquatic centre for swimming and diving and the Olympic stadium itself.

There will be an all-weather tennis centre and hockey pitches and, within walking distance, an athletes' village of 5,000 houses with 17,000 beds, together with the media and broadcast centres.

The redevelopment of one of London's most neglected areas will also involve the reclaiming of the River Lea and a co-ordinated network of roads to offer a picturesque and practical route through the Olympic venues.

Running through the middle of the Olympic zone will be a public plaza.

The London Development Agency, who are providing £15 million for the bid and underwriting the Games by up to £250 million, claim they will have acquired more than 50 per cent of the land by the time the capital's detailed bid plans are submitted to the International Olympic Committee in November 2004.

Even London's biggest bugbear, transport, appears to have been solved. The new international rail station at Stratford will be the principal hub while the main A12 and A13 roads will offer fast lanes into the centre of London.

Mindful of the IOC's growing obsession with the Olympic legacy, however, the London 2012 team have concentrated on what will be left once the Games have left town.

"We're committed to a legacy that will ensure that no venues are built without a clear plan for their post-Games use," said Mills. "There will be no white elephants at the London Games. We'll build what we need and no more."

The cycling facilities, aquatic centre and buildings used for the media centres will stay and the athletes' village will provide the housing stock so prized by Ken Livingstone and the Greater London Authority.

The major concern about the legacy left by the Games, however, will come with the stadium which will be, according to the plan, in Marshgate Lane.

Future plans for an almost new stadium with one careful owner remain unclear but those London football clubs looking for new homes provide several likely options.

"We are determined to show the IOC that we won't be left with something like the Homebush Stadium in Sydney," Mills said.

"There are various options on the table, including providing a new home for a London football club. But whatever is built there has to be economically viable and something the local community will sustain and support."

The IOC will announce their choice of the host city for the 2012 Olympics in July 2005.

rank_228.title: How an old people's home can bring London's dream to reality
rank_228.text:
If the Olympic evaluation commission were looking for the best examples of passion on their visit to London's venues yesterday, they came from an American and a Scotsman.

Tim Leiweke, the president and chief executive of the United States-based Anschutz Entertainment Group, impressed upon them how the Dome, once Britain's finest white elephant, was about to burst into life again with a 26,000-seat arena able to stage basketball and gymnastics. Leiweke, whose company were spending some £166 million on reinvigorating one of the capital's wasted wonders, said: "We are a US company helping London win the bid. That is very significant."

Sir Robin Wales, the mayor of Newham, explained how aspiration and the legacy of a London Olympics were firing up the good folk of Stratford as the bulldozers laid waste their corner of East London.

It was rousing stuff that could not have failed to impress Nawal El Moutawakel and her team of inspectors, in London to assess the capital's bid for the 2012 Olympics.

It was a day for El Moutawakel's commissioners to see if the reality matched the claims made in the 23-themed candidature file submitted by London to the International Olympic Committee in November.

What they saw was a city at work and eager to impress. The London 2012 banners were everywhere as they made their early-morning foray from their five-star Docklands hotel into the drab landscape of one of Europe's most socially deprived areas.

First stop for the IOC coach was Holden Point, a 22-storey, old people's home in Stratford, hardly the location they might have imagined for the best view of London's Olympic dream.

But it was from a prefabricated building specially erected on the roof of this building that they saw the focus of London's bid.

Stretching out beneath them and dominated by the mountains of mud surrounding Stratford's new international railway station was the proposed site of the Olympic Park.

Brightly coloured blimps marked where the park's sporting venues would be built. In the distance, they could see where the 80,000 seat Olympic stadium would be and where the world's media would report the Games. Later some computer-generated sequences illustrated how the building site before them would be transformed into the biggest new area of urban parkland in Europe, linked to central London by bullet trains taking only seven minutes to make the journey from Stratford to King's Cross.

The planning applications were in place, agreements made and the regeneration of Stratford would proceed, irrespective of the Olympic bid's success or failure.

Amid all the talk of grand schemes, the common touch came from Sir Robin, the Scotsman originally from Kilmarnock, who told the IOC inspectors of the latest example of London's Olympic legacy.

Sir Robin said: "This is a nice wee example of legacy, built for you to look out at the fabulous mounds of mud."

He explained that the prefabricated building erected to protect the IOC commissioners from the worst of the winter winds would be left for Holden Point's residents to enjoy.

From there, Nawal and her team were taken past the Railway Tavern and the gardens of Waddington Road to a clearing in the building site and a small white marquee put up for their convenience.

Even El Moutawakel would have smiled at the incongruity of it all. Here in the tent, she listened to more presentations on how life would be in the Olympic Park of 2012.

If the IOC team needed more reality, it came with their 15-minute journey by Land Rover through the 4.7 mile tunnel from Stratford to King's Cross.

Still two years away from carrying high-speed trains, the $5 billion Channel Tunnel rail link would be used to whisk 24,000 passengers an hour from central London to the Olympic Park.

rank_196.title: Coe insists London legacy is secure
rank_196.text:
Lord Coe, the chairman of the London Organising Committee for the Olympic Games, was at his diplomatic best yesterday in putting the Central Council for Physical Recreation in their place over the city's Olympic legacy.

Speaking at the 34th CCPR national conference, where the theme was "2012 - more than just medals", Coe assured his audience of officials, administrators and local authority representatives that the legacy of the London Olympics was in good hands.

The CCPR, a lobbying group established in 1935 who represent 270 sporting bodies and 150,000 clubs with 13 million members, had warned that plans to create a legacy of participation were in danger of falling behind schedule.

Tim Lamb, the CCPR's chief executive, said: "We want to see one organisation being given responsibility for delivering a legacy of physical activity from the Games throughout the UK.

"As things stand, there's no single body which can be held to account for this kind of legacy issue and that's something that could cause problems down the line."

In his 30-minute speech, however, Coe outlined a raft of programmes already in place, designed to increase awareness of the Games and participation in sport. He added that the legacy of the Games was ingrained in the work of the Olympic Board, who are overseeing London's preparations. He urged the CCPR to "keep doing what you are doing and have been doing for the past 70 years".

The Olympic Board, chaired by Tessa Jowell, the Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport, include Coe and representatives from the British Olympic Association and the Olympic Delivery Authority and meet twice a month.

Coe said later: "I think we have made an extremely good start. Denis Oswald, the chairman of the International Olympic Committee's co-ordination commission who is not taken to using hyperbole, said he was impressed by London's legacy plans."

rank_107.title: Olympics 2012: what will happen when the crowds leave?
rank_107.text:
The Olympic effort will boost the local market, but possibly at a huge cost after the Games, writes Doug Morrison

Last London's housing market will reap the benefits of the Olympics long before the start of the 2012 Games, although the much-vaunted legacy for property immediately thereafter is looking less certain, according to King Sturge.

New research from the property consultant – based on the experiences of the previous four host cities – suggests that house prices "influenced" by the Olympics will rise at least 5 per cent faster per annum than the UK market generally over the next five years. King Sturge reveals that many districts close to the Olympic Park – with the notable exception of Stratford itself – have already seen 10 per cent house price growth since the 2005 winning bid announcement, but remain at a discount to average London house prices.

Dr Angus McIntosh, King Sturge's research partner, says that a combination of transport improvements and the "Olympic effect" are likely to boost the local market before 2012. "But that's the issue,' he says. "When all the crowds have gone, what are you left with?"

King Sturge's main concern revolves around the glut of housing planned for the Lower Lea Valley – 40,000 new homes over the next 20 years – underpinning in principle the Government's aim to make the wider Thames Gateway one of its key growth areas. McIntosh says: "At the moment there's a lot of discussion about the [Olympic] construction programme being over budget, but we haven't found any clear vision of what legal or political structure will be in place in the future.

"You think of thousands of new homes, the parkland, the schools, the doctors' surgeries, all the bits that make sustainable urban development. Who is going to manage and maintain it? Who are the asset managers, not in 2012 but 2022?"

The Olympic Park site alone will accommodate 9,000 permanent homes, half of which will be redeveloped from the athletes' village by property giant Lend Lease and its housebuilding partner First Base.

Lend Lease and First Base want to turn the athletes' village into Britain's first £1bn residential real estate investment trust, banking on the idea that more Londoners will be prepared to rent property as London's housing shortfall and affordability crisis worsens.

Richard Powell, a director of First Base, says: "One of the primary reasons for the residential fund is that you have a single management entity. Over time that will allow us to sell chunks of stock but not flood the market. It's in our control."

But there is no such control beyond the village site, which is why there are concerns that the huge house-building programme could destabilise the market around Stratford, even allowing for London's overall imbalance between supply and demand. One of East London's biggest house-builders is Oracle Group, which is active everywhere except Stratford.

Chairman David Burke says: "One of the things we're keen to see is more of a plan for how the homes are going to be released after the Olympics." He added: "It's important to get good community spirit in a regeneration area and if they are all dumped on the market at the same time you're going to struggle to create any community spirit because you'll have lots of houses empty."

The London Development Agency (LDA) aims to address such concerns with an "Olympic legacy master plan", which will cover the new housing and related infrastructure and services in the Lower Lea Valley.

This week the LDA announced a short-list of private sector groups bidding for the chance to draw up the master plan. It will form the basis of an outline planning application in 2009 and provide the "context" for all development after 2012.

The LDA will regain control of the Olympic Park once the games are over but in its report, King Sturge recommends that a long-term trust or urban corporation be created immediately to co-ordinate the long-term sustainability of all the development sites.

King Sturge suggests there are salutary lessons to be learned from under-used former Olympic villages in Barcelona and Sydney. According to its report, there are concerns even now that these developments "can suffer social problems and isolation" rather than integration into the local communities. Athens, at least initially, was the worst of the lot, McIntosh says: "A full 12 months after the Olympic Games all the houses were empty."

Construction matters

Company set to build stadium has 'fantastic track record' reports Doug Morrison

John Armitt, the new chairman of the Olympic Delivery Authority (ODA), last week played down fears over the tender process and escalating costs.

The ODA is expected to unveil detailed designs of the Olympic stadium and sign off a final contract with the main builder, Team McAlpine, in the next few weeks. There have been concerns that the ODA would struggle to get value for money because Team McAlpine was the only bidder for the contract, even though the group has won plaudits for its work on Arsenal’s Emirates stadium.

But Armitt told The Daily Telegraph: "We’re getting a team with a fantastic track record. Very often in construction you don’t get continuity. We’re getting that with the main stadium."

Armitt, who joined the ODA from Network Rail in September, also dismissed similar concerns over the aquatics centre after German firm Hochtief and French group Eifel withdrew from the tender process, leaving Balfour Beatty as the only bidder.

"Two have pulled out but we’re quite happy with Balfour Beatty. We can now finish this with Balfour – it is one of the biggest contractors in the UK," said Armitt.

A final budget for the aquatics centre has yet to be agreed. He dismissed the idea that some contractors might regard London 2012 as a poisoned chalice, pointing out that there are multiple bidders on the other arenas and facilities.

"We’re quite optimistic," he said. Armitt was speaking after a forum in Stratford where members of the public quizzed the Olympic organisers over preparations for the Games. He told the Stratford audience: "When building projects are built on time they’re normally built to budget."

He was speaking the day after London 2012 organisers admitted to members of the London Assembly that the cost of the main stadium would be £496m compared with the £280m estimate made at the time of London’s bid for the Games in 2005 – a 77 per cent increase that the organisers attribute to inflation and VAT.

rank_248.title: IOC inspectors to give London a lift
rank_248.text:
The man in charge of construction for the 2012 Olympics has welcomed plans by London's new mayor, Boris Johnson, to appoint a team of city financial experts to examine the Games bill, insisting that there is nothing to hide.

As an International Olympic Committee inspection team begin a three-day visit to the capital today to monitor progress on the 2012 project, John Armitt, the chairman of the Olympic Delivery Authority, said the work remained on budget and on schedule.

Johnson, who will meet the IOC co-ordination commission for the first time when he takes part in a presentation on Olympic legacy this afternoon, made it a campaign pledge to keep control of Olympic costs and is understood to be planning to appoint a city high-flyer as his representative on the ODA board.

A recent MPs' report accused the London 2012 team of "spending money like water" and fears are growing that the global credit crunch could push the overall bill past the £9.3 billion ceiling announced by the Government last year. It has already risen sharply from the original £3.4 billion budget when London won the bid in 2005.

But Armitt remains confident that the new budget will not be exceeded. "We believe the budget to be a sensible one and we spent a lot of time developing it with Government," he said. "I've always said, 'Don't ask me to give you a guarantee', but we do stand a very good chance of completing the works within budget.

"It is understandable for a new mayor with a major piece of activity like this going on in his domain to want to make sure that the costs are under control. We'll be happy to work with anyone he appoints to have a look at them."

While arguments continue about the cost of the Games, the rapid pace of construction work is likely to receive a glowing report from the IOC.

On Thursday, the inspection team will be taken to the Olympic Park in Stratford, where a ground-breaking ceremony will mark the start of construction of the main Olympic stadium - three months ahead of schedule.

Work on the aquatics centre will begin in the summer while contracts have recently been signed to build the velodrome, though negotiations with developers are still continuing over the other two main building projects on the Olympic Park site - the media and broadcast centre and the athletes' village.

During their visit, the IOC are expected to rubber-stamp a proposal to switch the fencing venue from the Olympic Park to the ExCel Centre and to move basketball to the original fencing venue in the northern part of the Stratford site.

"We will be giving the IOC an upbeat message," Armitt said. "In sporting terms, what we'll be saying is the first lap has gone well but we are now into the long back stretch.

"The next couple of years, when the bulk of the construction activity will be taking place, are going to be a major challenge. But at least we've got off to a good start."

rank_201.title: Boris Johnson uncovers 'secret wine cellar' in City Hall
rank_201.text:
The new London Mayor says he is unsure whether it is owned by the Greater London Authority or by Ken Livingstone, the man he ousted last month.

In his first major interview since becoming Mayor Mr Johnson also reveals he has serious "issues" with planning for the London Olympics. He says there needs to be a new "master plan."

Mr Johnson told The Daily Telegraph how he had still been finding different parts of City Hall and "nooks and crannies" in his own "cavernous office" when he this week discovered the stash of wine.

He said: "Last night I flung wide a cupboard that I had not opened before and found to my delight a fridge, stocked with several bottles. But then, beside it was another cupboard. I opened that - it was like being Howard Carter with Tutankhamun - there was this astonishingly fine collection of wine.

"They were very fine bottles left behind by Mayor Livingstone. Whether they are GLA bottles of wine or his own we have yet to discover.

"There are rows and rows of glistening Chateauneuf du Pape, a goodly hoard, over a hundred bottles."

In his first month in charge Mr Johnson has been worried about some of the Olympic legacy planning.

He said: "We are going to see some action. We need a master plan. We need to know what we're doing and why we're doing it.

"We are looking at ways of saving. We don't want to sink billions into East London without having long term benefit for London."

Despite the battle with Mr Livingstone, Mr Johnson disclosed that he is trying to find a job for his predecessor.

Mr Johnson's Conservative career has been boosted by winning in London, but he said, borrowing Lord Heseltine's phrase, that he cannot foresee the circumstances when he might become party leader.

Mr Johnson will resume his role as Daily Telegraph columnist later this month.

rank_240.title: Visit London launches first global ad campaign to build on Britain's Olympic success
rank_240.text:
Visit London is to launch its biggest and first ever global advertising campaign on Saturday in a bid to capitalise on the success of Britain's Olympic athletes and drum up interest in the 2012 Games.

The £4m campaign will be centred around an aerial map of London transposed onto the globe, an image that will be projected onto landmarks including The Tower of London, The Globe theatre and The 02 arena.

The campaign, launched on the eve of the handover of the Olympic torch, will run under the banner 'See the World, Visit London'.

The advertising will be carried in the UK and London press, the capital's Underground network, online and on giant screens in outside venues in five continents.

James Bidwell, chief executive of Visit London, said: "In the words of one of the finest English authors, Samuel Johnson, 'there is in London all that life can afford' and as we prepare to host the greatest sporting event on earth our campaign shows there is no other place to be than here."

Pointing out that London already welcomes more overseas visitors than any other city in the world, Mr Bidwell added: "Tourism in London is big business and a deliverable legacy with a potential £2.2bn incremental revenue opportunity for London alone."

The campaign comes after UK tourism chiefs and MPs have in recent months blasted the government over a lack of funding for the industry and its threat to the Olympic legacy.

Last month a Treasury Select Committee report described the Government's decision last October to cut funding to UK tourism board VisitBritain by 18pc by 2010-11 as "baffling" and branded its reasons for doing so as "wholly unconvincing".

The MPs described the timing of the cuts ahead of the Olympics as "regrettable" but said with greater Government investment it was "not too late to realise fully the tourism benefits of the Games".

rank_247.title: Olympics: Youth sports struggle as British win gold at Beijing Games
rank_247.text:
Too much cash is being diverted to fund training for Britain's elite athletes, critics claim. The result is that the majority of the population, who enjoy physical activity but can never hope, or don't have the desire, to win awards, are losing out.

Olympic success has left many youngsters clamouring to join sports clubs – but the clubs are short of funds and are having to close the door on sporting hopefuls. It also comes in the middle of rising public concerns about the growing levels of obesity among the young.

So today, as the Olympic mantle is officially passed from China to Great Britain and the nation rightly celebrates the proud achievements of its sporting heroes, community sporting groups were left wondering who would pay for the future training of ordinary Britons who simply enjoy sport and want to play more of it.

While funding for the minority of truly talented athletes has increased significantly, grassroots sporting organisations say their cash injections have been meagre and fall far short of the sums needed not just to undo years of neglect, but to boost the sports' popularity. The cost of hosting the 2012 Games will only add to the problem, they claim.

And the policy, they say, flies in the face of a supposed legacy of the 2012 games: to get more people participating in physical activity.

"Community sport is now the weak link in the chain," Tim Lamb, the chief executive of the Central Council for Physical Recreation, which represents 270 sporting bodies, said last night. "Unless you develop volunteers and invest in clubs, you can't hope to grow capacity. And capacity is what we will need if we want to deliver an Olympic legacy of increased participation."

To date, tens of millions of pounds has been diverted from grassroots sports to support the costs of the London Olympics. In the past year UK Sport, which funds elite athletes, received £115.8?million from the Treasury and Lottery, an increase of 230 per cent since 2000. During the same period, funding for Sport England – and its Scottish, Welsh and Northern Irish counterparts – which pays for community sports, has been only £350?million, a 7 per cent increase.

"I would love to show someone from the government what it is really like for clubs," said Lia Borrotzu, of the Sutton School of Gymnastics, last night. "We are really, really struggling. Our phones are red hot because of the Olympics but we have to tell parents: 'Sorry, your child can't come.' I have had 13-year-olds on the waiting lists and not been able to get them into the club until they were 18. I am Mrs ­Desperate."

Miss Borrotzu's plight has been echoed nationwide. Athletics, swimming and gymnastics have all suffered similar shortages of facilities and resources, organisers say, with:

Just one 50m swimming pool for every 2.5 million people in Britain. France, by contrast, has one for every 650,000 of its population;

The average price of some sports club memberships for children having risen by more than one third in a year;

Eight English counties and the entire city of Birmingham doing without a single publicly accessible diving board over a metre high. Thirty years ago England had 298 publicly accessible pools with diving boards. Now there are just 84 in the whole of Britain;

Almost a quarter of a million aspiring gymnasts now on waiting lists because of insufficient facilities to train them;

One hundred and eighty-seven school playing fields having been sold off since 1998. Some 19 have gone in the past 18 months.

Yet Labour politicians have sought to claim credit for Britain's stirring success in Beijing. Andy Burnham, the Culture Secretary, linked our Olympic triumph directly to Gordon Brown, claiming his decision to put money into the team had resulted in this being Britain's best medal haul for a long time.

And last week Richard Caborn, the former sports minister, in an article entitled "Why Labour can be Proud of the Olympics", boasted: "We have put the Great back into Great Britain. The Tories left the most demoralised sporting family you could imagine. Labour turned this around with investment into schools, governing bodies, coaching."

But today Sir John Major, the former Tory prime minister who introduced the National Lottery, which provides money for sports, accuses the government of "siphoning off funds for their own pet projects".

While applauding our Olympic success, he claimed in The Sunday Telegraph that grassroots schemes have lost about a half a billion pounds to build Olympic venues and other infrastructure. "A contribution, as with the Commonwealth Games at Manchester, is acceptable but half a billion is far too high a loss for grassroots sports," he wrote.

Last night Derek Mapp, the former chairman of Sport England, the organisation which supports community sports, told The Sunday Telegraph: "If we are really trying to build a sporting nation, and a legacy before and after the 2012 Olympics, then we are going about it in totally the wrong way."

Mr Mapp left Sport England in November, eight months after £55.9?million of its Lottery funding for 2009 to 2012 was diverted to help cover the cost of the London Olympics venues. This "cut too far", he claimed, would in effect remove an extra £168?million from grassroots sports, because every £1 of Sport England funding attracted £3 of investment from bodies, such as local councils.

"Anyone who says that more money is going into grassroots sport is plain wrong. It is all very well to invest in UK Sport (which funds elite athletes) to win medals, but we should be aiming for the grassroots – the 10-year-olds at home watching the Olympics now," he said.

Competitive sport? Not here

DIVING

There are now just 84 publicly accessible pools with diving boards in the whole of Britain, according to the Amateur Swimming Association, compared with 298 in England alone in 1977.

Campaigners claim eight English counties and the city of Birmingham now have no publicly available diving boards of one metre height or above.

SWIMMING

Britain has 24 Olympic-length 50m pools, although one is currently closed for refurbishment while another is set to close. It works out at one pool for every 2.5 million people, compared with one for every 650,000 in France.

According to Sport England, 352 pools opened between 2004 and last year, compared with 164 that closed. But campaigners claim the figures include those in private health clubs and hotels, and do not paint a fair picture.

PLAYING FIELDS

Since 1998, 187 playing fields have been sold, with 19 going in the past 18 months.

A further 1,331 parcels of land smaller than 0.4 hectares have been sold off since 2001, without the need for ministerial approval.

This, despite a promise from Labour, on coming to power: “We will bring the Government’s policy of forcing schools to sell playing fields to an end.”

GYMNASTICS

Up to 240,000 aspiring gymnasts are stuck on club waiting lists, because of a lack of capacity in current facilities.

Even Huntingdon, the home club of Louis Smith, who won Bronze in Beijing – Britain’s first gymnastics medal for 80 years – is affected.

It cannot raise money for an extension and has a waiting list of 500 children.

CYCLING

There are four fewer cycle tracks than 10 years ago due to neglect, according to British Cycling, and no tracks at all in north-east England or Yorkshire.

Sixteen outdoor tracks exist, as well as two competition-worthy indoor velodromes at Manchester and Newport in Wales. One of the outdoor tracks, in Edinburgh, is earmarked for closure.

rank_204.title: London 2012: Scepticism over legacy plans cloud Olympic Games
rank_204.text:
The Government has set a target of getting two million more people involved in sport by 2012, yet some of those involved at the coalface claim that measures are incoherent and mis-directed.

Lord Newby, a Liberal Democrat peer who is chairman of sport for the Prince's Trust, remains highly sceptical of legacy plans. He said on Tuesday that he had received a letter from Lord Coe, the chairman of London 2012, explaining that it was not the role of the organisaing committee to find funding for community sport.

Lord Newby said: "I accept that funding for everyone is not possible, and that it is unrealistic for the committee to solve all funding problems, but people feel that in the third sector, we need a vision, or a visionary, and a forum for those who want to leverage a genuine legacy from the Olympics. We need a forum, a working party, to see what we can do, and we need to do it now. At the moment there is no vision, no energy going into legacy creation."

Brigid Simmonds, chair of the Central Council for Physical Recreation, insists that there is an urgent need for "national co-ordination for sports development" linked to the Olympic legacy plan.

"Some national governing bodies are doing what they can," Simmonds said. "But they are restricted by the intellectual property limitations around the Olympic marks, which makes it difficult to create explicit links between programmes and the Games."

Simmonds also says a caveat exists for a legacy of participation at community-level countrywide. "There is a real need for national co-ordination on a legacy of increased participation. Sport is having some good discussions with ministers about how it might achieve that but it won't happen unless one end of the country knows what is succeeding at the other end – and that requires the Government to bring the pieces together.

"At the moment, [amateur sports] clubs feel pretty far removed from what is going on in Stratford and the challenge for organisers is to make them feel more engaged with the aims of 2012."

This is a view shared by several charity and volunteer groups working nationally, and by opposition politicians.

Don Foster, Culture spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, said: "I raised the whole issue with Gerry Sutcliffe on the floor of the House of Commons on Monday this week. It is deeply worrying that we made a commitment to increase sports participation, and to date not a single organisation has sat down and worked out how we are actually going to advance it.

"These are really deep concerns. There is a real stagnation and no central co-ordination, no central planning of how we are going to move forward. I'm genuinely, deeply worried about the legacy from 2012."

Alison Moore-Gwyn, chief executive of Fields in Trust (previously the Playing Fields Association, concurs: "The grand legacy promises made by the bid team to help secure the Games are looking increasingly hollow – particularly the aim to get two million more people physically active."

Moore-Gwyn believes the legacy from the 2012 Games "should be both permanent and tangible" yet insists none of the official legacy schemes come close to achieving this.

"At Fields in Trust we have a fantastic legacy scheme to create a network of permanently protected playing fields in communities all across the UK ensuring that people will always have access to outdoor space for sport and play," she added.

rank_13.title: London 2012: Serious questions remain about Olympic legacy
rank_13.text:
"We will make the UK a world-leading sporting nation. We will transform the heart of east London. We will inspire a new generation of young people to take part in local volunteering, cultural and physical activity."

Four years ago Lord Coe stood before the International Olympic Committee and made an unashamed appeal to the hearts of an electorate that was about to decide the location of the 2012 summer Games. The pitch was unequivocal: a vote for London would see the Olympic brand used "to inspire young people to choose sport".

It proved decisive. The emphasis on legacy was a key factor in London's success, placing at the forefront of its proposal an issue that was often an afterthought.

It changed the rules of Olympic bidding, and no candidate city would today neglect the question of what the Games will leave behind. If London 2012 is to make good on its promise however, its legacy has to be more substantial than a campaign strategy, and with just over three years until the Games there are serious doubts as to whether they will deliver.

From the 'hard' legacy of the Olympic Park, where there is still no business plan or confirmed tenants for the venues being built, to the 'soft' legacy promise of increased sports participation, questions remain.

Taking the hard legacy first, it remains unclear how the facilities in the Olympic Park will be maintained and what they will be used for. A coherent plan for the Park, fusing the sports facilities with business and residential projects has been delayed by an abrupt change of approach following the election of Boris Johnson as mayor.

The London Development Agency had been charged with the project, but in February this year mayor Johnson abandoned the plan and created a new agency, the Olympic Legacy Company, to oversee the project.

Chair Baroness Ford has begun work three days a week and a chief executive has been appointed, but the new company will not formally begin developing a business plan that will sustain the facilities until October.

There is serious concern within the Olympic movement that the search for a financially-viable model, which has included looking at education options such as a university, risks diluting the sporting principles at its heart.

At the centre of deliberations is the question of what to do with the main Olympic Stadium. London promised the IOC a permanent 25,000-seat athletics facility after the Games, rejecting overtures from West Ham United to use the ground for football and insisting that an anchor tenant from another sport would be secured.

No tenant has been identified and now Ford is reconsidering the 25,000-seat option in favour of retaining perhaps 50,000 of the 80,000 Olympic capacity, a move that would allow the stadium to host the World Athletics Championships without having to be rebuilt.

It could also become a venue for the 2018 football World Cup and 2015 Rugby World Cup, should English bids prove successful, but how it will be paid for remains uncertain.

The stadium issue is mirrored across the Park, with the velodrome, aquatic centre and hockey complex all demanding subsidy if financing cannot be found.

This problem may come to be the least of London's worries compared to the task of delivering on the participation agenda. As well as being hugely challenging, it is a deeply political issue which has fractured the cross-party consensus on the Olympics.

It has also strained patience at the London 2012 Organising Committee (Locog), where senior figures are conscious that Coe will be held responsible if the promises he made are not delivered.

Hugh Robertson, the shadow Olympics minister, has been a persistent critic. "The lack of a mass participation legacy is the biggest single flaw in the 2012 project, and since 2005 we have made little or no progress on delivering on that promise," he said.

Jowell rejects the charge: "By 2012 every child will be offered five hours of sport a week and... we have half a million more people taking part in sport at grass-roots level. Some people say this would have happened anyway. It wouldn't.

"In terms of planning for a legacy in and around the park, we are far advanced in comparison to other countries at this stage. That's because legacy hasn't been an afterthought, it has been a key part of our plans from the outset."

The Government's central participation commitment is to getting two million more people into sport or physical activity by 2012. It has also cited the delivery of five hours of sport in all schools – an old commitment – and the provision of free swimming for under-16s and OAPs – genuinely new, if limited in ambition – as part of the participation package.

The two million target is not straightforward, however. Only half of participants actually have to play sport, with Sport England responsible for finding them using £500 million of government funding distributed to governing bodies.

Responsibility for delivering the other million into "physical activity" lies with other government departments, principally the Department of Health. Among the activities that will count towards this target is gardening, a subject noticeable by its absence from Coe's Singapore speech.

It is this dilution of the commitment to sport that most worries those who hoped the 2012 Games would be a landmark moment for the UK, pushing the passion for sport into practical action.

Jowell, Johnson and London 2012 have less than three years to prove them wrong and make good on their promises.

Olympic legacy by numbers

By Simon Hart

£8 billion

The Government’s construction budget, including a £2 billion contingency fund.

£140 millionThe cost of funding free swimming for OAPs and under-16s. The OAP scheme has been taken up by 80 per cent of councils, while 60 per cent of councils offer free under-16 swimming.

£550 million

The Government’s investment in Team GB, based on a target of a top-four finish in the Olympic medals table and second place in the Paralympic table.

2 million

The number of extra people the Government has committed to getting physically active by 2012, through sport or activities such as gardening and DIY.

1 million

The number of extra people (with the previous two million) the Government wants to be playing sport by 2012, defined by three 30-minute sessions of moderate intensity per week.

5

The number of hours of sport per week the Government wants schoolchildren to have access to by 2012.

rank_161.title: London 2012: British Olympic Association slams Government's post-Games planning
rank_161.text:
London put a commitment to a legacy of facilities and sports participation at the centre of its bid for the 2012 Games but Hunt told The Daily Telegraph that the promises may go unfulfilled.

Hunt is concerned that the sporting facilities in the Olympic Park will not be able to host elite competition after the Games, and fears that the Government's participation promises will not be met.

"We are interested in both the legacy of the park and participation element. There are some good individual initiatives but nothing has been drawn together. Time is running out to get this right. I think we have a year, at the most, to get this right and get a tangible benefit from the Olympics," he said.

On the park, Hunt's priority is to make sure elite sport is at the heart of all of the venues including the main stadium, which could host a school as its main tenant rather than a sport.

A new company has been established to run the facilities but is yet to take control of the project, and Hunt wants elite sport as the centrepiece.

"A lot of the plans that have been put together are excellent but the sporting part is missing. I am hearing rumours that the Olympic Park may not even be called 'Olympic'. Were that to happen all the emotional and psychological buy-in the public have would evaporate," he said.

"It has to be the Olympic Park, that makes it a sporting home for the country. For certain sports it will become a key location such as swimming who have done some great planning. Athletics, hockey and cycling all want a true legacy in the park.

"There is a need for these facilities to be in London and they should be the best in the country if not Europe come 2012, and we need to use these to attract and drive European and international competition in London."

Hunt supports suggestions that the stadium should retain at least 50,000 seats rather than 25,000 so it can host world-class events, and will resist attempts to prioritise community over elite use.

"The money that will be spent converting it from a 80,000 to 25,000 is a serious amount of capital, but what does that look like as an operating cost for the stadium, and should we be more ambitious about what the stadium can be used for in terms of bringing international competition to this country?"

On the participation legacy Hunt is highly critical of the Government, saying there is a lack of clear policy and casting doubt on the pledge to get two million more people "physically active", only one million of whom will have to actually play a sport.

"To me it looks like there are some good initiatives but there are lots of arguments around how participation is counted and that all looks very grey to me. We need to know how we can genuinely measure an increase in sporting participation as a result of the Olympics.

"We need more than initiatives, we need policy that clearly sets out and underpins the agenda. I am unclear what the policies are that will drive increased sports participation and get us back to Seb Coe's 2005 promise to use the power of the Games to inspire young people to choose sport. That is policy driven and I do not think that has been thought through."

rank_16.title: London 2012: Olympic legacy winners and losers
rank_16.text:
They are the big winners in the legacy game, beneficiaries of millions of pounds of investment that will leave their sports with permanent, state-of-the-art facilities that will be enjoyed by elite athletes and the local community for years to come.

"We believe the pool will rejuvenate swimming in the East End of London," said British Swimming chief executive David Sparkes of the new £244 million aquatics centre taking shape in the Olympic Park in Stratford. "It will also be a fantastic training and competition venue."

But where there are winners there are also losers, and for the majority of Britain's Olympic sports one is reminded of Anne Robinson's catchphrase on 'The Weakest Link': "You leave with nothing."

When the flat-pack temporary venues are dismantled and existing buildings such as the ExCeL centre and the 02 Arena are returned to their normal use, 17 Olympic sports will have no bricks-and-mortar legacy at all by which to remember the world's greatest sports festival.

The justification for building so few permanent structures is that the London organisers are simply following International Olympic Committee orders in cutting down on extravagance and avoiding white elephants.

In its bid book, London made much of the fact that no permanent venues would be built unless there was an identifiable need for sporting facilities after the Games.

But there are some who believe they have gone too far and that an opportunity is being missed to provide long-lasting facilities for Olympic sport.

British Shooting is even contemplating seeking a judicial review of the decision to stage the shooting competition in an entirely temporary venue at Woolwich Barracks, at a cost estimated to be as high as £42 million, instead of investing in a permanent legacy at Bisley, in Surrey.

Glynn Alger, secretary general of the National Rifle Association, said: "The only legacy Londoners will remember from shooting will be disruption caused by the building and demolition of the Woolwich venue."

AQUATICS (swimming, diving, synchronised swimming, water polo finals, modern pentathlon swimming element)

Where: Olympic Park, Stratford. A 17,500 capacity, purpose-built aquatics centre containing two 50m pools, a diving pool and a 'dry' diving facility. Water polo will be held in temporary 5,000-seat venue next door. Open-water swimming takes place in the Serpentine in Hyde Park.

Status: Construction work on Aquatics Centre began in July 2008. Wave-like roof now starting to take shape.

Cost:: £244 million

Physical legacy: Centre to be transformed into facility for elite swimmers and local community. Capacity reduced to 2,500 but with scope to be increased for major events. Temporary water polo pool to be relocated elsewhere.

ARCHERY

Where: Lord's Cricket Ground, St John's Wood.

Status: A temporary archery range will be created on the outfield of the main ground.

Cost: £3m (2004 bid figure, more recent figure unavailable as work on estimating cost of all temporary structures and Olympic overlay is currently being undertaken).

Physical legacy: None.

ATHLETICS

Where: Olympic Park, Stratford. An 80,000-seat stadium that will also stage the opening and closing ceremonies for the Olympic and Paralympic Games.

Status: Work began in May 2008 and construction of the roof is now well under way. On schedule for completion by summer of 2011.

Cost: £538m.

Physical legacy: Capacity will be reduced to a 25,000-seat athletics stadium that will also be used for other sporting, educational, cultural and community events.

BADMINTON

Where: 'North Greenwich Arena 2' temporary 6,000-seat venue next to the O2 Arena, though this is subject to change.

Status: KPMG report recommended scrapping venue to save costs. Badminton may now be moved to Excel Centre. If temporary venue goes ahead as planned, the tender will go out later this year.

Cost if temporary venue goes ahead: £16m (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None.

BASKETBALL

Where: A temporary arena seating 12,000 in the Olympic Park, Stratford, for the qualifying rounds and the 02 Arena (renamed North Greenwich Arena 2 for duration of Games) for the finals.

Status: O2 Arena already built and will stage four-nation basketball tournament next month. Contract for temporary arena awarded earlier this month and work due to start early next year.

Cost of temporary venue: £58m.

Cost of 02 Arena refit: £3m (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None. Temporary venue to be owned by construction company, Barr, and will be dismantled and moved elsewhere after Games.

BOXING

Where: Excel Centre at Royal Victoria Dock, but subject to change. Plans afoot to switch boxing to Wembley Arena, though the move is opposed by the sport's international federation. Decision expected within weeks.

Status: Excel is an existing exhibition centre that will be transformed into several sports arenas for the Games.

Cost: £24m for entire Excel refit (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None.

CANOEING

Where: Eton Dorney, Windsor, for the flat-water events and Broxbourne, Herts, for the slalom. Eton Dorney is an existing world-class rowing venue. The Broxbourne White Water Canoe Centre will be a brand-new venue boasting a 300m competition course and a 160m training course. Temporary seating for 12,000.

Status: Construction work on Broxbourne began this month.

Cost: £31m.

Physical legacy: World-class white-water facility for international competition and leisure use for canoeing and rafting. Temporary seating will be removed.

CYCLING

Where: State-of-the-art VeloPark in Olympic Park, Stratford, that includes a 6,000-seat velodrome for track racing and a BMX circuit. Mountain biking to take place at 3,000-seat temporary venue at Hadleigh Farm, Essex. Road races to finish in central London.

Status: Work on foundations for velodrome began in March this year and above-ground structure now starting to appear.

Cost: £94m.

Physical legacy: Alongside the permanent velodrome and BMX circuit, a new mountain bike course and road cycle circuit will be added post-Games to form a cycling hub for elite athletes and the community.

EQUESTRIANISM

Where: Greenwich Royal Park

Status: Course for the three-day eventing is at the design stage and a planning application is expected to be lodged by the end of the year. Some local residents have objected to the use of London's oldest Royal Park, which contains trees planted by Charles II. Locog insists park will be unharmed. Temporary seating for 23,000.

Cost: £10m (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None, though some of the fences may be re-used elsewhere.

FENCING

Where: Excel Centre in Royal Victoria Dock.

Status: Existing exhibition space that will host a variety of sports during the Games.

Cost: £24m for entire Excel refit (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None.

FOOTBALL

Where: Wembley Stadium (London), Old Trafford (Manchester), Millennium Stadium (Cardiff), St James' Park (Newcastle), Hampden Park (Glasgow), Villa Park (Birmingham).

Status: All stadia ready to host men's and women's matches. The finals will be held at Wembley.

Cost: £1.3m in total for Olympic overlay (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None.

GYMNASTICS

Where: 02 Arena (renamed 'North Greenwich Arena 1' during Games) for artistic and trampoline; 'North Greenwich Arena 2' temporary venue for rhythmic but subject to change.

Status: North Greenwich Arena 2 could be axed to reduce overall costs, with rhythmic gymnastics moving to the Excel Centre.

Cost of temporary venue if it goes ahead: £16m (2004 bid figure)

Cost of O2 Arena refit: £3m (2004 bid figure)

Physical legacy: None.

HANDBALL

Where: Olympic Park Handball Arena (prelims); Basketball temporary arena in Olympic Park (semi-finals and medal matches).

Status: Planning permission granted in February this year and site cleared ready for work to start on foundations.

Cost: £24m (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: The Handball Arena is a permanent venue that will become a multi-use indoor sports centre after the Games for use by the community and elite athletes for training and competition. Retractable seating will offer flexibility.

HOCKEY

Where: Olympic Park Hockey Stadium (temporary venue)

Status: The venue will have two pitches and spectator seating and will be located next to the International Broadcast Centre and Main Press Centre.

Cost: Undisclosed as bid book quoted cost of permanent stadium. Legacy stadium still awaiting approval.

Physical legacy: The stadium will be dismantled after the Games but a new hockey stadium with permanent seating for 3,000 is set to be built in an area north of the Olympic Park at Eton Manor to honour the bid book commitment. Approval for this is expected later this month.

JUDO

Where: Excel Centre, Royal Victoria Dock

Status: Existing exhibition centre that will be transformed into several arenas in Games time.

Cost: £24m for entire Excel refit (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None.

MODERN PENTATHON

Where: Greenwich Park (Riding and combined Run/Shoot); Olympic Park Handball Arena (Fencing); Aquatics Centre (Swimming)

Status: All venue designs are being developed to meet the requirements of Modern Pentathlon. Construction of the Aquatics Centre is well underway.

Cost: N/A as sharing venues with other sports.

Physical legacy: None.

ROWING

Where: Eton Dorney, near Windsor.

Status: World-class facility already in use for international events with a 2.2km, eight-lane rowing course. Additional facilities will be added for the Olympics to provide an enhanced athlete warm-up area for the Games. This includes adding a 50m-wide bridge and improved access for spectators.

Cost: £5.6m (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: Improvements to athlete warm-up area and pedestrian access remain.

SAILING

Where: Weymouth and Portland Harbour in Dorset

Status: The sailing venue is the first venue for 2012 where new construction has been completed. A new slipway, moorings and associated facilities have been built to enhance the venue for competition in 2012.

Cost: £7m.

Physical legacy: The extra facilities will benefit local sailing groups and elite athletes.

SHOOTING

Where: Royal Artillery Barracks, Woolwich.

Status: The existing Barracks date back to 1776. Several temporary shooting ranges will be built. Temporary seating for 7,500. Planning application to be lodged later this year.

Cost: £20m (2004 bid book figure but recent estimates put as high as £42m).

Physical legacy: None, though dismantled ranges may be distributed to shooting clubs.

TABLE TENNIS

Where: Excel Centre, Royal Victoria Dock

Status: Existing exhibition centre to host several sports during the Games.

Cost: £24m for entire Excel refit (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None.

TAEKWONDO

Where: Excel Centre, Royal Victoria Dock

Status: Existing exhibition centre hosting several sports during Games.

Cost: £24m for entire Excel refit (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None.

TENNIS

Where: All England Club, Wimbledon

Status: Existing world-class facility and the only grass-court Grand Slam venue.

Cost: £1m (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None, though Paralympic venue will provide permanent legacy for East London.

TRIATHLON

Where: Hyde Park, central London

Status: London's largest Royal Park and surrounding streets will be transformed into a venue for the three disciplines of Triathlon. Temporary seating for 3,000.

Cost: £7m (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None.

VOLLEYBALL

Where: Earls Court (Indoor Volleyball); Horse Guards Parade (Beach Volleyball)

Status: Earls Court, in west London, is an existing venue which will be turned into a 15,000-seat arena in 2012. Horse Guards Parade, which hosts annual Trooping of the Colour ceremony, to be turned into a temporary 15,000-seat venue.

Cost of temporary structure on Horse Guards Parade: £5.5m (2004 bid figure).

Cost of Earls Court refit: undisclosed as not part of original bid.

Physical legacy: None.

WEIGHTLIFTING

Where: Excel Centre, Royal Victoria Dock

Status: Existing exhibition centre to host several sports during Games.

Cost: £24m for entire Excel refit (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None.

WRESTLING

Where: Excel Centre, Royal Victoria Dock.

Status: Existing exhibition centre hosting several sports during Games.

Cost: £24m for entire Excel refit (2004 bid figure).

Physical legacy: None.

rank_230.title: BOA chief executive Andy Hunt angers Government with 2012 legacy criticism
rank_230.text:
Relations had eased since Hunt's appointment, but his comments are understood to have infuriated Tessa Jowell and sports minister Gerry Sutcliffe.

Hunt attacked the Government for the absence of a coherent policy for sports participation and the lack of planning for the use of venues after the Games, but the feeling inside the DCMS is that the comments were misguided.

Insiders point out that if Hunt wanted to raise these issues he could have used the BOA's seat on the Sports Legacy Venues Group, a body that meets to discuss possible uses for venue after the Games.

Hunt has yet to attend one of its meetings and the BOA has been to only three out of 10 meetings.

rank_251.title: PY Gerbeau may be just what the Olympics needs
rank_251.text:
He may be a self-styled "fat little frog" whose detractors call him "The Gerbil" but PY Gerbeau knows a thing or two about running a public attraction. And the trouble-shooter who presided over Disneyland Paris before valiantly trying to rescue the Dome has a stark warning about the Olympics: if you thought the Dome was a disaster, wait till you see the London Games.

"The Olympics is going exactly the same way as the Dome, except it is 15 times more expensive," he says. "It is a time bomb. British politicians have been there before, so why face the embarrassment again? You are setting yourself up for a massive fall."

His complaint? No one is in charge, budgets balloon seemingly of their own accord, disastrous decisions are made in secret, and the media is deceived. To students of the Millennium Dome fiasco it does indeed sound spookily familiar.

"This could be the biggest embarrassment ever," warns Gerbeau, now a popular business commentator and performer on programmes such as Question Time , while also running a successful business in London turning round failing companies.

"It is a ludicrous, half-baked organisation. Why is there no transparency? The building programme goes massively over budget and amazingly there is no public report asking what has gone wrong. If I'd gone so over-budget in a PLC without explaining why, I'd go to jail. The entire system is designed to cover people's bottoms. The tent was exactly the same. It's a disgrace."

And just as the Dome was conceived in the dog days of John Major's administration, so Gerbeau suggests the Olympics is suffering from an equally impotent and incompetent Gordon Brown government. "Who is in charge? Nobody. The malaise over the Olympics reflects the broader political malaise."

Gerbeau's solution? "We should give it to the Frogs," smiles the former winter Olympian who represented French at ice hockey. "They would take it. They have all the transport and stadia infrastructure, they would only need to build an Olympic village. It would then leave £50bn to inject into the British economy at a time of great hardship." Would France do it better? "No question. It's not about savoir faire, they are just better placed."

And before Gerbeau is accused of French bias, he is a rampant Anglophile who took considerable stick from former teammates when he turned out for Britain against France in a recent veteran's hockey match. He lives in London with his British wife and child ("I married the enemy"), describing himself as "an economic refugee from the last communist country in Europe". He also acknowledges Britain proved it can host big events, such as Manchester's Commonwealth Games in 2002. But for 2012, he simply thinks the cost is too high, the process too flawed.

"We need to really think if we want it or whether we can dump it. And if we are to keep it we need a national debate. If we want to go ahead fine, but the public have to be engaged, perhaps with a referendum. And then there must be quarterly reports into every aspect of the building programme." He pauses: "The Olympics really put Spain on the map. It should be getting really exciting now, the biggest thing to happen to Britain for a decade. Instead there are only problems. And if you vilify the media and lie to it, saying it knows nothing, there is sure to be a backlash."

He claims he tried a novel approach when he took over Peter Mandelson's Dome: telling the truth. And while it was too late to save a poorly conceived attraction, perceptions did improve.

Oh, talking of the Dome, Gerbeau reveals that Michael Jackson did visit the now re-named O2 after all. Before his sudden death Jackson was limbering up for a series of comeback concerts to be staged there, but back when Gerbeau was running the Dome Jackson made a secret inspection.

"We kept it quiet as we didn't think publicity would do either of us any good," laughs Gerbeau, who reveals he became friends with Jackson when opening Disneyland Paris at night so that Jackson and his entourage of children could visit without being disturbed.

"I was on standby to give evidence on his behalf in his court case," says Gerbeau. "He was strange, but not a dodgy man. The kids were only there to give him an alibi to behave like a seven-year-old. It was wonderful to get to know the best showman on the planet - apart from all the sleep it cost me while Michael embarked on his 13th ride on the same attraction."

To Gerbeau's disappointment, a little of that Disneyland escapism still pervades French life. "The attitude is 'we want to work less and be paid more'. When I left France I was being taxed 54%, so you just think 'why bother?'" He hoped President Nicolas Sarkozy, who courted London ex-pats like Gerbeau during his election campaign, would shake France out of its state-ist lethargy.

"Sarkozy is more interested in climbing onto a six-foot supermodel than tackling France's economic malaise," is Gerbeau's rather earthy assessment. "He is using the financial crisis as an excuse to attack the Anglo-Saxon model; he was doing nothing even before the crisis."

You can see why Gerbeau in his eyrie overlooking Buckingham Palace rather enjoys living in Britain; he has had done well in his adopted country. A sign in his office says "Aston Martins park here. All other cars will be crushed"; Gerbeau does indeed have an Aston, and a Lamborghini. He is great friends with Colin Montgomerie, the golfer, and is a member of five of our smarter courses, having become a scratch player in two years.

"I bust my leg in four places playing ice hockey, which was devastating as I dreamed of carrying the French flag at the winter Olympics," he says looking down. "But my ankle turned 360 degrees and that was the end of that. I spent 14 months trying to get out of a wheelchair and people try to talk to me about pressure. I told myself I could sit on a bench and become an alcoholic or do something with my life. I found golf has a very similar action to hockey, so I took up golf, and I also went into business."

And that, despite his jokey demeanour and slightly unfortunate green tank top, is something he takes seriously. He shrugs at piles of sporting and celebrity memorabilia: "People take the p*** out of my office, but it's where I spend 90% of my time so I don't want it to be boring."

Increasingly Gerbeau is exercised by politics – high taxes, federalism, corruption – and it would be no surprise to see him stand for office. He is contemptuous of the political class, recounting how "horrible" he found Caroline Flint in the green room before they appeared together on Question Time. He hopes the expenses scandal will result in "400 new MPs" at the next election, and he has sage advice to Eurosceptics.

"If you don't want a federal Europe you have to start learning about what the EU is doing," he says, waving his arms passionately. "It's where 70% of important decisions are made. And if you are worried about the expenses of MPs, MEPs are twice as bad."

He warns that Europe in general and Britain in particular is "creeping towards the French model" from Anglo-Saxon disciplines. He suggests there are limits to free markets and notes France enjoys superior public services, but that Britain now has the worst of all worlds: high taxes, low quality schools, hospitals and transport. He is desperate to say "au revoir" to Gordon Brown, whom he accuses of implementing many continental polices "which led to 90% of entrepreneurs leaving France ." But Gerbeau has yet to see anything from David Cameron to suggest the Conservatives have an alternative vision. "Where," he demands rhetorically "is the big fire? Maybe it's time for a new party."

Before that, maybe it's time for a new leader of our Olympic project. The Dome connection will hardly put much wind behind his candidacy, but if we won't give the Games to France, perhaps we should give it to our favourite "fat little Frenchman". Help – we need The Gerbil.

rank_218.title: London 2012: expert views on Olympic progress
rank_218.text:
Three years can seem like a long time, but in Olympic terms three years is like tomorrow, and so much remains to be built before the youth of the world comes to London.

London will be ready, just like Athens (2004) and Turin (2006) were ready just in time, but at an incredible human and financial cost because the global crisis has added to the difficulties inherent in organising the Games.

London will be ready to organise a superb and simple Olympics but Beijing must be remembered as the last gigantic, unreal Games.

The financial crisis has touched the whole world, and the International Olympic Committee and other international federations must realise that the golden age of enormous Olympics has passed.

The IOC executive committee speaks unceasingly about reducing costs, but the members often elect cities that do not have any sporting infrastructure and have to build facilities that will have no use after the 17 days of Olympic sport.

So it is thus time for the IOC to clip the wings of the Games by excluding certain sports and reducing the number of the athletes. London must be the last Games where 10,500 athletes come to compete.

If not, only G8 countries will be able to organise them.

Ed Hula

Editor, aroundtherings.com

London seems to be well on its way to the 2012 Olympics -- despite the sour world economy. There are few doubts, maybe even no doubts, among Olympic-watchers, over the ability of London to deliver great Games. Maybe it is the right city to host the Games in these tough times.

Steve Wilson

Olympic Correspondent, Associated Press

I have been impressed – amazed, really – by the progress and the massive scale of the construction work at the Olympic Park. I’ve been lucky enough to stand on the top level of the Olympic Stadium, which is further along than most of us could have imagined. Remember Wembley?

It’s not the Bird’s Nest [in Beijing], but it doesn’t need to be. It’s a real stadium already. I think the debate over how the stadium will be adapted and utilised after 2012 will continue to run for some time.

The defining architectural symbol of the Olympic Park will surely be the wave-like roof of the aquatics centre. It’s already quite a sight.

Keeping on budget and coping with the recession will remain major challenges. The fact that the project is progressing so rapidly despite the downturn is notable.

Transport will be one of the biggest tests for Locog. Getting people on time to and from the venues across the capital will be critical. The Javelin train service could be crucial. For the media, the dedicated buses from hotels in Bloomsbury must be reliable.

The British crowds and London’s backdrop should make the Games special. The great unknown, as ever, is the weather. Let’s hope it turns out like Wimbledon this year.

July 6: London defeats Paris to host the 2012 Olympic Games

Senior staff appointed, including Paul Deighton, chief executive of the organising committee, and David Higgins, his counterpart at the Olympic Delivery Authority
