rank_24.title: London 2012: Olympic Legacy Company set to create new east London community
rank_24.text:
Afterwards, the landmark site is set to be transformed into a new vibrant part of east London, creating new communities where people will want to live, work and visit for generations to come, all set within one of Europe's largest urban parks.

The Olympic Park Legacy Company is charged with the responsibility for making this happen. The company was formed in May this year by the Government and the Mayor of London and we expect it to be fully established in October this year.

We are clear in our aim: to transform the Olympic Park into a new prosperous and sustainable community for east London and to be a successful catalyst for investment and development opportunities.

Realising the potential of the Games, in terms of its legacy to the capital and the country, has been at the heart of work that is already completed or has been started by the Olympic Delivery Authority and the London Development Agency. We will carry on from this excellent foundation, working alongside the five host boroughs and our partners in the public and private sectors.

In the short term, we will be reviewing some aspects of the current legacy masterplan for the site with the aim of having a second iteration by the end of the year.

It will not happen overnight. Our plans will evolve and will look towards a 25-year horizon as we shape the park's landscape to create new communities with thousands of new homes, job opportunities and world-class sporting, educational and cultural facilities which will match those anywhere in the world.

During the Games, the 246-hectare Olympic Park will accommodate permanent and temporary facilities including the Olympic Stadium, Aquatics Centre and the Velopark. There will also be the Olympic Village, a media centre and new parkland all built around the Lea Valley waterways.

After the Games, the sporting legacy of the park will be at the core of our plans to fulfil the legacy obligations for community and elite sports participation. The centrepiece sporting venues and their ancillary faculties will be retained and adapted for use by sports clubs and the local community, as well as for elite and amateur athletes.

The Olympic Village, where athletes and officials will stay during the Games, will be converted into homes with many available for key workers such as teachers and nurses.

A further 10,000 new homes will be developed on the Olympic Park site itself. More than 40 per cent of these will be for families, with a large proportion offering affordable housing.

They will sit within all the elements which make up good communities: schools, libraries, shops, cafes, restaurants, green space and a wide range of community facilities to be developed alongside major cultural and visitor attractions.

One of our success measures will be transforming the park into a "must see, must return" destination for thousands of visitors from home and overseas.

In a similar way that South Kensington was bequeathed the legacy of the 1851 Great Exhibition as a world-beating cultural quarter and home to the capital's great museums, the Olympic Park can become a place of first choice for people to live, work and visit for generations to come – a place to celebrate its historic sporting legacy.

Already many of the transport improvements serving the Park are under way, including an extension to the Docklands Light Railway, increased capacity on the Jubilee Line and the upgrade of Stratford Regional Station.

Surrounding the park, people will enjoy wider access to the parkland and open spaces via a network of canal towpaths, footpaths and cycleways.

London is the first host city to have set up a dedicated legacy company for the Olympic Park site before the Games have even started. Together with our new chief executive, Andrew Altman, and my soon-to-be-appointed board, we are proud to be given such an excellent foundation.

There are a great many opportunities for us all to work together – not just to get it done, but to get it right.

rank_95.title: Council recruits Olympics co-ordinator despite staging no events
rank_95.text:
The council is looking to appoint the adviser on a three-year contract with the task of ensuring "the Surrey 2012 programme has maximum impact."

The council had hoped that Bisley in the county would be chosen to stage the shooting event but Olympic organisers eventually awarded the competition to a rival bidder.

A job advert says the council wants someone who will create an Olympic legacy for the county.

"The London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games offer a once in a lifetime chance to make a positive difference," it states. "We are looking for someone who will help Surrey's residents and businesses gain from this unique opportunity.

"We are looking for a skilled networker and influencer, who can inspire innovation and creativity in our partners."

The county is expected to provide facilties for a number of athletes competing in London during the games.

Matthew Elliott, chief executive of the TaxPayers' Alliance, said existing council officers can do the job.

"Given that Surrey aren't even hosting any Olympic events in 2012, this job is unnecessary," he said. "If there are implications for transport, leisure or other services, then that falls well within the jobs of existing council officers who are already quite well paid enough to do the job.

"This smacks of gimmickry by the council, who seem more keen to demonstrate that they are in touch with current events than to deliver good value for money."

A council spokesman said that although they are not hosting any events the co-ordinator will be seeking Olympics related contracts for the county.

Denise Saliagopoulos, the county council's Cabinet Member for Community Services and the 2012 Games, said: "Surrey's businesses play a key role in making the county a prosperous, vibrant place.

"If they thrive, we all benefit. In the current financial climate, it is especially important to help Surrey through the recession.

"The coordinator will work to help Surrey's businesses compete for Games related contracts and bring the Games to Surrey by attracting foreign teams to train at the county's excellent sports facilities and use the inspiration of the Games to involve more people in cultural and sporting events.

"Now is the time to give our businesses the help and advice they need to clinch work on offer in the run-up to and during the Olympics.

"The skills that they learn, will allow the same companies to bid for public procurement contracts. In this way, the benefits we create will have a legacy that will be enjoyed beyond 2012."

rank_109.title: Conservative party conference: Dame Kelly Holmes backs plan for Schools Olympics
rank_109.text:
Jeremy Hunt, the shadow secretary of state for culture media and sport, said that under a Conservative government, a national sports competition would run every year, climaxing in finals held at the Olympic Stadium in Stratford, east London.

In a speech to Conservative conference, he accused Labour of failing to ensure children took part in competitive sports at school, adding to an “obesity time bomb” among the younger generation.

As well as taking advantage of the London 2012 Games to introduce an annual under-18s competition, a Tory government would force schools to publish information about their facilities, and every child would have the opportunity to compete.

Mr Hunt said: “Let’s democratise the Olympics. Let’s not just have them in the stadium in London for three weeks only.

“Let’s have them in every school, in every town, in every city and every county not just in 2012 but every year from then on.

“Let’s use the London Olympics to bring back school sports league tables, with a proper system of town, city, regional and national heats.

“Let’s use 2012 to bring competitive sport – and sporting values – within the grasp of all young people.”

“The values of competitive sport are crucial in creating a society that brings out the best in young people. This initiative will allow us to use 2012 to bring competitive sport – and sporting values – within the grasp of all young people.

“Labour claim to love sport. But their culture of health and safety madness and political correctness is destroying the foundations of what sport should be about.”

A week after attending Labour conference in Brighton, Dame Kelly travelled to Manchester to tell Tory delegates of the importance of competitive sport in school.

The school games proposal is based on a recommendation she made last year after her Olympic Legacy Taskforce was asked by the party to examine ways to expand sports opportunities for all children.

She told the conference: "We need to give our young people opportunities, we need to give them direction, we need to give them a chance to be inspired.

"And with the Olympic Games coming, we're going to host the best games ever - we need to now make sure that we maximise what we're doing as a nation.

"So that's my challenge - the first Schools Olympics. I'll be right behind you."

Follow Telegraph TV's video diary from Tory Party Conference in Manchester

rank_215.title: London 2012: five challenges with 1,000 days until the Olympic Games
rank_215.text:
In a sign of the progress underway in Stratford the first new tree will be planted on the Olympic Park next month. The sight of landscaping, often an afterthought in Olympic construction, will boost optimism about the evolution of London’s park.

While the final venues for badminton and rhythmic gymnastics remain uncertain – both sports are being pressed to accept Wembley Arena – progress on-site has been relatively smooth, albeit at a fearsome cost to the taxpayer.

Plans to privately finance the Olympic village and media and broadcast centres collapsed like a distressed marathon runner as the credit crunch bit last year, and the public bail-out of both projects ensures that the bulk of the £9.3?billion build budget will be spent.

More than £1billion of contingency funding remains unspent, which will help as the immovable deadline nears and the big-ticket items approach completion. The Olympic Delivery Authority reaches its maximum of 10,000 workers in the next year.

The next 12 months will see the concrete-and-steel skeletons on site fleshed out, with the roof of the aquatic centre, which doubles as the main pedestrian access to the park, due for completion next summer.

The big deadline is the summer of 2011 when all the sports venues have to be complete and handed to the London organising committee for test events. The velodrome, Olympic Stadium, aquatics centre, international broadcast centre, basketball and handball arenas are all due to be ready 12 months out from the Games.

If its going to happen the ODA and its partners will need to maintain their discipline, particularly in relation to industrial relations, and make sure that they shrewdly use the pot of contingency cash to keep the wheels of progress turning.

TICKETS

Perhaps the most controversial and emotive issue the organising committee faces between now and the opening ceremony is ticketing.

About nine million tickets for the 26 Olympic sports will go on sale in 2011 and it will probably prove impossible to please everyone.

The key issues are price and availability. London won its bid on a promise of minimum ticket prices of around £15, but the economic realities of funding the Games means that figure has already been abandoned as organisers seek to meet their target of £2 billion in commercial revenue.

With higher prices certain the organising committee has to balance affordability with accessibility. Tickets have to be available to people from across the country and they have to be within the reach of ordinary families, particularly given the huge taxpayer investment in the project.

The question of sponsor and VIP access to events is also sensitive and London can ill-afford to allow the huge banks of empty seats left by sponsors in Beijing to be repeated.

Locog are already talking to the IOC about ways in which they can quickly fill areas of seating that have been left vacant, including bussing in schoolchildren to the Olympic Park in order to use them to fill in when required.

THE OLYMPIC SPIRIT

While the heavy lifting continues on site the organising committee has to develop a look, feel and tone for the Games that captures the public imagination. The challenge is to change post-recession perceptions so the project is seen as a point of light at the end of the tunnel, rather than a drain on over-stretched public finances.

To do this they will need to establish an identity that has widespread appeal while satisfying the fundamentals of London’s bid promise, that it would be a modern, vital and youthful Games.

This being an Olympics with a hard commercial edge one of the primary vehicles for this will be merchandising, which means mascots. They will be launched next year, a furry and probably irritating indicator of what is to come.

TRANSPORT

London's transport system is not going to turn into a network worthy of a first-world capital city just because the Olympics are coming, and ensuring the capital keeps the Games moving is a priority for the organising committee.

Transport for London and Games organisers are hoping that they can exploit the summer holidays with which the Olympics coincide to ease pressure on the network. Fast-tracked developments including the Dockland Light Railway extension, that will see five new stations open by next summer, should help.

More controversial are plans to introduce an Olympic Route Network that will see 'Zil lanes’ marked on some of the capital’s major roads, with use restricted to athletes, officials, media and VIPs for the duration.

A massive public consultation is underway to try to prepare London motorists but the issue is bound to prompt complaints, and Boris Johnson is on-the-record saying he opposes the concept.

The Olympic lanes will be particularly important if plans to use Wembley Arena as a venue are given the go-ahead. The most optimistic journey time for the trip from the athletes’ village Stratford to Wembley is 37 minutes, while the most realistic suggests it will take at least an hour.

That will not please the badminton players and rhythmic gymnasts sketched to be competing at the venue, so London will have to come-up with a bullet proof plan to convince sceptics.

LEGACY

London's pitch to the IOC was based on the promise of a Games to inspire the youth of the world, and to revolutionise participation in sport in the UK. Grandiose pledges made in the midst of a bid campaign seldom become reality but London’s credibility rests on delivering on this fundamental issue.

The transformational potential of the Olympics helped unlock Treasury vaults for the redevelopment of east London, but the public will not tolerate white elephants and there must be a sporting and health dividend for the UK to justify the cost.

Worryingly this is where progress has been most patchy, perhaps because the methodology for delivering it is woolly. Just how do you tempt a teenager off the sofa, or his father out of the pub?

Seb Coe believes it will take co-ordinated thinking by policy makers allied to the inspirational power of a great games, and slowly there are signs that the first is being delivered.

After Johnson ripped up existing plans following his election Baroness Ford is now chairing the Olympic Legacy Delivery Company, which will be responsible for managing the Olympic Park post-Games. Finding a permanent tenant for the main stadium, or failing that a business plan that pays its way remains the major challenge.

The soft legacy is more difficult, but the government insists that its initiatives such as free swimming are helping deliver on its target of 2 million more people doing sport or physical exercise by London 2012.

Assuming they win the next election, the Conservatives face a challenge to turn Labour’s promises into reality.

rank_205.title: World Cup 2018: guide to the shortlisted host cities for England's bid
rank_205.text:
London: Wembley will be the centre piece for the entire bid, while the Emirates Stadium was another automatic selection. That leaves a choice between the Olympic Stadium and the new White Hart Lane, something that will ultimately hinge on a political decision over the Olympic legacy.

Liverpool: The doubts over the ability of Liverpool's owners to fund their new stadium had prompted rumours that the city could miss out. However, the 2018 bid team is satisfied that either Anfield or the planned 72,000-capacity stadium could host World Cup matches.

Birmingham: A famous FA Cup semi-final venue, Villa Park also has a rich international pedigree, having hosted international matches across three different centuries, including three games in the 1966 World Cup. It was always among the certainties to be included in the bid.

Milton Keynes: Perhaps the most eye-catching selection, but logistically one of the safer bets. As a city that is just 43 years old, the transport and local infrastructure are excellent and the intention now is to extend the stadium to a capacity of 44,000.

Manchester: Both major stadiums in Manchester have hosted European finals and are already built to the required size, while Old Trafford will be in the running to stage one of the semi-finals. Manchester also won plaudits for the way it hosted the 2002 Commonwealth Games.

Sheffield: Hillsborough remains one of the most historic venues in English football and, having previously hosted matches at both the 1966 World Cup, and 1996 European Championships, would be renovated and extended to 44,000 for the World Cup.

Bristol: The new Ashton Vale stadium will be built to a capacity of 44,000 and its selection will help avert criticisms of the 1966 World Cup and Euro'96, which had no West Country venues, even though Bristol is England's sixth largest city.

Newcastle: Another city with an enormous heritage and fervour for football. St James' Park is well situated near the centre of Newcastle and the main train station and is already of the required size to host matches in the World Cup.

Leeds: Leeds United may have slipped to the third tier of English football, but the city remains one of English football's heartlands. Improvements will be made to Elland Road, but the intention is for the capacity to be extended to over 51,000.

Nottingham: A surprise choice as only the second Midlands venue, but a city synonymous with football after Brian Clough's achievements in the 1970s and 1980s. A proposed new stadium will have a capacity of 45,300 and be based in Clifton, replacing the old City Ground.

Sunderland: The City of Light Stadium is another venue that is already built and could theoretically hold World Cup matches immediately. Its inclusion alongside St James' Park also guarantees that, with Manchester and London, the North East will be one of the three main focal points for the tournament.

Plymouth: Location was surely the primary factor in Plymouth's inclusion and understandably so. Following the withdrawal of Portsmouth, it is the only South Coast venue and the matches are guaranteed to attract huge support across Devon and Cornwall. Home Park is to be increased to a 43,946 capacity.

rank_193.title: London 2012: British Shooting facing £400,000 Olympic legacy bill
rank_193.text:
The governing body, which had originally campaigned for a permanent legacy for the sport by holding the Olympic competition at its headquarters at Bisley, Surrey, has learnt that it will now have to find at least £400,000 if it wants to make long-term use of the temporary facilities that will be erected at the Royal Artillery Barracks.

That is the Government's estimate of the extra cost of making facilities "relocatable", which it insists is not part of the existing Woolwich budget. It would also cover the additional cost of purchasing rather than leasing certain pieces of equipment.

But the charge, which could be even greater depending on the amount of equipment to be passed on, has angered some within the sport who point to the permanent, multi-million pound facilities that sports such as cycling, athletics and swimming can look forward to inheriting after the Games.

"They're basically saying that if we want any legacy we've got to pay for it," said Glynn Alger, secretary general of the National Rifle Association and a British Shooting board member.

rank_216.title: London 2012 Olympics: West Ham's stadium bid backed by UK Athletics
rank_216.text:
Ed Warner, the chairman of UK Athletics, offered his full support to the joint bid by West Ham, Newham Council and entertainment company Live Nation just days after describing a rival bid by Tottenham and 02 owners AEG as “an insult to the whole Olympic project”.

Under Tottenham’s plans, the running track would be scrapped, breaking London’s promise to the International Olympic Committee to provide an athletics legacy. West Ham’s bid is for a multi-use stadium that includes athletics.

"What has impressed me so much about the joint bid from West Ham and Newham is their clear commitment to the spirit of the Olympic legacy and not just athletics at the elite end, but with the retention of the community track, our future champions and club runners too," said Warner.

"It was clear from the start that only a partnership approach would bring to life the vision Seb Coe had when he committed to an athletics legacy in 2005 and we believe the collaboration of West Ham, Newham and UKA gives the strongest opportunity for a vibrant sporting legacy that will go well beyond 2012."

Karren Brady, the West Ham vice-chairman, described the governing body’s backing as “fantastic news”.

rank_232.title: Tottenham and West Ham set for London 2012 Olympic Stadium shortlist as final decision is delayed
rank_232.text:
The OPLC’s announcement ends a five-year search for an alternative to football, and confirms the long-term view of most observers that the Premier League was the most likely means of ensuring the stadium’s future viability.

A third bidder, International Stadium Group, is understood to have been dropped from the process.

The deadline for selecting the winner has slipped by at least three months, however. Originally the OPLC said it wanted to have a preferred bidder agreed by the end of this year, with final contracts signed by March 31 2011.

Friday’s statement only committed to agreeing a “preferred tenant” by the end of the first quarter next year, meaning it could be next summer before a decision is made.

Negotiations between the OPLC and the two clubs will centre on how to ensure the stadium delivers on the London bid promise of an athletics legacy while ensuring the taxpayer is no longer burdened with cost of maintaining the arena.

They will also want to establish the seriousness of Tottenham’s bid, which has been made as an alternative to existing plans for a new ground next door to White Hart Lane.

West Ham’s proposal is favoured by a number of stakeholders including UK Athletics, as the Hammers are committed to retaining the athletics track in the main stadium.

Their bid is backed by Newham Council, which will borrow the bulk of the funding required secured against football club revenue. Their bid will ensure the stadium has community use, a key promise in the original Olympic legacy offer.

Tottenham’s proposal, backed by US entertainment giants AEG, who own and operate the O2, is effectively a hedge against the rising costs of their existing new stadium development in Haringey.

The athletics legacy is also uncertain as they plan to rip out the running track entirely and possibly rebuild a new stadium from scratch on the site.

With costs in Haringey rising by £50m that may still cheaper than proceeding in Haringey.

Spurs say they are committed to helping establish an athletics legacy elsewhere, but it is thought that they have had no contact with UKA about their proposals, which are likely to fall short of the West Ham offer.

In a sign that Tottenham’s threat to leave Haringey is gaining leverage, yesterday the council announced they would try to keep Spurs in the borough by offering to approve compulsory purchase orders necessary to the Northumberland Park development.

Margaret Ford, chairwoman of the Olympic Park Legacy Company, said: “We are very pleased with the extensive and serious interest shown in the stadium. We started this process to ensure the very best legacy for the stadium, and we are now at a point where we have selected the two strongest bids.

“We will go forward to start negotiations with the two consortia of Tottenham Hotspur and AEG, and West Ham United and Newham Council. The stadium is a vital and vibrant component of the Olympic Park - securing the most appropriate and viable solution is crucial for our long-term aspirations for the future Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park area.”

Haringey Council Leader, Cllr Claire Kober, said: “We recognise the importance of keeping Spurs’ rich heritage, history and future here in Haringey where it belongs, and the council is working hard to support Spurs with their proposals for the new stadium in Tottenham.

“We know that this multi-million pound scheme will have far-reaching benefits, not just for everyone who lives and works in this very deprived part of Tottenham, but also for London as a whole."

A CPO would allow the plans — which were unanimously agreed by Haringey Council’s planning committee — to progress.

rank_244.title: General Election 2010: how Conservative, Labour and Lib Dems compare on sport
rank_244.text:
Lord Sebastian Coe - a Conservative - says he is relieved that not one party has made political football out of the General Election. As chairman of the London 2012 Olympics and Paralympics, Coe, without too much difficulty, has managed to garner support from across the political spectrum from the time of the bid five years ago.

''The Olympics have not tumbled from the lips of a single politician in this campaign, they have not become a political football" Coe said when he reassured the International Olympic Committee that any change of government would not impact on the Games' tight deadlines.

But it is not that hard. As the Locog chief executive Paul Deighton noted, the upcoming Olympics is a prized asset. It is the one major good news event that the victor of the election will be keen to massage and manipulate and boost national pride while inflicting tough decisions elsewhere on the economy.

That is not to say the Olympics are immune from any projected spending cuts.

The £2 billion Olympic Games operating budget has been sourced from television rights, sponsorship, ticket sales and merchandise income and won't be affected, except in the question of affordability of Olympics tickets.

But the remaining £7.2 billion that is currently being spent on infrastructure and will underpin the expensive security arrangements may come under slight pressure to effect efficiencies. So too the money for sports via UK Sport, although the impact of any cuts may be hardest felt post -2012 if there is a debate of elite versus grass roots.

In the manifestos of the three major parties there are common threads: all want to have a successful Olympics and Paralympics as well as hosting other major sporting events; all want to tighten the laws around the sell off of playing fields, all want to tweak the Lottery Funding to boost sports funding from grass roots through to the elite, all want to have an inspired sporting legacy to tackle obesity and other social ills.

Sport is clearly good news, and no one wants to touch that.

Liberal Democrats

Use the Olympics, Paralympics, Commonwealth Games and rugby league and rugby union world cups to maximise legacy for the country and promote sporting activity.

Deliver a safe and successful London 2012 Olympics and Paralympics, strongly support the England 2018 football World Cup bid and support more high level sport.

rank_231.title: London 2012 Olympics: Great Britain Basketball seeking permanent home option
rank_231.text:
Instead, GB Basketball has already put in a tender to the Olympic Legacy Company for Arena 3, a permanent venue in Olympic Park which will be hosting the handball tournament in 2012.

“The 2012 legacy for basketball has to be an enhanced and more permanent status for the sport as we look to major competitions beyond the London Olympics.

“The 2012 basketball arena is very good but has always been earmarked as a temporary structure and we are much more interested in putting in our bid to OLC for Arena 3.

“And we are not the only ones because it is an excellent facility. I understand handball and boxing are definitely interested and possibly others as well.

“Arena 3 is a venue which would be an ideal base for the whole GB set-up, training and playing. It could be an important launch pad for the sport and, looking down the line, if we are going to bid for tournaments like Eurobasket 2015 we need our own base as well as brilliant occasional facilities like the O₂.

“We would also be looking to install a London team to compete at the venue in the British Basketball League. London sides have sometimes been ill-starred in the competition to date, with a suitable venue being one of the main problems, but there is huge interest in the capital and we need to get a London franchise well established.”

rank_209.title: Government scraps free swimming scheme ahead of London 2012 Olympics
rank_209.text:
The scheme for the under-16s and over-60s was launched by the Labour Government in 2008 as a London Olympic legacy initiative.

However Hugh Robertson, the sports and Olympic minister, said that the scheme was now considered too expensive to continue and has been axed as part of £73 million savings made by the Department for Culture, Media and Sport.

Robertson said: "This is not a decision that gives me any pleasure. However, the research shows that the great majority of free swimmers were swimming already, and would have paid to swim anyway. With a crippling deficit to tackle and tough decisions to take, this has become a luxury we can no longer afford."

ASA, the national governing body for swimming , expressed its disappointment but acknowledged tough funding decisions had to be made.

David Sparkes, ASA’s chief executive, said: “While we are disappointed to learn that Free Swimming will stop shortly we recognise that in the current economic climate the government needs to prioritise its spending and in that regard we understand the decision.”

Labour launched the scheme in 2008 as part of a bid to get more people involved in sport by 2012 and claimed their aim was to get England's swimming pools free to use by the time of the London 2012 Games.

Robertson said new research showed the scheme has not delivered value for money nor significantly increased physical activity.

He added: "Delivering a legacy from 2012 is one of my top priorities. I want people of all ages and abilities to have opportunities to take part in all kinds of sport, and under our plans to reform the Lottery shares we should see an extra £50million a year going on sports facilities by 2012.

"Our plans to deliver a community sports legacy, in partnership with Sport England, are progressing well and we expect to make a full announcement in July."

rank_227.title: London 2012 Olympics: Hugh Robertson vows to deliver legacy despite cutbacks
rank_227.text:
Falling at the halfway point of what promises to be a deeply difficult and unpopular Parliament, the Games could offer a distraction from the country's woes, and a unique chance to redefine the national image, domestically and in the eyes of the world

It is an oft-repeated fact in sporting-political circles that no Government that has hosted an Olympics has failed to be re-elected afterwards.

Some of those opportunities remain, but so deep is the fiscal hole that the new administration faces a more practical problem before it can look forward to Union Flags on the streets and a post-Games bump in the polls. How to deliver the Games that Britain promised in the face of huge cuts to the public purse?

It is a pressing quandary for the coalition and its sports minister Hugh Robertson, who came into office promising to deliver not just a world-class Games but a meaningful and abiding sporting legacy. The first part of the bargain may be easier to deliver than the second.

With just two years to go until the opening ceremony in Stratford, almost all of the construction work has been planned and contracted, with the next 12 months bringing the most intense period of work on the Olympic Park as it heads towards a completion date this time next year.

That means there is little room for manoeuvre in the £9.3 billion construction and infrastructure pot agreed by the last Government. David Higgins, chief executive of the Olympic Delivery Authority, has estimated that around £850 million of the contingency fund will remain unspent come next summer. Robertson's challenge will be to persuade the Treasury to allow that funding to remain within the broader Olympic pot, helping to underwrite other costs, including legacy projects, rather than being clawed back to help fill the deficit hole.

It is harder to see how the Olympic legacy, a promise that lay at the heart of London's bid and the incoming Government's sports manifesto, can be delivered as originally envisaged.

The Department of Culture, Media and Sport is responsible for co-ordinating the legacy, as well as the Government's approach to the Games, but it spent the first half of July drawing up proposed cuts of 25 and 40 per cent ahead of the comprehensive spending review due in the autumn.

Even if the Treasury goes for the lower figure, that still means £2 billion off the annual budget. As the smallest department in Whitehall, even one with an Olympics to deliver, it is hard to see the Treasury making an exception when the axe falls.

The cuts have made for a gloomy mood in the department in the run up to the two-years-to-go anniversary, with the reality that civil service jobs could be on the line as part of the austerity measures. Despite this, Robertson stresses his commitment to the Games and its potential to transform the British sporting landscape. He is hopeful that the ODA's careful stewardship of the construction project and an increase in the distribution of National Lottery funds to sport, will allow him to deliver. Specifically he wants the unused construction contingency to be channelled into the legacy project.

"The CSR process is only just started and it is going to have an impact on all departments, but because the ODA have made such good progress they have not used all of the contingency," he told The Daily Telegraph.

"There will be other areas that are not backed by contingency that might require support. No one wants to take the savings from the building project, give them back to the Treasury and then have to go back at a later date asking for more.

"We are in the process of articulating what the sports legacy means and we have made good progress in this regard. We know we will be able to finance it through the National Lottery, which we have restored to give sport its original 20 per cent share of the take."

He has already announced an Olympic-style school sport competition, and he has asked the British Olympic Association to work with Sport England on developing community projects.

Robertson is also effusive in his praise for the ODA – "I would be surprised if there was a body in British public life that has succeeded as spectacularly as it has in the last year" – and confident that the construction project will be completed on time and to budget.

While there is confidence about the Olympic Park, Robertson says "the penny is finally beginning to drop" among his colleagues across government about the scale of the challenge looming in 2012. A Games does not stop with the sports minister. "It stretches from the Home Office with the security responsibility, to the Foreign Office, which will be looking after 120 visiting heads of state, to the Department of Transport, which has to deliver the transport plan, and to us here at DCMS, who will have the job of delivering and co-ordinating it," he said.

"The trick for us is to drive more out of the projects that we are running across government, to 'Olympify' what we are doing to make sure that we take full advantage of what we are doing. At a time when the economy is very challenging it is great to have an event around which we can pull together."

rank_253.title: London 2012: £600 million budget unlikely to be enough for Games security
rank_253.text:
There could be a reshuffle of monies and responsibilities to tap into other Government security-related budgets.

This comes as a review of Olympic security conducted by Baroness Pauline Neville Jones is nearing completion and the Government is exacting savage cuts in its comprehensive review settlement.

It is understood Lady Neville-Jones's review will pinpoint the operational areas of the departments, such as the Metropolitan Police, London Organising Committee for the Olympic Games, the Home Office and the Olympic Delivery Authority, and reallocate monies accordingly.

The Home Office is in control of policing and security during the Olympics.

A Home Office spokesperson said: "We are reviewing the security arrangements, including the budget, to ensure that the measures in place are the right ones. The safety of those participating, watching and visiting the Olympics is paramount."

The Mayor of London, Boris Johnson, has argued strongly that the Olympic security budget had to be protected because "we have to understand how big it is going to be" and protect front line policing.

Security planners for the Olympic Games have been working on the premis of a severe level of threat, meaning an attack is likely.

London organising committee director of security and resilience Sir Ian Johnston told a world press briefing last month that to rachet up the level of threat to critical (where an attack is expected imminently) would be prohibitively expensive and was workable for only short periods of time.

Insiders have told The Daily Telegraph that the £600 million already set aside to pay for extra policing and security costs during the Games is expected to be fully drawn down but relying on other departments is difficult as their budgets are under increasing pressure too.

In its annual report earlier this month Locog indicated that the security and safety strategy of the Games was being paid out of the £600 million as well as other existing security arrangements such as the annual £12 billion policing budget and the £3 billion counter-terrorism budget .

Originally the £600 million, and a further £238 million of security contingency monies, set aside in July 2007 was to cover all of the additional costs involved in policing and securing the Games.

The Olympic Delivery Authority has flagged that it may require more than £110 million in extra money to take on extra security, logistics and facilities management at the Olympic park site after it was given additional control beyond the finishing of the venues to handing over to the Olympic Legacy Park Company in 2014.

Historically the security budgets at Games have escalated in the final two years, although none of the recent Games cities have had such comprehensive security plans in place as part of normal city operations.

Security costs to cover the low threat level at this year's Vancouver Winter Olympics rocketed from £110 million to £565 million.

rank_78.title: London 2012: Capital faces an uphill task to win Olympic legacy medal
rank_78.text:
On Thursday, the Olympic Park Legacy Company (OPLC), the quango tasked with the responsibility for the Olympic Park post-2012, began analysing the financial bids put forward by organisations seeking to operate the Olympic Stadium after 2012.

This comes just days after the OPLC also began its search for businesses to occupy the 1m sq ft press and broadcast centres after the Games.

Adverts appeared in the national press promoting a "new commercial district" in Stratford, with the desire to build a "media and creative industries hub".

If the regeneration of Stratford is to be viable, then attracting businesses to the area is pivotal. However, the ambitious pledge to revamp the Stratford region into a commercial base is attracting significant doubts in development and corporate circles. Can a hitherto unloved area of east London credibly be overhauled in such a manner?

Not only is the OPLC battling against the chequered post-Games history of most Olympic cities, but it is being challenged by the recession and competition from other regeneration projects. As Stratford seeks to promote itself as a realistic commercial district for creative industries, Nine Elms, Kings Cross and Paddington are trying to do the same.

Patrick Grincell, senior director in the planning team at Savills, says: "We are in a depressed market and this is likely to remain the case for a while. Nothing is easy at the moment and it's going to be a challenge for all those sites moving forward in the short term. The real challenge for Stratford will be to maintain momentum after the Games."

The man in charge of attempting to meet Stratford's regeneration goals is Andrew Altman, the former deputy mayor of Philadelphia who has been chief executive of the OPLC since its creation in May 2009.

This week, more hurdles have been put in his way with the change at the top of the Olympic Delivery Authority following the departure of chief executive David Higgins to Network Rail, and rumours that the OPLC will be scrapped as part of a Coalition bonfire of quangos.

Speaking to The Daily Telegraph, he said Mr Higgins's move was a "huge loss" to the ODA but that he expects a "solid transition". The American also dismissed the potential demise of the OPLC, insisting that a potential outcome is the Government scrapping its involvement and the OPLC moving solely under the remit of the Mayor of London.

He added: "We are part of the Comprehensive Spending Review and we are waiting to see what the outcome of that is."

Despite the doubts, Mr Altman's ambition for the site has not diminished. "Obviously there are challenges, but I think there is a great opportunity here. I think what makes the Olympic site unique is that it is incredibly bold. Some projects have a bold transport scheme, some have amenities, but it's extraordinary to have all in one place."

On the ground in Stratford, there are already examples of dramatic commercial change.

As well as the towering Westfield Stratford, which will be the biggest urban shopping centre in Europe when it is completed, new residential developments – primarily apartment blocks – are growing out of the ground.

One of those is by Thornsett Group, which in May completed a block of 64 luxury apartments at Lett Road.

Bernadette Cunningham, a director at the company, says: "If the Olympics weren't happening would Stratford be a no-man's land? Yes, probably."

However, while Miss Cunningham says the investment and manpower being poured into Stratford suggest it will enjoy an "amazing" regeneration, she warns that the recession has ravaged the ambition for private sector redevelopment in the area.

She estimates that just 10pc of the private apartments planned for the area ahead of the Olympics will be built because of the banks' reluctance to finance towers.

"For banks, towers have become a no-go because you can't phase the development, it has to be built in one go," she adds.

The recession and the constraints on finance are also a hindrance to Matthew Black, senior development director at property agent CBRE, as he tries to bring private investment to the area. Mr Black is helping the OPLC to attract businesses to the media centre while CBRE is also involved in letting the

100,000 sq ft of offices that Westfield plans to construct alongside its shopping centre, to which Capita has been linked.

Mr Black says he is "reasonably confident" about bringing companies to Stratford, pointing out that commercial rents will be cheaper than in other parts of London and stressing that Stratford will have the "best communication and transport infrastructure in the country" after the Olympics.

Over the next two months, Mr Black and the OPLC will compile a list of which businesses are interested in the site, with developers, operators, and potential occupiers invited to file proposals. He says there is a "desire" to make the area a media district, but that all sectors are welcome to apply. Conclusions of the market testing exercise will be made on December 17.

However, his task is considerable. A report by the London Assembly published last month warned that finding a tenant for the media development would be difficult not only due to the economic downturn, but also because of the 23-minute walk from the building to Stratford station, the lack of central heating, and the amount of pillars in the walls of the broadcast centre limiting potential revamps.

Mr Altman, however, is positive. "We don't have to wait like other projects for transport and infrastructure," he says.

"Also, we are going to have the largest urban mall in Europe," he continues. "When people ask 'When are we going to see the legacy? I say 'Look now'."

In an era of public belt-tightening, the ambition surrounding the Olympics and its legacy is refreshing. Sebastian Coe, chairman of Locog, has never wavered from his legacy pledge since 2005, insisting the Games and its £9.3bn budget will give something back to communities. Mr Altman claims that the Games have accelerated regeneration in Stratford by "a generation", while the profile and fixed deadline with which the project has been provided by the Olympics will also help it to be successful.

However, while there is much in its favour, in order for the regeneration to work, Altman and co will need to show the competitive spirit set to be demonstrated during the Games themselves. The starter's gun has been fired.

rank_217.title: London may withdraw bid for the 2015 World Championships due to lack of support
rank_217.text:
The promise of a track-and-field legacy from the Games was at the heart of the capital’s Olympic bid, and remains an article of faith for London 2012 chairman Sebastian Coe. It has proved easier said than done however, and after five years of wrangling the issue continues to cloud discussions over the legacy use of the stadium.

On Thursday it overshadowed the launch of the revised masterplan for the park, which as widely predicted will be known Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park from 2013.

Last week West Ham, in partnership with Newham Council, and Tottenham Hotspur, in partnership with the owners of the O2, AEG, both submitted initial bids for the stadium.

West Ham are committed to retaining the running track as well as a second warm-up track outside the stadium for community use, but AEG president Tim Leiweke said that the track would have to be ripped out for it to be attractive to Tottenham.

His comments re-opened the debate over whether an athletics legacy is viable, but on Thursday London mayor Boris Johnson, sports minister Hugh Roberston and Baroness Ford, the chair of the Olympic Park Legacy Company, all repeated the mantra that the stadium’s tenants should provide an athletics legacy.

“They would have to meet the Olympic promise for use of an athletics stadium - that has not changed,” said Ford, though she stopped short of saying that the track must be permanent.

At the same time, though, Robertson expressed scepticism about the viability of London’s bid for the 2015 World Athletics Championship. Without the Government agreeing to underwrite the staging costs of the event, and to share any losses, London’s bid will be withdrawn.

If it is, the UK will effectively be saying it will not host international track-and-field events in London at the same time as the OPLC demands that West Ham and Tottenham commit to a stadium designed to stage precisely such events.

The result could be London ending up with an athletics legacy that it does not use.

To add to the sense of farce, the British Olympic Association revealed that as a condition of allowing the word “Olympic” to be used in the park name, the legacy company had committed to help it attract major sporting events to the stadium.

The disconnect between the professed desire for an athletics legacy and the reluctance to underwrite it cuts to the heart of the problem. Athletics is the centrepiece of the Olympics but it is not commercially viable in its own right.

Even the World Championships lose money, relying on state and city governments to underwrite losses as the price of the global attention they bring.

Ed Warner, the chairman of UK Athletics, has argued that the 2015 bid makes sense because it will help bring to life the Olympic legacy promise. To have a chance of beating Beijing, however, his bid needs government support to underwrite the £45 million staging costs and to share losses that could reach £25 million.

On Thursday Roberston ruled out sharing any losses. “We are not shutting the door on underwriting the staging costs and provide other guarantees, but they [UKA] will not get a cheque to make up the shortfall if the event makes a loss. If we do that we will have every sport queuing up to provide the same guarantee for their sports,” he said.

Robertson added that no decision would be taken before the Comprehensive Spending Review on October 20. “If UKA wants an answer from me on before then it will be ‘no’. I will not make any decision before I know how much money we have to spend. But if I have to make a choice between underwriting losses and funding elite athletes I will choose athletes every time,” he said.

Warner said he was convinced the World Championships made sense for London. “We are pleased that Hugh Robertson is not shutting the door. We will continue to make the case that backing the championships is a prudent investment in the future of the Olympic Park and the stadium,” he said.

“We believe that it is the right thing to do for the stadium and the park generally, and will help bring the legacy promise to life.”

Grand designs for stadium post-2012

Nov 2006

Barry Hearn, the Leyton Orient chairman, reveals he is considering a bid for the stadium, but later changes his mind, calling it a "government cock-up".

Dec 2009

The stadium is named, along with the prospective new Tottenham stadium, as one of the possible venues for the 2018 World Cup.

March 2010

West Ham unveil their bid to move in, which would see football in the winter and athletics in the summer.

April 2010

It emerges Essex are in talks with Newham Council over playing Twenty20 cricket at the Olympic Stadium.

Oct 2010

Hours before the deadline for registering interest, Tottenham make a surprise latae move, creating the possibility of a bidding war with West Ham.

rank_221.title: West Ham United's plans to move to Olympic Stadium met with approval from UK Athletics
rank_221.text:
Ed Warner, the chairman of UK Athletics, offered his full support to the joint bid by West Ham , Newham Council and entertainment company Live Nation just days after describing a rival bid by Tottenham Hotspur and 02 owners AEG as "an insult to the whole Olympic project".

Under Tottenham's plans, the running track would be scrapped, breaking London's promise to the International Olympic Committee to provide an athletics legacy. West Ham's bid is for a multi-use stadium that includes athletics.

"What has impressed me so much about the joint bid from West Ham and Newham is their clear commitment to the spirit of the Olympic legacy and not just athletics at the elite end, but with the retention of the community track, our future champions and club runners too," said Warner.

"It was clear from the start that only a partnership approach would bring to life the vision Seb Coe had when he committed to an athletics legacy in 2005 and we believe the collaboration of West Ham, Newham and UKA gives the strongest opportunity for a vibrant sporting legacy that will go well beyond 2012."

"We believe ours is the only bid that can deliver London's legacy commitment to the International Olympic Committee," she said. "UKA's endorsement is a powerful and highly-valued testament of that."

Baroness Ford, chair of the Olympic Park Legacy Company, confirmed last week that the stadium would have to retain an athletics track after 2012.

The company hopes to make a decision on who will be the main tenant by December.

Meanwhile Hugh Brasher, the son of London Marathon co-founder Chris, is to succeed David Bedford as race director of the 29-year-old event when the former 10,000 metres world record-holder stands down in three years' time.

Brasher, who has been a director of the annual race from Blackheath to The Mall for the past two years, will take over in a structured changeover, acting as deputy race director next year, joint race director with Bedford in 2012 before assuming sole responsibility in 2013, when Bedford will switch to a part-time role.

Bedford, 61, said: "Hugh Brasher, through his business experience in sporting events and understanding of the sport from every angle, was head and shoulders above the other applicants."

rank_245.title: London Olympic Business: British companies could miss Olympic benefits
rank_245.text:
A new Deloitte report found that over two thirds of companies in the UK expect no impact on their operations from the Olympics. Only half expect to see any increase in demand for their services during the Games.

According to the survey, more than half of businesses in tourism, hospital and leisure expect "virtually no impact" from London holding the Games, despite 10m tickets being on sale for the Olympics and Paralympics. Meanwhile, more than 70pc of retailers expect no impact.

Rick Cudworth, head of business continuity and resilience at Deloitte, said: "Many of these businesses need a wake-up call. They operate in service industries where people are vital, where the supply chain is time critical, where having products on the shelf or food to serve in restaurants is essential to their daily business. Thinking through the impacts that an Olympic-scale event could have on logistics, the supply of goods and the movement of staff is essential."

Deloitte's Games Readiness report found that even in London, 60pc of businesses expect only a minimal impact from the Games, despite the potential disruption to transport and accommodation, and potential shortages of catering and security services. Only 7pc fear a lack of hotel availability, and 8pc a disruption to supplies.

Nigel Bourne, the CBI's London director, warned there needs to be an "education" with businesses about how to financially benefit from the Games and prepare for potential disruption. He said that demand on London's transport network during the six-week period that the Olympics and Paralympics are held will be "far greater than anything we have seen".

"I would urge businesses to start looking at these things now rather than at the end of 2011," he said. The CBI is holding regular meetings with its members about the Olympics, while the Olympic Delivery Authority (ODA) is also preparing a package on travel that it will distribute to companies.

A spokesman for the Department for Culture, Media and Sport said the Government was "working closely with existing business networks, such as CBI and FSB, to ensure that British firms maximise the opportunities created by the Games". He added: "These networks have also been used to consult with companies about possible short-term impacts on trading at Games-time and how to maintain business as usual."

Concerns about the preparedness of companies comes just days after figures from the ODA also called into question how widespread the economic benefits of the Games would be to the UK. Out of the 1,300 tier-one contracts worth £5.2bn for the construction of the venues, Welsh companies have won just £574,000 of work, the equivalent of 0.01pc. Meanwhile, Scottish groups have won just 0.43pc and Northern Irish 0.33pc.

The figures prompted criticism of the Welsh Government – which admitted it was "disappointed" over the lack of deals – about its efforts to help companies secure contracts, although the ODA has stressed that companies in the country have won work from the 70,000 contracts generated through the supply chain.

Mr Bourne, however, believes that the UK economy will still enjoy widespread benefits from the Games. The CBI backed London's bid to host the Olympics, believing there will be a boost not only from tourism but the "international promotion" of London and the UK, a sentiment backed by 92pc of business in a recent survey.

"If you look at other Olympic cities who have done a good job of staging the games, such as Barcelona and Sydney, they have been transformed," he added. "Businesses outside London have already benefited from winning contracts and I think businesses will also benefit from spending by people coming into the UK or from their community. We all hope that people who come to visit the Games will also spend some time in other parts of the UK. There will also be the knock-on effects from the various training camps."

In the Deloitte survey, although only half of businesses said they expect an increase in demand, 20pc expected a strong increase. Also, a quarter of the 200 large companies surveyed – which employ more than 500 people – have appointed an individual or group to assess the potential opportunities and disruptions from the Games. At BAA, for example, Danny Sloan is 2012 director. He is in charge of preparing for the huge influx of passengers that the company's airports will see during the Games, including the athletes themselves.

However, Heather Hancock, the London 2012 partner at Deloitte, warned: "There is a disconnect in that many businesses are expecting to see an increase in demand for their services but are not planning or thinking about what they need to do in order to secure that extra business. They should recognise that their competitors will be, and in some cases already are, planning for this upturn. Relying on an assumption that demand will increase automatically could leave them out in the cold come 2012."

rank_113.title: London 2012 Olympics: Government accused of 'devastating' legacy with school spending cuts
rank_113.text:
While the £9.3 billion budget for hosting the Games was left almost untouched by the Comprehensive Spending Review, cutbacks in school sport provision have raised questions over whether the country will be able deliver on the promise made by Sebastian Coe during the 2012 bidding process to use the Olympics and Paralympics to inspire a new generation of young people to take up sport.

The Department of Education announced it was axing the entire £162 million PE and Sports Strategy, which was introduced by the previous Labour administration with the aim of proving five hours of high-quality sport for all five to 16 year-olds. The five-hour target is being withdrawn.

In addition, a network of 450 school sports partnerships set up across the country and administered by the Youth Sport Trust to forge sporting links between schools and local clubs is to be scrapped.

It was also announced that the Government would no longer provide ring-fenced funding for the country's 3,000 specialist schools, many of which are sporting academies, offering a saving of £450 million for 2010-11.

Ivan Lewis, the shadow Culture, Media and Sports Secretary, said: "At a time when we are preparing to host the Olympics, bidding for the World Cup and fighting an obesity crisis, this dismantling of support for school sport is perverse and short-sighted.

"It will hit disadvantaged young people the hardest and makes a mockery of our commitment to deliver an Olympic legacy."

Baroness Sue Campbell, who is chairman of the YST and UK Sport, described the axing of the PE and Sports Strategy as "devastating news", claiming more than a million young people had been introduced to competitive sport in the past three years through the school sport partnerships.

Steve Grainger, the YST chief executive, said: "With just 21 months to go until the start of the London 2012 Olympics and Paralympics, Lord Coe's pledge to use the Games to transform sporting opportunities for young people is now hanging in the balance."

The Department of Culture, Media and Sport has also suffered a substantial cut to its funding, with cash earmarked for Sport England, which distributes funds for sport at community level, set to be reduced by 33 per cent over four years.

Sport England will consult the national governing bodies before deciding where the axe will fall in revenue funding and capital expenditure.

UK Sport, which looks after elite sport, faces a 28 per cent cut, though there will be no reduction in support for Olympic and Paralympic athletes until after the 2012 Games.

Both Sport England and UK Sport have been cushioned from the full impact of the cutbacks by an increase in Lottery funding over the next four years, with sport's share of the overall Lottery pot rising to 20 per cent from 13.7 per cent from 2012 onwards.

The two organisations have committed to reduce their administration costs by 50 per cent by March 2015. The two bodies will be merged by April 1, 2013.

The budget for hosting the Olympic and Paralympic Games remains largely intact, with the £1.1 billion contingency fund also preserved.

Hugh Robertson, the Sports Minister, said: "This is a straightforward government commitment to what we won in 2005. It's also a reflection of the fact that the building project is now 70 per cent complete.

He added: "In terms of the way that the project has been managed, it has already delivered £740 million in savings so the project has been well managed up to now. I think that has given the Treasury confidence that it can manage it going further forward."

rank_254.title: London 2012 Olympics: Jessica Ennis' hopes of double gold are hit by timetable
rank_254.text:
Ennis and her coach, Toni Minichiello, had lodged a request with the London organising committee (Locog) to build in three or four days' rest between the end of the heptathlon and the first-round heats of the hurdles to give her enough recovery time for a twin-pronged Olympic campaign in 2012.

A similar request was granted to American favourite Michael Johnson at the Atlanta Olympics in 1996 to enable him to attempt a historic double in the 200m and 400m. He won gold in both and set a 200m world record.

But, according to insiders, no such favour has been accorded to Ennis, the world and European heptathlon champion and also a world-class performer in the sprint hurdles.

The draft timetable for the 2012 Games, which has recently been finalised, allows Ennis a mere 36 hours' recovery time between events, making it almost impossible for her to contemplate the heptathlon-hurdles double.

An identical gap between the two events at last year's World Championships in Berlin proved too tight for the Sheffield athlete, who was forced to pull out of the hurdles on the eve of competition because she was still exhausted after her gruelling heptathlon victory.

Last night, Minichiello conceded that the gap between the events in London was probably too short to attempt the double.

"It's incredibly tight," he said. "Because it's the same as the Berlin timetable, it's probably too tight. I don't want to rule it out because I need to have a discussion with Jess. It's certainly something we'll still consider but I'm not sure. It might just be too tight."

The athletics timetable for London has been drawn up by Locog, the International Association of Athletics Federations and the Olympic Broadcast Service and is due to be signed off by the IAAF at its council meeting in Monaco next month.

Details of the schedule are being kept under wraps until then but The Daily Telegraph has learnt that the two-day heptathlon competition will take place on the first two days of athletics competition, beginning on the morning of Friday, Aug 3, and finishing with the last of the seven events, the 800m, on the evening of Aug 4. The opening round of the women's sprint hurdles is scheduled for Aug 6.

The night of Aug 4, when Ennis will be the overwhelming favourite to clinch Britain's first athletics gold medal, is certain to be one of the hottest tickets of the Games since it will also feature the second round of the men's 100m.

The showpiece men's 100m final, for which tickets will cost up to £725, is due to take place on Sunday, Aug 5. For triple Olympic champion Usain Bolt, the schedule will be more condensed than it was at the Beijing Olympics in 2008, when the 100m final took place on the Saturday evening.

Ennis may get another chance to win an Olympic medal if she is selected for the 4x100m relay, having already been sounded out about running the first leg by GB women's relay coach, Tony Lester. The first round is due to take place on Aug 9.

But the short gap between the heptathlon and hurdles will be a bitter blow for the 24 year-old, who is certain to be one of the poster girls for 2012. Earlier this week she was shortlisted for the IAAF World Athlete of the Year award following her pentathlon victory at the World Indoor Championships in Doha in March and her heptathlon triumph at the European Championships in Barcelona.

As well as reigning supreme in multi-events competition, Ennis also believes that, with continued improvement over the next couple of seasons, she could be challenging for a medal in the individual hurdles by the time of the Olympics.

She began this year by setting a British record of 7.95sec in the 60m hurdles in Glasgow, beating American world indoor champion Lolo Jones in the process.

Her personal best over 100m of 12.81sec would have got her to the Olympic final in Beijing, though she missed out on the Games after suffering stress fractures in her right foot.

In May this year, Ennis said she hoped organisers would do all they could to allow her to double up in London and make the most of the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity of competing at a home Olympics.

"I hope they'll be able to pull a few strings to let it happen," she said. "If the timetable did permit and I keep on improving, then I'd love to do it."

Jessica's highs and lows

2005: Heptathlon gold, European Junior Championships, Kaunas.

2006: Heptathlon bronze, Commonwealth Games, Melbourne.

2008: Suffered multiple stress fractures in right foot midway through Gotzis Meeting, ruling her out of Beijing Olympics.

2009: Heptathlon gold, World Championships, Berlin.

2010: Pentathlon gold, World Indoor Championships, Doha; heptathlon gold, European Championships, Barcelona.

rank_255.title: London abandons bid for 2015 World Athletics Championships
rank_255.text:
The decision leaves Beijing as the sole bidders for 2015 and the Chinese capital should be confirmed as hosts by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) on November 20.

The Government were unable to commit to backing a 2015 bid because a number of the tenders for the 2012 stadium - including Tottenham's - have plans that would see the running track removed.

Ministers feared if they committed to a bid for 2015 with the stadium as the centre-piece they would be open to legal action.

It is understood the decision to bid instead for 2017 has been made with the blessing of the IAAF.

Sports minister Hugh Robertson said he was now very hopeful the Government would underwrite the 2017 bid.

Robertson said: "That is still to be completely confirmed but I would be very disappointed if that were not the case."

The minister said the biggest danger would have been to make a bid and then pull out at a later date, as happened in 2001 when the then Government pulled out of London's Picketts Lock hosting the 2005 championships.

Robertson added: "The crucial thing was to avoid the collateral damage we suffered with Picketts Lock."

Ed Warner, the chairman of UK Athletics, said: "Obviously we are disappointed not to be pursuing our 2015 bid, especially after securing the support of both the Government and the Mayor of London.

"However, we need to present the IAAF with a bid that is free of any uncertainties.

"That is not something we can commit to until the process regarding the future of the stadium, which we fully support, is concluded.

"Our bid is, in my opinion, an excellent one and one that can deliver an outstanding championships for the IAAF. That fact remains.

"I would like to put on record my thanks to the Government and in particular the sports minister Hugh Robertson, the Mayor's office, the OPLC (Olympic Park Legacy Company) and UK Sport for their support throughout this process and their commitment to a 2017 bid."

Robertson added: "We are absolutely committed to staging the greatest sporting events in the UK and that of course includes the IAAF World Championships.

"In our bid to the IOC for the 2012 Olympics Games we were clear that the games would produce a legacy for athletics and that has not changed. We cannot stress enough the importance of athletics as part of the Olympic legacy.

"The deadline for the 2015 bid falls before the conclusion of the stadium process in spring 2011, but that does not diminish our appetite to host the event. The UK Government and UKA remain keen and committed to a bid as soon as we are able."

IAAF President Lamine Diack added: "We fully understand and respect the reasons for UKA moving their bid from 2015 to 2017. We are delighted that London are still in the race."

rank_182.title: London 2012 Olympic legacy set-back as England Hockey miss out on hosting World Cup 2014 to Holland
rank_182.text:
The news comes just over a week after UK Athletics announced its decision to retract a bid to host the 2015 World Athletics Championships meaning the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park legacy facility is yet to secure the rights to a world event in the years after the Games.

Had the England Hockey Board’s [EHB] proposal been successful, the 12-nation tournaments would have been the first world-level events to be staged at the legacy facility following the 2012 Games and the first World Cups to be staged simultaneously since Holland did at Utrecht in1998.

Speaking from the FIH congress in Montreux, Switzerland, EHB chief executive, Sally Munday said: “This is a real disappointment for hockey in England. We thought the London bid provided a fantastic opportunity to engage with the spectators that will be attending hockey matches at the London Olympics but clearly it was not meant to be.

“We felt that our focus on the legacy for hockey in this country and the commercial package that we put together would stand us in good stead; however, we always knew that it would be tough competition against the Dutch bid.

“Hockey is huge in the Netherlands, they have great experience in hosting world level events and I am sure the 2014 World Cups will be very successful.”

rank_117.title: London 2012 Olympics: 'spin before substance’ raises concerns of Olympic Legacy
rank_117.text:
In a letter sent to the chief executives of more than 40 sports this week, a senior executive at Sport England acknowledges that the consultation has not been exhaustive, and indicated that government news management may have played a part.

“To help shape the programme we have consulted with some individual national governing bodies. Unfortunately it has not been possible to engage widely because of the Government’s desire for a strong and positive impact at the point of announcement,” wrote Phil Smith, Sport England’s director of sport.

Sport England and the Department for Culture Media and Sport sources rejected concerns that this indicated spin was more important than substance in a project that has been a priority of sports minister Hugh Robertson.

It is understood that chief executives in three leading Olympic sports have given their endorsement to the programme.

The sources said that once the governing bodies saw the substance of the proposals, which will not be revealed to them until Monday, they would approve. “This is going to be a win for the sport because it is a fresh pot of money that they can access,” said one source.

The substance of the Olympic legacy has been a major issue for London 2012, which was won on a promise to transform sport in the UK. In the wake of the Comprehensive Spending Review, which produced 30 per cent cuts across sport and £160 million of school sports funding withdrawn altogether, the legacy package has become even more important.

It is understood that the legacy package will be entirely funded from the National Lottery.

It appears that the programme, which has been prepared in association with the British Olympic Association, will provide funding for facilities and volunteering programmes. It may also offer recipients some form of Olympic branding.

rank_101.title: England Hockey not giving up on London 2012 Olympic legacy plans after World Cup 2014 bid loss
rank_101.text:
On Friday the International Hockey Federation awarded the Men's and Women's World Cups to Holland - the only nation England found themselves up against.

And despite the disappointment of missing out, it seems the EHB's legacy projections go well beyond the 12-nation tournaments and that Lee Valley features highly in both their domestic and international plans for the future.

"Of course we're disappointed not to have been successful with the 2014 bid, but we will still work to ensure our legacy plans are successful," said EHB chief executive Sally Munday.

"The 2014 World Cups was just one event in a big picture of things to come. We have a massive commitment to legacy and the FIH support that. We have plenty of ideas and they [the FIH] have expressed interest in the use of Lee Valley from 2015 onwards.

"Legacy was the most powerful part of out bid and we will work to make sure this is successful. International events is only one part the facility is needed by the community.

"We'll be hosting so many things there - OK we havent got the 2014 World Cup but thats not the end of the story."

Munday added that though the FIH have not given a full debrief on what aspect of the Dutch bid had edged London out of the running, funding was at the fore front of her thoughts.

"We haven’t had a full explanation just yet but we have been told that both bids were strong and competitive. Ultimately, Holland put more money on the table.

"Our bid was so competitive, commercially very strong and we had fantastic support – both hands on and financial – from the London Mayor’s office, UK Sport and Frank Warren. The FIH recognised all of this.

"England Hockey, our team and what we're doing from grassroots to the elite is on the ascendancy. We're working so hard to get our sport back on the map and we're so proud of what we've achieved in the last 2 years.

"Internationally we're enjoying the success of moving up the rankings and we're heading in the right direction. This is one bid we didn't win but we will win more."

rank_41.title: London 2012 Olympics: 'Places People Play' legacy plan unveiled
rank_41.text:
The mass-participation legacy plan, called Places People Play, will see £135 million of Lottery funding spent on facilities, protecting playing fields, volunteering programmes and extending access to Olympic sports over four years starting in April 2011.

Of that sum, £98 million is previously unannounced and £37 million comes from Sport England's existing budget. All of the funding will come from the Lottery, restored by the coalition government to its original four strands, a move that will see sport's share increase to 20 per cent by 2012.

London put the sporting legacy at the heart of their bid to the International Olympic Committee, but the funding announced on Monday amounts to around 1.5 per cent of the £9.3 billion budget for the Games infrastructure.

Robertson insisted that while the funding package was lower than he might have hoped to spend on exploiting the "once-in-a-lifetime" opportunity, it represents a good settlement given the economic climate.

"If we had double the money then we could do double the good but we all know what the financial situation is. It is worth remembering that the amount of debt interest paid by the UK government each day is more than is spent on community sport every year.

"But this is a real sign of commitment to the Olympics. I would have liked to have £9.3 billion to spend, of course, but in the circumstances this is an extremely good offer and an indication that the Olympics legacy is a priority." Robertson said he had not yet decided whether to stick to the last government's commitment to get two million Britons playing more sport as a result of the Olympics, but its absence from Monday's announcement indicates it is unlikely to be retained.

Coe said he was satisfied with the programme, which is backed by the British Olympic Association and the British Paralympic Association.

"When we bid for the Games in Singapore in 2005 we said that we would use the power of the Games to inspire young people to take up sport. This will harness the inspirational power of the Olympic and Paralympic Games to promote sport across the country." Shadow Olympics minister Tessa Jowell was withering, saying that the programme was a drop in the ocean compared to the cuts to school sports funding announced in the Comprehensive Spending Review.

"This additional money is welcome but it goes nowhere near replacing the funds already taken away from sport, particularly sport in schools," she said.

"However they dress it up, the Olympic legacy promise that we made to this country's young people is yet another promise that has been broken by the Coalition Government."

The largest share of the new funding, £50 million, will be spent on 1,000 small and medium-sized grants to sports clubs to improve facilities, with Sport England negotiation procurement deals with suppliers to drive down costs to sports clubs.

All facility improvements will receive the London 2012 "Inspire" mark, an official logo that for copyright reasons does not feature the Olympic rings.

A further £10 million will be spent on protecting playing fields by "bringing disused playing fields back into use" and improving existing facilities. A further £30 million of existing funding will be spent by national governing bodies on enhancing existing "iconic" facilities.

The 'People' part of the programme will see £2 million spent on recruiting and training up to 40,000 "sports leaders" in partnership with the BOA and BPA.

The intention is to find volunteers below Level One coaching standard who can help make sport happen, by organising club competitions, maintaining facilities and such like. They will have to commit to 10 hours of volunteering.

The programme has also adopted an existing charitable programme called Gold Challenge, an independent initiative that encourages children to try Olympic sports, and a coaching programme targeted at school-leavers who drop out of sport called Sportivate.

rank_105.title: London 2012 Olympics: Great Britain's Shanaze Reade eyes historic double gold
rank_105.text:
