The Track Cycling will now start at the Olympic Park Velodrome on August 2 and Reade, is she earns selection in the Team Sprint, will be done and dusted by the following day allowingher to concentrate on the BNX competition which starts on August 9

"The final confirmation is fantastic news," says Reade who won her Third World BMX title this summer. "I can now seriously commit to trying to win selection for both. At one stage it looked like it was going to be completely the other way around which was definitely a big problem – there are a lot of crashes in BMX and I never hold back so I know the GB management were concerned about that and the challenge in the Team Sprint being affected if I was selected and then got injured on the BMX track.

"So the dream of chasing two gold medals in different sports is alive but it is going to be very difficult. Just getting into the GB Team Sprint team as the lead off rider for Vicky Pendleton is going to be a major challenge because Jess Varnish is going really well and getting stronger with every ride.

"For the time being I am not even going to think that selection issue, we all need to concentrate first on reaching the level of performance needled to win the gold medal, selection can take care of itself later. what I need to do now is to make some major inroads into my personal best for that first lap.

"The Australians are almost certainly going to be the team to beat and their leadoff girl Kaarle McCulloch is doing opening laps of 18.5 which is a fir bit quick than my best from a couple of years ago is 19 seconds. I'm off the track for another month at least with a wrist injury, I have just had the plaster off, and as soon as I get back that will be my focus, to get that time down.

"In one way BMX and track sprinting are closely related – you need fast leg speed and explosive power – but in other ways they are very different. The aerodynamics are completely different, your position on the bike is very different and you use different muscles in your back and your butt. When I do a big block of track training, after switching from BMX, I am always sore for the first two or three weeks as I readjust.

"I am going to try and address that this summer, when I am back on the BMX circuit, by making a strong commitment to doing one day's training on the track wherever I am in the world, just to keep ticking over on that side of things. It won't be easy but in the long term it has to be done.

"On the track its still on the technique side of things that I have work do to. Physically I score very well on all our tests, I have explosive power and plenty of endurance from the longer BMX races, so I have got to fine tune my pure sprinting technique.

"My wrist injury means I can't be considered for any of the first two World Cup meetings in December but I am not going to fret, the bigger picture is being at a new level for 2012. I should be back in full swing by early January and am hoping for a good ride at the Manchester World Cup and then we will see what the situation is with the World Championships."

Looking beyond 2012 you sense that Reade may be contemplating a more permanent switch to the track. With Pendleton widely expected to retire after London, there will be a vacancy as Great Britain's 'Golden girl' and although BMX has a loyal following and Reade enjoys cult status it remains very much a niche sport. In contrast Track cycling is now virtually mainstream with Great Britain's biggest stars becoming household names.

Above all else there is the attraction of competing in the Keirin which will become an Olympic event for the first time in London. If ever a rider was born to ride their Keirin it would seem to be Reade.

"I have always loved watching it, the Keirin in a real battle and reminds me a great deal of some of our BMX races. Its about speed and guts and tactics and looks great fun. You can't do it all at once and I have got enough on my plate at the moment but after London I would like to have a serious go at the Keirin and maybe the Individiual sprint as well."

Holiday Inn has introduced a programme to support up to 50 emerging and established British athletes by providing over 1,500 free nights at hotels across the IHG brand family worldwide.

rank_157.title: London 2012 Olympics: Tottenham stadium victory 'would be a betrayal of Olympic legacy'
rank_157.text:
Tottenham face competition from West Ham to inherit the stadium after the 2012 Games, with the Upton Park club, backed by Newham Council, long considered the frontrunners because of their commitment to meeting the Olympic promise of an athletics legacy by retaining the track inside the stadium.

That commitment has won the support of Ed Warner, chairman of UK Athletics, but the increasing seriousness and financial strength of Tottenham’s bid has prompted concerns that the athletics legacy promised by Lord Coe in London’s Olympic bid may be compromised.

Tottenham and their partners AEG, which owns and operates the O2, have said they will rip out the athletics track after the Games and build a new stadium on the site, but they are yet to articulate what alternative they will offer athletics. Warner believes that given the strength of the West Ham proposal, they will not be able to compete.

“We have come down in support of the West Ham-Newham bid for very good reasons,” he told Telegraph Sport . “It ticks all the boxes in terms of the legacy for athletics, both at an elite level and in the community. I cannot conceive of an athletics legacy that Tottenham can come up with that would be acceptable given that West Ham would give us the ability to stage the championships and make the stadium the iconic home of British athletics in the long-term.

“It is a very credible bid that follows the legacy promise London made to the IOC in the long term and anything less than their offer would be a capitulation and would be to renege on the promise we made when the Games were awarded.”

Warner’s disquiet over the athletics legacy betrays the growing conviction in Olympic circles that far from being a fall-back position for Tottenham in the event of complications with their existing development plans in Haringey, the Stratford site could become their favoured option. Spurs’ interest has hardened in recent months after the cost of their favoured new stadium development adjacent to White Hart Lane increased by at least £50 million because of planning and development issues.

There is a belief within the club board that the Olympic Stadium site offers a viable and potentially cheaper alternative. The Spurs bid is now described by sources close to the process as “deadly serious”.

“Some people have said that the Olympic bid is just a means of getting leverage over Haringey, but the club is committed to running this process in parallel with that development. If they are successful in winning the bid for Stratford they will have to make a decision, but it is deadly serious,” said a source with direct knowledge of the deliberations.

Tottenham have hired investment bank Goldman Sachs as advisers in negotiations that will open with the Olympic Park Legacy Company on Monday.

In a sign of the club’s interest Sir Keith Mills, deputy chairman of the London 2012 organising committee and a non-executive director at Tottenham, has absented himself from Olympic board meetings until the issue is settled to avoid any conflict of interest. Tottenham’s ultimate owner, Joe Lewis, the billionaire speculator, is also understood to have taken an interest in the project.

The club are yet to articulate their athletics legacy but are understood to have been in touch with Warner in recent days, and are said to be considering a number of options. These are thought to include revisiting the possibility of redeveloping the Crystal Palace site, an option rejected previously.

While Tottenham’s bid is weak on legacy it is considered financially strong. “Tottenham would score 10 out of 10 on finance but nought out of 10 on legacy, while West Ham get 10 out of 10 on legacy and do less well on finance,” said one source.

The OPLC’s tender documents make it clear that long-term financial viability is a prerequisite for the successful bidder, and Tottenham believe they can offer a more attractive offer than West Ham.

West Ham counter that they have a robust proposal that would mean Newham Council borrowing less than £80 million, secured against football club revenue, to fund the transformation of the stadium. The key to winning the bid, however, will be convincing the OPLC and the Government that their bid is viable in the long term, even if the club are relegated this season.

West Ham vice-chairman Karren Brady said she had no doubt it would. “It is ridiculous to say that just because we are bottom of the league our bid is less strong than Tottenham’s,” she said. “Newham will borrow the money and we will pay it back at a rate we can afford, whether we are in the Premier League or the Championship. We have modelled both situations and we can afford it. This is not an arrogant football club coming along to write a cheque, this is about a proper legacy and that is what we are going to deliver.”

The key to West Ham securing a stadium they have eyed for five years rests in their proving that the financial case stacks up in the long term, avoiding any future call on the public purse.

If they do that, given the commitment to an Olympic legacy that all the key decision makers, including London mayor Boris Johnson and culture secretary Jeremy Hunt have endorsed, it will be hard to refuse.

Head to head: how the rival bids compare

»West Ham

Aim: Convert Olympic stadium into a 60,000 seat stadium that will retain the running track and be long-term home for British athletics as well as venue for future World and European Championships. Would also host Twenty-20 cricket.

How: Bid is backed by Newham Council and concert promoters Live Nation. Sale of Upton Park will help raise funds.

Chances: If this was decided on legacy alone, West Ham would win. The bid meets the expectation of an Olympic athletics legacy but there are doubts about viability of the financial plan.

»Spurs

Aim: An alternative to Tottenham’s planned new ground next door to White Hart Lane, in partnership with AEG. Would demolish Olympic Stadium and replace with 60,000 seat arena, with no running track. Athletics legacy unknown.

How: Spurs would borrow the money to build the new stadium, hoping that the clean site, excellent transport links and straightforward planning issues would make it cheaper than the Haringey option.

Chances: The bid badly needs a plausible athletics solution but if the decision comes down to money they have every chance.

rank_246.title: London 2012: Women's volleyball team granted Olympics place despite funding cut
rank_246.text:
The British Olympic Association announced yesterday that both the men’s and women’s indoor volleyball teams would definitely be a part of Team GB in London after meeting the criteria of its Olympic Qualifying Standards Panel.

As the host nation, Britain has the advantage of automatic selection in most of the team sports on the Olympic programme but, to avoid any passengers on the GB team, the BOA insists teams will only be selected if they are capable a of “credible performance” at the Games and can demonstrate a long-term legacy for their sport.

The men’s and women’s volleyball teams are currently ranked a lowly 89th and 64th in the world respectively, with the men’s team rated equally with Saint Lucia, Honduras, Aruba and the Cayman Islands.

But the rankings are calculated over four years and not an accurate guide to current form. Andy Hunt, the BOA chief executive, said he was confident both teams would meet their target of a top-eight finish in 2012 if they maintained their recent improvement.

Hunt said: “We have applied quite tough tests and we have put British Volleyball and the coaches through a rigorous process of demonstrating quantifiable evidence around their performance to date since 2006 and their pathway through to the Games.”

The news represents a dramatic change of fortune for the women’s team, which had its funding axed in October when the British Volleyball Federation chose to concentrate its resources on men’s indoor and women’s beach volleyball.

Earlier in the summer, the women’s squad staged a sponsored bike ride from Sheffield to London to raise extra funds.

Lynne Beattie, captain of the women’s team, said: “This announcement is a huge boost for the women’s programme, especially after the uncertainty of the last few months.”

UK Sport board members are due to meet today to finalise funding allocations for 2011, and Hunt said he hoped money would be available for the women's squad.

“As part of the selection panel that we held, one of the things that we saw was the extraordinary determination and commitment from the women’s team, demonstrated through quite significant adversity," he said.

“We’re really hoping that UK Sport will consider strongly supporting the women’s team with the £200,000 they need to ensure they can compete on the international circuit next year.”

rank_223.title: London 2012 Olympics: stars of track and field plead with Games organisers to keep athletics track
rank_223.text:
Clearly aligning themselves with the Newham borough and West Ham joint bid – which promises to retain the track – 15 stars including Dame Kelly Holmes, Tanni Grey Thompson, Daley Thompson, Steve Backley, Jamie Baulch, Roger Black, Steve Cram, Lynn Davies, Brendan Foster, Kath Merry, David Moorcroft, Alan Pascoe, Wendy Sly, Ian Stewart and Alan Wells have signed an open lobbying letter.

The Newham-West Ham bid is up against a joint bid from Tottenham Hotspur and entertainment company AEG which has no plans for retention of the track in the main stadium.

But the athletes claim any move by the Olympic Park Legacy Company, which is currently considering the two proposals, to go back on promises made at the time of the 2005 Olympic bid would impact on the wider community.

The legacy company is due to make a decision early next year between the two bids.

On Tuesday the London organising committee chairman Lord Sebastian Coe told parliament he did not want to enter into a debate about the merits of the two proposals, but noted as a sportsman from track and field, he was clearly in favour of the track being retained.

The International Olympic Committee has been taking a keen interest in the ongoing debate as the legacy of a track was one of the key planks of the London bid back in Singapore in 2005.

“A home Games in 2012 gives our country a once in a lifetime opportunity to inspire future generations with a love of sport, be they future Olympians or the supporters that play such a crucial role in our success,” the letter states.

“One of the most compelling aspects of our bid back in 2005 was the promise of an athletics legacy in the form of a world-class stadium.

“This promise made the idea of legacy real. It showed that the Games would continue to touch the wider community long after the Olympics and Paralympic spectacular had left town.

“What made the legacy more persuasive was the fact that this wasn’t just about the top end of the sport and giving our top athletes a ‘home’ stadium to be proud of.

“This was about the community, about making a facility work as hard as possible and be as accessible as possible to a wide range of people from a wide range of sports.

“As Olympians we are all ardent sports fans and that is why we believe the Olympic legacy HAS to be The Olympic Stadium complete with track.

“It would be unacceptable for the stadium to lose the track and effectively become an Olympic Stadium with NO Olympic connection or legacy.''

rank_239.title: London 2012: the Olympics will be the ultimate test for the Bribery Act
rank_239.text:
The Olympic Games is the biggest sporting event on the planet, and provides the ultimate corporate hospitality opportunity for UK and global companies. The Games are attended by the rich and famous, government leaders and by senior representatives of global and national companies. It is a great opportunity to make friends and influence people, leading to lucrative business arrangements.

For the London 2012 Olympic Games, £700m of official sponsorship money has already been paid to Locog, the organising committee, by top global and UK companies through a tiered programme of sponsorship. This is a significant element of the commercial revenue derived from the Games, along with ticket and merchandise sales.

In addition, the opportunities for these companies for corporate entertainment are endless in the run-up to, during and in the aftermath of the Games.

It is estimated that £100m will be spent on events and hospitality during London 2012.

Individual countries are already setting up respective "houses" in and around London. This will be the centre of activities for athletes, sponsors and businessmen during the Olympics.

However, businesses, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and the London 2012 organisers, will need to give due consideration to the The UK Bribery Act. This Act comes into effect from April 1, 2011. This will mean that certain types of corporate hospitality and gifts may be considered a bribe and may be illegal. The penalties can include unlimited fines and heavy prison sentences for both employees and companies.

Sentences may be up to 10 years for the individual staff members, and organisations involved may be heavily fined. Additionally, company directors who may be found to have consented or be involved will be liable for the offence.

The offences include offering or receiving financial or other advantage, bribing or corrupting a foreign public official and the new and largely undefined corporate offences. However, we do know that the new corporate offences will include when a person associated with a company bribes another person for the benefit of said company. The company in question will be found to have committed a bribe.

Should a potential case arise, the only defence of the organisation is to show that it had adequate procedures in place to stop bribery. These procedures will not be fully defined until early 2011.

The Act includes all organisations incorporated in the UK, or undertaking all or part of its business in the UK. The Act, therefore, has both a domestic element and global reach into foreign companies with UK interests which may see the Games as a great opportunity to influence current and potential customers, suppliers and business partners.

The cost of compliance for UK corporates is likely to be high. Many are already revising arrangements to address the Act. Companies will need to review their policies, procedures and budgets for corporate entertaining to ensure employees stay within the law. In the run-up to the Act, companies need to establish internal policies, train staff, delegate responsibility for bribery monitoring, assess the risks of bribery and corruption and set internal disciplinary sanctions. All of this will obviously come at a cost to UK businesses.

Current guidance suggests that business lunches are reasonable but lavish corporate events may lead to undue influence, and there remain many grey areas. The Olympics, coming so soon after the Act is introduced, will surely be the ultimate test for this rigorous Act.

John Abbott is head of governance, risk and assurance at accountant RSM Tenon

rank_177.title: London 2012 Olympics: Tottenham's plans to demolish and rebuild stadium on agenda at IOC meeting
rank_177.text:
The north London club, who are vying with West Ham to take over the Olympic Stadium after 2012, made public their ambitious plans to demolish the existing structure in Stratford, east London, and replace it with a new 60,000-seat venue capable of hosting Premier League football and concerts staged by entertainments giant AEG.

But, crucially, the club have confirmed that there will be no place in the new stadium for an athletics track. The Tottenham -AEG consortium, as revealed by Telegraph Sport last month, has offered to pay for an upgrade of the Crystal Palace athletics stadium, providing 9,500 extra permanent seats to raise its capacity to 25,000 with the option of adding a further 15,000 seats to stage a World Championship.

The final decision on the stadium's future will be made by the Olympic Legacy Company and is expected on Jan 28th.

Should the OLC prefer Tottenham's bid to that of West Ham - who are committed to keeping the running track - there is likely to be a backlash from within the IOC.

Executive Board member Frankie Fredericks, who won four silver Olympic medals, said it was vitally important to retain the track in the stadium.

"This is not an easy one, especially when winning a medal in the stadium in Atlanta and the stadium being ripped up," said Namibian Fredericks, who twice won silver in the 100m and 200m in the Barcelona 1992 and Atlanta 1996 Olympics.

"It is a baseball stadium now. I ran my fastest time there (19.68 seconds) but the track is not there anymore," he said.

Fredericks said while he understood the finances behind such a decision, he still hoped the track, a legacy promise made by London during the bid, would stay.

"For me it is a special feeling to go back to Stuttgart," he said of the stadium where he became world champion in 1993. "Feelings are coming up. Being an Olympian I would like to continue to keep the legacy and the track (in London) to stay."

rank_207.title: Olympic Stadium will become 'desolate graveyard' if West Ham win battle with Tottenham, says Harry Redknapp
rank_207.text:
Redknapp's current club are competing with West Ham , who he managed from 1994 until 2001, for the right to move into the stadium in Stratford, east London, after the 2012 Games.

While Spurs propose to transform the stadium into a football-only venue and redevelop the Crystal Palace athletics stadium, West Ham intend to retain the running track so that the stadium can be a multi-use site.

Redknapp believes the Hammers' proposal would "kill" the atmosphere at the stadium.

"Try to mix football and athletics and you end up with a great big bowl of nothing," he wrote in his column for The Sun .

"The windblown no man's land between a pitch and the stands can kill football."

He added: "We keep hearing about the Olympic legacy and the need to have a world-class athletics stadium after the 2012 Games in London. But my big fear is that if West Ham move into a stadium in Stratford with a whacking great running track around the pitch, the only legacy for them will be a nightmare.

"And what if West Ham are relegated this season and then find themselves in a 60,000-capacity stadium in a Championship match.

"Can you imagine? Half the seats would be empty and it would become a desolate graveyard for a once-great club."

The president of the International Association of Athletics Federations, Lamine Diack, has warned that Britain's sporting reputation will be "dead" if the Spurs proposal is accepted and the athletics track is removed.

The Olympic Park Legacy Company (OPLC) will today receive final submissions from Tottenham and West Ham, who would keep the athletics track, ahead of a likely decision next week.

Meanwhile, Tottenham director Sir Keith Mills has stressed their bid for the Olympics Stadium would not leave London without an athletics track, following the criticism from Diack.

However, Mills is not convinced a multi-purpose athletics and football stadium would be the right option from a financial point of view.

Speaking to BBC Radio Four's Today programme, Mills - who is also the deputy chairman of LOCOG - said: "Lamine Diack quite rightly wants to see the Olympic legacy left in London and both of the bids on the table provide an athletics legacy.

"The issue here, and the one the OPLC will be looking at in the next 10 days, is what's going to provide the best long-term legacy for London and for the country.

"And that's all about which of the two bids is going to be economically viable in the long term.

"It's a difficult decision and we looked at during the bid whether an 80,000 seater stadium would work for a Premier League football club and determined that wouldn't work.

"I could roll off a list of a dozen stadiums that have athletics tracks and that historically have had a list of football teams, but the football teams have all moved away because they don't work in multi-purpose built stadiums.

"At the end of the day this is an economic argument. Someone has to pay for the next several decades for the stadium, and if West ham have found a way to work that economically, the OPLC will look on that favourably. But I find that difficult to see."

rank_123.title: London Olympics 2012: Association of British Athletics Clubs goes toe to toe with UK Athletics over running track
rank_123.text:
The Association of British Athletics Clubs has claimed that retaining a running track at the stadium – as West Ham would do – would provide little useful legacy for the sport. It is instead backing Tottenham’s rival bid to rebuild the venue as a football-only ground and redevelop the Crystal Palace athletics stadium.

UK Athletics, however, is right behind West Ham’s bid, saying London 2012’s promise to the International Olympic Committee to maintain athletics at the stadium should be honoured.

John Bicourt, an ABAC officer who competed in the 3,000 metres steeplechase for Britain at the 1972 and 1976 Olympics, said: “Saying that there would be a proper athletics legacy merely by keeping the track at the Olympic Stadium is a myth.

"The true reason for those touting the legacy myth is to save face over the wholly unrealistic promises made in Singapore by the Olympic bid team.

“West Ham, should they win the bid, would almost certainly demand the right to remove the track after a few years on the basis that the stadium is barely used for athletics enough to justify keeping it.”

Bicourt said the ABAC viewed the Spurs bid as a “realistic alternative” in that it would see the home of British athletics at Crystal Palace rebuilt as a 25,000-seat arena with the possibility of increasing the number of seats to 40,000 if needed.

He added: “There is no point keeping a 60,000-seat stadium for athletics, and in Spurs we have a football club willing to pay for the privilege of knocking it down to build a proper football stadium and a proper athletics stadium.”

UK Athletics insisted that almost all top athletes past and present support their stance.

“As the official internationally-recognised governing body for athletics, UKA wholeheartedly supports an Olympic legacy for athletics in the Olympic Stadium as part of a vibrant multi-use facility,” a spokesman said.

“Such is the strength of feeling about this issue, some of the biggest names in the sport have spoken out in support of retaining a track. These include Usain Bolt, Paula Radcliffe, Steve Cram, Brendan Foster, Michael Johnson and Dame Kelly Holmes.

“Additionally the entire current GB team, led by captain Jessica Ennis, have given their backing to West Ham’s bid.

“This is a sport united in its desire to give future generations the opportunity to compete on an Olympic track whether it be at the English Schools Championships or a World Championships.”

The Olympic Park Legacy Company is due to make a decision between Tottenham and West Ham’s bids this month. Both have until Thursday to provide further information on their submissions.

The recommendation will then be passed to the Government and London Mayor.

Meanwhile, the men’s GB basketball team will have the opportunity to be one of six nations to trial the Olympic Park venue in August, but the women have missed out.

London 2012 Olympic Games organisers have decided that the official test event, held from August 16-21 at the official Games basketball arena will be a male competition only.

rank_188.title: London Olympics 2012: keeping athletics track would be financial disaster, Tottenham's partners AEG warns
rank_188.text:
Tim Leiweke, the president of Anschutz Entertainment Group (AEG), insisted the company was very pro-Olympic legacy but that keeping a running track inside a football stadium would be an economic disaster.

Tottenham /AEG are bidding to take over the stadium after the 2012 Games but would remove the track and rebuild it as a football-only sports venue and to stage concerts.

Their rivals bidders are West Ham , who plan to retain the track in line with promises made to the International Olympic Committee when London won the right to host the Games.

London 2012 chairman Sebastian Coe is among those calling for the track to be maintained, but Leiweke said in the experience of AEG, the world's largest owner of sports teams and entertainment venues, it would not work.

Leiweke said: "I believe in the Olympic visionaries including Seb Coe – early on we invested a million dollars in support of London and got a lot of flak in the USA as New York was also bidding.

"That said, you should be trying to create a lasting legacy for sport, not just encouraging athletes to participate but events that work.

"What they are trying to do is force a legacy for track and field into a venue that won't work for football if it has a track. And guess what – it won't work for track and field either.

"People may not like to hear that but you cannot build a 60,000-seat stadium anywhere in the world that works for both. It would be broke in 10 years."

Leiweke said AEG had experience in turning around white elephants, such as the O2 Arena which had previously been losing money as the Millennium Dome, and knew what it took to make it viable.

"We told everyone up front our greatest concern was the track and controversial as that is, if you want to make it perfect I believe Tottenham has done this the right way," he added.

Tottenham's plan for an athletics legacy is to redevelop the old athletics stadium at Crystal Palace into a 25,000-seat venue, and Leiweke said the key to ensuring that did not lose money was to make sure the scale of the project was right.

"It would not work as a £400-500 million investment – the key is not to overbuild it, and about the community using it every day."

rank_186.title: London Olympics 2012: OPLC's stadium decision rests with 14 board members
rank_186.text:
The 14-strong board, which includes a former Arsenal executive, are led by chief executive Andrew Altman and OPLC's chair Baroness Ford.

Sir Robin Wales and Tessa Sanderson, two members who sit on the board, will not take part when OPLC reconvene. Both excluded themselves from voting as Wales is a West Ham season ticket holder while Sanderson has links with Newham Council.

Baroness Margaret Ford Former bank executive and current chair of OPLC board. Joined legacy company from the Royal Bank of Canada. Said in one of her first interviews: "It is cast in stone that we leave a Grand Prix athletics stadium. But what I have opened the book around is the other kind of value we can add to this stadium"

Andrew Altman Philadelphia's former first Deputy Mayor for economic development and highly regarded urban planner. Took up £195k-a-year role as chief executive of the Olympic legacy company in 2009.

Nick Bitel A leading events expert, Bitel is current chief executive of London Marathon. Also partner in sports law firm Max Bitel Greene LLP and recently appointed to Sport England board.

The east Londoner is corporate director of development and renewal at borough of Tower Hamlets. Leads on Tower Hamlets’ Olympic activities.

A qualified chartered accountant, Dutton is executive director of Finance and Corporate Services after a carer in investment banking.

Arsenal's former MD who oversaw club’s highly successful move from Highbury to the Emirates Stadium. Seen as key figure in Olympic stadium outcome.

David Edmonds

Chaired Crisis, the charity for the single homeless, as well as NHS Direct for four years. Current chairman of Legal Services Board, and Chairman of logistics company, Wincanton plc.

David Gregson

Chairman of leading UK private equity group and Precise Media Group. Previously chairman of the Mayor's Legacy Board of Advisors.

Chartered surveyor and chief executive of Kirsh Group's property division. Former chairman of Sport England.

Housing and regeneration expert who has been director of number of companies. Also advises on property development in Africa and India.

One of the UK's leading social entrepreneurs for over 25 years he has created a family of projects. Current leader in major projects including St Paul’s Way Transformational project.

Managing director of Madison Muir, strategic marketing, brand and business development advisors. Formerly head of international marketing for London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games bid.

Jules Pipe

rank_233.title: Olympic Stadium bid: West Ham and Tottenham row ... in quotes
rank_233.text:
Feb 10 West Ham vice-chairman Karren Brady revels in West Ham 's status as preferred bidder. "It is about good old East End values and, for us now, the pie's the limit," she writes in The Sun .

Feb 9 West Ham co-owner David Sullivan says that demolishing the stadium and "knocking up a plain football ground in its place is about as cold and clinical as it gets."

Meanwhile Tottenham Hotspur 's partners AEG claim that the Olympic Stadium would "go broke in 10 years" if an athletics track were retained in a venue used primarily for football. "People may not like to hear that but you cannot build a 60,000-seat stadium anywhere in the world that works for both. It would be broke in 10 years." says Tim Leiweke , AEG president.

Feb 7 Tottenham publish first images of proposed new ground, accompanied by another round in ongoing row. Brady says: “It’s a corporate crime to spend £500 million on a stadium and, just four weeks after the Games have finished, bring the bulldozers in.” Tottenham Chairman Daniel Levy counters: “A lot of emotive phrasing has been used regarding the dismantling of the stadium and it is scaremongering and irresponsible."

Feb 3 Levy warns politicians to stay out of the debate over who occupies the Olympic Stadium or face legal action: "The process has been fine but I only hope that the decision will be based on sound financial criteria and not by political forces."

Jan 31

Association of British Athletics Clubs claims that retaining a running track at the stadium – as West Ham would do – would provide little useful legacy for the sport. “West Ham, should they win the bid, would almost certainly demand the right to remove the track after a few years on the basis that the stadium is barely used for athletics enough to justify keeping it," says John Bicourt, an ABAC officer.

Jan 23

Seb Coe, London 2012 chairman, backs West Ham’s bid for the arena. "It's serious we deliver what we said we were going to unless we're prepared to trash our reputation."

Jan 20

“We made a promise about the athletics legacy London would offer when we bid for the 2012 Games, and we did not make it simply to see it broken a few years later," says Tessa Jowell, the former Olympics minister.

Jan 19

Charles van Commenee, the head coach of UK Athletics, wades in to the debate. “If London doesn’t have a stadium where we can organise major championships in athletics, that puts it in a category in Europe that I can’t even think of,” he said. "Even Vilnius or Tallinn can do that."

Jan 13

“If a solution could be found for the track we would be happy, but don’t expect the IOC to intervene in an issue where we are not responsible.” Jacques Rogge, the IOC president, keeps his distance.

Meanwhile Ed Warner, the chairman of UK Athletics, brands Spurs' proposals to fund the redevelopment of the Crystal Palace athletics stadium as "insulting". He adds: “I think what they’ve come up with looks incredibly thin,” he said. “They’ve come up with the bare minimum that they hope will pass muster with the legacy company when the decision is made

Dec 14

Former stars of the track – from Dame Kelly Holmes to Daley Thompson – sign open letter lobbying against bulldozing stadium. "As Olympians we are all ardent sports fans and that is why we believe the Olympic legacy HAS to be The Olympic Stadium complete with track," the letter states.

Nov 24

'We don't want to go anywhere else, it's all about staying in Tottenham. Spurs is really embedded in the community," Tim Framp, a Spurs fan for 20 years, gathers more than 2,100 signatories, in a "Say No to Stratford Hotspur" petition.

Nov 23

Sir Keith Mills, the deputy chairman of London 2012 and Tottenham director: West Ham's proposals are to leave the running track in place and if it stacks up economically I am sure the OPLC will award it to them. We promised in our bid to leave an athletics legacy.

Nov 17

“It is ridiculous to say that just because we are bottom of the league our bid is less strong than Tottenham’s," says Brady, keeping to the script. "This is not an arrogant football club coming along to write a cheque, this is about a proper legacy and that is what we are going to deliver.”

Nov 11

"There is a myth that we can't fill it and we can't afford it," offers Brady.

Oct 11

UK Athletics' Warner says: "What has impressed me so much about the joint bid from West Ham and Newham is their clear commitment to the spirit of the Olympic legacy

Oct 7

"No change''. Baroness Ford, chair of Olympic legacy board, hints that Olympic Stadium will retain running track following London 2012's key pledge to the IOC that athletics will benefit from hosting the Games.

Not knowing it would soon be for the wrong reasons, Ford adds: ''It is great news that there is so much interest in the stadium."

rank_219.title: London 2012 Olympics: Stadium not 'white elephant' says Hugh Robertson as West Ham confirm new bid
rank_219.text:
Legal challenges by Tottenham and Leyton Orient, plus an anonymous complaint to the European Commission, have led to fears that court action could drag on for years while the stadium remains empty.

The stadium will now remain in public ownership and will be leased out to an anchor tenant following a new tender process by the Olympic Park Legacy Company (OPLC).

West Ham vice-chairman Karren Brady has confirmed the club will bid again to become tenants at the stadium.

Robertson said: "The key point is the action we have taken today is about removing the uncertainty. The process had become bogged down in legal paralysis.

"Particularly relevant has been the anonymous complaint to the EC over 'state aid' and the OPLC received a letter from Newham Council yesterday saying because of the uncertainty they no longer wanted to proceed. That was the straw that broke the camel's back and we thought it better to stop it dead in it tracks now.

"We know there is huge interest in the stadium out there from private operators and football clubs and crucially we remove any uncertainty."

Some £35million already earmarked under the Olympic Budget will be used to transform the stadium after the Games. Prospective tenants will then be asked to bid for the stadium with the running track remaining in place.

Robertson added: "This is not a white elephant stadium where no one wants it, we have had two big clubs fighting tooth and nail to get it.

"The new process will be more like how Manchester City took over the Commonwealth Games stadium which is regarded as a leading example of how to do it."

London mayor Boris Johnson insisted the stadium would not become a burden to the taxpayer.

He said: "I am confident that this decision is the best way to ensure we have certainty over the stadium's future.

"I believe it will also put us in the place where we always intended to be - delivering a lasting sustainable legacy for the stadium backed up by a robust but flexible business plan that provides a very good return to the taxpayer."

The tenants would pay an annual rent to the OPLC, which should actually prove to be less costly for the likes of West Ham.

The move will also remove uncertainty over the stadium ahead of London's bid for the 2017 World Athletics Championships, although that was not a major consideration in the decision to abandon the current deal.

A joint statement by Brady and Kim Bromley-Derry, Newham chief executive, said they welcomed the move.

The statement said: "Uncertainty caused by the anonymous complaint to the European Commission and ongoing legal challenges have put the Olympic legacy at risk and certainly a stadium, as we envisioned it, may not be in place by 2014 due as a direct result of the legal delay.

"Therefore we would welcome a move by OPLC and Government to end that uncertainty and allow a football and athletics stadium to be in place by 2014 under a new process. If the speculation is true, West Ham will look to become a tenant of the stadium while Newham will aim to help deliver the legacy."

UK Athletics chairman Ed Warner also welcomed the move.

"It's fantastic for UK Athletics and it is a bold and decisive move by the legacy company," he said.

Warner also predicted that the decision would help London's bid for the 2017 World Athletics Championships.

"We had a meeting with the IAAF inspectors last week and we gave Government guarantees that the athletics track will stay in place. The move you see today is simply confirmation of what we told the IAAF.

"The IAAF were concerned when they arrived but when they left they told us that the issue was completely resolved. We laid out the legal options and they went away happy.

"I'm very hopeful that we will get the nod for 2017."

rank_106.title: London 2012 Olympics: Snowdome proposed as legacy for Games' broadcast and media centre
rank_106.text:
Acer Snowmec managing director Malcolm Clulow said the £40 million snow-in-the-city plan for the Olympics broadcast and media centre is for a large area incorporating five artificial indoor ski slopes.

One ski run would have a pitch of 35 degrees with sharp turns to test more capable skiers, while others would include a snow park with super pipe, rails, kickers and tricks for skiers and boarders, a cross-country course and boarder and skier-cross courses.

Clulow said the proposed 28,500 sq metre snow sports and leisure complex included other retail outlets and a hotel and he envisaged at least a million visitors a year.

“This will be a very special place,” said Clulow, who also built the Middle East indoor ski venue Ski Dubai. “We are in it for the long haul, we are looking at operating this centre for at least 20 years.”

Former British Olympic skier Konrad Bartelski is advising on the use and layout of the proposed ski area.

“Bringing the mountains to east London would create an Olympic legacy more exciting than anyone could imagine,” Bartelski said.

The Olympic Park Legacy Company is seeking expressions of interest for the broadcast and media centre, which will be the workplace for 20,000 journalists during the Games, and the bidders will go into a second phase of consideration at the end of the month.

Initial plans to create a site for media companies to relocate to post-Games has stalled from lack of interest and the distance of the site from Stratford station. Other bidders have shown an interest in the site, but their identities have yet to be revealed.

A snowdome would be a more attractive facility than the use found for the Sydney Olympics media centre: pig, sheep and cattle pens at the Sydney Royal Easter Show.

rank_195.title: London 2012 Olympics: Trafalgar Square countdown clock stalling after launch blurs line of reality and parody
rank_195.text:
This would be the same clock whose very concept had been lampooned not 24 hours earlier in the BBC Four mockumentary, Twenty Twelve , where the supreme vacuity of the official timepiece is captured in the fact that it counts not towards the official ceremony, but backwards to the present day.

It is, according to Hugh Bonneville, who plays the head of the portentously-named Olympics Deliverance Commission, a “powerful and at the same time playful comment on time itself”.

If only Omega, who designed the defunct version now standing in Trafalgar Square, could be as good at engineering that type of PR line as they normally are at making watches.

Naturally, there must be some areas where reality and parody diverge. Our own sadly stalled clock marks 500 days to go, while the fictionalised one launches on what is billed as the “1,000 day-day day”.

Sebastian Coe and Boris Johnson also both succeed in turning up for Tuesday’s sparkly unveiling.

In Twenty Twelve, Coe, the chairman of the Games organising committee, is stuck in the Rotherhithe tunnel as the Mayor of London remains under police protection, having been threatened by cabbies disgruntled at the Games’ traffic-phasing system.

Although derivative in style and characterisation from The Office — Vincent Franklin, aka Nick Jowett, the bluff ‘head of contracts’, even played in both series — the programme is not exactly caustic satire.

It has the gentle contours of an in-house comedy service for the suits in Canary Wharf, reflected in such knowing lines as, “Give Boris the scissors to play with, that should keep him happy”.

Coe, indeed, is so sanguine about the script that he has agreed to play himself in next Monday night’s instalment.

But if this is The Thick of It-lite, as forgiving to the world of sports politics as Malcolm Tucker’s creation was savage to Westminster, it is still a triumphant send-up of the PR horrors to which the clock stands as an enduring monument.

Siobhan Sharpe, superbly played by Jessica Hynes, radiates an enthusiasm as ‘head of brand’ surpassed only by her vapid Apprentice-speak. “Guys, this is a slam dunk,” she says of her beloved dial. “Break open the Google juice”.

As for the live webcam of said clock, she can merely blather: “It’s kind of, like, a dynamic thing.”

Coe was rather more eloquent this week when he declared: “The launch of the Omega countdown clock is an important milestone for any Olympic Games”.

By such grandiloquence does he disguise the essential truth that it is just, well, a clock. Anthony Preston, the graceless Liam Gallagher-esque artist whom Sharpe commissions to design hers, admits as much: “I want it to be simple. I don’t want any --------”.

And yet, the impulse of the Olympic movement is always to divine deeper subliminal currents. Why, Coe was at it again over the 2012 logo, heralding it as a “vision at the very heart of our brand” — quite a claim for anyone to make of a jagged pink squiggle.

It is not the essence of the Olympics that grates so much as the absurdity of its packaging. One cannot avoid the suspicion that Coe and his cohorts regard the ‘500 days’ watershed in the same way Sharpe sees 1,000: namely, not solely as a number, but as a “total game-changer”.

Is the notion of time going backwards from 2012 really so fanciful, either? Has it escaped wider notice that the inert London clock has 500 days, seven hours, six minutes and 56 seconds still to elapse? Suddenly, retrograde is all the rage.

Watching Twenty Twelve, we are supposed to be transported to a crazed parallel universe where no one can tell the difference between Duffy, middle-of-the-road chanteuse, and Carol Ann Duffy, Poet Laureate.

In these alternative Olympics, Gok Wan is identified as a national hero, and Peter Andre appointed chief torchbearer.

But then no indulgence appears too extreme for the Games’ real-life organisers, whose perceptions of Britishness — if the performance in Beijing is any gauge — involves Leona Lewis and Jimmy Page in duet atop a Routemaster bus.

The show is equally piercing on that vexed subject of Olympic legacy. One beautiful scene forces Kay Hope, the hapless ‘head of sustainability’, to explain to a youth group leader in Stoke Newington that London’s hockey arena is being redeveloped into “Urban Duck World”.

Likewise, the taekwondo venue is being touted, post-2012, as a national indoor donkey sanctuary.

It is a novel thought: maybe, given all that unseemly human squabbling between Tottenham and West Ham over rights to the Olympic Stadium, we should just hand everything over to the animals.

rank_229.title: Budget's Enterprise Zone is vital to an Olympic legacy of prosperity
rank_229.text:
SIR – We welcome the announcement in the Budget of new Enterprise Zones. The new zone in London will be in the Royal Docks. It is crucial that the 2012 London Olympic and Paralympic Games bring sustainable employment to East London as part of a lasting legacy. Newham alone has an employment rate of 60 per cent of the working age population – 10 percentage points below the national average. But East London has the potential to contribute an additional £13 billion to GDP.

We must ensure that we get the incentives right for each area, to maximise investment potential. Last year, the Prime Minister announced his plan for a tech city, stretching from Old Street to the Olympic Park. We look forward to working with the Government to maximise the opportunities for technology to drive our economy.

Kevin Murphy

Chief Executive, ExCeL London

Richard Gooding

Chairman, London City Airport

Hamid Kefayati

Managing Director, Buhler Sortex Limited

SIR – I wish the Chancellor had increased the tax on everything I don't buy and increased income tax for everyone who earns more than I do.

Rodney Howlett

Darley Dale, Derbyshire

SIR – How refreshing to have a Budget largely free of hubris and sleight-of-hand.

Martin Moyes

Holt, Wiltshire

SIR – With so many announcements made in advance of the Budget, what was the point of the speech?

In 1947, when Hugh Dalton, then chancellor, revealed tax details in an off-the-cuff remark to a journalist ahead of delivering his autumn Budget, he resigned.

Michael J. Hawes

Newark-on-Trent, Nottinghamshire

SIR – Ed Miliband and Ed Balls tell us that the increase in VAT is going to cost the average family an extra £400 per year. For the 2.5 per cent increase to cost me £400, I would have to spend £16,000 on VAT-able items in a year, which seems unlikely.

C. H. Thorp

Bridgend, Glamorgan

SIR – Hearing the Leader of the Opposition refer to "one pence" yesterday afternoon, brought to the forefront the question of what we call our coinage. Would everybody start referring to pence rather than "pee", which is best left in the lavatory?

Robert Pugh

Carmarthen

SIR – I would like to thank the Chancellor for giving a helping hand to smokers in these difficult times. With the high tax on cigarettes in Britain, I easily covered the cost of two holidays a year by buying my cigarettes in another EU country. With the Budget's additional increase in tax, I can add a weekend city break at no extra cost.

Peter Iden

Totnes, Devon

Finish the job in Libya

SIR – Machiavelli got it right. He advised that if you are going to antagonise a tyrant, you have no choice but to finish the job. If you leave the tyrant only partly damaged, he will come back with a terrible revenge.

Colonel Muammar Gaddafi will never forgive this country for what we have done. We have no choice, therefore, but to finish what we started. The only way will be covertly to train and equip the insurrection to sweep back out of the east and take the coast up to and through Tripoli. The rebels had almost achieved that a month ago.

Chances of success? Let us recall that when the insurrection was advancing, Gaddafi’s so-called loyalists were defecting, tribe by tribe and unit by unit. They say along that coast that you cannot buy the loyalty of a Libyan, but you can usually rent it.

And we used to do “covert” rather well.

Frederick Forsyth

Beaconsfield, Buckinghamshire

SIR – People should not condemn the American pilot who strafed the Libyans approaching the downed airman (report, March 23). Any wingman worth his salt would put down covering fire to safeguard his colleague. It would have been impossible to know whether the parachute descent was into friendly or unfriendly hands.

Huw Baumgartner

Bridell, Pembrokeshire

SIR – Gaddafi seized power when King Idris was holidaying in Turkey. Forty-one years later, Turkey, a secular state with a Muslim majority, has experienced military rule and is in a unique position to negotiate a settlement of the Libyan “war”. An offer of asylum to Gaddafi from Turkey may save more Libyan lives than continuing to unleash our military hardware. Turkey, moreover, has an army capable of providing the boots on the ground.

John E. Tricks

Crediton, Devon

First duty is to patients

SIR – As a GP, giving patients the best care possible is the main motive for me to support the health reforms, not financial rewards (“Sacrificing the NHS on the altar of ideology”, Features, March 21).

Under the new plans, I will have the freedom to decide the best course of action for my patients. This is why more than 5,000 GP practices have signed up to test the plans.

Dr Ken Aswani

London E4

Tricks at the till

Sir – Short-changing, which was common in the 1950s, appears to be back. One trick then was for a shopkeeper to leave a tin of evaporated milk sitting on the counter. Every likely mug was charged for it and, if challenged, the till operator would apologise for the “mistake”, saying the item must have been left there by a previous customer.

Today, I find the till display is frequently obscured, so that you only realise you have been short-changed when you examine your receipt. When you complain, you are often asked if you mind them serving the next customer, so that they can correct it without opening the till. This avoids it being noticed on the till records.

Brian Gilbert

Hampton, Middlesex

Mysterious hole in one

SIR – Why is it that on whichever foot one puts a sock with a toe hole, the hole is always where the big toe is?

Richard J.G. Waldron

Woolavington, Somerset

BBC looks North

SIR – The BBC has moved on since Trevor Taylor worked on the Today programme in the 1970s (Letters, March 21).

David Cameron was interviewed on BBC Radio Manchester after the leadership debate, and it was from a Manchester studio that Gordon Brown apologised after his comments about Gillian Duffy.

Ed Miliband and Andy Burnham appeared on Stephen Nolan’s show on Radio 5 Live and Ben Bradshaw and Kate Hoey joined Stephen for a live broadcast from Salford.

Numerous politicians and opinion formers from the North enrich the national debate from our Manchester offices. Bear in mind also that most senior politicians are interviewed “down the line” from Millbank and rarely travel to west London.

The BBC is moving 2,300 posts to MediaCityUK in Salford, moving departments and output to a new base in the North of England to reflect our audience better, to spread the licence fee more equitably and to be part of the future of the region; this is more ambitious than creating a branch office outside the M25.

Peter Salmon

Director, BBC North

Salford

Classified information

SIR – A friend was once chatted up on the dance floor (“Only members of the middle classes pretend that they’re not”, March 22). She was asked what social class she belonged to. The man had no hope with a chat-up line like that, but her answer was perfect: “I’m in a class of my own.”

Vivienne Howse

London N12

SIR – My great-grandfather was a pit blacksmith/farrier who could barely sign his name and only read the Bible. I worked for the Great Western Railway for 37 years. People who think themselves middle class are deluding themselves; if you sell your labour to feed your family, no matter whether you’re a barrister or a bootboy, you are a worker and therefore working class.

Michael Roberts

Evesham, Worcestershire

Tearing off a sheet

SIR – My rowing coach said the catch at the start of a stroke should be like tearing a sheet of paper from a loo roll (Letters, March 22): too aggressive and it rips, not sufficiently sharp and it unrolls. I suspect he envisaged the loose end at the front.

George Atkinson-Clark

Lidlington, Bedfordshire

Statisticians need to get their numbers straight

SIR – In another example of incompetence within government, the Office for National Statistics is displaying posters in bus shelters and elsewhere which bear the legend: “Complete your census online or drop it in the post today to avoid a fine.”

Yet the census questionnaire exhorts us to complete it “on March 27, 2011, or as soon as possible afterwards”.

If the Office for National Statistics can’t get its dates right, what hope have we got for an accurate census?

Christopher Martin

Winchester, Hampshire

SIR – When I worked on the 1991 census, in response to the question “how do you fill your working day?”, a cleaning lady wrote: “I fill my day hovering and moping.”

Diana Stevenson

Saltburn-by-the-Sea, North Yorkshire

rank_146.title: Olympics: 1,500 tickets reserved for 'business guests'
rank_146.text:
The allocation is expected to draw criticism among the one million members of the public who missed out in the ballots for tickets.

The Daily Telegraph revealed in February that the government had ordered 9,000 Olympic events tickets, with a total value of £750,000, at the taxpayers’ expense.

About 1,500 of these have been reserved for international business guests to showcase UK plc, in a bid to attract investment, it emerged last night.

A further 1,600 tickets are allocated for entertaining other international and domestic guests, such as foreign dignitaries, it was reported.

The School Games competition, intended to form part of the Olympic legacy, has an allocation of 450 tickets to be used as prizes for the children taking part.

The remaining 3,000 government-reserved tickets will be available to purchase exclusively for staff who have helped to deliver the Olympics, it was reported.

A Department for Culture Media and Sport spokesperson said in February that the Olympics provided a "once in a life time opportunity for the UK to showcase itself to a massive international audience".

He said: "Tickets will be used to invite and accompany a number of international influencers, and business leaders to the benefit of the UK, as well as dignitaries and others with a close connection to the games and its legacy.

“Some of these tickets will be available for people to purchase who have worked on the games for a substantial period of time. However, these are not freebies for civil servants at the taxpayers’ expense. Civil servants gaining tickets will have to pay for them."

They were unable to say what types of tickets had been applied for or whether they intended to buy any hospitality tickets, which cost up to £5,400.

rank_225.title: London 2012 Olympics: Games excitement starts to reach fever pitch but concerns about the future remain
rank_225.text:
If Lord Coe were ever to doubt his vision of London 2012 - the one he sold to the IOC in Singapore, the one which suggested a British-held games could inspire a generation of young people to get active - then a visit to Bacon’s College would reassure him.

Situated just over the River Thames from Canary Wharf, this London secondary school has embraced the idea of the games with gusto. From the 2012 logo by the front gate, past the photos of Olympians in the corridors, to the pupil-penned Olympic-themed limericks framed on the walls, nobody could accuse this establishment of missing the significance of what will be happening down the road next July and August.

“Why on earth would we wish to ignore it?” says Sue Ponulak, the school’s director of sport. “This is going to be the biggest thing in our lifetime, let’s celebrate it, let’s use it, let's embrace it. And let’s hope we can follow through with it.”

Sitting with four of the school’s pupils last week, the excitement was already palpable. The talk was of Usain Bolt being in this very neighbourhood next summer, of youthful competitors attempting to emulate his style at the school sports day, of, across the school, a rush to run, jump and throw. And this despite the fact that nobody knows anyone who managed to secure tickets.

“I applied for the badminton, but didn’t get any,” says 13 year-old Tom Long, who plays badminton in the gym every evening after school. “I met Gail Emms last year at a tournament. It seems ridiculous, but when you meet her, given what she’s achieved, it’s kind of amazing to discover she is an ordinary person. It inspires you to think you might do what she’s done, too.”

At Bacon’s, the alma mater of David Haye, sport is central to the curriculum. In addition to four periods of timetabled physical education, Feyi Shonde, for instance, takes part in after-school clubs every night of the week in term time, where she is coached in football, netball and athletics.

On the school’s freshly-installed floodlit artificial pitch, Sergei Baltacha, the father of tennis player Elena and a former Soviet international, runs a football academy in partnership with Fulham FC. Last week, 40 of the school’s pupils were on a basketball camp in Croatia.

The importance of sport - physically, emotionally, educationally - is understood here. And with the Games just a year away, even those disinclined to engage in anything physical have been getting the Olympic bug.

“It would be an exaggeration to say we’ll get everyone off the sofa,” says Ms Ponulak. “But we’ve got a programme here for 15, 16-year-old girls to train after school, using dance, that’s really getting people involved who wouldn’t otherwise.

"I’m not denying there’s a bribe involved with a nice new T-shirt for everyone who turns up. But you use anything you can. And the Olympics are the best encouragement we’ve got.”

The question facing teachers like Ms Ponulak, however, is what happens afterwards, in 2013 and beyond. In the build-up to next summer’s unforgettable fortnight, there is no doubt excitement will generate a surge of activity. Sustaining that is the challenge.

“It could be the greatest thing to happen to us. I say could be, But only if we back it up properly,” says Ms Ponulak. "I know you can’t predict, but I fear for the money post-2012.

"It would be hard politically to cut programmes in the run up to the games, easy afterwards. And at the moment the funding for the bottom of the pyramid is held together with sticky tape.”

Ms Ponulak points to the ending of the School Sport Partnerships as characteristic of the lack of commitment to sustained investment.

“It was a world-class initiative in identifying talent,” she says. “The Australians studied it and decided to start their own version. Just as we get rid of ours.”

At Bacon’s, too, the school tried to build a basketball centre to be used as a training facility during the Games. They failed due to a lack of funds.

“That would have been legacy,” says Ms Ponulak. “That kind of link-up. But it didn’t happen. The other issue we have is that in order to pay for our facilities here, we have to run them as a profit-generating sports centre, which inevitably restricts access.”

That, according to Michael de Giorgio, of the Greenhouse charity which runs sporting programmes in dozens of London schools including Bacon’s, is a central concern.

“The facilities are there,” he says. “The problem is access and, once you’ve gained access, ensuring there is sufficient coaching to meet the demand. The whole point of legacy is it can only happen afterwards.

"There will be a huge surge of interest from young people around the Games, it’s going to be great. We have to make sure that interest is nurtured and sustained by good, accessible coaching.”

This has not always been the British way. Interest generated by the golden deeds of Daley Thompson, Torvill and Dean and Coe himself was not translated into a growth in participation.

Even as recently as 2000, when Great Britain enjoyed a surge of unexpected gold medals in Sydney, several sports governing bodies were taken aback by the sudden gift of recruitment publicity. While some - rowing and cycling the exemplars - embraced the opportunity, in too many sports nothing was put in place to sustain the momentum.

With freedom of information legislation not extending to sports governing bodies, it is impossible to discover yet exactly what they have in mind to exploit London 2012. At Bacon’s, everyone is confident the excitement will deliver an eager generation. But it is in what happens afterwards, in the extent of coaching support, that the Olympic legacy will ultimately be judged.

“We have such high hopes here,” says Ms Ponulak. “We can’t let it happen and then just let it fade away.”

rank_235.title: London 2012 Olympics: Chance to ensure a victory roll for British enterprise
rank_235.text:
However, a common frustration among manufacturers is that their success is not fully recognised in the UK, where the historic image of "dark satanic mills" still exists, and in key export markets abroad, where the UK's manufacturing base is seen as eroded and riddled with industrial disputes.

However, the 2012 Olympics provides an opportunity to change those images.

With the eyes of the world on London and the UK, the Government estimates that 250 FTSE chief executives, 150 head of states, and 9m visitors will be in the country for the Olympics. This is on top of the billions watching on television.

The Games, therefore, should be an advertisement for the businesses delivering the Games – such as the builder of the Olympic Stadium Sir Robert McAlpine - and an opportunity for all businesses to network with industrial and political leaders.

However, some businesses are privately expressing concerns about the lack of firm plans from the Government to promote British business during the Olympics.

If it is not careful, British industry will be overshadowed by other nations who are already planning a takeover of London venues to advertise their commercial strengths.

Russia will host a winter wonderland in Marble Arch, Brazil has booked Somerset House, and France has Old Billingsgate market in the City.

Vince Cable's Department for Business, Innovation and Skills says it is "looking at holding a major exhibition" to run alongside the Games that will promote the "best of British manufacturing".

Sources say the venue will be announced later this year, but no details have yet been publicly confirmed.

A BIS spokesperson said the Government recognised the Olympics and Paralympics as a "fantastic opportunity to showcase everything that's great about the UK".

They added: "We want to show that British businesses are winning "gold medals" for growth, jobs and prosperity. When the world comes to visit for the 2012 Games, we want to demonstrate Britain's excellence in advanced manufacturing through an expo that goes beyond demonstrating British manufacturing strengths but surprises and confounds expectations."

Sources say UK Trade & Investment will also be making a "series of announcements" in the next few months on how it will deliver a business legacy from the Olympics.

It has formed an "Olympic Legacy Unit" and created Host2Host, which aims to help companies who won work on London 2012 to secure contracts on future sporting events, such as the 2016 Olympics in Brazil. This has involved attending overseas conferences with the Olympic Delivery Authority (ODA) and Olympic contractors to share how London 2012 has been constructed.

The official promotion agency for London, London & Partners, says it is planning to resurrect its "London House" initiative from the Beijing Olympics in 2008. This will see the creation of a physical hub which will host events celebrating London and its businesses.

Janet Coyle, associate director, 2012 Games for London & Partners, says: "The 'London House' for 2012 will actively showcase London's fantastic array of artistic, cultural and business assets and will highlight why London is considered as one of the world's most successful business capitals."

London & Partners says it will confirm the venue and details of "London House" later this year, but is pressing ahead with other initiatives in the meantime.

"London & Partners is creating a full programme of events and activities for potential business investors during the 2012 Games," says Coyle.

"This builds on the 2012 campaigns already delivered in key international markets which has so far resulted in over 5,500 jobs created in London by inward investors. The range of events will include business showcases, seminars, receptions and round table debates where potential investors will be able to learn more about London's key strengths as well as network with London businesses."

Traditional industry tradeshows in 2012 will also offer an opportunity to promote the UK and are being modified to make the most of the Olympics.

In aerospace, the Farnborough International Airshow, one of Britain's biggest tradeshows, has moved forward a week to July 9 in order to avoid clashing with the Games.

Organisers believe the show can benefit from an increase in overseas visitors to the UK and plan to take advantage of the country's focus on the Olympics by inviting former athletes to the show.

However, as the private sector firms up its own plans, it would also like to see the ideas of the public sector quickly turn into reality.

This would not only help businesses to prepare for the Olympics, but provide reassurances that the promotion of Britain will not be overshadowed by the lavish marketing of other nations. As well as Russia, Brazil and France, America and other leading economies have plans in place for London 2012.

"It is a big opportunity that does not last that long – probably for this year and the year after the Games," John Armitt, chairman of the ODA, says. "After that, the world moves on and people are looking at other things. You've got to maximise the sales pitch and the opportunity in that two year window."

A recent survey of London businesses by the London Chamber of Commerce and Industry found 69pc believe the Olympics can have a positive impact on the capital's reputation as an international business centre.

However, it also warned that more must be done to ensure that companies are ready for the Games, while Armitt has cautioned that problems with Britain's infrastructure during the Olympics, especially transport, could overshadow the prompt construction of eye-catching sporting venues.

Britain, therefore, has plenty of work to do before it can declare the Olympics a success.

rank_69.title: London 2012 Olympics: OPLC is back to square one with a problem all of its own making
rank_69.text:
Ford started a new tender race to try to find the answer on Tuesday after the process that she began 18 months ago collapsed late on Monday amid legal uncertainty.

With just 10 months to go before the Games begin, the credibility of London’s legacy rests on her finding a solution, but the precedent is not encouraging.

The new process marks the third time since 2005 that the Olympic stakeholders have tried to find a solution to a problem entirely of their own making. Both previous attempts have foundered for different specific reasons, but the failings stem from the same issue.

From the outset the Olympic and political leaders who so brilliantly delivered the 2012 bid failed to accept that post-Games athletics cannot be at the heart of the stadium without someone else, either public subsidy or Premier League football, to pay for it. They have also under-estimated the opposition, be it Tottenham or Leyton Orient.

London made a promise to the Olympic family that it would retain an athletics track, and it was a crucial factor in delivering the votes as International Association of Athletics Federations president Lamine Diack rallied his supporters behind Lord Coe’s vision. London is after Diack’s support again, in the bid for the 2017 World Championships, a factor in the timing of yesterday’s announcement.

The Government is desperate to win the competition but, even if London is successful on Nov 11, the welcome benefits for track and field will come at someone else’s expense.

The Olympic Delivery Authority was the first to wrestle with the problem in Sept 2006, after exploratory discussions with Tottenham and West Ham had ended without a deal when the clubs insisted that a permanent track was not viable.

With Coe, Tessa Jowell and Ken Livingstone all refusing to countenance a deal with a Premier League football club or taxpayer support, the ODA canvassed for a solution that would support the 25,000-seat stadium envisaged in the Olympic legacy.

Consultants PMP Legacy spent 18 months attempting to construct a financial case for a mixed-use stadium combining rugby, athletics, concerts and lower-league football. Premier League clubs were expressly barred from the consultation.

PMP’s findings, delivered in early 2008, were inconclusive and damning. They warned that Premier League football was incompatible with a track, and that potential tenants had serious misgivings and that none had been willing to commit to the arena. They concluded that proceeding with the 25,000-seat option was high risk.

That message was finally acted on by Boris Johnson in late 2008, when he accepted that Premier League football was the only way to make the stadium viable. The London Mayor then hired Ford in April 2008 to move the goal-posts, and encouraged Spurs chairman Daniel Levy to bid.

To get Tottenham into the process, the OPLC had to fudge the issue of whether there had to be a track in the stadium. With Spurs genuinely believing it was negotiable, they proposed tearing down the Olympic Stadium and building a new football-only arena on the spot.

With their financial case stronger than West Ham’s it was again the Olympic and athletic lobby that won the day, arguing that Britain had a “moral obligation” to retain the running track.

The OPLC chose West Ham but the legal basis of their bid, reliant as it was on £40 million of public funding from Newham Council, was challenged by Spurs and Leyton Orient and ultimately proved central to the collapse of their bid.

The Government said yesterday that “legal paralysis” was the reason for the change of tack but there was also the growing prospect of defeat.

Leyton Orient were due to file new expert evidence in the High Court this week that went to the heart of the State Aid issue. A former vice-president of Bank of America was ready to testify that no investor would make a loan on similar terms to Newham.

An anonymous complaint to the European Commission further complicated matters. Both Tottenham and Orient deny that they are the source but it raised the prospect of further delays.

Alongside the legal problems, the process was also damaged by the unintended consequence of the Government’s guarantee to keep track until at least 2017, a commitment made to the IAAF last week.

With their single bidder no longer able to guarantee they could open the stadium on time in 2014, facing a strengthening legal challenge and the clock ticking on a High Court date next week, Ford and sports minister Hugh Robertson pulled the plug on the deal late on Monday.

They hope that by offering West Ham a cheaper deal, they can finally square the circle. But it felt more like they were back to square one.

rank_214.title: London 2012 Olympics: West Ham bid again as Olympic stadium deal collapses
rank_214.text:
• West Ham and Newham deal collapses after complaint to EU • West Ham and Leyton Orient confirm they will bid to be new tenants • Boris Johnson says public ownership to "provide good return" • Johnson also backs West ham to win tenancy • Sports minister: process had been "bogged down in legal paralysis" • Tottenham welcome OPLC decision • UK Athletics welcome the move as "bold and decisive"

Mayor of London Boris Johnson said that West Ham were still likely to take over the stadium, which will now remain in public ownership.

Johnson said: "We will keep it in public hands but we will effectively rent it to a football club, almost certainly West Ham, and that will cover the costs."

The fresh bids for tenancy will need to be made after the Olympic Park Legacy Company board decided last night to abandon negotiations with West Ham and Newham over the initial process.

They agreed to launch a new tender process because of fears that ongoing legal challenges could delay conversion of the stadium after next summer’s Olympics.

It is understood that an anonymous complaint to the European Commission had raised the prospect of an indefinite delay to negotiations.

Johnson denied that the venue would be a burden to public finances, even if initially funded by the the public.

"I am confident that this decision is the best way to ensure we have certainty over the stadium's future.

"I believe it will also put us in the place where we always intended to be - delivering a lasting sustainable legacy for the stadium backed up by a robust but flexible business plan that provides a very good return to the taxpayer."

The OPLC will now try to find a range of tenants willing to pay rent on the stadium, which will be reduced to 60,000 seats at a cost of £50m drawn from OPLC funds.

Interested parties will have until January to submit their bids and the OPLC will then try and put together a package of tenants that makes the stadium viable.

The move is still a major blow to London’s legacy planning and continues the uncertainty over the flagship arena despite repeated promises over seven years that it would not be a white elephant.

But Sports minister Hugh Robertson moved to re-assure the public that it was the right decision.

"The key point is the action we have taken today is about removing the uncertainty," he said. "The process had become bogged down in legal paralysis.

"Particularly relevant has been the anonymous complaint to the EC over 'state aid' and the OPLC received a letter from Newham Council yesterday saying because of the uncertainty they no longer wanted to proceed. That was the straw that broke the camel's back and we thought it better to stop it dead in it tracks now.

"We know there is huge interest in the stadium out there from private operators and football clubs and crucially we remove any uncertainty. This is not a white elephant stadium where no one wants it, we have had two big clubs fighting tooth and nail to get it."

The board’s decision does remove uncertainty over London’s 2017 World Athletics Championship bid, a major priority for government, but the cost to the taxpayer could be significant and there is no guarantee that the bid will defeat that of competitor Doha. Athletics has not provided any funding towards the stadium.

Football at the Olympic Stadium

West Ham confirmed they will again look to be a tenant, while Leyton Orient, who along with Tottenham Hotspur have been at the forefront of challenging the initial decision, said it was "a fabulous day for Leyton Orient fans".

West Ham deputy chairman Karren Brady said: "Uncertainty caused by the anonymous complaint to the European Commission and ongoing legal challenges have put the Olympic legacy at risk and certainly a stadium, as we envisioned it, may not be in place by 2014 as a direct result of the legal delay.

"Therefore we would welcome a move by OPLC and Government to end that uncertainty and allow a football and athletic stadium to be in place by 2014 under a new process. If the speculation is true, West Ham will look to become a tenant of the stadium while Newham will aim to help deliver the legacy."
