But Orient chairman Barry Hearn said: "It puts the whole thing back in the public domain as it should be. The system of deliverance was fundamentally flawed and now they have got to go back to the beginning and start again and we will be an interested party in that bidding process.

"West Ham are not a shoo-in, that's very good because they will be competing with a host of other people who have claims on and plans for the Olympic Stadium. It's a legacy operation and at last the OPLC have finally listened to someone with common sense and said 'we messed it up before, let's not mess it up again'. The whole process starts now.

"I can tell you that I am definitely interested in being part of the tender process."

Tottenham, who were among the previous bidders for the Olympic Stadium, have also welcomed the decision. The club issued a statement saying: "We welcome the OPLC decision to end the current Olympic Stadium bid process. We firmly believe that the bid we put forward was, in fact, a realistic sporting solution for the stadium, along with a substantial return to the taxpayer, community programming and athletics provision."

Legal challenges to West Ham’s deal with Newham had been brought by Tottenham and Orient, with a full judicial review of the case scheduled for next Tuesday.

The case has been complicated by the complaint to the European Commission, which could result in key elements of the case being staid indefinitely next week.

Both Spurs and Leyton Orient argued that the original West Ham deal, which would see Newham contribute £40m as a loan to convert the stadium, constituted illegal state aid.

While Tottenham were likely to abandon their challenge in favour of remaining in Haringey, Orient were committed to the legal proceedings and were due to file fresh evidence with the High Court this week.

They were highly confident of success and this may have been a factor in the board’s decision to abandon the process last night.

Athletics

Ed Warner, the chairman of UK Athletics, welcomed the decision and said he now believed that athletics would remain central to the stadium's legacy.

"It's fantastic for UK Athletics and it is a bold and decisive move by the legacy company," said Warner.

rank_81.title: London 2012 Olympics: UK's tallest sculpture completed on Olympic Park
rank_81.text:
The twisting red tower, situated next to the Olympic Stadium, was designed by Turner Prize-winning artist Anish Kapoor and structural designer Cecil Balmond and cost £22.7 million to create.

It will have two observation floors, a 455-step spiral staircase a lift and even a restaurant, with the objective being that visitors go up to the top in a lift before walking down the spiral staircase to take in both the views and Kapoor's artistic detail.

Those involved in the project hope that the tower, which is 22 metres taller than the Statue of Liberty, will remain a must-see attraction long after the Games have finished.

Steel magnate Lakshmi Mittal, the chairman of ArcelorMittal, invested £19.6 million, while the remaining £3.1 million is coming from the Greater London Authority.

“We conceived this project in partnership to ensure the Olympic legacy will stretch well beyond the Games itself, helping to ensure the ongoing regeneration of this part of London,” said Mittal.

Mayor of London Boris Johnson gave the sculpture his full backing, and hailed the Orbit as an "iconic" addition to the skyline of the capital.

"What better calling card for London 2012 than a piece of truly spectacular modern British art to drive visitors to east London in perpetuity," said Johnson.

"It would have boggled the minds of the Romans. It would have dwarfed the aspirations of Gustave Eiffel, and it will certainly be worthy of the best show on earth, in the greatest city on earth.

"And as the final giant steel loop is swung into place, lifting the ArcelorMittal Orbit to its full height, we are truly witnessing the most significant iconic addition to London’s skyline for decades.”

Estimates suggest that the venue will generate up to £10 million of revenue per year and create up to 50 new jobs once the dust has settled on the Games.

rank_226.title: BBC wins back coverage rights to London 2017 World Athletics Championships
rank_226.text:
The International Association of Athletics Federations has signed a deal with the European Broadcasting Union, of which the BBC is a member, guaranteeing exclusive media rights to all World Series Athletics events from 2014 to 2017.

It means the championships will return to BBC screens when they are staged in Beijing in 2015 before the channel becomes the host broadcaster for the event in the Olympic Stadium in Stratford two years later.

London was awarded the championships by the IAAF less than a fortnight ago when it saw off a rival bid from the Qatari capital, Doha.

Barbara Slater, the BBC’s director of BBC Sport, said: “We’re delighted that the World Championships will be returning to the BBC.

The 2017 championships, taking place at the Olympic Stadium will be a huge moment for UK athletics, helping to deliver the Olympic legacy, and we’re thrilled to be bringing the event to our audiences.”

The BBC screened the championships from their inception in 1983 to 2009 before losing the rights to Channel 4 this summer.

That was because the EBU was outbid for the period 2010-2103 by Swedish media rights agency IEC in Sports, which then negotiated individual rights deals with broadcasters in each country.

IEC had hoped to extend its deal but this time it was outbid by the EBU, who are believed have offered in excess of £15 million a year to the IAAF for pan-European rights.

IEC continues to hold the rights for the 2013 World Championships in Moscow and has yet to finalise a UK deal.

Channel 4’s coverage of the championships in Daegu, South Korea, attracted an avalanche of criticism from viewers and it was forced to drop its main presenter, Ortis Deley, halfway through the event after a series of embarrassing gaffes.

The new deal means the sport will return to mainly public service broadcasters across the continent.

Lamine Diack, the IAAF president, said: “The EBU has been our partner for every edition of the IAAF World Championships from their creation in 1983 right through until 2009 and we are delighted to be partners again.

“This agreement not only secures the financial future of the athletics movement until the end of 2017 but is also strategic for the IAAF in guaranteeing maximum coverage of our premium events in key territories.”

rank_48.title: London 2012 Olympics: legacy chief Baroness Ford to retire after Games
rank_48.text:
The chair of the Olympic Park Legacy Company said: "The next phase of the legacy work, including major transformation plans to the Park, are critical and will require a great deal of attention.

"I have decided therefore that I cannot continue to give the substantial time required for the role, so after the Games would seem a natural point to make the change."

In the run-up to London 2012 she will become the interim chair of the new-look OPLC regeneration body called the London Legacy Development Corporation (LLDC).

This body comes in to force on April 1 when the OPLC will be turned into a Mayoral Development Corporation.

This new body will have greater powers over the future Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park in Stratford, east London, and wider area including planning and development control.

She said: "It has been an absolute privilege to work with such a supportive mayor and ministers, and extremely talented board and staff members.

"Together we have set down strong foundations for the future Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park and a major driver of the significant regeneration of this part of east London.

"But for now it is business as usual and I look forward to continuing to work over the next six months on the further challenges that lie ahead."

Baroness Ford takes on the role as LLDC interim chair until the Games are over when she has decided to step down from the role.

Her tasks will include overseeing the transition of the two regeneration bodies. There is also the job of securing tenants for the venues within the Park.

The new body will be directly accountable to Londoners through the mayor.

It will continue the work of the OPLC plus manage some of the assets and responsibilities of local regeneration agencies such as the Thames Gateway Development Corporation.

Securing the land and restructuring the debt plus submission of the planning application for the Park, which includes five new neighbourhoods and 7,000 homes, were among the work carried out at the OPLC during Baroness Ford's reign.

London mayor Boris Johnson said: "I am grateful for Margaret's huge contribution over the last three years planning and delivering a solid 2012 legacy and delighted she will oversee this important work until after the Games as well as setting the new Legacy Corporation on a firm footing.

"We have an extraordinarily exciting period ahead. Building on the momentum already created by the Legacy Company we are on track to grasp this unique opportunity and harness the Olympic legacy of new jobs, new homes and new communities which Londoners will benefit from for years to come."

rank_92.title: London 2012 Olympics: New Olympic stadium sponsor should pass 'morality' test
rank_92.text:
Advising on the subject of the venue's legacy at an ESC meeting at City Hall, Nigel Currie, director of sports agency brandRapport, warned of the dangers of picking a company such as Dow Chemical, who currently sponsor the Olympic Stadium wrap.

Currie said that to approach the American multinational chemical corporation as a potential post-Games named sponsor would be an "own goal".

"You would rule out certain categories - tobacco, alcohol, probably gaming. We have a problem with Dow Chemical at the moment with the Olympic Stadium," he said.

"There are a few names of sponsors at the political end, for ethical reasons, you would probably want to avoid, and you have every right to.

"You couldn't know [that Dow Chemicals would be a problem]. It is one of the things that people have blown up, in my view, out of all proportion.

"[But] it might be a bit of an own goal to invite Dow Chemicals in now, for example."

Dow, who has funded the £7 million wrap of the Olympic Stadium, has come under fire recently due to its links with Union Carbide Corporation, whose subsidiary, Union Carbide India, ran the Bhopal pesticide plant.

In December 1984, a gas leak at Bhopal proved one of the worst industrial disasters in history, officially killing 3,787 people though campaigners suggest the correct figure is nearer 25,000.

The resulting furore has led to calls in India for a boycott of the Games, and demands that the International Olympic Committee drops the company as a sponsor.

To complicate matters, the IOC receive £60 million a year from Dow, who have dismissed the protests against them.

Dow have stated that Union Carbide's £288 million ($470 million) settlement for those affected by the leak - which was paid in 1989 (10 years before Dow's merge) - is fair and final.

The IOC and British politicians have gone on record to say that Dow, the second largest chemical manufacturer in the world, will not be relinquished as sponsors of the London Games, for whom it will provide a fabric wrap for the stadium which will be 900m (0.56 miles) long and 20m (67ft) high.

Currie said that the "morality clause" should be in place for any sponsor of the Olympic Stadium so that in future, should a similar situation arise, damaged reputations will be financially rewarded.

Currie continue: "All you can do is put clauses in the contract to that effect - if anything happens subsequently which threatens to damage the reputation of you, or anybody else.

"Most sponsorships now have something called a 'morality clause'. It is less pertinent for a venue, it is more pertinent for a team or a sport where someone takes drugs, or what happened with Tiger Woods and the problems he had."

However, Currie said that the stadium and general Olympic legacy has an opportunity to be better than any other Games since 1984, when Los Angeles hosted them.

He added: "It is a fantastic opportunity - the revenue opportunities in venue sponsorship are hugely undervalued in this country. We have been way, way behind the game in terms of developing naming rights for venues.

"I think the last two Olympics are not great examples [in how to maximise naming rights and legacy] - Beijing have rules that don't apply in certain other territories and Athens was a very small territory.

"London is a real hub. We have more major sport in this country than anyone else. We are a major player in the sporting world. I think it is a much bigger opportunity than any of the last few Games, probably going back to Los Angeles.

"There is not a science to it [securing decent sponsorship] - I don't think we need to do too much wheeling and dealing, thanks to the hype of the Olympics.

"You have a great advantage and political power at a very high level. Other people selling sponsorships do not have that advantage. You have to contact the right people at the right level.

"It is going to be a big decision for companies - it is multi millions of pounds over a long period of time. It is potentially a huge commitment for brands to make. It will be made at a very high level."

Meanwhile, Robbie Millar, a senior partner of Effective Brands, recommended that Olympic Park be marketed under a single umbrella. "I agree with that and would actively encourage [the committee] to do that," he said.

"The Olympic Stadium will deliver huge revenues. We want to use this as a national focal point."

rank_76.title: Budget for London 2012 Olympics could hit £11billion, warns watchdog
rank_76.text:
A report published on Friday by the Public Accounts Committee warns that the Olympic budgets are “finely balanced”, and raises serious concerns over the budgets for security, Games-time operations and legacy.

The PAC, which is responsible for assessing if government spending offers value for money, is particularly concerned about the amount of public money now being controlled by the London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games, notionally a private company.

The report warns that Locog has just £5million of headroom in its own budget, raising the prospect of the Government being liable for any overspend.

Organisers have always separated the publicly-funded construction budget of £9.3bn from Locog’s privately-financed operating budget of £2.2bn.

Locog, of which Lord Coe is chairman, is now responsible for spending an additional £800m of public money, and the PAC raises concerns about its management of those funds.

The report states that the Government is “dependent” on Locog to meet its public and private funding targets, and calls on the Government to explain how Locog will be held to account.

They also estimate that the actual cost to the taxpayer of the Games will be £11bn once the £766m cost of buying back the Olympic Park and legacy costs of £826m are factored in.

This is challenged by the DCMS, which says legacy and land costs have always been outside the central Olympic budget.

At the heart of the PAC’s concerns is how the original security budget of £282m was allowed to double to £553m, which it says is the key factor in placing the Games budget in a perilous position.

The report raises uncomfortable questions for Locog and the Home Office, and calls into question Locog’s insistence that, as a private company, it can operate in a less transparent way than public bodies.

Locog and the Home Office initially estimated that they would require 10,000 security guards at a cost of £282m. Late last year however that estimate increased to 23,700, doubling the cost to £553m.

The Home Office described Locog’s original estimate as a “finger-in-the-air exercise”, but the PAC reject their argument that costs could not have been more accurately worked out earlier.

“We do not accept Locog’s and the Home Office’s assertion that the likely cost and numbers could not have been better estimated much earlier,” the report states.

Locog is criticised for agreeing the new terms of its contract with private security provider G4S. While the number of guards covered by the new contract has increased six-fold, G4S’s programme-management costs have increased nine-fold, and operational costs 20-fold.

The report states that Locog re-negotiated the contract too late, and should have demanded a reduction in G4S’s profit margin.

The PAC is also critical of government sports legacy plans, declaring that the £450m spent on increasing sports participation represents poor value for money, with just 106,000 more people taking up sport.

The report also warns that the Olympic Stadium must not become a “white elephant”.

PAC chairman Margaret Hodge said that while venue construction costs were on time and on budget, she was concerned about the eventual cost of the Games.

"The £9.3 billion Public Sector Funding Package is close to being used up and we are concerned about whether the running of the Games will be held within budget," she said:

"Taking into account costs outside the package, the full cost to the public of the Games and legacy projects is already heading for around £11 billion.

“We are particularly concerned about the significant increases in the security bill. LOCOG now needs more than twice the number of security guards it originally estimated and the costs have roughly doubled.

"It is staggering that the original estimates were so wrong. LOCOG has had to renegotiate its contract with G4S for venue security from a weak negotiating position and there is a big question mark over whether it secured a good deal for the taxpayer.

“We were promised a strong Olympic legacy but the Government has chosen not to adopt the target of one million more people participating in sport by 2013, and plans for the stadium have fallen through. It must not become a white elephant."

rank_17.title: London 2012 Olympics: hosting Games will leave lasting legacy for Britain, says Chinese ambassador to UK
rank_17.text:
At the closing ceremony of the Beijing Olympic Games in 2008 the Mayor of Beijing, Mr Guo Jinlong, handed over the Olympic Flag to the Mayor of London, Mr Boris Johnson. Since then people could not help wondering how the UK would once again wow the world.

Four years ago there was doubt and uncertainty about how the Beijing Olympic Games would turn out. The world gave Beijing a chance. In turn Beijing rewarded the world with a pleasant surprise.

Four years on, the Beijing Olympic Games has gone beyond being just a grand sports gathering, where both Chinese and British athletes scored high. It has left a profound legacy for China as a country.

Of course, part of the Olympic legacy is visible assets. They are the spectacular sports stadiums like the “Bird’s Nest” and the “Water Cube”. These stadiums are in constant use.

The visible legacy must also include the state-of-the-art transport infrastructure such as the T3 terminal of the Beijing Capital International Airport, the expanded underground rail network and the express road networks. These facilities have become indispensable in the everyday life of our capital and improved public facilities in culture, tourism and the environment.

Previously, Asia had hosted two Olympic Games, Tokyo in 1964 and Seoul in 1988. These two games had greatly advanced the modernisation process in Japan and the ROK. Likewise, the Beijing Olympic Games has also become a milestone in China’s progress.

In hosting the Olympic Games, Beijing achieved massive gains in its modernisation. Yet more importantly, the Beijing Olympic Games has left a wealth of cultural legacy for the whole of China. It has transformed China in several aspects.

China has become more confident. The Beijing Olympic Games was China’s long held dream coming true. It was also a symbol of China’s maturity after many years of growth.

The 2008 Games placed China on the global stage. This focus in the global spotlight helped China cope with much greater attention from around the world in a calm and confident way as befits a major country, no matter whether it is being complimented or criticised.

China has become more open. The Beijing Olympic Games was China’s debut on the world stage. It helped China send out a strong message of engaging with the world. It strengthened China’s conviction in openness.

Through the Beijing Olympic Games, China is now even more committed to peaceful development and fully aware of a big country’s responsibilities. At the same time China has become more inter-connected with the world. The Beijing Olympic Games offered a great opportunity for Chinese ideas to interact with those from other parts of the world.

The three guiding principles of the Games – green Olympics, high-tech Olympics and people’s Olympics – made the Chinese people far more conscious about environmental protection, scientific innovation and all-round development of themselves.

As a result, sustainable development and a clean environment is our basic goal now. The government is putting more stress on scientific innovation and shift of growth model. Civil participation and voluntarism is nothing new in today’s China.

My British friends often tell me that Beijing has set the bar too high for London. The 2008 Beijing Olympics would be a tough act for London to follow. My reply is there is no uniform criteria for the success of an Olympic Games. As long as the host presents interesting and creative ideas and athletes bring out their best in competitions, then the Games will be successful.

I believe these are exactly the strengths of the UK. Britain has a reservoir of wisdom and resources. It leads the world in ideas and creativity. This is why China has laid so much emphasis on cultural exchanges with the UK.

For the very purpose of boosting China-UK cultural and people-to-people exchanges, Member of the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China Mr Li Changchun and Chinese State Councillor Madame Liu Yandong are visiting the UK.

They will attend the China Market Focus event at the London Book Fair and Madame Liu will launch the high-level people-to-people dialogue with her UK colleagues. Their visits will certainly lend a new impetus to strong and sustained growth of China-UK relations.

I strongly believe that, like China in 2008, the 2012 London Olympics will be a great success and leave a lasting legacy for the British people.

rank_54.title: London 2012 Olympics will inspire future generations says Lord Coe as official slogan is unveiled
rank_54.text:
Lord Coe, the organising committee chairman, unveiled the slogan as London marked 100 days until the opening ceremony at a damp Kew Gardens, one place where the untimely rain that fell on a series of stage-managed media events was at least welcome.

There was no dampening Coe’s enthusiasm for the theme that was at the heart of London’s successful bid, however, and he summoned a resonant phrase to insist London’s legacy will be more durable despite the doubts and criticism.

“I hope there is no surprise in the motto,” he said. “It is the heartbeat, the very DNA of this organisation. It is also a rallying cry to the athletes to come to the UK and perform at their very best.

"The achievements of every one of those Olympians and Paralympians will create a symphony of inspiration.

“Every day I tell my teams that for the athletes the Games have been the focus of half of their young lives, and we cannot let them become a victim of our shortcomings.”

Landmarks such as the beginning of the 100-day countdown are an opportunity for Olympic organising committees, and London used theirs to try and excite international interest, celebrate progress, and focus attention on a party yet to fully ignite domestic enthusiasm.

London’s did so with a neat municipal touch, They unveiled flower beds in the shape of the Olympic rings at Kew, visible from the Heathrow flight-path, and pictures of a huge sandcastle on Weymouth beach that was washed away within hours of being photographed. They now have to prove that the Olympic legacy is more durable.

Perennial concerns around security, transport, ticketing, and even the drought were all raised by a significant international media presence yesterday — a Norwegian journalist asked if London had enough water, to which the answer appeared to be only just — but repeatedly the attention returned to the question of what the Games will leave behind.

London’s progress has been unusually serene for a modern Olympics. The organising committee, Olympic Delivery Authority and other agencies have ticked off milestones with comparatively little drama, notwithstanding the gradual depletion of contingency in a £9.3bn public-funding package that, in the government’s alternative motto, remains on time and under-budget.

As they have done so, however, attention on the legacy of the Games has grown, the focus sharpening as the prevailing economic climate has darkened and a tangible public return on taxpayer investment has become more imperative.

The case for the inspirational power of the Olympics is far from proven, and Coe set a high bar when he made promises on London’s behalf seven years ago.

No Games has ever delivered a major boost in sports participation, and London has followed the trend, with a target of one million more people taking part in regular sport abandoned after four years that saw £450m deliver just 10% of that number.

The Coalition’s commitment to youth participation was undermined almost immediately it came to power, with £165m of ring-fenced school-sports funding cut in an ideological change to education policy that a subsequent U-turn only partially reversed.

Former Olympics minister Tessa Jowell, an Olympic loyalist since leaving office, criticised the government’s progress on this key issue yesterday, but Culture secretary Jeremy Hunt and sports minister Hugh Robertson insist that London is already delivering.

Hunt claimed that the Olympics represented a huge opportunity for business and tourism, and defended sport’s funding. “We are operating in very difficult economic circumstances and we have a different policy to the last government, but we remain committed to delivering a legacy.”

Robertson was emphatic in his belief that British sport is better off, with more facilities, more funding and more opportunities than ever before.

“Central to the bid was the promise to regenerate east London and regenerate Olympic sport,” he said.

“If you look at what this has delivered you see new facilities, an increase in lottery funding that will put an extra £500m into sports, better-funded elite athletes, education programmes and millions of children in 20 different countries touched by out International Inspiration project.

"Taken together it’s an incredibly powerful package.” Coe is in no doubt. “I spend a lot of time in London, and globally, and I see a lot of things that just would not have happened if we had come back from Singapore empty-handed.”

rank_149.title: London mayoral election 2012: how Boris and Ken's records compare
rank_149.text:
When Ken Livingstone was confirmed in September 2010 as Labour candidate for Mayor of London , the stage was set for a clash of the Titans.

Two of the best known politicians in the country will slug it out today in a fight that is too close to call.

Currently the Conservatives' Boris Johnson leads in the polls, with 52 per cent of the vote versus 48 per cent, after second preferences are taken into account.

But even a small swing could be enough to tip the balance towards Livingstone.

Livingstone served as mayor for eight years until 2008, when he was toppled by the incumbent Johnson.

That is the background to one of the most bitterly fought elections of recent years, with each side liberally pelting the other with insults.

Here we compare their track record in four key areas, judged by Londoners [PDF] to be the issues they care about the most.

Crime rate

Total crime in London has decreased year-on-year since 2002/03, if you do not take into account last summer's riots (although there is controversy over how the rate is counted). Yet both candidates accuse each other in their manifestos of not combating crime appropriately.

Boris Johnson’s manifesto cites: “Comparing my term against that of my predecessor: There are 1,000 extra warranted officers on the London’s streets now than there were in May 2008. Total crime has been cut by 10.8 per cent”.

The annual figures do not quite bear this out. In 2007/08, the year before Johnson came to power, there were 113.5 crimes for every 1000 people. This dropped to 105.3 in 2010/11, the last year for which data is available - a fall of 7.2 per cent.

Meanwhile, Livingstone argues that although crime has fallen, the rate of decline has slowed to only one per cent. He adds in his manifesto: "Overall crime was cut significantly when I was Mayor and continues to fall. [But...] robberies have increased... It is scandalous that in the face of this crime wave the Tory Mayor cut the number of police."

In fact, robbery rates peaked in 2006/07, during Livingstone's second term, at 6.1 robberies per 1000. They fell to 4.3 in 2009/10, before a slight rise to 4.6 last year.

Livingstone's claims of a 'crime wave' could be seen as overblown, when the latest figure is 25 per cent lower than it was four years ago.

Travel costs

Bus and tube fares increased substantially during Johnson's term, including a whopping 14.1 per cent rise in bus prices in 2010.

This year, a week-long travelcard for zones one and two will set you back £29.20 - up from £24.20 when Johnson became mayor in 2008.

Johnson notes in his manifesto that delays on the underground system have been cut by 40%, but admits that more upgrades still need to be done.

He hangs back from promising price cuts, but says: “I promise to be honest and transparent about fares setting and by cutting waste at TFL, my approach will keep fares low in the long term”.

Livingstone shows no such hesitance. He writes: “I will cut fares by 7% this year and freeze them throughout 2013.”

Cutting travel costs is a real crowd pleaser in London, where many live more than an hour away from work.

Livingstone also cut fares in 2008, shortly before his pre-election campaign: bus fares fell by 6.6%, while tube fares were cut by 1.2 per cent.

But previously costs had risen across the board - notably in 2005 and 2006, when bus fares jumped by 9.7 per cent then 10 per cent.

Unemployment

London unemployment rate floated one to two per cent above the national average for more than a decade, and has echoed the nationwide rise since the financial crisis in 2008.

Boris Johnson promises in his manifesto to combat this by creating 200,000 jobs in London in the next four years, including 10,000 roles through the Olympic legacy and 14,000 in the Crossrail scheme.

Livingstone takes the alternative view that the London mayor's powers are insufficient to "boost growth in London's economy".

However, he claims that with his policies Londoners will have more money in their pocket and will be better equipped to survive the economic crisis.

He pledges to champion equal pay for women, to extend London apprenticeships for 16- to 18-year-olds and oppose restrictive practices on hiring skilled workers from abroad.

Housing

House prices have been on the rise throughout both of the candidates' past terms.

Indeed, London property sales have stayed strong while prices across the rest of the country have tumbled.

Although this has provided relief for home-owners, who have seen their assets grow in value, first-time buyers are struggling to get onto the property ladder.

Deposit requirements have risen beyond the reach of many young workers.

Livingstone pledges: “I will investigate providing mortgage deposit guarantee for people who are able to service a mortgage but not able to access the large deposit to get on the housing ladder”.

He also promises to build 35,000 new homes a year.

Similarly, Johnson pledges 55,000 new affordable homes by 2015 for low and middle income workers,

He adds: “I will boost the First-Steps programme of low-cost home ownership products as their circumstances change, and encouraging providers to develop products which let households convert rent into equity”.

rank_194.title: London 2012 Olympics: torch lighting one of many similarities between ancient and modern Games
rank_194.text:
The relay ritual itself is a relatively recent Olympic confection, but the symbolism of its journey from the movement’s spiritual home to the London stadium is an attempt to tie the ancient Games to the modern.

But it is far from the only link between the original Games, which began in Olympia in 778BC, and the modern incarnation. As Tony Perrottet’s The Naked Olympics describes, a visitor from pre-Christian Olympia would recognise London 2012 as a descendant of the ancient Games – and not always for the most welcome reasons.

Just as the members of the International Olympic Committee control the modern Games, a small elite based in the city of Elis, a provincial farming town 40 miles from Olympia, were the guardians of the ancient Games. A wealthy clan of aristocratic Elians, who owed their income to cattle and stud farms, controlled the Games and the athletes. The Elians formed an Olympic Council which ran the Games: they set the rules and appointed the 10 all-powerful Olympic judges, the Hellanodikai, who were part organising committee, part judging panel. Like the IOC the Hellanodikai were selected by a mix of voting and appointment, and once in post were granted privileges and huge status.

The original stadium represents the ultimate Olympic legacy, still visited by tourists 2,800 years on, but it was not always so. Between Games the arena fell in to disrepair. While the temples of Olympia were staffed year-round, the stadium needed full renovation in between Games.

Brutal qualifying

As in the modern games, the athletes arrived in Elis a month before competition got under way for their final selection and preparations. All potential competitors were required to report to the city 30 days before the Games and subject themselves to training and selection by the Elians.

The strict regime, in which slackers were flogged or dismissed, was used to winnow out the weakest athletes.

Unhappy punters

Around 40,000 people would flock to Olympia to watch the five days of competition, with the class divide between wealthy and ordinary punters as marked as at a modern Games. The rich would arrive with caravans of servants to nab the best camping spots, while ordinary fans who had trekked on foot to get there had to sleep in the dust in the heat of a Greek August. Conditions were appalling, with no sanitation and limited water as nearby rivers dried up. Thankfully there was a thriving army of licensed vendors ready to sell them food and wine.

'Plastic Greeks'

To win a place in the Games competitors had to prove that they were the legitimate son of a free-born Greek. While women, slaves and the illegitimate were banned, the definition of what constituted 'Greek’ could be more flexible. The boundaries of the Greek empire meant that some had a tougher job proving their heritage, and following the Roman conquest in 146BC the rules were relaxed to allow anyone who spoke Greek to compete. It was common for athletes to change their citizenship between Games, switching their city state for cash. Others were less welcome. A Spartan who claimed he was Boeotian to avoid a ban was flogged.

Exposing the cheats

The ancient games were held in homage to the gods but that did not prevent the athletes succumbing to earthly vices. Those found to have rigged results, usually by paying off the opposition, were shamed by the ancient equivalent of the BOA by-law, having their names inscribed on stones lining the athletes’ tunnel. BOA chairman Lord Moynihan pointed them out at the torch lighting in Olympia last week, but did not comment on whether he had brought his chisel to add a name or two of his own.

rank_159.title: London 2012 Olympics: Sport England claim participation surge despite missing targets
rank_159.text:
Increasing sports participation was a central tenet of London’s Olympic promise, but the final figures before the Games from Sport England offer mixed evidence that it has been delivered.

The numbers show that 1.3m more people are playing sport at least once a week since London won the Games in 2005, with the number exceeding 15 million people for the first time.

Just six out of 31 funded sports have shown a statistically significant increase in participation in the last four years, with 15 showing a decrease and 10 flat-lining.

Athletics (running), cycling, netball, boxing, table tennis and fencing are the sports that showed a significant increase, though of these only running (370,000) and cycling (170,000) delivered six-figure increases over the last four years.

Swimming has shown the largest numerical decrease over the last four years with around 430,000 fewer participants. For a core Olympic sport to suffer such a decrease demonstrates that the Games are not a guarantor of increasing interest.

Worryingly participation fell among 16-24 year-olds, precisely the age-group the Olympics was intended to inspire. New government policy is aimed at arresting the decline.

The figures also confirm that the number of people doing sport three-times-a-week, which for most of the last four years was the government’s primary Olympic legacy target, had increased by just 500,000 since 2008, just half of the one million target.

Had the Coalition not abandoned the target earlier this year when it became clear it was going to be missed by a wide margin, Sport England’s investment of £450m over four years might be judged a failure.

The picture after the Olympics is likely to become bleaker, with Sport England chief executive Jennie Price admitting that she is planning for cuts to funding after the Olympics.

“We realise like everybody else that this is a very difficult economic climate and we would be foolish to plan for any increases [in funding],” she said.

No previous Olympics has delivered a participation increase and these figures demonstrate just how hard it is. Despite the increase in once-a-week participation, some of which can be put down to a milder winter, the figures reveal marginal increases, even with the hype and focus provided by London 2012.

Price defended her organisation’s performance said the Olympics had delivered an increase for those sports that prepared for it.

“Our overall numbers are strong, and our numbers are up both in terms of actual participants and the trend so we are pleased,” she said. “There is evidence of growth in these numbers, but we would just like to see more of it.”

“The Olympics were always an opportunity, never a guarantee. If you look at sports that have really thought about how they can capitalise on interest in the Olympics, such as hockey, then you can see an increase. There is evidence of an Olympic effect but only for sports that worked hard to secure it.”

Asked about the three-times-a-week target she said: “You would expect me to say this but the current government has decided to abandon that target.

“We have got 500,000 more people doing sport three-times a week, and there has been a 350,000 increase in the last six months so there is an upward trend. The date for judging the target is also 2013, not this year. But there is evidence of real growth in tough circumstances.”

Sport England will reveal how much money it intends to distribute to governing bodies in its next four-year cycle, from 2013-2017, in December. It will be increasingly reliant on Lottery funding in future, with 75 per cent of its income coming from that source.

It is also expected to merge with high-performance agency UK Sport after the Olympics, a process already fraught with internal politics and friction.

rank_38.title: London 2012 Olympics: Seb Coe honoured with award in recognition of Olympic legacy
rank_38.text:
The award, launched by global organisation Beyond Sport in partnership with P&G and The Telegraph to recognise the UK's most innovative and successful sport for change projects, was presented by Coe at the Beyond Sport London Reception, held just one month before the Beyond Sport Summit & Awards are staged in London in the week of the Olympics opening ceremony.

Across the UK, Street League uses football to reach young people who are NEET (Not Employed, in Education or Training) and strives to improve their lives.

The programme has impacted over 20,000 hard-to-reach young people, many of whom have offending and/or substance-misuse backgrounds.

By combining soft-skills training with accredited courses – including CV writing, interview training and FA Level 1 coaching – Street League has been able to provide participants with routes to employment, training or schooling.

Chief executive Matt Stevenson-Dodd said: “We are very proud of our track record, which sees three out of four graduates from the Street League academy get a job or return to education. But with more than one million 16 to 24-year-olds currently out of work in the UK, we are committed to expanding our programme and changing the lives of yet more young people. This award will have a direct impact on helping us achieve that.”

In a year when youth unemployment reached an all-time high, Street League’s efforts and outcomes make it stand out as a project using sport to mitigate a serious issue affecting the whole of the nation.

Two other projects were highly commended by the judging panel: Extra Time, run by the Football Foundation, which engages more than 3,000 elderly men and women in physical activity to help improve emotional wellbeing and reduce social isolation; and Everton in the Community's Tackling Inequality, Empowering Ability programme, which addresses mental health issues on Merseyside.

All three projects will receive a support package from Beyond Sport to enable them to further develop their activities.

The evening also saw Coe and Sir Keith Mills receive Beyond Sport’s Leadership in Sport Award, supported by P&G. Coe and Mills, the Chair of the II Foundation, received the award on behalf of International Inspiration, the official international sports legacy programme of London 2012.

International Inspiration, a unique partnership between the British Council, UK Sport and UNICEF, has worked with an astonishing 12 million children to fulfil the promise made by Coe and the London 2012 bid team in Singapore in 2005, when the two-time Olympic gold medallist vowed that the London 2012 Games would "reach young people all around the world and connect them to the inspirational power of the Games so they are inspired to choose sport, improving their lives as a result."

“International Inspiration’s work has been a key part of London 2012’s vision to inspire young people around the world, and I am delighted to accept this Award from Beyond Sport on behalf of everyone who has contributed to its success,” said Coe.

“To have made a difference in the lives of over 12 million children around the world before London 2012 even gets underway is testament to the incredible power of sport.”

Nathan Homer, Sports Marketing & Olympics Project Director at Procter & Gamble (P&G), added: “We are delighted to support both of these Awards, which celebrate the impact of London 2012 and the Olympic movement both within the UK and abroad.

"P&G are proud of our place in the Olympic movement and welcome this chance to pay tribute to the inspirational leadership that Seb Coe and his team have provided around the world, and to recognise the outstanding projects on the ground in the UK.”

rank_55.title: London 2012 Olympics: Stratford Stadium makes pitch to host Rugby World Cup 2015 matches
rank_55.text:
The application is receiving serious consideration by England Rugby 2015, the organising company for tournament which will be staged in England and Wales during September and October of that year.

There is a strong hope the Olympic venue could host a number of high-profile Rugby World Cup pool matches – possibly involving France, Italy or Scotland – as well as the third-place play-off.

“It would be great to have a world-class event in a world-class venue,” said Paul Vaughan, the chief executive of ER 2015.

“It will help the Olympic legacy as well, so we are very keen to work with them on that, particularly because rugby is going to go into the Olympics in 2016 in Brazil.”

The key consideration is whether the Olympic Park Legacy Company can guarantee that the venue will meet all of the criteria laid down by the International Rugby Board for tournament stadiums – which include the requirement that the stadium is free of advertising.

That is likely to be dependent on who wins the right to be the anchor tenant for the Olympic Stadium, a decision which is not expected until after the end of the London Games in August following the collapse of the West Ham deal.

ER 2015 is to give Olympic Park Legacy Company as much time as possible to provide the necessary guarantees, having received the formal application in February after a month of exploratory talks.

The Olympic Stadium is set to be reconfigured to a 60,000-seat venue after the London Games and the infrastructure and transport links would make it an ideal World Cup venue.

If the Olympic Stadium’s application is successful, it is likely it would replace Arsenal’s Emirates Stadium, one of 12 venues included in the original RFU bid in 2009 as one of the tournament stadiums.

ER 2015 is inspecting those venues, which also include Wembley, Old Trafford, Newcastle United's Sports Direct Arena, Anfield, Elland Road, the Ricoh Arena and St Mary’s Stadium, to ensure they are still committed as a number have changed ownership in the last three years.

Villa Park, the home of Premier League side Aston Villa, is also under strong consideration.

ER 2015 is expected to confirm its tournament stadiums early next year, with Cardiff’s Millennium Stadium expected to host two quarter-finals as well as some of Wales’s pool matches.

rank_148.title: London’s warming to the Olympics
rank_148.text:
When the American novelist Willa Cather came to London in the summer of 1902, she noted that “if the street life... is in any city more gloomy, more ugly, more grimy, more cruel than in London, I certainly don’t care to see it”. To this assessment she added that “possibly all the failures of this generation, the world over, have been suddenly swept into London, for the streets are a restless, breathing, malodorous pageant of the seedy of all nations”.

All these years later, I am rather inclined to agree with Ms Cather, who would have slipped into a catatonic depression today had she got off her plane from New York and queued for several hours at border control. Sadly, our capital can often seem like a stinking hellhole, and if Samuel Johnson had had to spend every morning waving eight Tubes past until one arrived that he could squeeze in to by folding himself in half, he would have tired of London – and life – pretty damn quickly.

My first experience of the city came in the summer of 1980, when I was born in a hospital west of Hammersmith. I have spent the years since living here – and desperately trying not to. As a girl whose school was situated on the most polluted road in Europe, I would beg my parents to send me to some bucolic boarding school – but they told me that because we lived in London, they couldn’t afford to.

Not being able to afford things is the main experience of people who live in London; we can’t afford to live here, but we can’t afford not to, what with the rocketing costs of rail travel in from the ''burbs’’, coupled with the fact that all the jobs are here. We’d talk about it, get through the experience through shared counselling, but of course we don’t talk to one another, except to be rude. To wit: I was once mugged (not to be confused with the three times I have been burgled) in broad daylight, on a main road, in front of a bus stop crowded with people who did nothing because they were too busy silently seething at the fact they had already waited 25 minutes for the 44.

When ''we’’ – as if anyone in London is in anything together – ''won’’ the Olympics in 2005, my reaction was not of joy but incredulity. As in: “Really? You want to do it here? In London? In east London [where I lived at the time, in a cramped flat above a Nando’s restaurant], of all places? Are you quite sure about that?” I thought London’s Olympic dream would be rather like trying to put lipstick on a pig.

The Games did at least give Londoners something to moan about. “The traffic’s going to be awful,” taxi drivers would say, while stuck in traffic. “There’s going to be loads of tourists,” people would spit, as they elbowed their way past... well, loads of tourists.

But look. Something has changed almost overnight in London. Big pink neon signs have gone up all over the transport system offering directions to Olympic venues – Horse Guards Parade several miles this way, the Olympic Village several miles that way – and they make me smile.

Londoners are even being nice to tourists, trying to show them the best of the city. And taxi drivers have stopped whingeing.

People I have met who had refused to get involved with the rigmarole of ticket applications now wish they had entered the ballot; my friend Olivia is beaming at the prospect of the freestyle wrestling tickets she obtained for 8.15am on a Sunday.

You can say what you like about London (and I believe I just have), but when it comes down to it, we know how to put on a show. Look how beautifully we behaved during the Queen’s Diamond Jubilee, and the royal wedding. As a city, we are tremendously good at playing host to other people, not so good at conversing with one another. Perhaps the real Olympic legacy that Locog endlessly talks about could be extending to ourselves the courtesies we so readily offer to other nations.

Daddy’s girl Nell does him proud

Nell Diamond, not to be confused with the singer Neil Diamond (no relation), is the daughter of Bob Diamond – or, as she tweeted the other day, rather drolly, “Bob Diamante” (goodness knows what fate awaits his former Barclays colleague Rich Ricci). She also tweeted that Ed Miliband and George Osborne could “HMD”, a yoof phrase newspapers have attempted to spell out without being able to actually spell it out, given its fruity nature.

Anyway, all of this has landed Nell – a Princeton graduate who works at Deutsche Bank – on the front pages, which makes a change from seeing her father’s increasingly worn-down mug there. Poor Nell has been rounded on in much the same way as Dad, but I think her behaviour is rather touching. In this day and age it would be all too easy to distance yourself from an embarrassing parent – change your name to Nell Cubic Zirconia, for example – but instead she has stood up for him and deflected criticism by acting like an embarrassing daughter. Here, for example, is a Tweet outlining young Nell’s work ethic, one that would make all bankers proud: “Tabs on my Internet Explorer: Puffin Livecam, Pugs Dressed as Darth Vader, Hedgehogs Cuddling, Federal Reserve Outright Treasury Holdings.”

So thank God for Nell. Without her, we wouldn’t have the picture of her father throwing shapes at a Jay-Z concert, or the snap of him dressed like Inspector Gadget, clutching the FA Cup as he stands next to John Terry (two of the most loathsome men in Britain in one family photo – wonderful!).

The member of the Diamond clan I am most keen to know more about, though, is Nell’s brother Rob (as his father is Robert Diamond Jr, does this make him Rob Jr Jr? Please do keep up at the back). A close friend who met young Rob tells me that he is fascinated with British government, and that he planned to do his dissertation on William Hague’s failed election campaign. On many levels, he probably won’t be so enamoured with our political system now.

We should be nice to them – they didn’t ask to be born into a world of privilege or wealth. Also, it’s worth noting that both our Prime Minister and his deputy are the offspring of bankers. Who knows, the next stop for Nell might just be the White House.

That’s enough flashing of the athletic flesh

While I am excited about the Olympics, there are certain elements I am a little sick of: namely, the athletes’ bodies, which I feel I know more about than the athletes themselves. If it isn’t Victoria Pendleton showing us a shapely bottom in an arty black and white photo, then it is Jessica Ennis (below) posing in a skintight frock for Cosmopolitan magazine, telling us that she is “comfortable being naked” and that she rates her body confidence as seven out of 10.

Of course, Ennis was hitting back at the senior UK Athletics official who said she was “carrying too much weight”. But I can’t help thinking there are more important things to be discussing at this juncture. Plus, if her body confidence is only seven out of 10, what hope for the rest of us? Anyway, it is unthinkable to imagine Chris Hoy telling, say, GQ how he rates his self-esteem out of 10 – then again, men aren’t subject to the same ridiculous standards as women, who must be both athletes and “normal” girls the rest of us can relate to. But I don’t relate to Ennis any more than I do Cindy Crawford or Queen Noor of Jordan; the point of her is that she is absolutely, wonderfully, nothing like the rest of us.

Soon after the “fat” jibe, she set a new heptathlon record. When it comes to silencing her critics, there’s a better way than posing for a magazine: winning an Olympic medal.

Fifty shades at least – and we’ve read them all

Loath as I am to give any more publicity to the Fifty Shades phenomenon, I want to ask: since when was sex in literature anything new? Mills and Boon have been accused of jumping on the bandwagon with their new series of racy e-novels, but they’ve always been a bit naughty; it is a little patronising to women to suggest that we have all had sexual awakenings thanks to E L James. Bad sex is so absolutely British that there is even a literary award for it, won in the past by figures as prestigious as Haruki Murakami and David Guterson, the author of Snow Falling on Cedars. One must beg the judging panel not to insult their writing by giving the prize to James this year.

rank_151.title: London 2012 Olympics: The Games can be a beacon of aspiration amid the gloom
rank_151.text:
This is a summer of giddy mood swings, of bipolar Britain. The economic skies are as gloomy as the weather, the disgrace of the banks deepens, the media is still on trial at the Leveson Inquiry, and the Prime Minister tells The Daily Telegraph that “I can’t see any time soon when the pressure will be off.”

Yet this otherwise solid wall of grey has been broken up by moments of glorious colour and celebration. First, the Diamond Jubilee was triumphant evidence that one national institution at least is in robust good health, and that the monarchy, now thoroughly at ease in its modern setting, is still capable of encapsulating and inspiring the spirit of British optimism. When the Queen walked on stage at the end of the celebratory concert outside Buckingham Palace last month, to acknowledge graciously the Prince of Wales’s perfectly judged tribute and the applause of 1.5 million Britons gathered in London, it was hard to believe that this is a country in the grip not only of austerity-without-end but of an intermittent panic attack about its trajectory, compounded by collective fury at the political and financial elites which got us in this mess in the first place.

On Friday, this mood of misery and apprehension will be suspended once more as the opening ceremony of the London Olympics is beamed around the world. The needle on the national dashboard will again swing from one extreme to the other. There will be glitches, complaints, and strongly worded letters to the press about the way in which the broadcasters are covering outdoor Jenga. Any travel delays will be treated as the infrastructural equivalent of an outbreak of Ebola (not to be confused with Jenga). But – I submit – even the most anti-Olympic Grinches, even the hardest-bitten cynics and Games-haters, will feel a batsqueak of excitement and patriotic pride as the curtain rises on the greatest show on earth.

Such moments in national life are routinely hailed by politicians as “non-political” and “above politics”. Of course, the opposite is true. Yes, Tessa Jowell (who, more than anyone else, has steered these Games from underdog bid to glorious reality) and Seb Coe, the doughty chairman of the organising committee and an Olympic hero in his own right, have transcended party in their decade-long partnership. But, ever since Pierre de Coubertin revived the Olympic tradition, the Games have positively groaned with political significance. It is no accident that Tony Blair, whose sleepless diplomacy did much to secure victory for London in 2005, has returned to the fray now to advise Labour on the Olympic legacy.

No 10, for its part, is all too aware that David Cameron cannot be seen to be “muscling in” on the Games – but also knows an opportunity when one comes knocking on its lustrous black door. Hence, I am told, the PM will be chairing regular meetings of Cobra, the Civil Contingencies Committee, to ensure that all is going smoothly at the Olympic Park. There will be plenty of prime ministerial schmoozing with international businesses, too. Whether or not the Olympics will indeed boost the UK economy by more than £13 billion over the next four years – as Cameron predicts – is impossible to say. But host governments have always seen economic hope etched into the sacred rings. When London last hosted the Games 64 years ago, senior ministers were no less optimistic about the potential bounty. “There are few better ways of making such a net contribution to the balance of payments with so little offset in the form of imported materials,” Herbert Morrison wrote to Attlee in 1947.

At a more primitive level, there will be a totally unacknowledged but completely obvious battle between the PM and Boris Johnson to assert brand ownership of the Games. Anyone who has been near a mainline train station in London recently will have heard the Mayor’s unmistakable tones in a recorded message urging all of us “folks” to plan ahead when making journeys during the Olympics. For which read: these are the Boris Games.

Those Tories who are militantly opposed to the idea of the Mayor as Cameron’s successor are worried that the Games will be the most sensational leadership campaign launch in history. They are right to be concerned: Boris will have plenty of opportunities, ex officio, to go global in the weeks ahead, and his performance at the handover in Beijing four years ago shows that he thrives under this sort of spotlight. But the flipside is that all the bad stuff will be laid at the mayoral door, too. If London snarls to a grisly halt during the Games, so too might Boris’s ambitions.

Like a Rorschach test, the spectacle and scale of the Olympics allow observers to draw whatever ideological conclusions they please. You see what you want to see: John Pilger writes in the current New Statesman of “the London Olympics’ razor-wired, PR-and-money-fuelled totalitarian state within a state”. Others regard the 2012 Games as a festival of soggy multi-culturalism and (our old friend) “PC gone mad”. In the fiasco of G4S and its awesome failure to provide sufficient security personnel for the Games, some have detected yet another parable of free market failure and of “contracting out” to the private sector. In the Border Agency strike threatened by the PCS union, meanwhile, others have scented a sour whiff of the Seventies, proof that the unionised public sector can be relied upon only to sabotage what really matters.

I think it is hazardous – and wildly premature – to pronounce upon the ideological lessons of these Games. But when the audit comes, it will surely find that truth lies in the Blairite maxim now adopted by the Cameroons: what counts is what works. Philosophers call this “model agnosticism”. The rest of us call it common sense. Without the state-subsidised Army and police riding to the rescue, G4S’s failure would have become a catastrophe. Without reform of union law, the public sector’s supervision of our borders will become untenable: a prime case for the “contracting out” that has been so criticised in recent days.

One of the great British exports is irony. It is entirely appropriate that in the superb comedy series, Twenty Twelve, we satirised our own Games pre-emptively: no other nation on earth would do that. True Britishness straddles the boundary that separates irony from determination. We are capable of mocking ourselves but also – when it counts – of Corinthian grit. The trick is striking the right balance.

I am always suspicious of politicians who blame everything on “media cynicism” when what they really mean is that they don’t like their press coverage. But there is a deeper point at issue in all this – in these Games – which is that no country can long prosper if its default setting is to be jaded, its aspirations are moribund, and its reserves of trust exhausted. The struggle to regain that trust, to rekindle that aspiration, is and will continue to be the story of this Coalition. So, too, it is the story of the London 2012 Games; and, in the final analysis, of our times.

rank_11.title: London 2012 planners 'did everything right' with Olympics legacy, say Australians
rank_11.text:
Australia’s biggest city, widely praised for hosting the best Olympics , today faces an "ongoing catastrophe" over failures to adequately plan for life after the Games, one of the country's leading commentators said.

Sydney’s Olympic Park , in the city’s western suburbs, today resembles a “ghost town” as government blunders leave the “genial garden-party feel” of 12 years ago largely forgotten, she wrote.

Elizabeth Farrelly, an Adjunct Associate-Professor of Architecture at the University of Sydney, criticised the city’s legacy plan as “lamentable”, which London has “comprehensively” trounced.

The Sydney-based author, who holds a PhD in architecture, said London 2012 officials “did everything right” in their legacy planning and “at every strategic turn, where we made wrong decisions, they made right ones”.

Consequently the local New South Wales government faces an “ongoing catastrophe” over its wasted investment of almost $2 billion (£1.34 billion) on the new Homebush Bay suburb.

The former Sydney City Councillor said the area, about 10 miles west of the city centre, was now a “ghost town”, with the main train line to the city operating “four times a day, off-peak, and not on weekends” and a lack of any sense of vibrancy.

“Legacy depends far more on front-end strategy, connectivity decisions; location, urban fabric, transport,” she wrote in the Sydney Morning Herald newspaper on Thursday, in an article titled "Where the Brits have us beaten".

“It is not rocket science. Cities have always lived and died by connectivity. So it should be obvious that any Olympic legacy is only as good as its connectivity.

“Yet Sydney, already tyrannised by distance, did everything possible to deny such connectivity, forever. It never made sense. Despite our best efforts, the place is a ghost town.”

A CGI impression of what the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park could look like post-Games (Picture: LEGACY COMPANY)

In comparison London planners identified a “rust-pocket that was accessible but seedy, needing help” early on and created excellent transport links, such as the Docklands rail systems, close to the 560 acre Olympic Park.

London also correctly decided to host events at city locations such as Hyde Park, Greenwich and the Mall so the “Queen can watch cycling from a Buckingham Palace balcony and the plebs can watch beach volleyball in Horse Guards Parade”.

Problems were evident as early as 1990, three years before Sydney won its Games bid and a decade before it hosted the Olympics, as senior bureaucrats dismissed arguments to build the precinct in a centrally located area, such as Darling Harbour.

But officials also had an “amazing” lack of plan to deal with toxic waste at ''one of the most contaminated sites in the world”, no understanding of its location and link to the rest of the city while they also created “idiotic” transport proposals.

The Olympic Park at Stratford, east London, will be revamped into a new suburb called "Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park" (Picture: GETTY IMAGES).

The London Legacy Development Corporation will revamp “Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park”, in Stratford, east London, into a regenerated district with 8,000 new homes, schools, nurseries and health centre.

It will also have new visitor attractions while the Olympics facilities will continue to be used for sporting events.

rank_21.title: An Olympic blueprint for a better Britain
rank_21.text:
Those watching the Olympics this week may have been left with a certain ringing in their ears – not from the cheers of the crowd, or the thump of the stadium sound systems, but from the thunderous sound of preconceptions being shattered. Those who delighted in arguing that London 2012 would be a flop – that a dismal, second-class nation such as Britain could never raise its game to the required heights – have been robustly confounded. All the pre-Games fretting about the logistics, the transport, the security, have thus far proved largely groundless. Instead, the public, and our foreign guests, have found themselves in a kind of Wonderland version of Britain, in which everything works, everything comes off, and everyone smiles all the time.

Where does this feeling come from? An explanation is found in the work of Sir John Keegan, this newspaper’s eminent former defence editor, who died this week. His greatest achievement as a military historian was to write from the perspective of the soldier rather than the general, to treat war as a bottom-up rather than a top-down affair. So it is with the Olympics. It may have been the politicians and sporting bureaucrats who bid for the Games and constructed the venues, and the sponsors who emblazoned them with their logos. But the most striking feature of London 2012 has been the sense of public ownership, a whole-hearted and near-unanimous enjoyment of and participation in the whole enterprise. It is something shaped by enlightened decisions from above – such as the light touch and relaxed professionalism shown by stewards, security personnel and officials – and by the exemplary performance of so many of the home nation’s sportsmen. But it is also something that no politician or bureaucrat could have ordained. To call them the “People’s Games” is a cliché, yet they have become precisely that.

For a nation that has recently seemed unsure of its place in the world, the reception that the Games have received offers a certain reassurance. We are suddenly realising, as we did during the Queen’s Diamond Jubilee, that we do not need to present ourselves to others as ancient or modern, traditional or radical, but simply as the nation we are – which happens to be a nation that the world rather likes. This comfort with the many layers of our national identity was perfectly reflected by the Olympic opening ceremony’s blend of whimsy and spectacle, and has been reinforced with every shot of beach volleyball players in Horse Guards Parade, or horses leaping towards the distant spires of Docklands from the eventing course in Greenwich Park. Indeed, given the chance to see ourselves as the world sees us, through the prism of the television lenses, we are learning to appreciate the beauty of our capital in new and delightful ways.

What is most encouraging about the Olympics, however, is the way they have raised the national mood – or rather, transformed it. A culture often dominated by cynicism, pessimism and complaint is experiencing the heady effects of a daily infusion of optimism and joy. The pleasure is all the greater because of the bittersweet aftertaste, the knowledge that it cannot and will not last: we may summon some of the same happy spirit for the Paralympic Games, but by and large, at the end of the closing ceremony, the party will be well and truly over.

Which raises the question: what next? Will this happy spirit simply vanish, snuffed out alongside the Olympic cauldron? Certainly, the empty streets in central London suggest that the promised economic boost will be hard to come by. There will be a sporting legacy, not least in the form of the stunning venues that will now be put at the community’s service. But the real consequence of the Games, if they continue on this golden path, will be more psychological than monetary, or even sporting.

rank_64.title: Tessa Jowell: London 2012 schools legacy at risk
rank_64.text:
The government’s decision to remove millions of pounds from school sport had dealt “a devastating blow” to hopes that the Games would encourage children to lead more active lives, she said.

Dame Tessa suggested Team GB’s medal prospects at future Olympics could be jeopardised unless more funding is provided for school sports.

She intervened after the Conservative peer, Lord Moynihan, lamented the dominance of privately educated athletes among Britain’s list of medal winners.

In an article for the Telegraph website , Labour’s shadow Olympics minister, who was Culture Secretary when London won the 2012 bid, warned school sport was already suffering as a result of Michael Gove’s decision on school sport.

She urged “cross party” efforts to secure the legacy that the UK had promised to deliver for the London Olympics.

However, her comments will be seen as signalling an end to the political truce which has held since the start of the Games.

In her article, Dame Tessa dismissed the “myths” that Labour had sold playing fields and “outlawed” competitive sport in schools.

“A decade of investment, through school sports partnerships, was yielding real results, giving young people in state schools the same sporting opportunities that had long been enjoyed in private schools,” she said.

“Improved elite performance and grassroots participation does not simply happen by accident. It requires the active support of Government,” she said.

“But two years ago, at the stroke of a minister’s pen, we saw the Government cut funding for school sport and dismantle school sports partnerships.

“This was a devastating blow to sport in schools and to the ambition to be the first Olympic Games which could point to a public health legacy.”

Earlier this week, Lord Moynihan, who is Chairman of the British Olympic Association, said it was “wholly unacceptable” that more than 50 per cent of Britain’s medallists at the Beijing Olympics in 2008 had been privately educated.

rank_36.title: Olympic legacy must mean more school sport
rank_36.text:
Old myths have resurfaced about Labour’s time in Government. Here are the facts.

After 10,000 playing fields were sold off between 1979 and 1997, it was the Labour Government that legislated to ensure that they were protected.

For the first time, sales of any part of a playing field would require support of the Secretary of State. Less than 200 applications to sell off playing fields were granted in the next ten years.

The myth that we outlawed competitive sport is absolute rubbish. Over the course of a decade, we both promoted it and funded it.

A decade of investment, through school sports partnerships, was yielding real results, giving young people in state schools the same sporting opportunities that had long been enjoyed in private schools.

Between 2002 and 2010, the number of young people doing at least two or more hours of sport per week rose from 25% to 90%. The number of boys and girls taking part in sport outside lessons almost doubled.

There was a real and visible change in the range of sports that are offered in schools. Fifteen years ago, if you weren’t any good at football, netball or cross-country, there often wasn’t much sport on offer for you.

By 2010, the average secondary school offered 25 different sports – including Olympic sports such as judo, cycling and badminton where we have seen so much progress in recent years.

Half-baked accusations about the last decade’s sporting developments are dangerous not just because they are simply untrue, but because they also make it more difficult to have an honest and open debate about how we improve sport both in our schools and in our country.

In the 1996 Atlanta Games, Great Britain came 36th in the medal table – our worst-ever Olympic performance, which followed two decades of underinvestment. Through finishing fourth in the medals table at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Team GB recorded our best ever performance in the modern Olympics.

This has been accompanied by a substantial increase in participation in grass roots sport – which has seen a million more people playing sport at least three times per week since 2005.

Improved elite performance and grassroots participation does not simply happen by accident.

It requires the active support of Government, both in funding the necessary infrastructure and putting the right systems in place to support its development.

That is why a total funding package of £2 billion to support elite, grassroots and school sport in the run up to the London Games – targeted at sports that could demonstrate success – and a schools sport system that was the envy of the world.

But two years ago, at the stroke of a Minister’s pen, we saw the Government cut funding for school sport and dismantle school sports partnerships.

This was a devastating blow to sport in schools and to the ambition to be the first Olympic Games which could point to a public health legacy.

School sport partnerships have been so successful that they have been reproduced in Canada, Brazil and even our arch-rivals Australia.

Their incomprehensible abolition has seen a 60% reduction in the amount of time spent organising sport in schools.

Any debate around improving sport in our schools needs to look at how we can re-create this world-beating system.

The Olympic and Paralympic Games are a once in a lifetime event that will get young people excited about sport. It is important that schools are able to maintain this momentum and help young people develop sport and exercise as a habit that will keep them healthy and fit for the rest of their lives.

In the spirit of cross-party co-operation that has marked the success of the Olympics, let us apply the same determination to creating the legacy we promised – to inspire a generation through sport, here in Great Britain and across the world.

rank_165.title: Olympic legacy: Coalition axes school sports targets
rank_165.text:
Amid continuing debate over the Olympic legacy, it was revealed that the Department for Education is no longer forcing state schools to provide 120 minutes of PE and sport.

The Coalition insisted that head teachers should be given the freedom to organise physical activity themselves instead of following a “bureaucratic system”.

It was also feared that many schools were shunning competitive sport and favouring disciplines such as yoga and circus skills to hit targets imposed by the previous Labour government.

But the move will raise fears that some children may not be getting access to the necessary amount of exercise every week.

The disclosure comes just days after Jeremy Hunt, the Culture Secretary, admitted that school sports provision was still too patchy.

It was also revealed this week that Michael Gove, the Education Secretary, has approved the sale of more than 20 school playing fields since the last General Election.

Officials insisted most became surplus when existing schools closed or amalgamated.

But the figures could prove embarrassing for the Government as the nation continues to be swept along by the success of the London Olympics and Team GB’s medal haul.

Today, the Youth Sport Trust criticised the decision to scrap the two hour PE target, claiming it was now difficult to identify which schools were failing to provide enough lessons.

“Measuring the number of young people participating in two hours of school sport did give a clear indication of participation levels in sport in schools across the country,” a spokesman said. “There is still some great work going on in schools but it is now more difficult to know exactly where provision is good and where it needs to be improved.”

Under the previous Government, all children of compulsory school age were expected to take part in two hours of sport a week. By 2009/10, some 86 per cent of pupils were meeting the target.

Labour later outlined a long-term goal of ensuring children did five hours a week of physical activity during lesson time or after school.

As part of a new school sport strategy published in late 2010, the Coalition axed the last Government’s targets – including the new “five hour offer” – claiming they led to a decline in the number of children taking part in traditionally competitive sports such as rugby union, netball and hockey. A sports census completed by schools every year was also scrapped.

But a statement released at the time suggested that all schools would be expected to “continue providing two hours a week of PE and sport”.

Today, the Department for Education insisted that this was no longer the case.

“Instead of handing down target and quotas from Whitehall, we have chosen to trust teachers and parents when it comes to deciding how much sport pupils should do,” a spokesman said.

“We want to strip away the red tape that takes up too much time teachers should be using to teach, run sports clubs or plan lessons. In the past, schools were heavily over-burdened with paperwork and form-filling.”

Speaking earlier this week, Mr Hunt said: “I think at the moment school sport provision is patchy in some places, and we need to do what we can to make sure that the very best examples are spread throughout the whole country, and this is absolutely going to be a focus over the next few months and one of the things that we really want to take away from these Games."

rank_18.title: Olympic legacy: 21 school fields sold off in two years
rank_18.text:
Despite a promise to safeguard playing fields from development, Education Secretary Michael Gove has approved the sale of 21 since the Coalition was formed.

The figures, released by the Department of Education, were announced in the middle of what could be one of Britain's most successful Olympic Games , featuring athletes who first tried their sports while at school.

Team GB's first medal winner, Lizzie Armitstead has said she would have never thought to try cycling if her PE teacher had not organised a visit from British Cycling's talent team.

Some schools, including Winchcombe school in Newbury, Berkshire, have lost their playing fields to housing developments while others have been sold after schools were closed, according to the Guardian.

At Woodhouse school in Staffordshire, a new school was built on the playing fields while Kingsbury high school in Brent, north London, will lease its playing fields to a five-a-side pitch firm.
