Culture Secretary Jeremy Hunt, whose brief includes the Olympics, said more National Lottery money was being pumped into sport but admitted there was "patchy" provision within sports.

"I think at the moment school sport provision is patchy in some places, and we need to do what we can to make sure that the very best examples are spread throughout the whole country, and this is absolutely going to be a focus over the next few months and one of the things that we really want to take away from these Games," he told the Guardian.

Earlier this year, Prince Harry spoke out against developments on school playing fields as he awarded prizes to the winners of the London Marathon.

He said charities like Fields in Trust were important because "everyone wants to build everywhere nowadays".

A DfE spokeswoman said the sale of sports fields would only be approved if the schools' need could still be met.

She said that 14 fields belonged to schools that had closed, four were sites that became surplus when existing schools amalgamated and one was spare "marginal grassland" on a school site, whose sale was invested in a new library and sports changing facilities. The other two were leased to clubs or companies that put the sites to other sporting uses.

“We will only agree to the sale of school playing fields if the sports and curriculum needs of schools and their neighbouring schools can continue to be met," she said.

"Sale proceeds must be used to improve sports or education facilities and any new sports facilities must be sustainable for at least 10 years.”

rank_134.title: Keep the flame alive: athletes and politicians swing behind campaign to build on the Olympics legacy
rank_134.text:
A chorus of sporting voices has swung behind the drive to improve sport in schools and communities following Britain’s success at the London Olympics.

Top athletes and politicians said Team GB’s performance must be seized on, and warned against allowing the legacy of the Games to be lost.

Teachers should bring back competition in every school and more people should volunteer at local sports clubs, they said.

Jessica Ennis, the gold medal-winning heptathlete, said children needed to learn that competition was positive.

David Cameron claimed that teachers “don’t want to join in” and ministers suggested that the medal success was unlikely to be repeated without a significant change.

Roger Black, the former Olympic athlete, argued that sport was not currently valued in schools, while champions including Sir Matthew Pinsent and Laura Trott spoke of the importance of funding for sports.

Tessa Jowell, the shadow Olympics minister, said all political parties should commit to a 10-year plan for sport to build on public enthusiasm for London 2012.

Young people face an obesity epidemic, with many offered few opportunities for the sort of competitive sports that used to be the norm. Only about four in 10 children regularly take part in such sports.

Many clubs are seeing a surge of interest from the young but do not have the resources to offer them the opportunities that could help produce future medal winners.

The Daily Telegraph today launches the Keep the Flame Alive campaign to increase volunteering and return competitive sport to all schools.

“I started doing athletics when I was nine years old,” Ennis said. “I had loads of support from my school and PE teachers.

“I think it’s really important to have great sport in schools and teach it well and obviously create great role models. That will make a huge, huge difference.” She said it was important to “teach kids that it is not a bad thing to be competitive” and that she hoped some of the thousands of volunteers and visitors to the Olympics would be inspired to help run local clubs.

The Prime Minister welcomed the campaign as attention would shortly turn to the legacy of the London Olympics, whose motto is “inspire a generation”. “For the moment everyone is revelling in a golden summer of British sport, with Britain showing the world what we can deliver in all sorts of ways,” said Mr Cameron. “But in a few days it will be time to focus on the legacy and I welcome the intervention and ideas of the Telegraph and its readers.”

Jeremy Hunt, the Culture, Media and Sport Secretary, said that action in schools and local communities was essential to the legacy of the Games.

“The Olympics have highlighted what a fantastic sporting nation Britain is and we want to harness that inspiration to ensure that more children take part in competitive sport,” he said.

“The past few weeks have shown the importance of competitive sport and we want to ensure it is at the heart of the legacy left behind after the Olympics.”

Labour added its support to the drive to protect the Olympic legacy, with Dame Tessa Jowell calling for a cross-party consensus on school sports and a ten-year plan to build on the public enthusiasm for the Games.

The Shadow Minister for the Olympics said it was time to put arguments about what happened in the past behind us and focus on the future.

The important question was “how do we get every child having sport as part of their lives and how do we get children competing for the sake not only of children developing their sporting potential but also for the read-across to other parts of children’s lives?” she told the BBC, adding: “Schools that major on sports often show better academic results.”

Ms Jowell said: "This has got to go all the way from the child coming into reception class in primary school, taking part in PE, right through to our extraordinary medallists.

"Chris Hoy is absolutely right, it has been the investment in elite training which has created stability for high performance training for those athletes. We have got to make sure that money continues."

Olympic athletes lined up to back the call for a change in culture. Michael Jamieson, silver medallist in the 200 metre breaststroke, said: “I started at a small community run club, Scotia, in Bishopbriggs, Glasgow, and all the coaches were volunteers. Without them I wouldn’t be here.”

Nick Dempsey, 31, who won a silver in windsurfing, added: “At the end of the day, sport is about competition and it’s about learning to deal with the emotions involved.”

However, there are concerns that schools will struggle to cope with the expected rise in interest in sport. Fatima Whitbread, the former world champion javelin thrower, said: “What concerns me is a sudden influx of young people coming into sports clubs and the schools are going to struggle.”

There were also suggestions that schools did not place enough emphasis on sport, which was often eclipsed by a focus on academic performance.

Black, who won a silver medal in the 400m in 1996, told ITV’s Daybreak programme: “We have to recognise the importance of sport to schools.

“The problem is sport is just way down the agenda when it comes to the time children spend at school. It’s just not taken seriously enough.”

The Government has already faced accusations that it was undermining sport with the potential removal of funding.

The Prime Minister insisted that simply spending more was not the solution. “The problem has been too many schools not wanting to have competitive sport, some teachers not wanting to join in and play their part,” Mr Cameron said.

“So if we want to have a great sporting legacy for our children — and I do — we have got to have an answer that brings the whole of society together to crack this, more competition, more competitiveness, more getting rid of the idea you can’t have competitive sports days. We need a big cultural change — a cultural change in favour of competitive sports.”

But for many athletes, funding has also been essential to their success.

Trott, the double gold cycling medallist, told The Independent: “Funding is very important – it is the key to our sport, really. We would be lost without it.”

And Sir Matthew, the Olympic rowing gold medallist, warned that funding cuts could hit swimming, gymnastics, equestrianism and triathlon, arguing that “the only solution is to give sport a higher priority.”

Writing in The Times, he said: “Perennially it is dismissed as a side issue in Whitehall, a little add-on in the Department of Culture and Media.”

But identifying talent “needs money and commitments from politicians who, far too often are used to making decisions that pay off while they are still in office,” he said.

Critics say that sport in state schools began to suffer in the 1980s, when councils started selling playing fields and industrial action by teachers’ unions resulted in staff refusing to run sports during lunch breaks or after hours.

Teachers said that the claim that they did not want to take part in school sports was “extremely rude” and that the biggest threat to physical education was cuts in funding. The National Union of Teachers called the Prime Minister’s comments “foolhardy”.

Alan Watkinson, the former PE teacher of Mo Farah, the 10,000m champion, said: “We need to look much broader than teachers.

“Successive governments have asked teachers to do more and more.

“Teachers work extremely hard. We need to look outside of that, we need to look at teaching assistants, people in administration roles, community and parents.”

Labour said the Government had removed a target for each child to do at least two hours’ sport a week. Ministers claimed it was an “unenforceable aspiration” that led to unnecessary red tape.

rank_32.title: Boris Johnson: London's Olympic legacy 'must harness Team GB momentum'
rank_32.text:
Boris Johnson, the Mayor of London, told journalists at a press conference into the legacy of London 2012, that it was time to "prepare, plan and work blindingly hard" in the manner of Britain's successful Olympians, in order to secure a positive lasting impact for the capital.

Claiming that the Olympics had allowed the British public to see themselves in a "new light", Mr Johnson said that this energy must be harnessed to do good, rather than to gloat.

"If we can take our cue from those Team GB athletes who have prepared and planned and worked so blindingly hard as they have over the last few years for this moment, then I think we can ensure the continued momentum of London 2012," he said.

rank_185.title: Olympic legacy: 10-year-plan needed to keep the flame alive, says Tessa Jowell
rank_185.text:
The plan would focus on schools but Ms Jowell echoed cycling gold medal hero Sir Chris Hoy's call to ensure funding for elite training continues.

Sir Chris's comments came after Culture Secretary Jeremy Hunt said he could not promise the funding would continue at its current level.

Ms Jowell told BBC Breakfast: ''This has got to go all the way from the child coming into reception class in primary school, taking part in PE, right through to our extraordinary medallists.

''Chris Hoy is absolutely right, it has been the investment in elite training which has created stability for high performance training for those athletes.

''We have got to make sure that money continues.''

Labour's Ms Jowell said there should be cross-party backing for a 10-year plan as schools that do a lot of sport also do well in other areas.

She said: ''Schools that do a lot of sport tend to have better behaviour, less truancy, more children arriving on time. Schools that major on sport show better academic results, often from a very low base.''

Ms Jowell also called on the Government to bring back the commitment to two hours of compulsory PE in primary schools.

She said: ''Let's get that commitment back because PE in primary schools, not taught by teachers who are busy doing other things, but taught by teachers who are trained to teach PE to children is absolutely essential.''

Of any potential plan, she said: ''We know how to do it, so let's work together and put that plan into action.

''In doing so we will realise the promise we made all those years ago in Singapore to inspire a generation and we will build on the huge public enthusiasm to take the spirit of the Games on into real life.''

rank_91.title: London 2012 Olympics: Free children to compete, urge Britain’s winners
rank_91.text:
Britain's leading Olympic athletes yesterday backed The Daily Telegraph’s campaign to return competitive sport to all schools and encourage people to volunteer at local clubs. This newspaper has launched Keep the Flame Alive to ensure a lasting legacy from the London Games, the most successful for British athletes in more than a century.

The campaign has already been backed by leading politicians and athletes including Jessica Ennis, the gold-medal winning heptathlete. Yesterday, more medal-winners added their voices.

Alistair Brownlee, who won gold in the triathlon, said: “One of the biggest things about legacy is that it’s not about money. It’s about the attitude. It’s about inspiring teachers at schools to go that little bit further to help their kids learn a sport. It’s about inspiring the kids themselves to try sport. I wholeheartedly back the Telegraph’s initiative.”

Louis Smith, who won a silver and a bronze in the gymnastics, said: “We have had volunteers in and out of the gym throughout my whole life – people who sacrifice their time to come in and help.”

He promised to volunteer after the Games. “I want to give so much back to the sport and really see how far we can take British gymnastics,” he said.

Paula Radcliffe, the women’s marathon world record holder, speaking at an Olympic legacy event in London, said: “The biggest failure that we made in sport in this country was stopping competitive sports in schools. That has to come back. All kids are competitive and it’s about channelling that and giving them an outlet for it.” She missed out on London 2012 because of a foot injury.

Cycling expects a particularly large increase in popularity following the extraordinary success of the British team. David Brailsford, head of British Cycling, said that volunteers were vital. “There have to be people running sport where parents feel confident that their kids can go there and they’re in good hands,” he said.

In an interview with today’s Daily Telegraph, Sir Chris Hoy discloses the important role played by his great uncle in encouraging amateur athletes, and urges others to follow suit. “He didn’t go on to be an Olympian but he was a world-class mile runner who came back from being a prisoner of the Japanese not the same as when he went out there,” said the six-times gold-medal winner.

“Then he started an athletics club in Carnoustie and inspired people to get into sport. He’s lived the life he’s had – an amazing life – because of sport, and he’s taken a lot of his enjoyment from seeing other people enjoy it too.”

rank_122.title: Keep the flame alive: The Olympic legacy and the new country we could be
rank_122.text:
Over and over again in the past two weeks, we have witnessed scenes reminiscent of those brightly coloured 1950s postcards or an illustration from a Ladybird book. Two tiny children stroking the nose of a police horse; a squirrel eating nuts from a soldier’s rucksack; a young man helping 80,000 people across the road.

London 2012 has, at times, seemed like a throwback to an older, gentler Britain, where kindness and generosity were the order of the day. There may be towering fences and huge steel roadblocks surrounding the Olympic venues, but in and around those compounds a different spirit has been allowed to flourish.

Never before in this century have you seen so many people draped in the British flag. It has become the fashion accessory of the moment, thrown elegantly over shoulders, tied around jeans, worn as a jaunty plastic bowler, painted on cheeks and nails, vigorously waved.

That adoption of the flag is more than superficial. It is a symbol of the pride that people have felt as the athletes on the track, the sailors and rowers, the dancing horses and their riders, the cyclists, the fighters and swimmers, have struggled and shone for Team GB. In turn, that slightly clumsy ad man’s phrase has come to feel like a truth: we are all in this together, a country united.

No wonder people’s attention has turned to legacy, to keeping these feelings alive when the Games have gone, and the Olympic flame is just a fading photograph, not a real cauldron. Just as inevitably, the second that politicians open their mouths, divisions that have been disguised open up. David Cameron says it is important to encourage competitive sport and that the Government is spending a billion doing just that. Ed Miliband points out that the Coalition has savagely cut the funding for the School Sport Partnerships, which linked state school pupils with professional coaches.

Both parries seem like political platitudes set against the immensity of the big picture that the 30th Olympiad has brought into focus. It is in that sense that Danny Boyle’s opening ceremony was so significant: a vision of a country where soldiers were important, but so were trade unionists; where town and country both had a role; where the family was central; where people were full of ideas and worked for the common good. It was an image of a value system as well as an entertainment.

So when we try to draw lessons from the Games, instead of bandying words around, we should pause, think and recall the moments we have witnessed, creating a kind of manifesto of memories which will stand us in good stead in the bleak months ahead.

One of our first acts should be to acknowledge something we knew but had half forgotten – that we are actually quite good at this kind of thing. We can build a huge temporary city within our capital, welcome thousands of extra visitors, and make it work.

Security has been tight, but it has never been overwhelming. Early-morning runners in Hyde Park could jog without being disrupted by the professionals undertaking the triathlon; normal life has gone on. Public transport has been stretched but continued to function. The flow system guiding more than 100,000 people from the Olympic Park to their various Tubes and trains is worthy of a Nobel prize.

That efficiency looks back to the past, but should continue. The Games have allowed Britain, almost for the first time in memory, to celebrate its history while acknowledging its rich multicultural present, which is now leading the way into the future. We have seen a country at ease with its past, capable of sticking a ritzy beach volleyball court in the middle of Horse Guards Parade, or its monarch in a sketch about a spy and a helicopter. But that narrative must also encompass the tolerance that welcomed Mo Farah when he arrived as a child from Somalia – and which has been rewarded with one of the best pictures of the Games, the sight of Britain’s greatest distance runner wrapped in a flag, hugging his wife and child, applauded to the skies.

The exploits of our sportsmen and women, the memories they have conjured, have been inspiring in all sorts of ways. After this Olympics, nobody can claim that women’s sports are second best. Every little girl who went to Wembley to see US v Japan, or caught a glimpse of the British women’s team’s valiant efforts on TV, will know once and for all that football doesn’t belong to blokes, it belongs to them as well. There are girls’ football leagues across Britain that should benefit.

As for Nicola Adams and her Irish counterpart, Katie Taylor, they have not only made redundant any arguments about the rightness of women boxing, they have also revealed their discipline in all its glory, as a sport of strength, speed and grace, not slugging in corners. Their legacy will be huge.

But the athletes have also offered a view of Britain as a complete society, North and South, rich and poor. On this team, the dressage gold-medal winner Charlotte Dujardin on her horse worth millions happily rubs shoulders with Louis Smith, the gymnast whose single mum drove him on a 52-mile round trip to the gym each day; Jessica Ennis, of mixed-race, working class stock from Sheffield, is a gold medal winner alongside Anna Watkins and Katherine Grainger, top-class scullers and studying for doctorates. All human life is here, whether it has subsisted on a diet of potatoes and pasta without funding, like Adams, or been fast-tracked to success.

In this context, the memories of the Games have to encompass those who have been excluded from the stadium as well as those lucky enough to get a ticket. Talent exists everywhere, in the estates of Hackney, Haringey and Salford, in suburban homes as well as on the lawns of public schools. If these Olympics are to be more than the bread and circuses claimed by the naysayers, then those gifts must be recognised and encouraged just as fiercely wherever they are found.

If children languishing in difficult circumstances can suddenly feel that they can change their lives, they can dream and have the means to fulfil those dreams, then the legacy of this Games will be immense.

But to do that they don’t just need politicians to stop point-scoring and start trying to make a practical difference on the ground in every impoverished and undernourished community. They also need the great silent majority who have revelled in the atmosphere of this Games to assert their sense of what living in a good community means. You nurture ability on the one hand, but on the other you must respect your fellow citizens.

In this sense, the abiding image of London 2012 has not been the triumphant smiles and tears of Bradley Wiggins, Sir Chris Hoy and the victorious cyclists, or the joy of the other medal winners; it has been the great, anonymous mass of volunteers, dressed in unflattering (but strangely welcoming) purple, pink and red, directing visitors around London. Some of the 70,000 have glimpsed the action inside the Olympic venues; others have done nothing more glamorous than direct human traffic at the transport hubs.

But they have done so with resolute cheerfulness and good will, bringing virtues of humour and irony to a task that has made their instructions a million miles from the meaningless “Have a good day”. At St Pancras, as the crowds waited for the super-fast Javelin train emblazoned with Rebecca Adlington’s name to take them to the Park, a young rail worker shouted through a megaphone: “You will not be allowed on the train without…”

Everyone bristled, waiting for some petty instruction. “…a smile on your face”. The entire platform broke out laughing.

It is a simple enough thing, but it has worked. For the duration of the Olympics, London has put a smile on its face. Britain has begun to remember the country it can be. In the hard times of recession ahead, when we are still trying to build for the future, the real legacy of the Games must be that determination to be generous to each other. Nurture talent, show respect and smile. Not a bad manifesto of memories.

rank_46.title: Boris Johnson tells David Cameron to 'go for growth' to harness Olympic legacy
rank_46.text:
In an interview with The Sunday Telegraph , Mr Johnson urged ministers to take bold steps on housing, infrastructure and regulation to take full advantage of the confidence and international respect hosting a successful games has won Britain.

For the past two weeks Mr Johnson has been basking in the reflected glory of an Olympic Games almost universally considered a rip-roaring success – at a time when the economy is labouring in recession, five years on from the start of the economic crisis.

“The most important thing about the Olympics is that they have shown that Britain really can do things,” the Mayor said. “We have shown the world we are a happy, ambitious, modern, successful economy.

"We have shown incredible logistical skills. We now have every reason to be in confident in ourselves and the future.”

But Mr Johnson said London – and Britain with it – still remains beset with barriers that stand in the way of economic growth and he seems unimpressed with the pace of the Coalition’s reforms.

“They need to go further,” Mr Johnson said of the Government. “They need a series of supply-side reforms. London really can be the motor of our economic recovery.”

The Mayor’s words echo the concerns of other leading lights of the Conservative Party. Many of the party’s Right wing – including Liam Fox, the former defence secretary - feel that the chancellor, George Osborne, and his fellow ministers are failing to deliver the business-friendly policies vital to power our debt-laden economy out of recession.

The Institute of Directors, a leading business lobby group has also attacked the “glacial speed” of Coalition’s reforms designed to encourage firms to hire and invest.

It is a claim denied by Coalition ministers including William Hague, the Foreign Secretary, who has argued that the Government has done a great deal to help the economy and that it’s up to businesses and individuals to get out there and make the recovery happen.

Stung by criticism that Government is not doing enough on growth, ministers are drawing up an economic regeneration bill for the autumn that will outline a range of new infrastructure projects and measures to cut business red tape.

Sorting out the congestion above London’s skies is a priority, the Mayor said.

“We need a new airport – whether it is in the Thames estuary or wherever, I don’t care. But we need to address that problem. An extra runway at Heathrow alone won’t do it – it would be full in a flash.”

Justine Greening, the Transport Secretary, was supposed to publish a new consultation document setting out the Government’s aviation strategy by mid-July, but this has been shelved until the autumn.

The delays are infuriating many in the business community keen to land deals in fast-growing emerging markets.

Mr Johnson also wants more river crossings in London, extra money to extend to tube lines and “Crossrail II”. The first of these new underground railways running beneath London is set to be completed in 2017.

As soon as the first Crossrail opens he wants work to begin on a second new line, running between Chelsea in the west and Hackney in the east.

The Mayor said more needs to be done and quickly to streamline Britain’s planning system to pave the way for a housing boom.

Earlier this year the Government published its National Planning Policy Framework which aimed to make it is easier for developers to build houses, but official figures suggest house building remains subdued.

“We need to build hundreds of thousands of new homes. If we invest in a huge building programme, put in a lot of public sector land, de-risk it for the developers and get the construction sector going again it will start to drive the economy.”

There is already a serious housing shortage in parts of London, but this situation could become acute by the next decade when London is expected to surpass New York as the world city with the highest population.

“London’s population is going to reach 9 million in the next decade,” he said. “People should not be paranoid about this – we are only now getting up to the levels reached in 1939 or 1911. There is room for great regeneration in the east.”

However, there needs to be jobs for this burgeoning population and the Mayor also insisted the Coalition must do more to make it easier for firms to hire and fire, especially for businesses with five workers or less.

Many on the Right of the Conservative Party remain dismayed that the Government failed to implement many bold recommendations made by the financier Adrian Beecroft in a Downing Street report on employment law reform.

In the last few weeks around 4,000 businessmen, foreign officials and other potential investors have shuffled into the Mayor’s Thameside offices where he has sold rundown parts of the capital – including Battersea Power Station, Brent Cross, Croydon and Tottenham – as lucrative investment opportunities.

The digital businesses Facebook and Amazon are set to create new jobs in the capital over the coming months, but only time will tell if more follow.

The critics may have fallen silent while Team GB was winning gold medals, but once the games end tonight the questions about their legacy will begin.

The futures of two of the Olympic Park’s venues – including the stadium – remain undecided.

Mr Johnson was typically bullish about the prospect of future Olympic champions learning their skills in the aquatic centre. Again, only time will tell if these grand building remain largely unused in the future.

Mr Johnson also spoke vigorously about the army of “games makers”, thousands of volunteers who have sprung to life across the City.

He sees these people as the embodiment of Mr Cameron’s Big Society. The London games apparently has a far higher retention rate of these volunteers than previous Olympic cities. Will these people remain on hand to encourage young Londoners to take up sport?

Of course, it will be years before it will be possible to say whether the 2012 games’ legacy was a success, by which time Mr Johnson will be doing a very different job. Conservative party leader or even Prime Minister, perhaps?

“Nonsense,” he roared in response to recent speculation that he is destined to replace Mr Cameron. “No serious student of politics could possible think that would happen.”

But they certainly do and the London Mayor knows full well that his part in these memorable Olympics will ensure such speculation will continue.

He said he will not contest a third term as London mayor, but was uncharacteristically pianissimo when asked about what he plans to do after the 2016 election.

He dismissed the current tensions within the Coalition as “classic midtermery” and can’t resist joking that the Games helpfully presented “a very good moment” to discreetly ditch House of Lords reform - something he sounds about as enthusiastic about as a spin on the Olympic BMX track.

He described his past two weeks as a “Himalayan range of exciting peaks”. “I’ve been on my feet absolutely yelling,” he said.

“I’d never been to a velodrome before. That was great. That sort of ritual the cyclists do like mating pigeons waggling their bottoms – I love it.”

That’s not to say he doesn’t have a few regrets about the past couple of weeks.

“I won’t be trying to get on a zip wire again in a hurry,” he puffs, recalling the well-publicised gaffe which saw the accident-prone London mayor suspended high above a London park.

“Although in a way that was successful – it massively increased the popularity of the Victoria Park zip wire from a very low base.”

He also seemed abashed that one of his savvy media advisors “quashed” a guest appearance in Twenty Twelve, the BBC spoof documentary about the London Olympics’ organisers.

Was there in any truth in the show’s depiction of a gaggle of bumbling bureaucrats, some of whom seemed to be competing for a gold medal in political correctness?

“Oh it was absolutely truthful. The endless conversations about inclusivity, sustainability, multiculturality, posterity…”.

He then erupted into giggles. “We had a lot of that. And the makers seemed to know some things that we were doing that weren’t public. But there will be no mole hunt.”

He used a typical “BoJo” turn of phrase to describe a meeting with Laura Trott, the double gold medal winning poster girl of cycling - a phrase which given his well-documtened personal life suggests he is still willing to sail close to the wind despite the added profile the Olympics.

“I’ve got a date with Laura Trott,” he said of the 20-year-old gold medal-winning cyclist who has agreed to front an annual London two-day festival of cycling, the first of which is set to take place next summer.

“She’s going to teach me how to ride one of those carbon fibre bikes. I watched her win the Omnium – wow. She is like a whippet. And you meet her and she’s tiny.

"You can’t understand where the speed comes from. And she’s very charming, blonde and all the rest of it.”

Charming, blond, all the rest of it - now who else could that be?

rank_210.title: London 2012 Olympics: Great Britain men's hockey team miss out on bronze after 3-1 loss to Australia
rank_210.text:
Great Britain were not only playing for a place on the Olympic rostrum but also pride as just 48 hours before they had been subjected to a humiliating 9-2 defeat by Holland — their heaviest loss on record and one that risked becoming an unwanted Olympic legacy.

The question on everyone's mind was: could they come back from such an experience?

Could they show the same fight they did when they turned a 3-0 deficit into a 3-3 draw in their pool match against Australia?

Could they overcome a side they have beaten just five times in 48 attempts?

The answer was no, but while there was no medal, it was a performance to be proud of and the best Olympic finish for a British men’s hockey team since they won gold at Seoul 1988.

“I’m glad we’re not leaving on the 9-2 that’s for sure,” Lee said afterwards.

“We had a bad taste in our mouths about the semi-final result and wanted to come into this and play like ourselves and I think we delivered that.

“We had aspirations and dreams of a medal and against the world No 1 it was daunting for us to play this game but I’m really just relieved the players’ lasting signature won’t be that result on Thursday.”

Lee had warned that Australia were a more attacking side than the Dutch, but in the early stages James Fair had little to contend with in GB’s goal.

That, together with flashes of creativity in attack, made for an impressive opening period.

For their part, Australia were uncharacteristically scrappy in the early stages. Matthew Butturini struggled to keep simple passes in play while five time player of the year Jamie Dwyer was kept quiet by Iain Lewers.

If anything Australia were lucky to go ahead after 18 minutes when Simon Orchard struck from the top of the area.

On Thursday, Holland’s first goal marked the start of a mauling but GB were calm and patient and their approach paid off 10 minutes later when the first penalty corner was awarded after the ball clipped Fergus Kavanagh in the area.

It was a sublime set piece. As expected, the feed went to Jackson who dummied his strike before sweeping the ball left where Iain Lewers was waiting to convert.

Little separated the sides but it all changed 11 minutes after the break when Australia called on the video umpire claiming the ball had struck Harry Martin’s foot on a clearance.

The decision went their way and a penalty corner was given — the first of three in as many minutes.

The first two were cleared but the third was tapped in by Dwyer on the left post. From this point, Australia’s attack was relentless and struck again 13 minutes from time when Kieran Govers tapped in a deflected striker. The medal belonged to Australia.

When asked if he would lead the team to the 2016 Games in Rio, Lee said: “It’s iffy to be honest. I’m low on energy and I’ve found this very challenging. I’ve given my heart and soul to coaching for 25 years and there have been tears of joy and ocean of heartache. It’s been emotional but a very special time with great memories.”

Great Britain: G Kirkham, A Jackson, J Clarke, R Moore, B Hawes, B Middleton (c), J Tindall, I Lewers, J Fair (GK), D Fox, R Smith. Subs: H Martin, M Daly, A Wilson, I Mackay, N Catlin.

Australia: J Dwyer, L De Young, S Orchard, G Turner, C Ciriello, M Knowles, E Ockenden ( c), J Carroll, M Gohdes, N Burgers (GK), F Kavanagh Subs: M Butturini, R Ford, T Deavin, M Swann, K Govers.

Umpires: C Blasch (Germany), G Simmonds (South Africa).

rank_168.title: Olympic Park should be kept as a sports training centre for the young
rank_168.text:
SIR – The Olympic Park should not be dismantled but used as a sport and education camp for the nation's most promising school athletes. It should be a place where they could be sent for intensive coaching while continuing their education for varying periods.

Discussions about the future of sport in Britain should, moreover, be apolitical. David Cameron has made promises and Ed Miliband, the Labour leader, has already started to quibble.

SIR – God forbid that all children in our schools be pressed into competitive sports. Many of us recall the pain of being dragooned into teams only then to suffer the humiliation of being hopelessly inadequate.

Those who preferred the co-operative and creative to the competitive seem to have grown up as well-adjusted, committed team workers, able to perform at least as well in life as sports achievers.

John Smallwood

West Auckland, Co Durham

SIR – Shall we now be unafraid to acknowledge that we're good, or will there be a reversion to carping? I'm proud to be British – are you?

Elizabeth Biggs-Poyner

Harborough Magna, Warwickshire

SIR – The outstanding success of the competitors from Great Britain and Northern Ireland has been backed up by the excellent performance of the volunteers and the men and women of the British Armed Services. The good humour, efficiency and dedication shown by both groups has been a notable feature of these wonderful Games.

Lt Col Paul French (retd)

Andover, Hampshire

SIR – As we search for an Olympic legacy, the challenge is to harness a spirit of participation to tackle social problems. The National Citizen Service, of which we are the largest provider, is this summer bringing together 30,000 young people from very different backgrounds to promote long-term involvement in their local communities.

The fantastic army of Olympic volunteers has shown what is possible. We must use this spirit and sense of purpose to inspire a generation to feel they have a stake in society and take responsibility for their communities.

Craig Morley

The Challenge Network

London SE1

SIR – The Prime Minister has rightly shown that we cannot only stage the greatest Olympics in history, but that our nation believes in an Olympic legacy that is about more than arenas ("Mo's next goal is to wipe out child hunger", report, August 13).

On Sunday, David Cameron shone a spotlight on one of the biggest crises the world shares: that, despite there being enough food in the world to feed everyone, one in seven people goes to bed hungry every night and more than two million children die from malnutrition each year.

We applaud the Prime Minister's commitment to focus on this issue at next year's G8 summit in Britain. With the leadership of Mr Cameron and his counterparts, the millions of lives it could save would be the greatest legacy the Games could ever leave.

Richard Miller

Executive Director, ActionAid

Chris Bain

Director, Cafod

Loretta Minghella

Director, Christian Aid

Rose Caldwell

Executive Director, Concern Worldwide (UK)

Stephen Brown

UK Campaigns Manager, Global Poverty Project

Penny Lawrence

Acting Chief Executive, Oxfam GB

Tim Aldred

Head of Policy, Progressio

Justin Forsyth

Chief Executive

Save The Children UK

Matthew Frost

Chief Executive, Tearfund

David Bull

Executive Director, UNICEF UK

SIR – At the start of the Olympic closing ceremony, shown on Lewisham council's big screen, 3,000 south-east Londoners spontaneously leapt to their feet and stood for the national anthem.

I didn't know whether to be proud or sheepish, since it was the indifference of my generation that killed off this public show of respect, once common in cinemas.

Alex McIntosh

London SE3

SIR – In view of the resurgence of patriotism during the Olympics, may we have Britannia back on our coins?

Geoffrey Bishop

Malvern Wells, Worcestershire

SIR – The closing ceremony was touching and amusing. But roller-skating nuns? You've got me there.

Greg Morris

London SE4

SIR – It just goes to show that you don't need alcohol to enjoy a good party.

Janie Binns

Bramhall, Cheshire

SIR – Now that more than 17 per cent of the British population is over 65, and we are exhorted to work until we are 70, it was fitting for the Olympics to close with My Generation sung by Pete Townshend (67) and Roger Daltrey (68). But I didn't hear the line: "Hope I die before I get old."

Graham Masterton

Tadworth, Surrey

SIR – Two weeks of aspiration, inspiration and acclamation, then who do we get? George Michael, Kate Moss, Naomi Campbell and Russell Brand.

Andy Barnett

Foulsham, Norfolk

SIR – If Russell Brand is the walrus, I'm a gnu.

Simon Baumgartner

Hampton, Middlesex

SIR – I enjoyed the closing ceremony, but when trying to show off the best of British why do we put centre stage people known to have taken drugs?

What message are we sending out to the generation we are trying to inspire?

Yvonne Findlay

London SW5

SIR – After the first hour, I lost the will to live and would even have welcomed good old Cliff Richard driving a London bus with Vera Lynn as a clippie. There was virtually no traditional music that represented England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland.

Janet Turner

Frome, Somerset

SIR – As Jessie J was in mid-screech I turned to my husband and said: "I don't think I can stand any more of this."

We switched the television off and the sound of silence was the best thing we had heard all night.

June Green

Bagshot, Surrey

SIR – Thank goodness for Eric Idle, is all I have to say.

Alison Gibson

Holdingham, Lincolnshire

SIR – During my Army career I won various medals and trophies, mainly for football and shooting.

To my eternal shame, not once did I manage to shed any tears. Should I seek medical advice?

Donald McKenzie

Kelso, Scottish Borders

SIR – Sir Chris Hoy took the record as the British Olympian with most gold medals from Sir Steve Redgrave. Mo Farah became the first British winner of the 10,000 and 5,000 metres at the same Olympiad. All celebrate their birthdays on March 23. Just a coincidence?

J R Kingston

Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire

SIR – By my calculation, countries that have the Queen as their sovereign won 47 gold medals against 46 for the United States.

Francis Dobbyn

Semington, Wiltshire

SIR – Does anyone else find it strange that, in these days of integration and equality, the Olympics and Paralympics are still two completely separate entities?

It seems to me to be degrading for the thousands of competitors in the Paralympics that all the talk is about the Olympics being over. Their time is about to start. Could there be complete integration within our lifetime?

Claire Walker

Leeds, West Yorkshire

SIR – We should not overlook the security services. That there has been no terrorist act or loss of life is undoubtedly due to their unseen activities, which cover us at all times.

Alan Tyler

Surbiton, Surrey

SIR – I'm in my early fifties, reasonably fit and now longing to take part in the Rio Olympics.

What discipline should I go for to get me there?

Lesley Walford

Pewsey, Wiltshire

rank_67.title: Keep the Flame Alive: Pele sets his sights on Olympic legacy
rank_67.text:
The former Brazil striker, who is often cited as the greatest ever footballer, is the face of the Rio 2016 Games.

After retiring, he has carried out humanitarian work and acted as an ambassador for a number of charities, including Unicef.

He is also likely to have a starring role in promoting the next Olympics in his home nation.

The legendary footballer featured in the Brazilian segment at the Closing Ceremony as Mayor of London Boris Johnson handed over the Games to his counterpart in Rio de Janeiro, Eduardo Paes.

Speaking after the Daily Telegraph launched its Keep The Flame Alive campaign to secure a legacy of volunteering and competitive sport in schools, Pelé said the Games could set an example.

“Sport is something that is very inspirational for young people,” he said.

“For me, I want people to remember me not as a great player, but as a role model and a humanitarian, and for what I try to do for the new generation.

“In my position, I want to set a good example for the younger generation, and I believe the Olympics is a platform that can help do just that.”

Last week, Pelé announced a four-year deal with media agency MediaCom Sport as the competition for branding and sponsorship for the next Games begins.

The contract is likely to lead to Pelé featuring in TV adverts and product endorsements as well as signing lucrative sponsorship deals.

The 71-year-old said he was looking forward to representing his country on the world stage once again.

“I believe the 2016 Olympics is an important and great opportunity for Brazil,” he said. “Not only for the sport, but also for Brazil as a country. And, most importantly, these events will inspire the new generation.”

rank_71.title: Sir Steve Redgrave: Competitive sport is all very well but helping every child reach their potential must be Britain's Olympic legacy
rank_71.text:
In this post-Games glow, we need to be able to engage more with children passionate about sport, to harness the phenomenal enthusiasm generated during the past 2½ weeks, but we cannot be sure of being successful just by creating extra competition.

While I am never one to shy away from being competitive, the encouragement of young people towards sport has to be done in the right way.

Sport should not be portrayed to them just in terms of winners and losers. Children should not be made to think that whoever crosses the finishing line first is rewarded, while another who is not the most talented can never hope for a certificate to mark a sporting achievement.

The Olympics are all about being the best you can be. None of us should forget that even those who have come away from London without gold medals are winners already, because they represent the best from their countries.

The people who finish last are still outstanding athletes in their own right, and this is the message we need to convey to young people: that they should always feel they are moving forward, that their sporting activity is a part of their lives and stays with them for the rest of their lives.

As has been demonstrated by Britain’s remarkable accomplishments at London 2012, we need to widen the potential areas of success, not narrow them.

It concerns me, too, that by over-stressing the competitive side, we might be scaring off people who struggle with coordinated skills. My own sport, rowing, is highly coordinated.

As I was never the most academic pupil at Great Marlow comprehensive, I was fortunate to be persuaded to take it up at 14 by my English teacher, whose interest was rowing. But I recognise that a lot of youngsters do not have the same co-ordination, and that their abilities still need to be maximised.

I am the chairman of a company called Personal-Best International, which has been driven by the conviction that people are capable of far more than they believe, that everybody can achieve a personal best.

This is the ethos we should impart to children committed to sport. But we must also make the most of our talent identification schemes.

In 2007, as president of UK Sport’s Sporting Giants programme, I sent out a message in a newspaper to girls who were at least 5ft 9in tall: “Do you want to be a part of 2012? Would you like to be going for medals at the Olympic Games?”

Helen Glover was one of the people we discovered, and she has just won Olympic gold for Britain in the women’s pair.

I conveyed my views about the direction of Government policy to David Cameron during the Olympics, and I am hoping to arrange a further meeting with him after the Paralympics. But in the meantime, with most schools on summer holidays, it is up to our sports clubs to engage with the new-found interest in sport. A great deal of expectation is invested in these clubs.

Daley Thompson is right when he says there are going to be a lot of children knocking on doors wanting to take up sport, but are there going to be enough coaches to meet the interest?

At rowing clubs, there are so many people on waiting lists. Being inspired by what you have seen in London and then ending up on a waiting list is not a great start in anybody’s sporting life. This is where coaching education programmes become significant.

The change we have witnessed at these Olympics should not be underestimated.

We have reinvented ourselves from a nation of plucky losers to one of proud winners, and on the back of that we must make sure that the concept of legacy really does mean something.

What could make a profound difference is the way our women have performed. We are all aware that there is a substantial drop-off in the number of teenage girls pursuing physical activity when they leave secondary school, and this is where the gold medals for Jessica Ennis and Katherine Grainger, for example, could have a bearing.

Their achievements can spread an attitude that it is no longer ‘uncool’ for girls to take up sport.

So it is up to the Government and UK Sport, and all the potential agents of change, to grasp the momentum. Our female Olympians have enjoyed huge success across all manner of events – in rowing alone, they outdid the guys by three golds to one.

Why not, then, create a catch-all programme that involves girls across the whole spectrum of sport?

We could be reaping the benefits of such a scheme for decades. I sense that there is the political will, but we have to act now, to seize a fabulous moment for British sport and deliver on our promise to inspire a generation.

rank_59.title: Good News Britain: Balfour Beatty builds bridges for London Olympics legacy
rank_59.text:
In recent weeks the excitement and pride in the success of Team GB at The Olympic Games has been palpable around the country. Rightly so; the years of rigorous planning, training, and dedication, culminating in some truly outstanding performances should be an inspiration to us all.

The Team GB athletes have exceeded all expectations and they deserve the accolades of the entire nation, as do the host of Games Makers, whose passion and enthusiasm infected all those they engaged with.I am sure the Paralympic Games will provide a platform for yet more inspirational performances.

But long after the Games have ended, the permanent venues of the Olympic Park will stand as testament, not only to these sporting achievements, but also to another area where Britain truly leads the world. I’m talking about the creation of civil infrastructure.

And here I believe the Park will stand for decades to come as a 'world trade fair’ of British design and construction skills – our ability to produce unforgettable, unique structures on time and on budget.

The firm that I lead, Balfour Beatty, brought to life the iconic aquatics centre design of

Zaha Hadid. We did it ahead on time and on budget. And more than that, by integrating our design and engineering expertise with our construction skills, we transformed the environmental footprint of the building.

Our innovative approach to planning and sequencing throughout the construction process reduced the use of hardwood and steel without compromising the integrity of the building.

After the games are over, the temporary seating structures that form the 'wings’ of the building will be removed and the walls of the core structure will be completed creating an enduring aquatics facility that many thousands are expected to benefit from in the future.

Balfour Beatty will continue to manage and operate the building, as well as the rest of the Park, helping to fulfil the potential of the Olympic legacy.

Using the same planning processes and assumptions we built innovative bridges that span the river that meanders around the park. These bridges provide access to the Olympic Stadium for the millions of visitors attending the Games.

Of course once the events are over, visitors will continue to enjoy the wonderful parkland that has been created around the sports facilities but in much smaller numbers.

So our bridges were designed specifically so that they can be easily narrowed to be more in keeping with visitor numbers expected in the post-Olympic era.

The Olympics have shown Britain at its very best. The Games have been a huge success for our athletes and it is right that the government should make every effort to build on this success and create an enduring legacy in sport. For me, it has also showcased the capabilities of the British construction and engineering industry that collectively delivered these great venues. Working alongside the good management of the Government, our key stakeholder and in partnership with each other, we have delivered some of the most complex designs ever seen in the UK – this is something our industry, and nation, should be proud of.

The government should not miss the opportunity to crystallise a positive economic legacy through the development of civil infrastructure projects. Perhaps they should host a trade summit there – while the memory of the wonderful XXX Olympiad is still fresh in everyone’s minds.

Ian Tyler is the chief executive of Balfour Beatty

rank_197.title: Keep the flame alive: Olympics inspires nation to volunteer
rank_197.text:
Eight times as many adults said they were more likely to help to give their time to local sporting clubs or schools after the successful Games.

The goodwill follows a wave of national pride at the achievements of Team GB and praise for the smooth organisation of the Olympics.

David Cameron has hailed the efforts of the 70,000 “Games Makers”, who volunteered to staff sports venues free, as essential to making the Olympics so successful.

The Daily Telegraph has launched the Keep the Flame Alive campaign to secure a lasting legacy for the London 2012 Games, with an increase in volunteering at local sports clubs.

A poll of 1,896 adults older than 18, conducted this week by Opinium Research, found that a quarter (24 per cent) were “more likely” to consider volunteering as a result of the Olympics.

Support was higher among younger people, with more than a third (35 per cent) of 18-34 year-olds saying they were slightly or much more likely to consider volunteering at sports clubs or schools or assisting other good causes.

Only three per cent of respondents said they were less likely to help after the Olympics, while those older than 55 were less likely than younger groups to consider giving up more of their time.

Sir Stuart Etherington, the chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations, welcomed the findings. He said: “London 2012 has ignited interest in volunteering and community action across the population.

“It’s particularly heartening that the goal to 'Inspire a Generation’ is so far on target.

“People volunteer for a wide range of reasons but some of the most common motivations are feeling that you are making a difference, working as a team and feeling that you are part of something.

“The task ahead is to build on this enthusiasm and energy in the long term, and ensure that everyone gets the most out of their experiences and knows what opportunities are available to them locally.”

According to government figures, about four in 10 people volunteer to help community organisations at least once a year, with a quarter volunteering once a month or more.

The Telegraph/Opinium poll found wide variations across the country, with adults in the South East twice as likely as those in the East Midlands to say the Olympics had inspired them to consider volunteering.

When the results were analysed by the regions, respondents living in Northern Ireland (32 per cent), London (30 per cent) and Yorkshire and Humberside (27 per cent) were more likely to consider volunteering than those in the East Midlands (11 per cent) and Wales (18 per cent).

Mr Cameron said this week the Games confirmed that Britain was “a great volunteering nation”.

He praised the “passion and professionalism” of the 70,000 Olympic volunteers for making the Games a “monumental success”.

Tim Lamb, chairman of the Sport and Recreation Alliance, representing 150,000 amateur sports clubs, said the results were “massively encouraging”.

“Community sport simply wouldn’t be able to function without volunteers, and we rely on their commitment to ensure that local clubs thrive,” he said.

“Volunteer retention is a problem for 53 per cent of sports clubs and the average club needs some 20 volunteers in order to function.

“The strong response from young people is particularly encouraging, as they are key to ensuring we maximise the potential of this Olympic legacy.”

rank_211.title: England's 2015 Rugby World Cup tries to learn the lessons of London's glorious 2012 Olympic Games
rank_211.text:
Paul Vaughan, chief executive of England 2015, effectively the Rugby Football Union’s organising committee for the tournament, was all over the Olympics for insights and ideas, and he loved the experience. No traffic, wonderful volunteers, great atmosphere, sensational competition. What’s not to like?

But the trouble with the Olympics is that they have raised expectations, expectations which rugby has to meet if Vaughan is to deliver his, and his team’s, ambition of “staging the best Rugby World Cup ever”.

“The scale of the Olympics is so much bigger,” Vaughan explains. “We can’t compete with that. The Olympics involved 36 separate sports played out in multiple venues, but focusing mainly on the Olympic Park. We are a single sport running across 10 to 12 venues over 6½ weeks. The look and feel of our competition will be quite different.

“What we have is the passion of one sport and we have to market that. The Rugby World Cup is the world’s third largest event if you look at it in terms of viewership and attendance.

“The Olympics had 10,500 athletes, the Paralympics has 4,000. We have 20 teams, so there is a big switch of emphasis.”

That is the tricky bit right there. How to make the experience memorably unique. In 2011 New Zealand tugged the heart strings and sold the World Cup as a stadium of four million awash, engulfed, engorged by rugby. For the best part of seven weeks New Zealand offered total immersion. Turn on a mid-morning television cookery show and it was Rugby World Cup themed.

England cannot do that. The tournament will be up against football’s Premier League and it will take place in a context which is far more diverse and diffuse.

Vaughan’s strategy is to go big and to tap into the life experiences which he believes rugby offers. “We will have a capacity of 2.9 million tickets, which we expect to sell out,” he says. “New Zealand sold 1.4 million tickets, so we will effectively be double their size. That gives us the ability to maintain reasonable ticket prices.

“ We believe in some of the pool games we will deliver ticket prices starting below £10. Our size also allows us to expose more people to the game and allow more fans to get to games.”

And life experiences? “We’re very aware that rugby is more than 80 minutes. It’s a whole day out, or, if people are coming in from abroad, a sort of tour. It’s all about community. You make friends. Win or lose, you can still have a beer. For us, it’s about being inclusive, about celebration, about how we inspire people. Most importantly, though, it’s about a sport about which a huge number of people are passionate.”

And it is not all just about the delivery. An ‘appropriate’ legacy is the current justification for the millions pumped into major sporting events, and the Rugby World Cup will be no different. “A lot of the Olympic legacy is in infrastructure and buildings, the regeneration of a chunk of east London, and how the sports themselves manage growth from the event,” Vaughan says.

“Our legacy will be primarily about human and intellectual capital. We’re trying to drive more people into the game on the back of the World Cup either to play, referee, coach, volunteer or spectate. We’re also going to invite representatives of the less well developed rugby nations to come to the tournament and place them with Premiership clubs.

“We hope they will benefit from seeing how rugby is administered here. Spain and Portugal have about 20,000 players each, but they do need assistance in terms of their administration.”

A few years back, during the bitter civil war which ransacked the English rugby scene, the thought of anyone learning anything worthwhile about running the sport was laughable, but there is less rancour around now. If there is a touch of colonialism about the strategy, big blazer helping the little blazers to be more efficient and effective, then at least it is well-intentioned and deliverable.

One thing, though, which will not be happening is an opening ceremony of Olympian scale. Rugby World Cups have always disappointed in that regard.

In Cardiff in 1999 the tournament was framed by a parade of so-called home-grown greats, many of whom went unrecognised in Penarth a few miles down the road let alone the major rugby cities of the world.

New Zealand’s was some wishy-washy Maori affair which looked fine on television but was impenetrable from the stadium itself. And the RFU? Their track record is not great either. It is normally a toss up between the military abseiling from the Twickenham roof or a regimental goat leading a marching band. My favourite is the goat.

“We’re working on that,” Vaughan acknowledges. “The Olympics has a budget of £27 million for the curtain raiser which was a ticketed event in its own right. They then spent a week turning the venue back into an athletics stadium. We’ve got a match on the same day in the same stadium, so we are thinking about doing it differently.”

Good luck to him with that, and good luck on following an experience as sumptuous, as intimate and as compelling as the Olympics. If Rugby World Cup 2015 is just half as good, then we are in for a treat.

rank_50.title: Parents need to get involved to ensure Olympic legacy, athletics clubs say
rank_50.text:
Athletics clubs have been “inundated” with enquiries from young people wanting to take up sport since Team GB came third in the Olympics medal table. Over the weekend an estimated 250,000 people turned up at open days at 6,000 sports events across Britain.

However sports and athletics clubs have warned that without more adults willing to act as volunteers, they will struggle to cope with the demand. They called for people to donate more time behind the scenes if the Olympics is to have any lasting legacy.

Parents are the most likely source of volunteering. Many of Team GB's gold medalists thanked their parents for the help they gave and the sacrifices they made.

Bill Adcocks, secretary of the Coventry Godiva Harriers athletics club, said that for the first time in the club’s 133-year history it has had to introduce a waiting list for young athletes

“The reason is that we don’t have enough coaches… We have 110 new members every year, most of which are young, and we welcome them with open arms. But at the other end if you’re going to have them you’ve got to have the people and infrastructure to do that,” said Mr Adcocks.

A spokesman for Join In Local Sport, which organised the weekend’s 6,000 events, said that the Olympics legacy risks being watered down due to a lack of volunteers.

“A limiting factor [to the legacy] is not the number of kids at the door it’s the number of adults who are willing to help out.

“One of our main focuses has been about making sure that we don’t just have a sporting legacy to London 2012 but we have a volunteering legacy too,” he said.

The Daily Telegraph has started the Keep the Flame Alive campaign to boost school sport following the success of the London Olympics.

Gold medalists such as Mo Farah and Greg Rutherford, the long-jumper, turned out at events yesterday to help build a sporting and volunteering legacy after the Olympics.

Maureen Shirley, membership secretary of Barnet & District Athletic Club in north London, said the club had been “inundated” with emails and phone calls from people wanting to take up sport since the Olympics ended.

“I have had a lot of enquiries from sprinters. A lot of that is inspired by people watching Usain Bolt,” she said.

Although the club should be able to cope with the increased demand, Ms Shirley said there needs to be more investment in “grass roots” athletics.

“Everybody is volunteers and this is what people sometimes do not realise. Amateur athletics clubs are run by volunteers,” she said.

The Join in Local Sport spokesman said that as well as coaches, athletics clubs need accountants, drivers and administrators.

“For people to end up on a podium there are hundreds and thousands of volunteers behind the scenes who give up their time. Those are roles that nobody ever hears about,” he said.

Coventry Godiva Harriers’ Mr Adcocks estimated that for the four track and field gold medals won by Team GB athletes, there were 150,000 volunteers beneath them.

“It was only four people in GB team of about 80 that won gold medals. You put another slice of people underneath that. You have most likely got 150,000 [people] involved in that,” he said.

Eddie Izzard, the comedian, called for a “new beginning” in sports clubs.

He said much of the Olympics’ success was down to the “largest volunteer force this country has seen since World War Two”.

In a video posted on the Join in Local Sport website, Mr Izzard said: “This must not be the end of all this enthusiasm and energy, it must be new beginning.”

He praised volunteers in sports club who “put the cones out”, make the tea, and do the washing.

The Join In Trust is chaired by Sir Charles Allen, a founder member of the London Olympics 2012 bid team and mayor of the Athletes’ Village, is hoping to attract a new wave of adult volunteers to keep local sporting clubs going.

Despite the shortage of adult helpers, some people have been a little too enthusiastic. Ms Shirley of Barnet & District Athletic Club said that one parent had tried to enroll their six-year-old child in a 5 kilometre run.

“We have had some parents who are unrealistic with very young children,” she said.

rank_40.title: London 2012 Olympic Games: Minority sports channel planned
rank_40.text:
London Legacy will make its debut in around three months, showing 24 Olympic sports that “just don’t get enough sports coverage” on the major channels.

John Fairley, chairman of Highflyer Group, the company behind the new channel, said the combination of a fall in production costs and an increase in interest in niche sports meant there was an “enormous opportunity” to make money from televising them.

“The amount on athletics on the main channels has been very small, especially when you think of all the disciplines within athletics, but the Games has changed all that,” he said. “We have had two or three companies, including one Olympic sponsor, make very serious undertakings [to back the channel] in the last week. The Games have changed all that."

London Legacy will focus heavily on athletics, gymnastics and judo, but handball, fencing, track cycling and wrestling will also receive substantial airtime. Coverage of championships will be mixed with programmes offering “masterclasses” or showing viewers how they can get involved.

“The number of participants in these sports is already very high - a sport like judo has more than 40,000 [in the UK], many of them women and many of those under 16. There is this enormous opportunity...and no sign that any of the main broadcasters is going to pick it up and run with it,” Mr Fairely said.

The channel will initially launch on Sky and is also expected to air on other platforms in the future. The launch will cost £5.5m.

The London Olympic Games was the most watched sporting event in Britain on record, according to BBC figures. More than 50m people in Britain, nearly 90pc of the total population, watched at least 15 minutes of coverage over the two-week period. The Opening and Closing Ceremonies drew the biggest audiences, closely followed by Usain Bolt’s victory in the 100m final.

However, lower profile events also attracted substantial audiences.

More than 24m people watched the Games using the BBC’s red button service, which enabled viewers to choose from 24 events not being shown on the main channels, by pressing a button on their remote controls. Less well-known sports such as judo and gymnastics were often annexed in this way.

Separately, Channel 4 said demand for its advertising slots during the Paralympic Games was ahead of expectations and that those around the Paralympic Opening Ceremony were “sold out”.

The broadcaster, which paid around £5m for the exclusive rights to air the games, saw revenues for its flagship channel fall by £19.5m to £622.1m last year as its share of the advertising market shrank. Overall revenues for thegroup rose from £935.2m to £941.4m.

rank_96.title: Olympics' closing ceremony, tuition fees and inspiring our youth
rank_96.text:
SIR – Two weeks of aspiration, inspiration and acclamation, then who do we get? George Michael, Kate Moss, Naomi Campbell and Russell Brand.

SIR – After the first hour, I lost the will to live and would even have welcomed good old Cliff Richard driving a London bus with Vera Lynn as a clippie. There was virtually no traditional music that represented England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland.

SIR – I enjoyed the closing ceremony, but when trying to show off the best of British why do we put centre stage people known to have taken drugs?

What message are we sending out to the generation we are trying to inspire?

Yvonne Findlay, London SW5

SIR – If Russell Brand is the walrus, I’m a gnu.

Simon Baumgartner, Hampton, Middlesex

SIR – Thank goodness for Eric Idle, is all I have to say.

Alison Gibson, Holdingham, Lincolnshire

Olympic legacy

SIR – There are millions of Brits around the world who would have appreciated access to the reported UK-biased presentation of the Olympic Games.

The coverage by the BBC World News TV service was less adequate than it could have been.

To partially rectify the situation, could the BBC produce a summation from all the footage that was churned out for the home front? A series of hourly programmes over the next few weeks would be ideal, but even just a couple of one-hour shows would be very welcome.

Brian Hughes, Vancouver, Canada

SIR – Arrangements should be made by the London Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, after the Paralympics, for the millions of Britons who could not afford to buy tickets for the Olympics but who would be thrilled to see inside the main London venues.

People visiting the venues would help to “Keep the Flame Alive”. Such a project needs to be put into action to capitalise on the excitement engendered by the Games.

Ron Kirby, Dorchester

SIR – Does anyone else find it strange that, in these days of integration and equality, the Olympics and Paralympics are still two completely separate entities?

It seems to me to be degrading for the thousands of competitors in the Paralympics that all the talk is about the Olympics being over. Their time is about to start. Could there be complete integration within our lifetime?

Claire Walker, Leeds, West Yorkshire

SIR – The very successful London Olympic Games has drawn renewed attention to the immense expenditure of hosting these events.

Although a case can be made for getting all the world’s greatest athletes together on one occasion, this is becoming increasingly impractical for most cities or even countries. Given the state of the world economy and national indebtedness, there is increased risk of financial disaster for the host country.

Already the Olympics are divided into summer and winter sports. I suggest the games be divided into four annual events, held over a four-year cycle. The winter games would remain as it is. The summer games would be divided into three, loosely labelled water games, indoor games and outdoor games.

Reducing the scope of each Games would, by reducing the costs, enable smaller countries to host them, and provide a major sporting event on an annual basis.

David K.C. Cooper, Pittsburgh, US

SIR – What can we do to reward Lord Coe for his sterling work on the London Olympics? He is a Lord, so we have already ennobled him.

I suggest that he would make an excellent Mayor of London, and that would free Boris to go to the Commons.

Leon Rose, Stockport

Boundaries battle

SIR – The Liberal Democrats are being naive and short-sighted in threatening to oppose the recommendations of the Boundary Commission because of their failure to secure House of Lords reform (report, Issue 1,099).

Labour looked likely to achieve a comfortable majority at the next election. However, with the proposed boundary changes, there would be a chance Labour could not win enough seats and will need to work in coalition. It is perhaps appropriate that the Lib Dems’ childish behaviour may condemn them to a generation or more of irrelevance on the back benches.

Paul Homewood, Stocksbridge, South Yorkshire

Respect our home

SIR – The two articles of your new guest columnist Karen Wheeler that I have read are bizarre to the point of absurdity.

Firstly, she was incredibly rude about the food available in restaurants in the Poitou-Charentes (Expat Life, Issue 1,095). I have to report that I have found wonderful places to eat here, where fresh, local produce is used daily for an imaginative range of menus.

Secondly, one of the reasons why Poitou-Charentes is so attractive is that the crime rate is very low – a statistic she omitted to point out in her second article on being fined by the local gendarmes (Issue 1,098). She complained that she had been fined for a piffling offence, but she did break the law. The requirement to stop at a solid white line is well known in France – you ignore it at your peril.

The overall question is – why did Ms Wheeler move to France if all she can do is find fault with it? We British who love our new home find her disrespectful comments do not help our relationship with our French neighbours.

Michael George, Ruffec, France

The lure of the large

SIR – Nick Collins reports that anxious men prefer larger ladies (Issue 1,099).

That’s the best reason so far for sticking to the diet.

Paula Spurrier, Eversley Cross, Hampshire

Inspiring our youth

SIR – David Cameron says that competitive team sports will be made compulsory for all primary school children in England (report, Issue 1,099).

I suggest a new sport for the Olympic Games: knee-jerk reaction. This sport has the advantage that it does not require the use of playing fields. This fits in well with the policies of successive governments, which have sold hundreds of playing fields.

David Laycock, Malvern, Worcestershire

SIR – It is not only budding athletes who should be inspired by the Games. All those people who came together to plan, build and prepare the Olympic Park can inspire the nation’s youth to become architects, electricians, plumbers and carpenters.

These careers can hold great job satisfaction. If this could be communicated, maybe with the use of an inspirational film of the development of the park that could be shown in schools, then it could convince children that such work can be rewarding.

Pam Raymond, Ringwood, Hampshire

Tuition fees’ impact

SIR – Almost one in 20 students are put off applying to university by rising tuition fees, according to a report (Issue 1,099).

I suggest that the acid test is not the number applying but the number who graduate. Those who enjoyed university education at the taxpayers’ expense had a higher drop-out rate than those who would have wasted their parents’ money by skipping lectures.

I suspect that those who pay for the privilege will continue to be more likely to stay the course and the graduate output will be practically unchanged.

Brian Tordoff, Chalfont St Giles, Buckinghamshire

These letters were originally published in The Telegraph Weekly World Edition

Email your letters to weeklyt@telegraph.co.uk

rank_70.title: Keep The Flame Alive: Mo Farah backs new £240,000 athletics track
rank_70.text:
The champion long-distance runner, who won both the 5,000m and 10,000m at London 2012 , spoke out in support of the project to help secure an Olympic legacy for the capital on Paddington Recreation Grounds.

Westminster City Council has secured £130,000 in funding from the Marathon Trust and an additional £44,000 from the London Mayor's Legacy Fund to help pay for the work.

The improved track will meet International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) standards and will also be able to support long jump, high jump, triple jump and shot put training.

Speaking after the birth of twins, Mo Farah, who lives in London, said: “Central London getting a new running track is great news for athletes of the future.

“The London Olympic Games will inspire a whole new generation of potential sports men and women and it is good to see Westminster City Council leading the way in bringing important new facilities to the heart of the capital.”

The running track is on the grounds of a former cinder cycle track, which was built in 1888. A sprint track was added by 1900 and was used by Sir Roger, 83, in the 1950s before he became the first man to break the four-minute record on May 6, 1954.

Moment of history: Roger Bannister breaks the four-minute mile

In 2000, Sir Roger unveiled a plaque on the side of the pavilion to mark the track as his training ground.

Cllr Steve Summers, deputy cabinet member for Olympics, sport and leisure, said: “It is great to see that of the stars of the Olympic Games is backing this project.

"This is an important new facility for Westminster as we want to leave an Olympic legacy in the centre of London to inspire the next generation of sporting heroes.

“We hope that hundreds of people will be inspired to take up track and field sports and maybe even go on to represent the UK in Olympics around the world.”

The new track is due to open on September 26.

rank_43.title: Scottish Rugby warns Olympic legacy at risk
rank_43.text:
Scottish Rugby, the game’s ruling body, said its in-school projects found that fitness levels among even some of the most athletic pupils north of the Border were “very poor” compared to the international norm.

Among the reasons highlighted by the organisation were substandard facilities, poor provision of physical activity in the school curriculum and even PE teachers who are physically incapable of teaching sport.

However, Scottish Rugby also criticised the BBC and STV for broadcasting too little of its sport, saying this was harming both participation levels and match attendance.

The warning about the paucity of facilities, made in a submission to a Holyrood inquiry, was echoed by the ruling bodies of other sports including cricket and canoeing.

The Daily Telegraph has launched a campaign called Keep the Flame Alive to help secure an Olympics legacy of competitive school sport.

It has won the backing of the Scottish Government but the rugby chiefs concluded there must be “sustained investment” in the game if children are to benefit long-term from London 2012 and the Glasgow 2014 Commonwealth Games.

They called for “urgent action” from ministers, councils, sports quangos and the teaching profession to ensure all pupils have access to high-quality competitive sport.

In a written submission to the inquiry ahead of appearing before MSPs next week, Scottish Rugby praised the SNP administration’s Cashback for Communities scheme, which sees money seized from criminals distributed among good causes.

The organisation decided to spend £250,000 of its proceeds on a scheme to improve school rugby and described to MSPs the disturbing results of tests conducted on S1 and S2 pupils.
