Using an American system called Functional Movement Screening, they were asked to perform seven basic movements required for them to lead a healthy lifestyle, including a deep squat or a push-up.

“During our pilot projects we found that pupils’ fitness levels and physical competencies were so poor coming into secondary school, that we had to set our targets at a realistic level,” the submission to Holyrood’s health and sport committee states.

Colin Thomson, Scottish Rugby’s director of rugby operations, said: “Bearing in mind the kids concerned were at the better end (of the fitness spectrum) – they’ve offered to do extra rugby – but the reality is they were not good enough.”

Listing the problems in the schools system, the body said it is “impossible” to increase participation when sports provision often relies on PE staff on short-term contracts.

However, some PE teachers lack “either the physical competence to teach sports” or “the skills, experience or qualifications to confidently teach technical elements”.

This is compounded by there being insufficient sport in the curriculum thanks to the number of opt-outs. The result is: “Pupils possessing very poor levels of physical fitness, physical competence or generic sporting skills / experience.”

Arguing for more all-weather pitches, the submission states: “Scotland needs to develop world-class facilities as part of the Olympic legacy. Too often our enthusiastic local clubs have to endure completely inadequate facilities.”

But Scottish Rugby also said it was also “disappointed” by the amount of rugby on terrestrial television, saying that other parts of the UK, particularly Wales, has much higher coverage.

In their submissions, Cricket Scotland and the Scottish Canoe Association also argued that facilities must be improved and called for a “comprehensive programme” to open up access to facilities at schools, colleges and universities.

But Shona Robison, the Sports Minister, told the committee the SNP has spent £33 million on sports facilities since coming to power in 2007 and plans to roll out 150 “community sports hubs” across the country by 2016.

In addition, she said Sportscotland, the sports quango, is reviewing access to existing facilities to see how this can be improved.

A BBC Scotland spokesman said the corporation broadcasts a wide range of rugby including the Six Nations, Melrose Sevens and the forthcoming autumn international test matches.

But he added: “It’s important that we balance these competing interests against a finite sports rights budget.”

An STV spokesman said: "STV is a strong supporter of rugby and provides regular coverage on air, online and as part of our sports news."

rank_135.title: Olympic and Paralympic Athletes' Parade: where to go
rank_135.text:
Britain's sporting heroes will be saluted as a huge precession snakes its way through the streets of London in front of tens of thousands of adoring fans.

Olympic and Paralympic heroes will be celebrated at the end of a sparkling summer of British sport as London streets are brought to a standstill for The Greatest Team Parade.

Athletes will travel on 21 open-top floats, grouped in alphabetical order by their sport. The stars of the Olympics' Super Saturday will be on the first three floats.

The first will include Mo Farah, the Olympic 5,000 and 10,000m winner, followed by heptathlon gold medallist Jessica Ennis, with long jump champion Greg Rutherford in the third float.

Team GB's cycling stars Sir Chris Hoy, Jason Kenny, Laura Trott and Victoria Pendleton will be in float seven, followed by double equestrian gold-medal winner Charlotte Dujardin, rowing champion Katherine Grainger, Ben Ainslie, Britain's most successful Olympic sailor, and triathlon gold medallist Alistair Brownlee.

Paralympians Hannah Cockcroft, Jody Cundy, Sophie Christiansen and Jonnie Peacock will also take part in the parade.

London mayor Boris Johnson said: "This summer our great city has hosted an unbelievable spectacle of sport and thousands will want to celebrate the achievements of our athletes by coming to the parade.

Farah, who won gold medals in both the 5,000 and 10,000m, said he had had the "perfect" Olympics and said he was "very excited" about today's parade.

He told ITV's Daybreak: "I could never have imagined it would be like that. As an athlete you dream of becoming an Olympic champion, but not in front of a home crowd, and also twice doing it.

"It should be good. There's a lot of people out there, you know [Sir] Chris Hoy and the rest of the guys, Bradley Wiggins.

"I'm looking forward to it, mixing with everyone and having a good laugh. It's time for us to enjoy it one last time, I guess."

1:30pm Start Mansion House (Disabled viewing)

Crowds expected at the crossroads near Bank tube station. The best views should be near the Mansion House itself. Most roads throughout the parade route will be closed from 11am.

Mo Farah (Picture: GETTY IMAGES)

One of the first points the procession passes by is St Paul's Cathedral. The cathedral grounds have plenty of space but try to stay close to St Paul's Church Yard.

For those who don't want to stand on the pavement all afternoon, window seats at one of the pubs lining the route are expected to be at a premium.

A giant viewing screen near Nelson's Column will show the action as it unfolds, with the parade passing the square from the Strand to the Mall. The parade is expected to arrive about 2.30pm.

A fly-past includes the Red Arrows, RAF Typhoons and a BA plane used to bring the flame to the UK, which will display a "thank you" message on the bottom of its fuselage. They will fly at around 1000 feet.

Laura Trott (Picture: JULIAN SIMMONDS)

rank_208.title: Dame Tessa Jowell stands down from shadow cabinet saying 'job done' on the Olympics
rank_208.text:
The Labour MP for Dulwich and West Norwood, who fired the starting gun on the Olympics after persuading Tony Blair to bid for them 10 years ago, said: "It's job done" after submitting her resignation to Ed Miliband, the Labour leader.

“It’s very rare in politics to see something through from beginning to end and I’ve been able to do that with the Games,” she added.

Mrs Jowell had been minister for the Olympics and London in the shadow cabinet, and also served on the cross-party team which helped to ensure they were such a success.

During the two weeks of the Games, she stayed alongside TeamGB in an apartment in the Athletes' Village beside the Olympic Park.

Mr Miliband paid tribute to Mrs Jowell after the news was announced. He said: "Over her career, Tessa has been an amazing asset to the Labour Party and to Britain. Her legacy is enormous.

"What we have seen at the London 2012 would not have been possible without Tessa’s determination and dedication both in championing the bid and playing a major role in delivering the Games. For this the whole country owes her a huge debt of gratitude."

The 64-year-old mother-of-two, who was first elected to the Commons 20-years-ago, was a loyal supporter of Mr Blair, and it was in her role as his secretary of state for culture, media and sport that she first approached him with the proposal that London bid for the Games.

At the time, none of her Cabinet colleagues or civil servants in the department were in favour of the bid. But three years later, she was beside Mr Blair in Singapore as the Olympics were awarded to London.

And she continued to work on delivering the Games, both in government and opposition, until the last day of the Paralympics on Sunday.

Mrs Jowell, who separated from her husband, David Mills, in 2006 after he became embroiled in a financial scandal involving Italian premier Silvio Berlusconi, is chairman of the City Safe Foundation, which works to create safe havens in buildings across London for youngsters at risk of gang crime.

She did not disclose whether she would remain in Parliament after the next general election, or rule out a return to front-line politics in the future.

“Most of all I want to give time to my constituency,” she said.

Several of Mrs Jowell's colleagues paid tribute to her on Twitter.

Douglas Alexander, the shadow foreign secretary, said: "There was a warm thank you from the whole shadow cabinet this morning for @jowellt She's a great colleague and was an outstanding minister."

Chuka Umunna, the shadow business secretary added: "v.emotional shadow cabinet - the last with our @jowellt, who's made a huge contribution to our party and country ... and will continue to do so!"

And Clive Efford, Labour MP for Eltham, said: "Those of us who feel pride over Olympics can thank Tessa Jowell she had the vision to see of what Britain could achieve. Thank you Tessa!"

Hugh Robertson, the Conservative Sports minister, also sent his good wishes to Mrs Jowell. He said: "I'd like to pay tribute to Tessa's excellent work on the Olympic and Paralympic Games.

"Not only did she play a vital role in the winning bid team but she laid the foundations for a successful Games, which was recognised in this year's Queen's Birthday Honours.

"I was pleased that, with the cross-party approach to the Games, Tessa continued to be involved throughout, with a position on the Olympic Board and as deputy mayor of the Athletes' Village during the Olympic Games. She took on both roles with her usual enthusiasm and expertise."

Mrs Jowell took to Twitter to express her gratitude for the tributes. She said: "Thank you for all your good wishes. It's been a huge privilege to have served on the front bench in Govt and Opposition for 19 years.

"This is the right time to stand down, 10 years on the Olympics - job done!"

rank_212.title: Rugby World Cup 2015 organisers hoping to use Olympic Stadium as a venue
rank_212.text:
There are still uncertainties regarding who the tenants of the 80,000-seat arena will be after the London Games, with Premier League football club West Ham one of four bidders.

But if a tenant is secured before the list of 10 to 12 venues is submitted by the World Cup's organising committee at the start of next year, the iconic stadium that staged the gold-winning displays of Usain Bolt and Mo Farah could add rugby to the list of sports it will host.

"We have engaged with them from the very early part of this year and through the Olympic legacy company – you would be mad not to include it as part of your thinking," said Ross Young, chief operating officer of England's organising committee.

The strong ticket sales that the Olympic Stadium would generate will help organisers post the profit of 100 million pounds ($162 million) they are aiming to raise from the tournament.

With that in mind, football stadiums with big capacities such as Old Trafford, Anfield and Wembley will be relied upon to host matches along with the international grounds of Twickenham and Millennium Stadium. So far, only Leicester Tigers' Welford Road and Gloucester Rugby's Kingsholm are under consideration as English club rugby venues.

"To get as near as we can to the 3 million ticket sales, we have to engage with football clubs because they are the only ones who are going to give us the capacity to drive those numbers," Young said.

Tuesday will mark the three-years-to-go stage for organisers, who have recently brought in Debbie Jevans – a key player in the delivery of the Olympics and Paralympics in London – as chief executive.

Replicating the feel-good factor that surrounded the London Games is a key part of the World Cup organisers' overall strategy.

"We are conscious that there has been an amazing event that has happened in London in the Olympics. Everyone is having withdrawal symptoms," newly appointed IRB chief executive Brett Gosper said. "It really did capture the hearts and minds of this country and cross the world. Everyone was in awe of what happened ... it's putting the right kind of pressure on us."

The build-up to the World Cup will start in earnest in early December when the pool allocation draw and match schedule is announced. Seedings are only finalised after the autumn test matches, which will see New Zealand, Australia and South Africa head over to Europe for matches against the northern hemisphere's best.

rank_84.title: Michael Gove seeks new way for school sport to deliver on London 2012 legacy promises
rank_84.text:
The lack of a coherent school sport strategy has been highlighted as the missing link in the Government’s legacy plans, and the meeting at the Department of Education on Thursday was aimed at addressing the issue.

Governing bodies including the Football Association, the England and Wales Cricket Board, the Rugby Football Union and the Lawn Tennis Association were called in to meet the minister, who ended ring-fenced funding and targets for PE and school sport in his first months in office.

The department would not comment on the talks, but the meeting was said to be constructive, despite the absence of several sports that believe they could make a genuine contribution to the debate.

Gove appears to have ruled out reversing his decision to scrap the School Sports Partnership that ensured all primary and secondary schools had access to professional PE teaching.

He is interested in exploiting the expertise of sports clubs and increasing their links to schools, though the means by which any relationship would work remains unclear. The potential of exploiting sports’ sponsors already working in grass roots coaching also appeals to government.

The Prime Minister is understood to be pressing for a meaningful policy so that his lavish Olympic legacy promises are not exposed.

The Sports and Recreation Alliance, which speaks for governing bodies, welcomed the talks.

“It’s pleasing that the secretary of state recognises that there is a clear need for an appraisal of policy when it comes to school sports,” said chairman Andy Reed, a former Labour MP.

“School sport plays a crucial part in inspiring young people to stay active but there’s no doubt that it hasn’t been as high up the agenda as it needs to be.

“School sport really is vital if we are going to truly ‘inspire a generation’ and it is essential that the right mandate is provided from the top. We have tried leaving sport up to teachers’ discretion in the past and that hasn’t worked due to pressures from other curriculum topics.

"Sport is one of those areas that gets squeezed when heads look to make cuts to their budgets or concentrate on academic subjects.

“Let’s grasp this opportunity for an overhaul of the status quo and capitalise on the excitement and interest the Olympics have generated to transform school sport for the better.

“The Alliance is pleased that national governing bodies are involved in the policymaking process but all sports must be included as part of a wider consultation if any new system is to work.

“If we are going to have a school PE programme that works for every pupil, we need to invite all stakeholders into a discussion. That should include all sports, recreation and dance solutions as well as those who understand education needs”

rank_66.title: Video: 2012 Business Bullet, Episode 24: Legacy
rank_66.text:
The Olympic Games have not been positive for model train-maker Hornby; it has put out a profit warning. London 2012 organisers are on course to hit their target of £1 billion of sales of merchandise.

A report by MPs argues that security company G4S should give up its management fee from its Olympics contract as a result of its failure to hire enough staff.

Mayor of London Boris Johnson has put himself in charge of the London Legacy Development Corporation, the organisation that will decide who will take over the Olympic Stadium, with West Ham United Football Club still the favourites.

rank_33.title: Olympic legacy risks failing women
rank_33.text:
The Women's Sport and Fitness Foundation will on Wednesday warn a committee of MPs and peers that the Olympic Games legacy risks not doing enough to promote women in sport – despite the success of Team GB female athletes at the London 2012 Games.

Research from the charity shows only 5pc of all sports media coverage is dedicated to women's sport, that all-female matches receive just 0.5pc of all commercial sponsorship and that only one in five board members of national sports governing bodies are women.

The under-promotion and underfunding of women’s sport is leading to an "inactivity crisis" among women, with just 20pc of females currently doing enough exercise to benefit their health, the charity warns.

The warning comes as Helen Glover , the first female athlete to win gold at London 2012, says too many girls drop out of sport at school due to "peer pressure".

Sue Tibballs, chief executive of WSFF, will tell MPs in a parliamentary meeting on Wednesday: "The London 2012 Olympic and Paralympics were the greatest Games for women ever. The achievements of Jessica Ennis, Sarah Storey, Kath Grainger and so many others have taken support for women’s sport to new heights, and made 2012 a landmark year for women’s sport.

Sporting stars of summer: Jessica Ennis, left, and Laura Trott (PA)

“But, we cannot rely on goodwill alone to overcome the obstacles that are preventing women’s sport taking its proper place in public life. Currently we have a media that values male achievements over females’ and a prevailing culture where girls grow up wanting to be thin rather than active and healthy. This has to change or the Olympic legacy will have failed for women.

“The time to act is now. 81pc of people think that the female athletes at London 2012 make better role models for young girls than other celebrities. This is great news. However, we need to make sure that young girls and women are given more opportunities to see their female sports heroes in action to inspire them to get active.”

Among the changes WSFF will be calling for are:

– increased media coverage that reflects growing demand for women's sport

– a new approach to school sport that priorities getting girls active

– more female leadership at the highest levels of sport

– more and better opportunities for participation

rank_152.title: Lord Coe fills British Olympic Association chair as door opens to IOC membership in 2013
rank_152.text:
Coe will on Wednesday be appointed chairman of the British Olympic Association following the resignation of Lord Moynihan. He is the sole candidate in the election after Richard Leman, head of British hockey, withdrew from the race last month.

However, being granted entry to the IOC would represent an even bigger honour for the former middle-distance runner, who helped deliver London’s triumphant Olympics.

Previous efforts to elevate Coe into the IOC have been stymied by the high number of British members already ensconced in the organisation. The Princess Royal, Sir Craig Reedie, Sir Philip Craven and Adam Pengilly are four of the 104 current IOC members and the body has been trying to widen its membership across more of its 204 national Olympic committees and 28 international federations, as well as promote more women.

But under reforms enacted in the wake of the 1999 Salt Lake City bribery scandal, the IOC executive board can nominate presidents and chairmen of national Olympic committees for consideration, with a handful of vacancies due to be voted in at the 2013 session next September in Buenos Aires.

Telegraph Sport has been told that any Coe nomination through this route would be favourably looked upon by members. It had been assumed that Coe would gain entry to the IOC through his possible appointment as the next president of the International Association of Athletics Federations, but this represents a less treacherous route.

Coe may also find he will be considered for the role of World Anti-Doping Agency president, given his strong anti-drugs stance throughout his stellar athletics career. The next Wada presidency is due to be filled by an IOC-nominated person when the current president, the government-nominated former NSW state premier John Fahey, steps down.

Notwithstanding Coe’s international forays, he will also have to address five key domestic challenges upon assuming his four-year BOA post on Wednesday, the most pressing of which is the organisation’s parlous finances.

While the BOA had been hamstrung in its marketing activities because of a previous deal with the London Olympic organisers, it still managed to raise £88 million over the past eight years to cover the cost of sending teams to Beijing and London.

When Locog contributes a further £5 million from any Games profit, the BOA will technically be in the black, but continuing to raise the £10 million a year required to keep it in the black in the tough economic climate will be a priority.

Another priority will be the BOA’s relationships with government and ensuring athletes benefit from a sports legacy. Certainly Coe’s close relationships with Sir Keith Mills and sports minister Hugh Robertson will play a huge role in developing this front.

rank_53.title: Olympic Stadium reopening delayed until 2016 after modifications are required by potential bidders
rank_53.text:
The London Legacy Development Corporation is still deciding whether to accept any of the four bidders — West Ham, Leyton Orient, Formula One and the UCFB College of Football Business — seeking a 99-year lease on the £500 million stadium, some of which requires substantial modifications, including providing a roof to cover all of the seating, and possible retractable seating. West Ham’s requirements for new seating and a roof has been roughly estimated at costing £200 million.

Dennis Hone, the LLDC chief executive, told the London Assembly that there have been no formal bids from an NFL American football franchise, although the London Mayor, Boris Johnson, and others had held “encouraging” talks about stadium management with NFL executives during a recent trip to the capital.

Although football was still among the front-runners to take up tenancy of the venue, Hone insisted a 2014 reopening was out of the question.

Hone said: “The four bidders have put some requirement on the LLDC as the landlord — seating, roof, hospitality – they change from bid to bid.”

Hone said if none of the current bidders were accepted, with a decision expected in the first half of next year, the promise to the International Association of Athletics Federations for covered seating during the hosting of the 2017 World Athletics Championships may have to be renegotiated.

He said it was unlikely the corporation would pay for covered seating without the changes being required by a long-term tenant. If no changes were required the stadium could be open to athletics in 2014, when the northern area of Olympic Park featuring the VeloPark cycling centre is expected to open to the public.

Hone explained that the modifications, if a long-term tenant was appointed, may be lengthy because of the need for detailed design, construction and reconfiguration and may push back occupancy of the stadium to August 2015 at the earliest, or even August 2016.

But Hone defended the protracted process in deciding on a tenant, which has dragged on for years amid legal challenges and uncertainty. “If it takes a couple of extra months to get the right decision for the public purse I will take it, because I don’t want to make a decision that we will regret in three or four years,” he said.

The corporation is looking to sell five outstanding large tracts of land on the Olympic Park for future housing developments providing around 8000 residences: a mixture of social housing, family housing and flats.

Hone said it was a reasonable estimate to expect £1.1 billion from this housing development, but that the time frame, originally anticipated to be until 2030, may be fast-tracked because of strong demand for housing in the capital.

rank_145.title: Lord Coe honoured and flattered as he begins new challenge as head of British Olympic Association
rank_145.text:
Coe, the dual Olympic gold medallist and most recently the chair of the hugely successful London Organising Committee for the Olympic Games will now be charged with steering the organisation to continue inspiring young people to take up sport as well as prepare future Olympic teams, specifically for Sochi in 2014 and Rio de Janeiro in 2016.

Mr Cameron said: "Combined with his role as the Government's legacy ambassador, Seb will play a crucial part in maximising the benefits from London 2012, helping our athletes achieve gold in Rio and British businesses win new trade and investment deals."

Coe's election, which was by acclamation from the national sporting federations after Lord Moynihan stood down after seven years, has been praised by the International Olympic Committee president Jacques Rogge and the Minister for Sport Hugh Robertson.

"I congratulate the BOA for picking a winner," said Rogge, while Robertson noted there was no better successor than Lord Coe.

"His leadership will enable the BOA to capitalise on the fantastic opportunities coming out of a home Olympics."

Coe was "honoured and flattered" following his election, and offered an early indicator as to his aims in the role. "This is not an organisation that delivers elite athletes," said Coe. "That's the job of governing bodies."

rank_155.title: Olympic and Paralympic legacy in danger of being lost due to government funding cuts
rank_155.text:
Leading educationalists involved in the delivery of school sports have called for urgent measures following the removal of funding for school sport partnerships.

At least two prominent sports educators argue that the Olympic and Paralympic legacy is in danger of being lost due to a lack of opportunity to participate in sports beyond what schools can provide.

One of them, Darren Padgett, runs Team Activ, a not-for-profit company delivering sport in schools and communities.

Padgett has been shortlisted for an Unsung Hero honour at the Aviva/Daily Telegraph School Sport Matters Awards.

He led a secondary school PE department for nearly 20 years before managing the School Sports Partnership programme in Barnsley for almost 10 years.

“What we are seeing less of are proposed solutions to our nation’s questionable track record in developing sport in schools,” he explained.

“Various ill-thought-out government interventions over the past 30 years or so have often pushed sport to the periphery of our education system.

"Having seen what had already been achieved I decided to give up the relative security of employment in the state education sector and set up a non-for-profit organisation aimed at delivering exactly what school sport partnerships had done.”

The issues for Padgett are clear: while investment in new schools is welcomed, it does seem to be causing some unforeseen problems around sport.

The need to make money from new sports facilities is at the expense of sports for children outside school hours, he has noticed. Schools would often allow sports providers to offer sports activities using their facilities for free.

They are now charging to rent pitches and equipment, which limits participation to children who can afford to pay.

Moreover, staggered starts and finishes at some of the new schools are creating issues around post-school hours sports activities: arranging inter-school tournaments is increasingly difficult.

Sporting facilities such as tennis courts that were once open for general use are now locked up and have to be rented. This means availability is much more limited and community use is reduced.

Padgett believes that “a society-wide change” is needed. By charging local communities and businesses for sporting events, Team Activ will raise £250,000 for local schools by 2017.

Similar issues have recently been raised by Alan Watkinson, a former PE teacher (and winner of the Sports Teacher of the Year award) who helped develop Olympic champion Mo Farah’s interest in running.

Watkinson runs a School Sports Partnership based at Isleworth and Syon School in west London.

Watkinson says he is “very angry” about Education Secretary Michael Gove’s “offensive” summary dismissal of the outstanding work of the network of School Sport Partnerships.

Watkinson outlined his thoughts recently at a school sports conference organised by the Youth Sport Trust. The former PE teacher has since moved on, but the Games’ promise of being able to inspire a generation remains at the forefront of many educational minds.

There are proposals – a cross-party, cross-department plan is needed – but Watkinson’s first concern is this: “The number one priority should be movers and shakers round a table with Lord Coe in charge – now, where have we seen that before?”

As for funding, he urges ring-fenced levels. “We need immediate ring fencing and retention of the current level of funding to keep the life support switched on.

“The further diminishing of our already beleaguered system would be catastrophic. This is still an 80 per cent cut on what went before and greater resource will be needed.”

Watkinson also espouses high-quality primary school physical education, believing it should be the “top priority”.

It has long been an issue which School Sport Matters has recognised and identified. The bottom line is that there is still no solution for the delivery of PE and sport in primary school. “We need to accept that despite pockets of outstanding practice, the problems are so deep rooted that there is no quick fix,” reckons Watkinson.

“The suggestion is that rigorous Ofsted criteria take the physical development of young people and

all the well-researched, unarguable benefits more seriously.”

Unless those at the coal face are listened to, the legacy from London 2012 could end up fading fast.

Aviva and The Daily Telegraph, recognising tomorrow’s champions today. Email your letters on school sport to gareth.davies@telegraph.co.uk

rank_60.title: PE teachers 'must be given bonuses' to build on Olympic legacy
rank_60.text:
The head of the London 2012 organising committee called for a shake-up to avoid allowing the spike in enthusiasm created by the Games “to crumble under our feet”.

He said the need to increase the quality of PE teaching should be addressed just as maths and science had previously been targeted for improvements.

Lord Coe, the new chair of the British Olympic Association, suggested that money should be made available to encourage the practice of teachers running competitive sports for pupils outside school hours.

He said: “I think we need to recognise within the funding mechanism the role that PE teachers are going to play if you want them to be involved in competitive sport that is inevitably going to take place outside the timetable.

“There are young schoolteachers with family commitments, and all the other pressures there are now in a very prescriptive curriculum. We are going to need to create space outside the curriculum for sport.”

Lord Coe made the remarks while addressing the London Assembly.

He added: “We are also probably going to have to recognise the work of physical education teachers in exactly the same way that we did in many of your boroughs when we needed to increase probably the quality of maths and science teachers.”

Under previous schemes, graduates have been awarded with thousands in annual payments for training as teachers in subjects seen as vital to the economy.

Lord Coe, a double 1,500m Olympic champion, reflected on his own sporting education within the state system to illustrate his point, and that it was a geography teacher who urged him to take up athletics seriously.

He said: “All my competitive sport took place outside the curriculum and the normal school day. They were not always physical education teachers that were inspiring kids like me to play sport.”

Lord Coe said improving conditions for school sport faced challenges such as the sell-off of playing fields and an “anti-competitive ethos” dating back to the teacher training colleges of the 1960s.

He said figures showing that 70% of parents said their children were much more positive about sport than they were before the Games must be built upon.

“That is not a platform we can allow to crumble under our feet,” he said.

Lord Coe also said the issue of school sport should be dealt with in a “grown-up” way with “a more consensual cross-party approach”, and that it was “frustrating” that this was not already the case.

He suggested that the enthusiasm of the thousands of “Games Maker” volunteers who helped make the Olympics such a success could be utilised by sending them into school clubs and voluntary organisations.

rank_128.title: Artist claims Danny Boyle 'copied' London 2012 Olympic opening ceremony
rank_128.text:
A spiral, grassy mound echoes the ancient history of a green and pleasant land. Figures in white dot a pastoral landscape under fluffy white clouds.

It sounds like the first scene of Danny Boyle’s Olympic opening ceremony – but in fact they are ideas submitted for a London 2012 art competition, several years before Boyle’s £27 million “Isles of Wonder” show was hailed as a masterpiece.

Lee Merrill Sendall, the artist who entered the contest, is seeking legal advice after claiming that the team behind the opening ceremony in July copied his proposal.

He submitted his design for Large Spiral Mound in 2009 to the Artists Taking the Lead competition – a joint initiative by Locog, the organisers of the Games, and Arts Council England (ACE) to fund 12 regional projects where artists could create an Olympic legacy.

Mr Sendall, 42, from Hull, was shortlisted for the £500,000 prize for his proposal to build a 200ft spiral Neolithic mound in East Yorkshire, representing the ancient history of the United Kingdom.

One of five finalists, in October 2009 he presented his proposal to a panel of judges including officials from Locog and ACE, with illustrations, a slide show and a written brief. He also provided judges with a set of postcards featuring the images.

Mr Sendall said: “When I saw pictures of models presented by Danny Boyle and his team for the opening ceremony, I was stunned at what appeared to be a copy of my proposal.

“On the night of the opening ceremony, I received messages from relatives and friends asking if Danny Boyle had permission to use my idea.

“Too many of my concepts and visuals appeared in the ceremony to be shrugged off as coincidence. I would have liked to have been asked if my ideas could be used and I would like proper credit for the project which I put a lot of work into.”

Boyle, 56, called his opening scene “Green and Pleasant”. He presented a model of the idea in June, featuring a spiral mound which he said was based on Glastonbury Tor in Somerset, surrounded by a lake, a farmhouse, and fluffy white clouds suspended from wires, all of which appeared in Mr Sendall’s original competition entry.

Images for Large Spiral Mound, which ACE included on its website during the competition process, also featured a man with an Olympic torch ascending the mound, which was enacted during the opening ceremony.

The artist wrote a blog about his proposal, entitled “Through the ages”, with accompanying images of how his mound would develop over several centuries.

Boyle’s opening ceremony portrayed Britain through the centuries, using scenes depicting the Industrial Revolution and music from the Sixties through to the present day.

A Locog spokesman said: “Danny Boyle was not involved in the Artists Taking the Lead programme and would not have seen any of the submissions.

“Danny’s vision for the opening set for the Olympic Games opening ceremony was inspired by the very well known Glastonbury Tor landmark and British history.”

Locog also told The Art Newspaper: "The vision was Danny Boyle's and his only."

A spokesman for ACE said: “In order to apply for Artists Taking the Lead, all applicants were asked to submit their idea to an open website. It was clear to artists by its nature that their ideas were open to comment and review by anyone.”

Sean Egan, the head of arts and media at the law firm Bates Wells & Braithwaite London LLP, said: “If it is the case that the creators of the opening ceremony were aware of the image, then the similarity is so striking that we would expect Lee to have a good case for copyright infringement.”

rank_65.title: Olympic legacy failing on the school playing fields
rank_65.text:
The Olympic legacy suffered a blow after research suggested that more than half of children fail to get at least two hours of physical education every week.

Just 100 days after the closing ceremony of the London Games, it emerged that about 54 per cent of parents fear that their children are struggling to get access to enough sport at school.

The majority of schools are cutting back on sport and about one in seven teenagers fails to get any PE at all in their final year of school, it found.

Chance to Shine, a sporting charity, surveyed more than 1,000 parents and found 15 per cent believed their children did more sport outside of school.

Eight in 10 parents said the amount of games lessons had either stayed the same as before the Olympics or decreased. Three per cent of those asked said their children did no sport at all.

Wasim Khan, chief executive of Chance to Shine, said: "Parents are saying that many of their children were inspired by the Games to play more or to try a new sport. We owe it to those children to ensure we have the right infrastructure to make it a reality."

The Department for Education insisted that it was placing competitive sport at the centre of its school reforms.

rank_127.title: Sarah Weir: My career path has been nerve-wracking - but never dull
rank_127.text:
Last Thursday, Canary Wharf's Wintergarden hosted the London Means Business Dinner. It highlighted the beginning of London moving from an Olympic City to a Legacy City as well as hosting the inaugural annual platform for Mayor Boris Johnson to announce his economic policy for the year ahead.

I spoke at the dinner - a true career highlight. Monies raised were directed to the Legacy List - a charity founded by The Mayor and The London Legacy Development Corporation - of which Sarah Weir OBE is CEO.

Sarah's path to her current role has been colourful. She told me how she "slid into school at the usual age, slid out again at 16 the minute I could - uninspired, pretty much unnoticed, certainly uneducated".

She worked in a hairdressers on Saturdays, which she hated, then a boys' prep school darning socks and reading bedtime stories. The jobs enabled her to buy her first car and then a cheap airline ticket to the US where she spent a year doing everything from teaching Scottish dancing in Baltimore to selling orange juice to tourists in Florida.

After nannying, she fell into the City as a gopher in a Lloyd's insurance broking firm: Opening the post, making tea, cleaning the coffee machine and running errands. She made her way up, broking deals in the Lloyd's market. After 15 years she became their first female MD.

Having got there, she realised it wasn't what she wanted to do, however. Seeking advice, it became clear that she was strongly arts rather than the City oriented. She applied to Birkbeck University and started a part-time course in History of Art. She was MD by day - university student by night. It was hard work, she says, but recalls collecting her BA after a 'four year slog' as one of her proudest moments.

She left the City - taking a 90pc reduction in salary, giving up the company car, discovering public transport and working part-time in a contemporary art gallery - one of her personal passions. And so began a career in a variety of roles starting as deputy chief executive of Arts & Business, fundraising director at The Royal Academy, director at The Almeida Theatre and then Arts Council England.

She left ACE at the end of 2007 - taking roles at LOCOG (London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games), the ODA (Olympic Delivery Authority) and the London Legacy Development Corporation before becoming chief executive of the Legacy List in 2011.

Set up as a 'force for good' to support the long-term social, cultural and physical regeneration of the East End, it is using London 2012 as its launch pad to support a range of arts and education projects making creative connections between people and the Olympic Park.

It's been going for one year, has leveraged £1.5m of investment from private and public sources and has got a series of three year creative projects off the ground around the park.

They employ two young women who live close to the Park in east London with CVs which do not immediately look great on paper. Sarah says they are "the sort of CV I had at their age. A few O levels and no experience". Someone took an initial chance on her so she has spent most of her working life taking chances on others when she could.

Looking back, she feels that spending so much time being unsure what she wanted to do and trying out different things in both the private, public and charity sectors turned out to be useful. She learnt to be flexible and adaptable - and adept at speaking all the different 'languages' of these varied arenas.

Some chances were offered to her, some she sought out and others she created by "wriggling my way through into gaps no-one had noticed had existed".

She describes the path she took as "stimulating, nerve-wracking but never dull". Sarah Weir - BA, OBE and CEO.

rank_15.title: Video: 2012 Business Bullet, Episode 25: Olympic Legacy
rank_15.text:
In the wake of the London 2012 staffing fiasco, G4S has been stripped of a prison contract and barred from new bids in the sector. The army had to be called in to make up the shortfall when G4S failed to hire enough staff.

The chairman of UK Athletics has called on Boris Johnson to resolve the question of the future of the Olympic stadium. West Ham United Football Club remain the favourites to take over the stadium but funding has yet to be agreed.

Logistics company UPS predict that the Olympics will provide a £21 billion boost to UK GDP in the long term, primarily through growth in exports. London 2012 already helped the economy grow by 1 per cent in the third quarter of 2012.

rank_174.title: UK Athletics chief Neils De Vos puts Olympic gold rush down to 'technological doping’
rank_174.text:
De Vos, who has been in charge of the athletics governing body since 2007, was delivering what he clearly understood to be a private lecture to students of his former Oxford University college, Keble, a month after the Olympic Games.

But on Friday night he was forced to own up to an “ill-chosen phrase” after drawing a distinction between the technology-driven sports that delivered the bulk of Britain’s gold medals at London 2012 and his own sport of track and field.

Outlining the history of Lottery investment since the low point of the 1996 Atlanta Olympics when Britain managed just a single gold medal, De Vos highlighted the influence of Peter Keen, who preceded David Brailsford as performance director of British Cycling.

De Vos said: “Peter Keen came in and said, ‘Forget about cycling, it’s all about sprinting on the track because if you give me money I can make a difference and win medals’.

“That philosophy flowed through. It flowed through rowing, it flowed through sailing. We had an inbuilt advantage anyway as we could afford to do those sports. But you knew that if you were technologically ahead of everyone else, it could make half a second difference.

“They talk about aggregation of marginal gains. I personally don’t buy it. It’s actually technological doping, but none the less it works and we’ve won a vast number of medals as a result of it.

“You can’t do that in track and field athletics. You can’t do it in a team sport where the bounce of a ball can make the difference between success and failure.”

De Vos’s remarks came in an hour-long lecture on elite performance, motivation, and leadership in the wake of London 2012.

On Friday night, he said his comments were in response to a question from the audience and that he was not criticising other Olympic sports but merely pointing out the difference with athletics.

“I made the point, and perhaps it was an ill-chosen phrase, that one of the reasons we do well in certain sports is perhaps because we have the financial wherewithal to achieve a level that others can’t.

“There are some sports where certain well-applied financial modals can bring you a certain advantage. My point was that it doesn’t apply in athletics. It’s very, very hard to achieve that.”

During the lecture, De Vos also turned his ire on the Education Secretary, Michael Gove, describing his policies on school sport as “stupid”.

Criticising the Government for its failure to deliver an effective Olympic legacy in terms of school sport provision, De Vos said: “It’s not the place for political grandstanding but Michael Gove’s decision of two years ago to effectively take it off the curriculum for infants schools and make it an optional curriculum for junior schools seems to me the single-minded most stupid piece of dogma that has imposed upon anybody for a very, very long time.

“I think they probably realise that by now and are finding it quite hard to back-rack from that position in the glory of the Games.”

De Vos insisted on Friday night that he stood by his position. “I do think that,” he said.

“I think it’s wrong because actually 20 or 30 years down the line, if we haven’t got active sport in schools we will suffer as a sporting nation.”

De Vos’s lecture concluded with reflections on the performance of Britain’s track and field athletes at the London Olympics and he admitted that the euphoria of the gold rush on ‘Super Saturday’ had masked deficiencies in the rest of the squad.

“Actually we didn’t have a great Games,” he said. “We had quite a bad Games. Things didn’t go the way we wanted it to. We didn’t get as many finalists as we wanted or as many personal bests as we wanted. There were some spectacular under-performances.

“But actually, you know what, it didn’t mater because we’re so obsessed by the culture of celebrity and gold that 99 per cent of the population would go, ‘Athletics had an absolutely fantastic Games’.”

rank_183.title: West Ham top bidder for London's Olympic Stadium
rank_183.text:
The Mayor spoke after a meeting of the London Legacy Development Corporation (LLDC) which is coordinating the leasing and development of Olympic venues after the Games.

"We have got a first-ranked bidder for the stadium. Four good bids came in as everybody knows but the bid that has been ranked top is West Ham United and I am very pleased about that. It will, if it goes through, mean a football legacy for the stadium but it needs to be sorted out."

The London Games were won with a clear statement that Olympic venues were designed to be used fully after the Games were over, but the stipulation that the athletics track had to be available for international meetings while the infield was used for soccer matches has been seen as a sticking-point with bidders.

"We are very confident that there is lots of time to get the negotiations under way," said Mr Johnson, but he said an alternative plan to use the stadium for athletics, music and entertainment was possible too.

"Either we can go with plan B with lots of cultural events, lots of sporting events – a great future – lots of operators coming forward to say how they could animate the stadium in a way that would really draw a huge number of people to the park. We can get all of that going. But we have got plenty of time to get in a football solution if that is what we get in time for 2016, 2017."

rank_202.title: Whitney Houston musical, The Bodyguard, up for six Whatsonstage.com awards
rank_202.text:
The Bodyguard is the show to beat with six nominations in the annual Whatsonstage.com Awards despite only opening this week at the West End’s Adelphi Theatre.

Theatregoers have been nominating the musical adaptation of the film that starred the late Whitney Houston during its preview period to put it into the running in all the top categories, including Best New Musical and Best Actress and Best Actor in a Musical for stars Heather Headley and Lloyd Owen.

The London 2012 Olympic legacy lingers on as Danny Boyle’s Olympics opening ceremony is short listed for Theatre Event of the Year and Chariots of Fire is looking at five potential wins. Boyle walked away with the Best Director award last year for Frankenstein. Also in the running for Theatre Event of the Year are the Globe to Globe season, the opening of the state-of-the-art St James Theatre in Victoria and the world premiere of Susan Boyle bio-musical I Dreamed a Dream.

With its year-round productions and three auditoria, it's no surprise that The National Theatre dominates with 25 nominations for 13 different productions, including six for The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time. The Chichester Festival should also be pleased with its 18 entries including three musical hits, Singin’ in the Rain, Sweeney Todd and Kiss Me, Kate.

The nominations were revealed today at London’s Café de Paris. The Awards, run by the UK theatre website, are the only major UK theatre awards voted for purely by the ticket-buying public. Over 50,000 nominations have been submitted across 27 categories in the past month.

Voting for the 2013 Whatsonstage.com awards winners opened today and closes at midnight January 31. Winners will be announced Sunday February 17 at the Awards Ceremony and Concert hosted by comedians Rufus Hound and Mel Giedroyc at the West End’s Palace Theatre.

rank_112.title: Four sports starved of Rio Olympics funds by UK Sport ask, what about our legacy?
rank_112.text:
Basketball, handball, wrestling and table tennis will all receive no funding between now and the Olympics in Rio in 2016. Indoor volleyball has also been cut adrift, although the British women’s beach volleyball team will receive support.

UK Sport, the body which awards funding for elite athletes, has pledged a total of £347 million to Britain’s Olympic and Paralympic hopefuls between now and the Rio Games. They have set them the challenge of winning even more medals than they managed in London, something no host nation has achieved before.

But where all sports were given financial backing before this summer’s Olympics, UK Sport has adopted a far more ruthless approach this time around.

Sports minister Hugh Robertson admitted on Tuesday that the sports which had had their funding cut off were only supported before London because organisers thought it would help them sell tickets.

Robertson said: “When we hosted the Olympics we supported all sports, mainly to drive ticket sales, although it turned out that that wasn’t a huge problem. But going forward it is done on a performance basis and there is not a lot of point of funding a few sports which will not be there in medal contention.”

The cut in basketball funding was most savage, falling from £8.6million to nothing and promoting a furious reaction from British Basketball’s performance chairman, Roger Moreland.

“We knew the criteria that UK Sport were applying for Rio, but having been funded to the tune of £8.6million in the lead up to the London Olympics because of the sport’s medal potential for the future, this is a devastating decision and is a waste of that investment,” he said.

“Over the last five years, the GB teams have done the equivalent of going from League Two in football to the Premier League.

"They have been competing with the very best countries in the world. It doesn’t seem much of a legacy from 2012 to dash the hopes and aspirations of a sport whose heartland is founded in Britain’s inner cities.”

The decision not to award funding to volleyball, other than the beach version, means there will be no support for sitting volleyball, the Paralympic sport at which 7/7 bombings survivor Martine Wright competed for Britain.

Volleyball England’s chief executive Lisa Wainwright said UK Sport had made a mockery of the concept of an Olympic legacy.

She said: “The investment requested from UK Sport was less than £500,000 per year per squad over the next four years. Everyone will have seen the impact sitting volleyball can have on people with the winner of the BBC’s Helen Rollason Award, Martine Wright. When we speak of legacy remember this day, the flame has well and truly been extinguished.”

In general, Paralympic sports were winners in Tuesday’s announcement with funding levels increasing by 43 per cent, while 19 Olympic sports were given greater sums in funding than before London.

Cycling’s success at the Games reflected in them being awarded the biggest grant but swimming, which with three medals fell short of its London 2012 target, was cut by nearly £4 million.

“This is not about punishment [of the swimmers],” said UK Sport chief executive Liz Nicholl, but swimming is now considering whether it will close up to three of its five elite training centres, although a final decision will not be taken until a new performance director is appointed.

The funding, of which two-thirds come from the National Lottery and the final third from the taxpayer, also gave a major boost to boxing, whose increase of £4.3million was in percentage terms the biggest of any sport. But it came accompanied by a warning that boxing’s governing body in England must iron out disputes with counterparts in Scotland and Wales or risk losing the money.

Nicholl said the ambition of winning 66 medals in the Olympics and 121 in the Paralympics in Rio – exceeding the totals in London – was an “incredible challenge” but Robertson added: “There are very few sports where we see a reason for a huge fall off and quite a few sports which can do better.

"Australia’s funding fell off a cliff and that is the first mistake we haven’t made, we are making sure there is more money available to be the first home country to improve performance at the next Games.”

Some of the sports which did worst out of Tuesday’s announcement were awarded far higher levels on funding by Sport England on Monday. Sport England funds grassroots while UK Sport is solely concerned with top level sport.

“There has been a real effort to align the two strategies,” Robertson said.

Baroness Sue Campbell, Chair of UK Sport, added: “It is not about being popular, it is about making tough decisions.”

In general, Paralympic sports were winners in yesterday’s announcement with funding levels increased by 43 per cent, while 19 Olympic sports were given greater sums in funding than in the lead-up to the London Games.

Cycling was rewarded for its ­success at the Games with the biggest grant but swimming, which fell short of its London 2012 minimum target of five medals by delivering just three, had funding cut by nearly £4million.

“This is not about punishment,” said UK Sport chief executive Liz Nicholl, but British Swimming is considering whether to close up to three of its five elite training centres. A final decision will not be taken until a new performance director is appointed.

One major beneficiary of the funding, of which two-thirds comes from the National Lottery and the final third from the taxpayer, was boxing, which had its budget increased by £4.3million. It came accompanied by a warning that boxing’s governing body in England must iron out disputes with counterparts in Scotland and Wales or risk losing the money.

Nicholl said the ambition of winning 66 medals in the Olympics and 121 in the Paralympics in Rio – exceeding the totals in London by one medal each – was an “incredible challenge”, but Robertson added: “There are very few sports where we see a reason for a huge fall-off and quite a few sports which can do better. Australia’s funding fell off a cliff and that is the first mistake we haven’t made, we are making sure there is more money available to be the first home country to improve performance at the next Games.”

Some of the sports which fared worst out of yesterday’s announcement were awarded far higher levels of funding by Sport England on Monday at the grassroots level.

Baroness Sue Campbell, the chairman of UK Sport, said: “It is not about being popular, it is about making tough decisions.”

rank_181.title: Jessica Ennis to stay put in Sheffield as coach Toni Minichiello hits out at proposed Don Valley closure
rank_181.text:
Ennis had her first taste of athletics at Don Valley when she attended a summer camp there at the age of 10 and she has continued to train at the stadium throughout her career.

But Sheffield City Council, which honoured Ennis with a civic reception following her London triumph, has confirmed that demolishing the 25,000-seat stadium is one of a number of cost-cutting proposals under consideration as it looks to find £50 million in savings to its 2013-14 budget.

It estimates that closing the venue would save £700,000 a year in running costs plus an extra £1.6 million in essential repair work.

The stadium’s fate will be decided at a budget meeting in March, where councillors will also discuss the option of revamping the city’s much smaller Woodburn Road Athletics Stadium, which was closed 18 months ago to save money.

But Minichiello said it would require a considerable investment to bring the run-down Woodburn Road venue up to scratch and that it would be no substitute for the facilities on offer at Don Valley, which was built to host the World Student Games in 1991.

Ennis currently divides her time between the outdoor Don Valley track and the indoor facilities at the neighbouring English Institute of Sport.

UK Athletics has recently announced plans to centralise its coaching and support services at Loughborough but Minichiello said Ennis had no plans to relocate and wanted to remain in Sheffield, where she was born and raised and where she has recently bought a new home. If Don Valley were to close, Minichiello said they look at other nearby options such as training outdoors in Leeds.

He added that demolishing the stadium would be highly damaging for the sport after the success of London 2012, with the number of children enrolling for the City of Sheffield Athletics Club having doubled to around 600 since the end of the Games.

“The saddest thing about this is what it says about Olympic legacy,” said Minichiello. “Don Valley was where it all began for Jessica and demolishing it means kids in Sheffield will not have the opportunity that Jessica has had.”

Don Valley has become so synonymous with Ennis’s achievements that, after her Olympic victory, former Sheffield MP Richard Caborn called for it to be renamed the ‘Jessica Ennis Stadium’.

A council spokeswoman said: "These are extraordinarily difficult times and we have said that we will have to look at tough budget options because of the devastating Government cuts to public spending and local government. We have said all along that we have to consider all options and Don Valley Stadium is one of the bigger options on the table.”

rank_31.title: Tom Daley's ITV1 reality show Splash! is an undignified leap in the right direction for London 2012 Olympic legacy
rank_31.text:
For in the early 1990s, the libertarian right picked up the phrase. From that point, the reaction against ‘political correctness’ became an almost evangelical crusade. Its infinitely broad span encompassed all sorts of reactionary concerns, from ‘Stalinist speed bumps’ to the ‘global warming myth’, from councils banning Christmas to the inalienable right of every Briton to call a bender ‘a bender’ if he so chooses.

This process of linguistic hyperextension (it actually has its own word — ‘catachresis’ — mind you use it correctly) is evident in other contexts too. Let us examine the peculiar mutation of one particular term that has been legion in recent months.

“The saddest thing about this is what it says about Olympic legacy,” says athletics coach Tony Minichiello of the proposal to demolish the Don Valley Athletics Stadium in Sheffield.

“So much for this Olympic legacy,” shouts the Daily Mail website, reporting that “Olympic organsiers [sic] have come under fire” over the fact that Greenwich Park “remains a muddy quagmire” and “closed to the public six months after the end of the Games”.

The Independent , meanwhile, reports that the first property on the site of the Olympic Park will soon be receiving residents. “The most dedicated and nostalgic Olympic fans will soon be able to purchase their own part of the Olympic legacy,” it writes.

There are early signs — and they are but early; like good scotch, good catachresis takes years to perfect — that the term ‘Olympic legacy’ is destined to suffer the same fate as ‘political correctness’: a nobly-conceived phraseology contorted and corrupted to such an extent that it is ultimately drained of all meaning.

It is interesting to consider what people were expecting Britain’s Olympic legacy to look like. Vast numbers appear to have mistaken it for some sort of halcyon, Danny Boyle-curated Elysium. Lithe, smiling children skip through emerald-encrusted streets, gleefully hurling javelins. Kenneth Branagh leans against a row of red-brick houses, absent-mindedly reciting Shakespeare while the Chariots of Fire music plays on a loop. To whooping crowds, the wildly popular Michael Gove announces the construction of 100,000 new velodromes on existing brownfield sites.

It is hardly surprising, therefore, that when the reality fails to keep pace with the reverie, it is the legacy rather than the reverie that is blamed. “Tube out of service? So much for our Olympic legacy.”

“Just seen a fat kid eating a packet of crisps. Is that what Lord Coe meant by Olympic legacy?”

“Four consecutive days of rain? What sort of Olympic legacy is that, Lord Coe?”

The same lines were being trotted out after the launch of ITV1’s new game show Splash!, in which Tom Daley introduces an assortment of D-list celebrities to diving. For a start, the title seems a trifle misplaced, given that splash is a diver’s worst enemy; they may as well call a cycling show EPO! or a show featuring racehorses Shotgun!.

The programme itself is, at 90 minutes, around 84 minutes too long. Daley grins; Vernon Kay gurns; Gabby Logan, one of the few sources of true compassion in this turbulent world, sympathises. Almost without exception, the celebrities are desperate, washed-up and just a little bit tragic.

All well and bad. But it seems to me that the very existence of Splash! — a show about diving on prime time national television — is a wildly impressive feat in itself. If minority sport really is going to conquer the public consciousness, then gaudy, trashy TV for the masses is going to be one of the only means of doing so. The road to the mainstream may be paved with good intentions, but it will also be littered with detours into the adulterated and the hybridised.

What next? Pommel!, a celebrity gymnastics show featuring rising star Louis Smith, is my bet. Keel!, starring Ben Ainslie? Or possibly, given Splash!’s injudicious title, a celebrity boxing show entitled Cut Above The Eye!? Now that, to coin a phrase, would be Olympic legacy gone mad.

rank_51.title: Olympic legacy 'in tatters' over school sports failings, Labour claims
rank_51.text:
Teachers and parents have expressed dismay that Ministers are squandering the enthusiasm and passion generated by the success of last summer’s Olympics.

A majority of people think that official support for grassroots sport has either stagnated or been cut back since the Coalition came to power in 2010, a new survey found.

Just one in 10 people believe that the Government has increased its backing for sport in schools and communities.

Two-thirds of parents with children of school age or younger, felt that support had stayed the same or been reduced since 2010, with only 17 per cent saying it had increased, according to the poll for The Observer .

Critics have accused Michael Gove, the Education Secretary, of undermining the importance of school sport by scrapping the requirement for all pupils to have at least two hours of PE a week and dismantling Labour’s school sport partnerships, local networks of organised sport and competition.

Stephen Twigg, the shadow education secretary, claimed that the Government had failed to build on the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity created by the 2012 Games to improve children’s fitness.

He said: "Six months on, the Olympic legacy is in tatters. This survey shows those booing George Osborne in the Olympic Stadium spoke for the nation.

“We've seen partnerships that enabled primary school children to do competitive sport scrapped and the proportion of pupils doing two hours of sport a week collapse from 90 percent under Labour to 50 percent now.

“Labour would get Ofsted to inspect school sport, enable teaching assistants to become PE teachers, and ensure parents know how much sport their children get at school.”

A Government spokesman said: “We are working on a variety of measures to improve school sport as part of the Olympic and Paralympic legacy. We will announce our plans in due course.”

rank_98.title: Olympics companies to be allowed to use Games experience in marketing
rank_98.text:
The unsung businesses that helped design, build and run the venues, including the Olympic Park in Stratford, will be able to apply to be recognised as participants in creating the 2012 Games.

“This should be a catalyst in creating new business opportunities and further growth for these companies, and that is an important economic legacy of the Games,” said British Olympic Authority (BOA) chairman Lord Coe.

The deal between the Government, the BOA and the International Olympic Committee is the first of its kind after an Olympic Games. It comes as companies are looking to use the experience built up in London to pitch for work at major sporting events in Brazil, Russia and Qatar over the next decade.

Brazil is hosting the football World Cup next year and the Olympics in 2016. Russia is hosting the World Cup in 2018, with Qatar holding the event in 2022.

Almost all the small companies and many of the larger ones that took part in the Olympics have been unable to use their involvement with Games in promotion work because of strict licensing agreements. Restrictions on companies that worked on the Games were some of the toughest ever created for a sporting event of its kind.

However, with billions of pounds of business currently up for grabs and many UK companies well placed to secure it, pressure has been growing for some kind of relaxation in the rules.

The move was welcomed by the Federation of Small Businesses, although it warned that licences needed to be issued promptly to allow British businesses to leverage the experience they gained at the London Games.

Many household names, such as construction companies Balfour Beatty and McAlpine, worked on the Games for years leading up to the July opening. Although their participation is widely known about in their industries, they have not been allowed to trumpet their work elsewhere unless they paid to be sponsors.

Only official suppliers to the Games, companies that paid millions of pounds to carry the Olympic logo, have been allowed to associate themselves with the event. Around 40 companies paid £700m to sponsor the London Games in addition to the big, regular international sponsors of the event.

Companies that receive licences will now be allowed to promote their Olympic role at trade fairs and when going for international contracts.

The Government has put aside £2m to help fund the scheme, which will be operated by the BOA.

rank_171.title: Belgrave Harriers' men's team to bow out of British Athletics League due to lack of volunteers
rank_171.text:
The Wimbledon-based club, who were founded in the Belgravia area of London in 1887, boast the most successful record in league history with an unrivalled Premiership 11 titles but have been left with no choice but to leave the competition after seeing the number of volunteer officials drop from 30 in their heyday to six.

The decision raises concerns about the health of the sport at club level just six months after Britain’s athletes performed in front of full houses in London’s Olympic stadium.

Only last month, Sheffield City Council admitted it was considering demolishing Don Valley Stadium, the home track of Olympic heptathlon gold medallist Jessica Ennis and her Sheffield club, because it was too expensive to maintain.

Bill Laws, Belgrave’s long-serving men’s team manager and also chairman of the Association of British Athletics Clubs, said clubs were failing to see any Olympic legacy and that the success of a handful of elite athletes at London 2012 was disguising the sport’s decline at grass-roots level in terms of numbers of athletes, coaches and volunteers.

“The thing about athletics is that if you get one or two good athletes, the whole sport can survive with just those names,” he said.

“UK Athletics has really set its stall on a few very good athletes. Mo Farah is now virtually supporting the sport and it used to be Paula Radcliffe. You don’t need many for the sport to look as though it’s successful but, in point of fact, for those in the know the sport has declined to such a degree that it is now a minor sport really.”

Belgrave were founder members of the BAL in 1969 – the premier inter-club competition for male athletes – and their alumni include international stars such as John Regis, Jon Ridgeon and Paul Evans. Idowu and Chambers have been club members since their teens.

Although the women’s section, which includes javelin thrower Goldie Sayers, will continue to take part in the main UK Women’s Athletic League, the men’s team will now withdraw from the First Division and compete in lower-level meetings.

The club are also diversifying into the fitness industry, having received a £42,000 grant from Sport England to convert their clubhouse into a gym for general public use.

“I’m sad, but I’m realistic enough to realise that nothing’s for ever,” said Laws, who has run the men’s section since 1980. You get your highs and your lows.

"We’ve had the good times and we’ve enjoyed them and we’ve done our bit for bringing athletes through. We will continue to support our athletes and hopefully we’ll have more money in the future because we’re setting the club up on a more commercial basis.”

In its recent Active People Survey, Sport England reported that athletics had enjoyed an increase in participation levels since 2008 and rewarded the sport with an investment of £22 million, a rise of £1.6million, for the next four-year cycle.

But the headline figure of 2,033,700 people taking part in athletics at least once a week included recreational joggers. Sport England puts the number taking part in track and field at 91,700.

Meanwhile, Ennis has announced she will not compete indoors this year and will instead concentrate on regaining her title at this summer’s World Championships in Moscow.

Ennis, who is due to be married in the spring, is not expected to compete outdoors until a low-key Edinburgh Women’s League meeting on June 8. Her first heptathlon of the year is likely to be the European Cup Combined Events meeting in Tallinn, Estonia, on June 28-29.

Belgrave Harriers on the global stage

Phillips Idowu

Former world outdoor and indoor triple jump champion and silver medallist at 2008 Beijing Olympics.

Dwain Chambers

Former world indoor 60m champion who has rebuilt his career as Britain’s No 1 sprinter after serving a drugs ban.

William Sharman

110m hurdler who has finished fourth and fifth respectively at the last two World Championships.

John Regis

Former world indoor 200m champion and the only British athlete under 20 seconds for 200m.

Jon Ridgeon

Silver medallist in the 110m hurdles at the 1987 World Championships, beating Colin Jackson.

rank_56.title: Usain Bolt gifted a tax-free trip to London for 2012 Games anniversary meeting at Olympic Stadium
rank_56.text:
With the exception of the Olympics, Bolt has not raced in Britain since 2009 because the tax rules for foreign sports stars would leave him out of pocket.

But the Chancellor has agreed to a “one-off exemption” for the meeting that will allow the triple Olympic champion and the rest of the world’s leading overseas athletes to compete tax-free in a reprise of the track and field programme at the London Olympics.

Osborne said: “The Government is determined to do everything possible to secure the Olympic legacy and I am delighted to grant this exemption.”

The Chancellor’s decision follows a series of meetings with Lord Coe, the London 2012 chairman and now the Government’s Olympics legacy ambassador, who had lobbied for the tax rules to be waived to allow Bolt to take part.

Although stars such as double Olympic champion Mo Farah and heptathlon gold medallist Jessica Ennis had already pledged their support for the event, the presence of the world’s most iconic athlete will add lustre to the anniversary celebrations.

The meeting, which forms part of the international Diamond League series, was originally due to be staged in its traditional home of Crystal Palace but was switched to the Olympic Stadium last month to mark the first anniversary of the Games on July 27.

It is understood that the meeting will retain its two-day format, with an evening session on Friday, July 26, and a second session the following day. The two days of competition are now set to be one of the highlights of the athletics summer, possibly even rivalling the World Championships in Moscow in August in terms of spectator interest.

The huge number of people who have already registered for priority tickets on the UK Athletics website means there are high hopes that both sessions will be an 80,000 sell-out.

Bolt has always insisted that he would love to compete in Britain again, particularly because London is his main European base during the summer season, but tax regulations made it impossible because he would be paying out more than he earned.

Although he commands a typical appearance fee of $250,000 (£160,000), tax rules mean he would be paying tax not just on his earnings at the meeting but on a proportion of his entire global income, including his multi-million dollar sponsorship deals.

Last night Bolt’s London-based agent, Ricky Simms, welcomed Osborne’s decision to relax the rules.

“It’s good news for the Diamond League meeting and British sport in general,” he said. “The rules were discouraging a lot of the top stars from competing in the UK when they had options elsewhere.”

Simms added that Bolt had already signed contracts to compete in various meets around the world this summer and he would now have to talk to the sprinter and his coach, Glen Mills, about adding London to his programme.

Simms said: “I think it’s about two weeks before the World Championships, which is quite late, but it’s London and it’s the Olympic Stadium again so it obviously has an attraction.”

It is understood that Osborne was persuaded to offer the tax concession because of the significance of the anniversary and the importance of cementing an Olympic legacy. The loss of tax revenue is believed to be negligible compared to the wider benefits to London and athletics.

The exemption affects only non-resident athletes, and covers any appearance fees, prize money and the slice of sponsorship income that would normally be taxable.

A Treasury source said the Chancellor was keen to play his part in building on the momentum of the Games by re-creating another “Super Saturday” in the stadium. Privately, there is high praise for the efforts of Coe in arguing for a tax amnesty and banging the drum for athletics.

The news has been welcomed by UK Athletics, which said in a statement: “We are delighted with the announcement from the Chancellor, which recognises the unique nature of this summer’s weekend of international athletics in the Olympic Stadium marking the first anniversary of London 2012.”

The governing body has yet to announce a new sponsorship deal since its contract with Aviva expired at the end of last year but the prospect of two capacity crowds in the Olympic Stadium will be a big selling point for would-be corporate backers.

The London Grand Prix will be the first sports meeting to be exempted from the tax rules for non-resident athletes at the discretion of the Government.

The 2011 Champions League final at Wembley and the Olympic Games were both subject to a tax amnesty but that was a contractual obligation agreed with Uefa and the International Olympic Committee. This year’s Champions League final and the 2014 Commonwealth Games in Glasgow have similar contractual exemptions.

rank_45.title: Where did that Olympic legacy go?
rank_45.text:
Could Britain’s body image be any more warped? It’s hard to believe that we spent last summer gazing in admiration and envy at our honed, toned Olympians. We watched the lithe, fit, not necessarily able‑bodied, athletes run and swim and dive. We were riveted by Bradley Wiggins cycling and Katherine Grainger rowing to victory; here were sportsmen and women of all shapes and sizes; the one thing they had in common was that they were in peak physical condition.

But instead of striving to emulate them, we snacked in front of the telly and put on a collective 18.9 million stone – much of it, apparently, in Tamworth, which has led to the town being crowned the chubbiest place in the country.

Whither the inspirational 2012 legacy, now that we have figures from the Health and Social Care Information Centre (HSCIC) showing that 10 per cent of children are obese by the time they enter primary school? More alarming still, that rises to an appalling 20 per cent by the time they leave, presumably having devoured their SATS (and the classroom furniture).

At the other end of the spectrum, we also learnt this week of the death, from anorexia, of “bright and beautiful” Laura Willmott, a privately educated 18-year-old, who used her considerable intelligence to engage in what was described as “breathtaking” deceit against those who fought so hard to keep her alive.

Her terrible plight makes harrowing reading for any parent, not least because once she passed her milestone birthday, Laura was deemed old enough to make the decisions governing her care.

Old enough maybe, but surely not well enough. It’s hard to reconcile the photograph of a pretty, poised teenager with the medical details that emerged in the coroner’s court – malnourishment, hair loss, a weight of five stone that left her too weak to walk and reduced her to effortful crawling.

Her mother, Vickie Townsend, a nurse, was deeply unhappy when her daughter was discharged from hospital in Bristol in October 2011 as “an experiment” to see if she could cope. She couldn’t. Within weeks she was re‑hospitalised and died. Now it is her family who must see if they can cope.

Laura’s case is an extreme example, but figures from the HSCIC reveal that the rate of hospital admissions for treatment of eating disorders increased by 16 per cent over the past year. Most – 91 per cent – were girls and the majority 55 per cent were aged between 10 and 19.

Anorexia is mental illness rooted in an individual’s irrational belief that they are fat. The obesity epidemic arises from parents en masse overfeeding their children in the irrational belief that they aren’t fat.

The HSCIC discovered that half of the parents of obese children thought they were “about the right weight”.
