rank_19.title: Olympic and Paralympic legacy rewarded by Boris Johnson as organisations use Games to initiate social change
rank_19.text: Bois Johson, Lord Coe and Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson were among the attendees who saw organisations rewarded for using London 2012 to initiate positive social change. The six award winners named at the Beyond London 2012 Awards will receive business support and/or funding packages through the Beyond Sport Foundation. Boris Johnson's own sports participation fund has supported one of the winners – E18HTEEN– a programme run by the Tottenham Hotspur Foundation providing one-to-one mentor support for young people who are not in education, employment or training. Mr Johnson also announced that a further £2.7m from his fund is now available for community projects to improve facilities such as club buildings and playing fields. He said: “Helping more people get active, more regularly was always at the heart of London's 2012 Games. Beyond Sport's inspirational winners show that an army of dedicated folk are keeping the Olympic and Paralympic flame alive in communities across the capital." Twitter: Boris Johnson - Thrilled to announce £2.7m additional investment to support the grassroots sports legacy of the Games. #BeyondLondon2012 Other winners included School of Hard Knocks, a rugby programme that uses sport to tackle the issues surrounding unemployment, Fathers Football which helps teenage fathers strengthen relationships with their children through football and Born to Succeed, a project helping young Muslim girls to participate in sport. Lord Coe said of the awards: "London 2012 gave this country a once in a lifetime opportunity to boost sport’s place as the unseen social worker." "As we focus on securing a strong legacy and look to the future it is important that those programmes and projects which have successfully capitalised on the opportunity are rewarded, and that the UK does not lose sight of the future opportunities in this area. That is why awards such as these that show the strong legacy that is in place are so important." Lord Coe also announced the launch of the charity International Inspiration which will continue London 2012’s international legacy programme. He said "This venture is an opportunity for me and others to be involved personally in making sure that the legacy of London 2012 benefits the youth of the world for many years to come, and that the UK continues to blaze a trail as a global leader in enriching lives through sport for development."

rank_203.title: Keep the Flame Alive: Two school playing fields a month sold since 2012 Olympics
rank_203.text:
Figures published by the Department for Education show that 50 playing fields between May 2010 when the new Government was formed and June 2013.

Of those, 19 applications were approved by ministers since last August’s London 2012 Olympics, which was meant to increase sports participation.

The figures also disclose that the Government over-ruled its own advisers on playing fields six times in the past three years.

Last year Education secretary Michael Gove was forced to apologise after an investigation by The Daily Telegraph found that the number of school playing fields in England sold off was higher than had been previously admitted.

The revelations led to tens of thousands of people to sign a petition urging Mr Gove to bring in more protections for playing fields.

Labour criticised the sales. Stephen Twigg MP, Shadow Education Secretary, said: “David Cameron and Michael Gove are putting the Olympic legacy at risk.

“Parents will be shocked that the Government is still selling off playing fields, many against the advice of the independent playing fields panel. School sport provision is already patchy since Michael Gove dismantled Labour’s School Sports Partnerships.

“The Government needs to focus on school sport – they should start by restoring Labour’s minimum requirement that all children do at least 2 hours of PE and competitive sport every week.”

When playing fields are sold other sports facilities were put in their place, while any proceeds had to be put back into improving sports and school facilities.

A department spokesman said: “The number of playing fields approved for disposal by the Government is falling. It is not the Government or the Department for Education that instigates the disposal of school playing fields.

“It is the schools themselves and their local authorities that propose to convert these often surplus or un-used fields to invest in school sport or education. Local authorities must consult widely prior to making an application.

“This Government will only give local authorities and schools permission to dispose of school playing fields if the sports and curriculum needs of the school and its neighbouring schools can continue to be met.”

Some 10,000 playing fields were sold off between 1979 and 1997 under the Tories. But under Labour, between 1997 and 2010, only 226 were sold.

rank_129.title: Vince Cable: Case for HS2 still being made
rank_129.text:
The Business Secretary’s comments are the first indication of jitters about the projected cost of the link between London, the Midlands and the North.

Earlier this month transport secretary Patrick McLoughlin warned that the cost had climbed by £10billion to £43billion.

However writing in The Daily Telegraph, Mr Johnson said: “This thing isn’t going to cost £42 billion, my friends. The real cost is going to be way north of that (keep going till you reach £70 billion, and then keep going).”

In an interview on BBC Radio Four Today programme on Friday, Mr Cable confirmed that costs were still being looked at.

He said: “Well, the case for High Speed 2, which is still being made – I mean, the figures, as you know, are being revisited – have to meet a standard of cost/benefit analysis which the Treasury seeks, and which meet the requirements of the Green Book, as it’s called, on public investment.”

The news came as the Business Secretary admitted that a Government claim that the Olympics have been worth £10bilion to Britain's economy may not survive “a rigorous academic approach” although they had been approved by auditors.

But Mr Cable said that that the Government had been right to try to work out the degree to which Britain had benefited economically from the London Games.

The Government published figures on Friday that claimed there had been a £9.9 billion boost to the economy from the Games in the last 12 months.

More contracts have been secured for British firms and more foreign investment has been made in Britain as a result of the Olympics, the government said.

If true, this means that the cost of the Games – estimated to be under £9 billion – will be been outweighed by the economic benefits.

However the figures were questioned by presenter and former economist Evan Davis, on the BBC Radio Four Today programme because it included a new £2.5bllion shopping centre, 16 miles away from the Olympic Park in Croydon, south London.

Mr Cable replied: “I can understand a rigorous academic approach that is sceptical of these things, that is entirely justified, but there is more in it than you are giving credit for.”

He added that this was “using methods approved by the National Audit Office which is a very tough test.

“It is the best we can do – it is not necessarily something that would pass muster in the best academic journals but a test of credibility has been applied to it.”

Mr Cable continued: “The analysis that was done involved talking to the companies who were making the inward investment and asking them the question: ‘Would you have invested otherwise?’”

He said that the question was “would this have happened anyway. Well some of these activities clearly would – but the Olympics was a key catalyst in making those investment decisions real.”

Asked by Mr Davis if he “really, really believed” the figures, Mr Cable added: “It is reasonable to argue that in a lot of these big inward investment decisions, there is a catalyst, they may well have been proceeding.

“But a lot of negotiations were brought to a head by the Olympics, by the top executives coming; I met quite a lot of them myself.”

He said that the effect of the Olympics was that talks with top business people had progressed better than they otherwise would have done.

Mr Cable said an anonymised survey, using methods “approved by the National Audit Office”, had tried “to establish things have happened that would not have otherwise taken place”.

The research also found the London Olympics are forecast to deliver a £41 billion boost to the British economy by 2020.

Almost one and a half million more people play sport every week and a future has been secured for all the permanent venues on the Olympic Park.

However, the report, published on the first anniversary of the Games, warned that it will be a “challenge” to create a lasting Olympic legacy of more volunteers.

And while the Paralympics improved public attitudes to disabled people, this has been undermined by the debate over the government’s welfare reforms, the evaluation suggested.

After the Games last year, The Telegraph launched the Keep the Flame Alive campaign to increase volunteering and return competitive sport to all schools following the success of the Olympics.

rank_72.title: Britain will have to step up volunteering efforts to protect Olympic legacy, says Lord Coe
rank_72.text:
The peer, who oversaw the Games and now holds the role of Olympic Ambassador, said it was “tough” to convert the 70,000 “games makers” who volunteered last year into regular helpers at sports clubs.

Volunteering has been hailed as one of the successful legacies of the Games, which began on July 27 last year.

Lord Coe told a hearing at the House of Lords that it took hard work to translate enthusiasm for one-off volunteering into the regular commitment required by grass roots sport.

“I am not sure that the motivation for many of those games makers to take part in what we saw last summer, Olympic and Paralympic, is going to extend to coming out of an Olympic stadium and running the line at Tunbridge Wells Rugby Club or raking the sandpit at the Hallamshire Harriers in Sheffield,” he said.

“We will have to look at this slightly differently. Going back to the 10 years that we have in front of us with these great sporting events, we can excite volunteers around that, but we are going to have to work quite hard to convert those volunteers into community sports.”

Lord Coe described the challenge as a “tough one” that has “not always been captured in other [previous host] cities either.”

Yesterday, charities and sports groups said that Lord Coe was correct to say that a lot of effort and support was needed to encourage volunteering.

Andy Reed, the chairman of the Sport and Recreation Alliance, said: “Giving up your time to volunteer at an exciting one-off event is totally different to giving up your time week in, week out to help out at your local hockey or netball club — this requires long-term commitment from people and this is where the challenge still lies.”

Mr Reed’s group represents 300 sporting associations including the FA, the Rugby Football Union and British Athletics.

Joe Irvin, chief executive of the National Association for Voluntary and Community Action, said it was a “challenge to maintain the enthusiasm” but one which organisations were embracing.

“The big one for us is how to turn a volunteer at a big event into a regular volunteer in the local community,” he said. “There was a big increase in volunteering in London, but it was much more patchy elsewhere in the country.”

He said he hoped the volunteer spirit of the Olympics would be refreshed by campaigns such as Britain’s Personal Best — a drive to get people to set challenges for themselves.

The National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) and the Royal Voluntary Service (RVS) said they had seen an increase in volunteering over the past year in the wake of the Olympic spirit.

Dr Justin Davis Smith, of the NCVO, said: “It might have been lurking in the back of someone’s mind but it usually takes some kind of trigger. That’s what the Olympics did. Every day you saw it being visible in a way it’s normally not.”

The challenge, he said, would be finding volunteers the right positions to suit them.

rank_22.title: 'Staggering’ pay-off for the £1m Olympic Games boss
rank_22.text:
Dennis Hone, the former chief executive of the Olympic Delivery Authority, received almost £1 million last year in salary, bonuses, pension ­contributions and severance pay, according to the organisation’s annual report.

On the eve of the first anniversary of the London 2012 Games, it emerged that he and three other executives received pay-offs worth £638,000 between them.

In total, 144 officials who left the Olympic Delivery Authority over the past year were given £2.8 million in compensation between them.

The executives received the pay-offs because they were put on permanent contracts, despite the fact that the authority is due to wind down after 2014.

Stephen Barclay, a Conservative member of the House of Commons public accounts committee, said: “I am deeply concerned to learn of these staggering pay-offs, which are clearly out of touch with the principle of the Olympics legacy and supporting grass-roots sport.

“It is perverse. We knew when the Olympics were going to finish, and executives should not be allowed to profit like this.”

Mr Hone was appointed as chief executive of the authority in February 2011, replacing Sir David Higgins, who joined Network Rail.

Mr Hone was paid £233,000 in salary, a bonus of £153,000 and received £36,000 in pension contributions. He also spent two days a week as interim chief executive of the London Legacy Development Corporation, the body overseeing the legacy of the Olympic Park. He was paid £90,000 for this. The two jobs brought his total pay package last year to £512,000.

In addition, he was given an £80,000 exit package, including a “terminal bonus” and redundancy pay. The authority also paid an extra £373,000 into his pension pot. This meant that in total, he was paid £965,000 last year.

He was entitled to the pay-off because Jeremy Hunt, the former culture secretary who is now Health Secretary, put him on a permanent contract when he appointed him.

Mr Hone has since been appointed as the full-time chief executive of the London Legacy Development Corporation, where his basic pay is £195,000 a year.

Boris Johnson, the Mayor of London, has praised him for his “wealth of skills and experience”.

A spokesman for the authority said payments to Mr Hone were “legal and contractual obligations”, saying: “We used a variety of incentives to recruit the best staff, who proved themselves by completing venues and infrastructure on time and under budget, in fact making savings of over £1 billion.

“We had to adopt a flexible approach to managing staff contracts to ensure that key people, especially directors, remained with the project throughout periods critical to its success, until such time as the ODA could be certain that their skills and knowledge were no longer required.”

rank_94.title: Olympic Delivery Authority staff get £2.8 million in the form of exit payments in last financial year
rank_94.text:
One hundred and forty-four staff were given redundancy payments after being given permanent contracts, despite the authority winding down in 2014.

Dennis Hone, the ODA's chief executive, who was made redundant at the end of March, was paid an exit payment of £80,000, as well as an immediate pension of £373,000.

The ODA's annual report and accounts said Hone, now chief executive of the London Legacy Development Corporation, was entitled to statutory redundancy pay and a terminal bonus equivalent to 60 per cent of his salary.

It said: "The remuneration committee decided to award a terminal bonus of 49 per cent of his salary and to defer 50 per cent of the bonus until the successful completion of the sale of East Village to QDD."

The ODA's director of transport, Hugh Sumner, also received £73,000 in exit payments, while director of venues and infrastructure Simon Wright received £72,000.

rank_61.title: Olympic legacy 'threatened by poor quality PE', say MPs
rank_61.text:
In a report, the Commons Education Select Committee warned that successive governments had used school sport as a “political football”, prioritising short-term “pump-priming” over sustained investment.

It was claimed that PE lessons were still not good enough in almost a third of primary schools, with some teachers given just one day’s training to deliver the subject.

The cross-party group warned that too many schools had “inadequate access” to high-quality facilities such as swimming pools, preventing children meeting the national requirement to swim 25 metres by the age of 11.

Policies designed to get more children to take part in competitive sports such as football, rugby or netball – a centrepiece of Government PE reforms – can also “deter many young people from taking part in sport at all”, the report said.

A study last week found that the UK economy had seen a £9.9bn boost in trade and investment from hosting the 2012 London Olympic and Paralympic Games.

Ministers have repeatedly claimed that the Games would have a positive impact on school sport.

But research last year found that half of children failed to do at least two hours of PE each week and one-in-seven teenagers did not get any sport at all in the last year of school.

In today’s report, MPs praised a number of Government reforms such as the pledge to train 120 new primary PE specialists but insisted it would have limited impact on England’s 17,000 primary schools.

It was also pointed out that new “primary sport premium” funding was only in place for two years, which was “not sufficient to allow a long-term provision to be built”.

In a series of recommendations, the report suggested that the Government should effectively reintroduce a previous Labour target requiring all pupils to complete two hours of PE a week, which was axed by the Coalition. It was needed to make sure “key groups” such as girls and obese children get enough access to exercise, MPs said.

The report also criticised the controversial decision to scrap the last Government’s School Sports Partnership – a scheme linking pupils with local sports clubs and coaches – saying that it had a “negative impact” on children’s access to coaching.

The study suggested that a new cut-price version of the programme should be reintroduced.

Graham Stuart, the committee’s Conservative chairman, said the Olympics was a “magical time”, but added: “The Government needs to act to ensure that the momentum is not lost amid short-term plans and funding. If school sport is to grow, it needs sustained funding and time to develop.”

He added: “Successive governments have kicked school sport around as a political football, announcing short-term fixes without any sustained vision for the future. Occasional pump-priming is simply not good enough for something so important.”

Stephen Twigg, the Shadow Education Secretary, said the Government had “failed to create a legacy for school sport”.

rank_23.title: Olympic legacy hampered by 'barmy' lack of national strategy, says former London 2012 deputy chairman
rank_23.text:
As the anniversary of the London Games approaches, Mills says the country has not done enough to work together to improve the provision of sport.

He admits he is "frustrated" at the lack of progress since London 2012 and says the government needs to take a lead on developing a national strategy.

"[Sports participation] is not growing as much as we want. I do think there is an opportunity for the government to be more joined up," he said in an interview with The Guardian.

"It hasn't happened. I'd like the government to develop a national sports strategy that brings together health, education, sports clubs and local authorities. At the moment, they all pretty much do their own thing and that seems to me to be a real waste.

"For me the big step change would have been a national sports strategy, with organisations coming together to use the assets we've got.

rank_120.title: Mo Farah 'stronger' than ever as makes emotional return to Olympic Stadium for Anniversary Games
rank_120.text:
The Londoner competes in the 3,000 metres at the Sainsbury’s Anniversary Games on Saturday and if he produces anything like the speed he generated in his 1500m race in Monaco last Friday when he shattered Steve Cram’s UK record, then David Moorcroft’s 31-year-old UK 3,000m mark of 7min 32.79sec will also be obliterated.

Whether he attacks it will depend on the say-so of his American coach, Alberto Salazar, who will have his eye on the bigger picture of ensuring he is at the peak of his powers when he attempts to repeat his Olympic feat by winning golds in the 5,000m and 10,000m at the World Championships in two weeks’ time.

Record attempt or not, Farah arrives in east London as arguably the most dominant track athlete in the world this year and with an aura of invincibility that not even Usain Bolt can claim on current form.

“I’m definitely stronger, more experienced but it all depends on championships,” Farah said. “I am definitely a better athlete than I was, but you have to go and do it when it matters.”

In the afterglow of Monaco, where he only entered the 1500m to sharpen up his speed for Moscow and came away with a time of 3-28.81 that puts him sixth in the global all-time list, Farah admitted he was in the best physical shape of his life and attributed it to running with “joy” and without the pressures he faced in Olympic year.

“I’ve never been this happy in my life. I’m enjoying running and doing what I do, instead of thinking that I have to do something.”

No longer burdened by the nation’s expectations, he returns to Stratford determined to enjoy every moment of the raucous reception that awaits him from the capacity 60,000 crowd a year after he was roared to victory in the 5,000m to complete his historic double.

"It would be amazing if they made same noise. It will never be the same again, having the Olympics at that moment, but it will be great if it is close to that. They said the photo finish camera shook with the noise. That showed how loud it was in that race.”

Farah admits it will be emotional to be back in the Olympic Stadium, but above all it will be exciting. “I’ve been back there once since for a photo shoot and it was an empty stadium. You picture things, where you were at that that point and what happened. It will be quite emotional but at the same time it will be great to go back and win.”

With Greg Rutherford nursing a hamstring injury and Jessica Ennis-Hill still not certain to compete this weekend because of a long-standing ankle problem, the organisers’ best-laid plans to stage a Super Saturday reunion have been thwarted. Fortunately, though, Farah still has vivid recall of the greatest night in the history of British athletics.

“It was very exciting,” he said. “I was just buzzing. At the same time there was a lot of pressure, but having an Olympics on your doorsteps, coming into the stadium and having people shout your name, was just incredible. It was something I could never imagine.

“I knew Jess had done well and could see her going round and celebrating. Out of the corner of my eye I could see Greg was super-happy too. I didn’t know how well he had done but I knew he was up there. The crowd was just getting louder, so I knew he had done well.”

Saturday’s race will be Farah’s last before Moscow, where his target is nothing less than two golds – one better than at the 2011 World Championships in Daegu, where he had to settle for silver in the 10,000m.

Lord Coe, who was relegated from second to third on the all-time UK 1500m list following Farah’s speed show in Monaco, believes his all-round running ability will make him virtually unstoppable in Russia.

“He’s obviously very quick,” Coe said. “You have to say that the great thing he’s got over anybody else in the field by a country mile is that he can run it anyway he wants. We know he can run from the front if he has to and we know he can make a long run home if he wants to, but when you’ve got 3.28 under the bonnet, does it really matter?

“Anybody who’s running 3.28 and has the kind of times that he posts at 3,000, tells me that he’s going to be incredibly difficult to beat on current form.

"It’s a hell of thing for a field to go into a race knowing that there’s a guy in that field that, if you let him go on his own 1200 metres out he’s going to run away from you but if you leave it late and it becomes cat and mouse, he’s got every weapon in the armoury to win it whichever way he wants.

“It’s an extraordinary range of skills to have and clearly he’s been doing the right things in training to be get that kind of leg speed.”

If we don’t get it right now, we’ll lose the momentum we gained from London.”

WRESTLING

Elite funding pre-2012: £1,435,210

Elite funding post-2012: £0

Adult participation pre-2012: 459*

Adult participation post-2012: 648*

British Wrestling chief executive Colin Nicholson: “Losing our elite funding has been hugely difficult. It’s very much a Catch-22. Athletes have to get a job but then can’t train hard enough, so can’t fulfil their potential. But we’ll be making a case to get money back in October as we have medalled since and one of our wrestlers is ranked fourth in the world. September’s also a huge month because the International Olympic Committee will vote on whether wrestling remains on the Games programme in 2020.”

* Figure is for number of members as participation is too low to be measured accurately.

rank_27.title: Britain's Olympic heroes are the true inspiration for legacy of the London Games
rank_27.text:
Gone are the wild flower meadows, the basketball arena and the hockey stadium. Gone, too, are the less lamented giant McDonald’s outlets and the bar selling warm champagne at £30 a bottle. Everywhere are cranes and diggers and hillocks of ballast.

Still there were sufficient landmarks to make the place recognisable: round the velodrome we went, past the media centre, before, after circling the Orbit tower, we ended up in the stadium. And it was at that point that I realised the utter futility of scepticism.

The stands were about half full of runners’ friends and family, plus many of those who had already completed the route. A good 25,000 people were in there and looking up at them as they waved, clapped and shouted was an invigorating sight.

But it was the noise that really knocked me back. As we ran in, moments of commentary from last year’s athletics programme boomed out of the public address system, playing on a loop, serving as a greeting for every runner.

Just as I began to circuit the track, the closing moments of Mo Farah’s 10,000-metre victory were replaying all around. I looked at my fellow entrants and realised that every single one of us was grinning.

The reaction was written there on every face: all of us were, just for a moment, recalling what had happened on Super Saturday and were imagining ourselves to be Mo. It put a spring in the weariest of steps; lifted by a communal surge of adrenalin, there was not a runner there who did not attempt to sprint for the line. Even those who were walking broke into a jog.

It was astonishing to observe. Like a sort of evangelical prayer meeting, suddenly everyone was infected by the spirit of the place. There was no one involved who would not have deposited in their memory banks the moment they crossed the line of the Olympic Stadium doing the Mobot (and yes, I did).

It was seeing this reaction that made me realise where the true legacy of the Olympics can be found. Until that point I was not entirely convinced the Games would have much relevant life beyond last summer’s extravaganza. It seemed to me that what we had paid for was a fortnight-long carnival; fun for sure, but not something that was going to effect permanent change.

I thought all Lord Coe’s insistence of a lasting benefit was a smokescreen to justify the vast expenditure: he wanted us to believe there would be something more tangible from spending £9 billion than a shiny new home for West Ham.

But watching the runners complete the course, telling each other as they lined up for their souvenir goody bag that it was the best thing they had done, it became obvious from where any wider effect of the Games will be derived. It is from the achievement of the British team. That is what drove those runners to arrive in east London at some absurdly early time on a Sunday morning.

That is what sold out this weekend’s Anniversary Games within an hour of tickets being made available. The opportunity to run where they had run, or to sit in the stadium where they had delivered so much, is what proved inspirational.

Had the same building staged victories solely by Jamaicans, Kenyans and Americans the response would not have been anything like as enthusiastic. It is not bricks and mortar that will haul people off their sofa to participate or watch. It is local success.

The stadium has particular meaning for us because of what Farah, Jessica Ennis, Greg Rutherford and David Weir did in it. Had we spent last summer simply observing the efforts of Usain Bolt, David Rudisha and Allyson Felix, this weekend’s anniversary event would be half empty.

You might call it the Murray effect. Every year the All England Club hosts a beautifully staged tournament at Wimbledon. But it is only this year, when Andy Murray won there, that rackets have been dragged from cupboards in quite such profusion.

There is no way the number of small boys currently thrashing a ball around their local park court would have been out there if Novak Djokovic had won. For events and facilities – however splendid – to have any wider resonance they need a meaning, a meaning that comes from winning performance by those who grab the local imagination.

If on Sunday what I saw in action was the sum total of the Olympic legacy, it will still be a significant thing. What we runners were out there doing, in our limited, wheezing, flabby way, was attempting to emulate what we had seen. It is the memory that inspires. Fortunately for Lord Coe and his extravagant promises of how his Games would change our nation’s emotional and physical landscape, those memories linger powerfully indeed.

Ian Botham has turned me off Sky

Watching Sky’s coverage of the Ashes (and I have done little else for the past fortnight) one important question needs to be answered. It is nothing to do with Australian batting failures or the deficiencies of the DRS system.

It is simply this: how come no one in the production office has told Ian Botham that repeated, stuck-record jokes about David Gower’s butler are about as funny as reading your latest bank statement?

No expired nag has ever suffered such a thrashing as that administered by the knight of the realm on an observation that was at best passably amusing the first time it was uttered back in 1997.

So slack-jawed in astonishment have I become at its endless overuse, I have latterly deserted the excellent Michael Atherton and adopted a watching technique my father swore by 40 years ago. I have taken to turning down the television volume and tuning in to Test Match Special.

The schoolboy burblings of Henry Blofeld, the knowing chuckle of Vic Marks, the shrewd analysis of Jonathan Agnew are like aural balm after Botham and his butler. Indeed, so woefully unfunny is the Botham shtick it makes Phil Tufnell sound like Oscar Wilde. Which, we can all agree, is an unlikely achievement.

rank_26.title: Boris hails Olympic baby boom
rank_26.text:
The Mayor of London said the “euphoria” in the wake of Team GB’s success at last summer’s Games has led to a surge in births not seen in the capital since 1967, the year after England won the football World Cup.

Mr Johnson said he had instructed his City Hall demographics team to study the birth data after recalling last year telling Olympic medal winners that they had caused such joy in Britain that they had “not only inspired a generation, [but] probably helped to create one as well”.

His comments came ahead of the one-year anniversary of the Games this weekend, which will be marked by a series of athletics events in the Olympic Stadium.

Usain Bolt, the current 100 and 200 metres record-holder, has returned to London to take part in the competition and was on Thursday forced to distance himself from the latest doping scandal to engulf sprinting.

Bolt said that he is a “clean” athlete and that he had been doing “phenomenal things” since he was 15.

Sprinters including American Tyson Gay and Jamaican Asafa Powell, both finalists at London 2012, have recently tested positive for banned substances.

Mr Johnson claimed that his statisticians have estimated that the number of births in London in 2013 will be 137,900.

The Mayor said that there were approximately 135,000 births in 2012 and 134,000 the year before that.

“That tells us that we’ve got an Olympic baby boom legacy,” he told BBC London radio.

“We’re now up to the biggest number since…the year after the World Cup.”

The Mayor added: “I said as a kind of joke at the end of the Olympics and Paralympics, I said to the team that you’ve caused such paroxysms of joy on the sofas of Britain that you’ve not only inspired a generation, you probably helped to create one as well.

“And actually, when you look at the demographics of what’s happening in the maternity wards of London it turns out to be broadly true.”

Mr Johnson disclosed that a giant snow dome to rival the largest indoor ski resort in the world is to be built next to the Olympic Park.

The £200million ski centre will feature several runs of varying difficulty, snowboard ramps and an ice-skating rink.

Hugh Robertson, the Sports Minister, said that the full value of hosting the Games will not be able to be judged for up to 10 years.

However, he said that the impact on sport from hosting Olympics is “already extraordinary and compelling”.

rank_73.title: 'Our stadium rehearsals for the medal ceremonies were a disaster but luckily it was alright on the night'
rank_73.text:
I am retired and I knew that it was very unlikely I was going to be able to afford many tickets to see any of the action, so I thought, “This might be a good way of seeing some of it” and it would be great fun.

I ended up in charge of flags for the Olympic Stadium’s medal ceremonies and was there for every day of the Olympics and Paralympics.

The only thing I knew about the flags was that, at the front of the teams in the athletes’ parade, one person carried a flag. so I said to them: “I think you’ve got the wrong guy.” Luckily for me they hadn’t.

We went through a vast amount of training, about 15 days in total.

We were inundated with health-and-safety talks and the importance of political correctness. But there was nobody there who had ever had anything to do with flags at all.

Our two rehearsals at the stadium were disastrous, really. The flagpoles didn’t work and then there was an emergency re-order of flags because they didn’t fit them.

There was also a major scare in the last few days when we nearly put the British flag up instead of the German flag.

We’d gone through all the checks and, unfortunately, one of the checks had been done twice by the same guy, who made the same mistake both times, pulling out the GBR flag instead of the GER flag.

The flag store was a 15-minute walk from where the ceremonies took place so there was no choice but to delay the presentation.

But the most memorable moment was the tearful reaction we got when we broke all the rules by handing Mo Farah a Union flag on the last day of competition. He was overwhelmed.

After the Games, I was asked to present a paper at a Flag Institute Conference on my experiences at London 2012.

I wrote a report, which I kept as positive as I could – because it really was a great experience – but making it clear that a lot of things could have been done much better.

I also wrote to the International Olympic Committee and the International Paralympic Committee. Eventually, I got a letter back from the IOC thanking me for my report but insisting that any organisational problems were the host country’s problem and not the IOC’s.

London 2012 did renew my willingness to be a volunteer, which was at a little bit of a low ebb because I hadn’t been all that successful in my previous efforts.

I have contacted various Games since – such as the Commonwealth Games, Rio etc – with a view to being involved in some way in those as well, but I haven’t had a reply from any of them.

I would love to volunteer at those events but I would need to have my expenses covered, which is probably the biggest problem for me.

I was fortunate in London in being able to stay with my son in Lewisham, without which I could not have had the involvement I did.

I’m having slight withdrawal symptoms this summer with the anniversary coming up. I’m planning to watch recordings of the Games!

I met lots of new people but one disappointment is that everybody goes their own way afterwards.

I still exchange emails with the flag manager, and we’ve met up a couple of times, but all the others were from different parts of the country. So it hasn’t ended up with a legacy of friendships. I do still have my uniform. It’s in the wardrobe in the black bag it came in. And no, I’ve not worn it since.

rank_29.title: What did London Olympics 2012 do for us?
rank_29.text:
A couple of days into the London Olympics last July, the heavens opened; about a month’s worth of rain fell in a half-hour deluge. As the torrent came down, I was dashing from the Olympic Park to Stratford station when I passed a young man sitting atop a stepladder. He was a volunteer, one of the small army of purple-clad Games Makers on duty across London.

And, despite the cascade falling on his head, he showed no inclination to desert his job of directing visitors to the transport links. Soaked to the bone he may have been, but, as I passed, he serenaded me in song through his megaphone. And the tune? He was reprising that great anthem of carefree optimism, he was singing Singin' in the Rain in the rain.

It was that moment, barely hours into the event, that first made me fully appreciate the Olympic effect. What this cavalcade of running, jumping and – in the case of many a British gold medallist – sitting was doing was this: it had given us Brits permission to be enthusiastic.

Everywhere you went the mood was the same, an overwhelming can-do spirit prevailed. There was the volunteer at Custom House DLR station rapping out directions for hours – days – on end. There was the middle-aged Games Maker high-fiving everyone who passed her as she picked up litter in Hyde Park. There were thousands of wonderfully helpful people you encountered across our capital, their faces surely aching with all that grinning.

For once friendliness, civility and good cheer were the dominant moods as London embraced the world. Among the volunteers, among the supporters in the magnificent venues across the city, even on the sofas of the nation, suddenly our collective attitude had swung in an upwards trajectory. No longer were we a bunch whose glass is invariably half-empty. For a glorious few weeks our cup was not just half-full, it was overflowing with positivity.

Not that many were predicting beforehand that this would be the case. In the weeks immediately before it all began, the vibrations on the radio, in the newspapers and on that 140-character shredder of reputation Twitter, insisted that we should prepare ourselves for national humiliation.

The way it was being told, everything that could go wrong with our hosting of the Games was certain to go wrong. We had outsourced the security operation to cack-handed, greedy incompetents, we had surrendered our civil liberties to the commercial interests of the sponsors, and allowed London’s road network to be thrown into jeopardy in order to accommodate the Ruritanian requirements of officials. Travel agents reported a surge of late bookings as people sought to flee from the anticipated omnishambles.

As a strategy, however, the escape plan began to unravel from the first beat of the opening ceremony. The moment the lights came up on a stadium transformed into a bucolic paradise, complete with livestock, it became clear that those who had deserted our shores were in the wrong place. Ninety minutes of dazzling theatre, dance, film and music later, the telephone lines must have been thrumming with refuseniks trying to negotiate passage home.

An innovative, witty mash-up of our cultural history, the opening ceremony spun the head, brought a tear to the eye and made everyone lucky enough to witness it smile hard and long. Danny Boyle’s brief had been to reintroduce Britain and its capital to the world. How successfully he achieved that, presenting his homeland as a modern, friendly and, above all, humorous place. It quickly became clear that London was now the centre of the known universe, the place on which the world's eyes were trained.

The ceremony was a reminder to the world – and perhaps, more to the point, to ourselves – that this country has long held within it a wellspring of joy. It was the most enticing welcome to these isles of wonder.

For the Mexican journalist sitting next to me in the stadium, the high point of that evening was the Queen’s cameo in a James Bond pastiche. He could not believe it really was her, could not believe the Queen was hitching up her skirt to join in the party. And he was right to be astonished. At that moment, all suggestions of stiff formality were bundled out of the helicopter. What her appearance insisted was that the next fortnight, everyone was invited to participate in the fun; we really were all in it together.

And improbable as it may have seemed, from that vertiginous high spot, things just got better. Snapshots of our glorious capital – of horses apparently leaping over Canary Wharf, of cyclists skirting a sun-dappled Buckingham Palace, of female athletes in micro bikinis playing volleyball on Horse Guards Parade – spun round the globe. How wonderful it all looked. The facilities were brilliant, the transport smooth, everything just worked.

Even the assumption that corporate ticketing would preclude the ordinary citizen from observing the action at first hand proved unfounded. The opportunity to watch for free was everywhere seized. Tens of thousands filled Hyde Park to witness the Brownlee brothers dominate the triathlon. A million people lined the streets around Hampton Court to see Kilburn’s King of Cool, Bradley Wiggins, win the time trial.

There is no doubt victories such as these by local competitors added to the overall sense of well-being. Not even in the wilder reaches of Lord Coe’s imagination could such a happy confluence have been envisaged: jaw-dropping facilities, brilliant hosting, and world-beating achievement by the home team.

And what was so inspiring about Jessica Ennis, Mo Farah, Chris Hoy and the other British champions was that they delivered. There was no failure of nerve, no wilting under the weight of expectation, no hint of the traditional way of British sport of crumbling when faced with a crucial penalty in a shoot-out. For a fortnight, spot kicks were smashed unerringly into the top corner.

Thus it was that the Games became awash with an unstoppable benevolent momentum: everyone – administrators, spectators, volunteers and athletes alike – quickly recognised they were having the time of their lives. This was an intoxicating daily demonstration of our best side: civic-minded, helpful, properly patriotic, proud of our culture’s sterling qualities. As Mayor Boris Johnson put it, this was “a nation at ease with itself”.

A year on, looking back at that month-long festival of good cheer, however, we are obliged to wonder what the lasting effect of those beguiling few weeks might be. The talk now is of legacy. Messrs Coe and Johnson insist that the Olympic Park – currently being reconfigured for future public use – will continue to draw the curious in their thousands. But questions are rightly being asked about future funding: how active those inspired by what they saw can become if their local swimming pool is closing or their PE teacher is being laid off.

Talk of participation targets and bricks and mortar, however, may be missing the fundamental point about what the Olympics gave us. Surely the most significant benefit of the Games is the alteration it brought in our wider sensibility. What the festivities proved to us is that we can do things not just well, but better than anyone else. We can take on the world at anything, from a firework display to a rugby Test match, from a transport network to a tennis grand slam, from the production of motor cars to the Tour de France – and win.

We have discovered, moreover, that the best way to enjoy something is to embrace the effort, to immerse ourselves, to volunteer. A year on, this is what really counts: we now know we can be proud of our country and what it can achieve. And that is surely worth £9 billion of anyone’s money.

rank_124.title: Olympics boosts sports clubs' finances
rank_124.text:
Research by R3, the insolvency trade body, shows that while the number of sporting clubs and businesses entering formal insolvency procedures over the past year was down from 123 to 82, the improvement in their fortunes stretches back five years. Insolvency numbers are down 42pc from their 2008 level.

Liz Bingham, R3’s president, said: "Regular British sporting success, as well as the feel-good glow of the Olympics, may well have encouraged both children and adults to try new sports, join local teams, or keep on going with their gym membership.

“It would certainly be a positive Olympic legacy if any burst of grass-roots interest in sport were to be sustained and translated into healthier sports clubs.”

But she cautioned that despite the fall in failures, many sports clubs were still hard-pressed.

Among those which fell into insolvency in the past year were Fitness First Clubs, Aldershot Town FC and Coventry City FC.

rank_34.title: Keep the flame alive: Coalition has squandered Olympic Legacy, say Stephen Twigg and Harriet Harman
rank_34.text:
From the pride of the opening ceremony to the magic of Super Saturday, we all have our special memories of London 2012. A year on, we can rightly take a moment to celebrate our Olympians and Paralympians and all those, like the Games Makers, who made last summer so wonderful.

We know that it took time, hard work and dedication to pull it off. Queen Elizabeth Park wasn’t built in a day – it took investment and focus from successive Governments over a decade in grassroots and elite sport to ensure our medal tally.

A year on, the worry is that the Government has failed to keep the flame alive. While David Cameron promised that the Olympics would ‘inspire a generation’, the evidence on the ground is that the legacy is under threat.

Take school sport. In 2010 Labour had a system in place for ensuring that school pupils got access to at least 2 hours of sport and physical exercise a week. Our ‘School Sports Partnerships’ allowed schools to work together to share equipment, teachers and playing fields.

But since David Cameron scrapped it, two thirds of school sport staff report that there has been a decrease in pupils doing sport.

When Labour left office, there was a requirement that pupils had access to at least 2 hours of sport. Now teachers say fewer than half of their school children get this amount of PE – surely a basic minimum.

It is not for lack of enthusiasm. A majority of young people say they were inspired by the Olympics to do more sport and two in five feel they don’t get enough sport at school.

We know how important regular sport is not just for staying healthy and finding the Olympic stars of the future, it improves academic results too.

Sadly, it’s not just school sport that’s being squeezed. The latest Active People survey found that the number of adults participating in sport once a week has fallen by 200,000.

That’s why to mark the one year anniversary of the games, Labour is calling for a clear action plan to get the legacy back on track.

The minimum two hour target for PE in schools should be reinstated, which is supported by 97 per cent of school sport staff.

We want to ensure that all schools, including academies and free schools have a suitable amount of outdoor space for sport.

We would improve PE teaching too, ensuring that sports is a high priority in teacher training, and ensuring there is a PE subject coordinator in every primary school and a qualified PE teacher in every secondary school.

If David Cameron is serious about the legacy, he needs to take real action – unfortunately, the independent Education Select Committee warned last week that his approach to school sport is little more than a “gimmick”. Instead, we need a 10 year strategy for community and school sport.

This Government had a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to inspire a generation after the success of London 2012. But the sad truth is they are squandering the Olympic legacy.

Stephen Twigg is Labour's shadow Education secretarty and Harriet Harman is Labour’s Shadow Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport.

rank_116.title: Academic paper says one-third of medals at last four Olympics were won by privately-educated athletes
rank_116.text:
The record at Sydney was 32.7 per cent, Athens 26.6 per cent, Beijing 37.7 per cent and London 37.5 per cent. It will become essential reading for headteachers, directors of sport, PE teachers and sports coaches. It is particularly poignant as the UK discusses the grassroots legacy from the 2012 Olympic Games.

Tozer, a former physical education teacher at Uppingham School and headmaster at Northamptonshire Grammar School and Wellow House School, argues that the impact independent schools have had creates a template to be adopted nationally for how sport ought to be rationalised.

Tozer’s theorising is clear and concise. On the day that Team GB’s first gold medals of the 2012 London Olympics were won by a pair of privately-educated rowers, Lord Moynihan, the British Olympic Association chairman, stirred up a controversy by announcing: “It is one of the worst statistics in British sport, and wholly unacceptable, that over 50 per cent of our medallists in Beijing [at the 2008 Olympic Games] came from independent schools, which means that half of our medals came from just seven per cent of the children in the UK.”

UK Sport and Olympics bosses had already admitted privately that they expected more than a third of athletes in the 500-strong Team GB for the London Games to have been educated at independent schools.”

“Neither fear was realised – whether at the London Olympic Games or earlier at Sydney, Athens or Beijing. So was it a fuss about nothing? No – but the wrong questions had been asked,” Tozer explains in his report.

rank_47.title: Blow to Olympic legacy as fewer children take up sport
rank_47.text:
Ministers had hoped that staging the Olympics in London would help "inspire a generation" and encourage more young people and adults to take up sports and become fitter and healthier.

However, figures published by the Department for Culture, Media and Sport suggest that the afterglow of the Games may already be wearing off.

A survey of 2,000 children found that almost three quarters under the age of 10 said that the Games had not inspired them to take up a sport. Just over half of 11 to 15-year-olds shared the same view.

Over the past yeart here has been a decline in the number of children involved in sport across all age groups, with the figures even more stark over five years.

A quarter of girls aged between five and 10 said they had not taken part in any sport over the past month, up from 17 per cent five years ago. One in seven boys also said they have not taken part in any sport

The proportion of young children under the age of 10 doing gymnastics, going swimming and playing rounders has also fallen significantly over the past year.

Even walking appears to be declining in popularity. A total of 17.4 per cent of children said they have been on a walk in the past month, down from 22.5 per cent the year before.

The proportion of girls aged between 11-15 taking part in sport has fallen from 94.9 per cent to 92.5 per cent, but has increased slightly among boys of that age group.

It has been claimed that a lack of funding is preventing schools from running sports clubs, competitions and events, resulting in “fewer opportunities” for children to take part in football, athletics, rugby, hockey and swimming.

It follows a series of controversial reforms to school sport introduced by the Coalition, including the abolition of the £162m a year “school sports partnerships” scheme.

Ministers also scrapped previous targets requiring pupils to take part in two hours of sport a week and introduced a new Olympic-style “school games” programme to increase access to competitive sport.

Clive Efford, the shadow sports minister, said: "The government had no intention at all of delivering a sports legacy on the back of 2012.

“We need to instil sport and activity in children at a very young age if we are going to deal with the problems they face in later life. The cost to the NHS and the impact in the long term is impossible to calculate.”

A spokesman for the Department of Culture, Media and Sport, said: “We are completely committed to getting more young people participating in regular sport.

“We are investing £300 million over the next two years direct into primary school sport – that will improve the coaching and experience children have.

“On top of that we’re investing over £1 billion of public money over four years to strengthen grassroots sport and upgrade facilities in communities across England.”

rank_110.title: London 2012 legacy will be helped by FA Tesco Skills initiative
rank_110.text:
“More youngsters around the country can access free quality football coaching during the school week now within their PE classes thanks to the FA’s multi-skill coaches, who have been trained to work with youngsters and deliver the programme nationwide,” Sir Trevor, the FA’s director of football development told the Daily Telegraph , as the programme for 5-11 year old boys and girls takes hold in the primary sector.

FA Tesco Skills is part of a new £150m investment by the Government in Primary School sport, as part of the 2012 legacy. “We’re also the only governing sports body to be officially endorsed by the Association of PE with an official accreditation for developing teachers through one-on-one support and resources.”

There are 158 full-time Skills coaches working within the programme while over 7,500 primary schools and 21,500 teachers have been involved since the launch.

To build on the support to teachers, the FA will invest in a dedicated staff who will support the professional development of existing and trainee teachers, and also coaches who deliver in schools, including Premier League Community coaches.

“The FA has been building up to this moment for quite some time as Frank Lampard helped me launch FA Tesco Skills at Wembley Stadium back in 2007 with an overall aim of getting youngsters active and enjoying both football and exercise on a regular basis alongside their peer group,” explained Brooking. “It’s been a fantastic success to date with over 4.5m places offered to youngsters who have attended sessions in schools and clubs over the last six years.”

There is also a pathway programme to academy football with senior clubs

“When I was a youngster, I used to work on my skills by kicking a tennis ball against a wall for hours on end. It meant that when I was in a match situation I was comfortable in controlling the ball and I was already thinking about where I’d pass it next,” explained Brooking, the former West Ham and England midfielder.

“But the demands of modern life mean that youngsters don’t always have the time to invest in endless practice like I did and that’s where The FA Tesco Skills Programme will be key in providing regular football opportunities for 5-11 year olds in both term time and school holidays.”

Email your letters on school sport to gareth.davies@telegraph.co.uk

rank_62.title: Leyton Orient refused judicial review in bid to ground share Olympic Stadium with West Ham United
rank_62.text:
Orient yesterday failed to convince the High Court to sanction a judicial review into the decision to award the Hammers sole tenancy of the London 2012 centrepiece, which may signal the end of their fight with the London Legacy Development Corporation.

The club could take their case to the Court of Appeal or instead resume proceedings against the Premier League, which chairman Hearn has accused of breaching its own rules by sanctioning West Ham ’s move to Stratford.

Hearn has previously vowed to fight to the bitter end over the saga, which saw Orient’s written application for judicial review rejected back in April and its oral submission similarly dismissed by Mr Justice Lewis yesterday.

The club said it felt “a real sense of injustice” at the verdict, accusing West Ham of changing its position on ground sharing.

“Our real concern is the lack of transparency that has been shown throughout the process by a public body. It is deeply disappointing that both the court and the LLDC have made decisions based only on financial considerations, when the purpose of the stadium’s legacy was regeneration of the area with a community focus.

“Delivering a new brand to West Ham United was not the intended purpose of the Olympic Stadium, and we now have to look to the House of Lords to find a common sense solution for Olympic legacy and local community.”

West Ham said in a statement: “West Ham United welcome the decision to not grant permission for a judicial review into the LLDC’s process that awarded the club the opportunity to make the Olympic Stadium its home in 2016.

“Although the application for a judicial review would not have had any impact on West Ham United’s move to the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park, the club have always believed the process was robust, fair and transparent.”

rank_68.title: Olympic spirit inspires the next generation of volunteers
rank_68.text:
More than a year after the flame was extinguished in the London stadium cauldron, the Olympic spirit is still burning at St Saviour’s Church of England Primary School in Lambeth.

In this neat little school in the south London suburbs, it lives on, but not in running, jumping or throwing. At assembly they don’t hand out medals to those who have done well in maths, or raise a flag up the pole to celebrate an unblemished attendance record.

The spirit can instead be found in a somewhat unexpected place, embedded in a series of pots dotted around the playground. Made, decorated and planted with foliage by the pupils, these are pots waiting to be delivered to local old people.

They were put together by the children in their spare time, as part of a pilot project for Team London, the Mayor of London’s junior volunteering programme that is being rolled out across the capital.

“The idea came from the Mayor,” says Veronica Wadley, the coordinator of Team London. “He wanted there to be a real Olympic legacy delivered in volunteering as well as in sporting participation. And the best way to do that is to introduce the idea of volunteering to the next generation of the capital’s citizens.”

There is no doubt that the vast army of upbeat Olympic Games Makers, wearing their purple tunics and broad smiles, not only gave the London Games a memorably warm, human dimension, they also altered the wider attitude to giving up your time and energy freely for the community.

While it is moot whether the nation was motivated to get off the sofa and put on its running shoes by watching the brilliance of Jessica Ennis and Mo Farah in action, there is no question that the thousands of cheery Olympic and Paralympic volunteers inspired a big spike in coming forward.

Last summer made it fashionable to be helpful, to do your bit for the community. At every major sporting and cultural event in the capital you now encounter volunteers guiding the way, providing information, picking up litter in the same way as their Olympic models.

To help coordinate that new, widespread enthusiasm, there is now a Team London website.

“It’s very simple,” says Wadley. “If you want to plant a tree in Camden on Saturday, there is now a place you can go which can tell you how to go about it.”

The Mayor, though, was keen that the spirit of the Games Maker passed down to the city’s youngest citizens. The idea was that every school in the capital, junior and infant, secondary and primary, was to be involved.

After securing funding of £555,000 to help deliver it, a pilot project was established in a dozen schools last year. One was St Saviour’s.

“We thought the best way forward was for the pupils themselves to decide what they would do,” says Flora Vidal, the senior teaching assistant who was put in charge of organising the school’s approach. “So we got the school council – which consists of two children from each of the seven classes – to discuss what they would like to do.”

The idea they came up with did not involve changing the school uniform to a purple tunic with red-fringed epaulettes. Rather it was green tinged.

Pots were made and planted around the playground. Then, after a couple of months of careful cultivation, they were taken on a surprise trip to a residential home close by.

Here each of the elderly residents was presented with their own pot plant. There were a lot of smiles – and no few tears – when children, some as young as four, delivered their specially made gifts to the old people.

“It was a lovely day,” says Vidal. “There was a couple in there who happened to be celebrating their 70th wedding anniversary that day. They were so touched to get their two pot plants. They said they couldn’t think of a nicer present.”

But the really interesting thing about this small act of volunteering was what happened next.

“Everywhere around the school, people started volunteering,” says Vidal. “They were sharpening pencils, helping with the lunch queue, picking up litter. Now they are busy getting stuff together for children in Syria. A huge parcel is being put together to send there for Christmas.”

The reason, she is convinced, is that the plant pot idea was theirs in the first place.

“It came from the school council,” she says. “Because it was not imposed on them by adults, the children really bought into what they were doing. They couldn’t wait for lunchtime so they could get out there watering the plants, or decorating the pots. Children are naturally really helpful anyway, but what this did was make them more aware.”

And that awareness has spread well beyond decorating pots.

“For the first time I can remember, children want to be on the school council. More than half the pupils now want to be on council. It’s made them more confident about coming forward. It has made them more communally minded. They just want to do more. They want to join in, be involved. A couple of parents have said to me their children’s confidence had really been boosted by being on the project.”

The pupils at St Saviour’s are not unusual. This is often the consequence of volunteering: as those behind institutions such as the Scouts, Guides and Cubs long ago recognised, it has a largely beneficial effect on those who volunteer.

“I think everyone saw through the Olympics that it’s great fun, great social networking, getting together, making friends. Which are all wonderful things in themselves,” says Wadley.

“But if you integrate volunteering into children’s lives there is something more. Self-esteem, confidence, communication, teamwork all improve. These are soft skills that ultimately lead to an improvement in educational results.”

Wadley is convinced that it is this that will ensure every school, no matter how pressed it may be for time and resources, will engage enthusiastically with the idea of volunteering.

As Marc Kielburger, co-founder of Free the Children, the organisation tasked by Team London to deliver the Mayor’s project across all of the capital’s schools, puts it: “We’ve seen first-hand that involving students in their communities creates an atmosphere of caring and compassion, and over the years we’ve seen the confidence and social conscience of hundreds of thousands of young people involved in our programmes grow and flourish.”

Free the Children will use young coordinators to encourage the pupils to come up with their own initiatives. No one will be told what to do by Team London. And this is the key. Not only does volunteering make the streets cleaner, the mood lighter and the smiles broader, properly directed it has a practical consequence on those who do it.

“Statistics show the value of volunteering,” says Wadley. “Research by Reed employment showed that 73 per cent of employers would employ someone with volunteering experience over someone without. What makes you stand out when you go for a university place or a job? It’s not just good GCSEs or A-levels. It’s those soft skills. Put volunteering in your life and it will help you.”

Head to volunteerteam.london.gov.uk to find out how you can get involved.

rank_14.title: Peers warn over 'faltering' legacy of London Olympics
rank_14.text:
The Olympic legacy is “in danger of faltering” because of squabbling over major projects and a failure to boost the number of children playing sport, peers warned today.

A wave of public goodwill generated by the London Games has been replaced with political bickering, confusion over timeframes and a lack of clear leadership, it was claimed.

In a highly-critical report, a cross-party group insisted that many of the promises made after last summer’s event had already been broken, with particular concerns raised over a failure to agree about future use of the £429 million Olympic stadium.

Lengthy legal rows over the stadium between West Ham United, Tottenham Hotspur and Leyton Orient football clubs have been a "disappointing distraction", the committee said.

Peers also insisted that there had been “little evidence” of a general post-Games increase in sporting participation, particularly among children.

The Lords Olympic and Paralympic Legacy Committee called for “urgent action” to be taken amid fears a golden opportunity to transform Britain’s sporting habits will be wasted.

Peers said the Government should create a new ministerial post with specific responsibility for the Olympic legacy to coordinate the UK response to the Games, which cost almost £9 billion to stage.

They also recommended a greater drive on school sport, including additional training for primary teachers to deliver PE amid fears that too many young children are not getting a proper introduction to the subject.

The conclusions follow the publication of a survey by the Department for Culture, Media and Sport in the summer that found a decline in the number of children involved in sport across all age groups over the past year.

Lord Harris of Haringey, the Labour peer and committee chairman, said it was clear that the "Games were an outstanding success, both for the country and for British sporting achievement".

“It couldn’t have been done without incredible cooperation between the numerous organisations involved, the Government and the host borough councils," he said.

“However, since the Games, the same political impetus and agreed deadlines no longer exist and many aspects of legacy are in danger of faltering, whilst some have fallen by the wayside.

“There is confusion on the timeframes and targets involved in delivery and a lack of clear ownership of legacy as a whole.”

Lord Harris said that the Olympics had promised to “inspire a generation”, but insisted there was “little evidence that a general post-Games step change in participation across the UK has materialised”.

"We are calling on the Department for Education and Ofsted to give greater emphasis to PE in schools and to ensure that teachers have the training and skills necessary to carry this through, particularly at primary level," he said.

"At a time when the UK faces an obesity epidemic, encouraging more physically active lives is of critical importance, and school is where lifelong habits will be set."

In further conclusions, the report questioned the Government’s policy of weighting sports funding towards those with the best chance of securing medals, saying the approach “fails to help emerging sports, some of which, such as handball and volleyball, generated real enthusiasm at London 2012”

It called on the Department for Transport to take “proper ownership” of securing international train services at Stratford station next to the Olympic Park to “generate a return on the substantial investment made in the station”.

The report also said the Government and tourism groups should “work to ensure that the longer-term economic benefits of the Games are felt outside southern England, where legacy benefits are currently less obvious”.

A Department for Culture, Media and Sport spokesman said: "The Government remains committed to building on the legacy created from hosting the 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games to benefit the entire country for generations to come.

"Our legacy has been hailed by the International Olympic Committee as a 'blueprint' for future Games and over the next 10 years we aim to use the inspiration of 2012 to deliver lasting change in sport, communities, the economy, east London and awareness and perceptions around disability."

rank_178.title: East Village welcomes Tinchy Stryder for school project
rank_178.text:
Internationally acclaimed rapper, Tinchy Stryder, has launched the East Village ‘Artists in Residence’ programme which will celebrate the homes and cultural legacy at the former Athletes’ Village, now London’s newest neighbourhood in E20.

Tinchy Stryder has revealed a new track developed with sixth-form performing arts students from the new education campus, Chobham Academy, in East Village. The new school anthem was unveiled last week by a live performance from students with Tinchy Stryder in East Village.

Following a visit to East Village earlier this year, which helped Tinchy draw inspiration from the people and surroundings in the new neighbourhood, he surprised the Chobham Academy students by hosting a masterclass to develop new ideas and hone their natural talent. A follow-up visit gave the students the chance to present back to Tinchy before they combined their talents to finish the anthem.

Tinchy Stryder, said: “I’m passionate about passing on my musical knowledge to young people and I was proud to be East Village’s first Artist in Residence. Having grown up in Bow, and having been previously asked to develop the Olympic Torch Relay song, it’s an honour to give back a lasting cultural legacy to the area that I grew up in.”

What is the East Village Artists in Residence programme?

The East Village Artist in Residence programme is an important part of the cultural legacy and artists come in to help that grow. I was honoured to be asked to be the first Artist in Residence and also that the anthem created with students at Chobham Academy will speak directly to the kids and be a true legacy.

Why did you want to get involved with the project?

I’m from Bow, East London, just around the corner from everything going on at the Olympics last year, and helped out with the torch relay song. With the Olympic legacy, if I can be an influence by getting involved in any way then that’s dope.

How do you think the project will affect the community?

I think it is very positive because it brings more opportunities. It would be nice for the people who have been living here for a while to benefit from the developments and improvements, I know this will happen but I know it will take time.

What’s it been like seeing the incredible transformation in the area?

I could never imagine or picture anything like the developments going on today. It feels like a whole different place. It shows how we have progressed, when a lot of stuff you could only imagine a few years ago, comes true. It feels really good.

What is it you love about the area and what makes it so unique?

For me personally it’s the friends and family I have here but when I was younger I guess watching TV, like Eastenders. It feels good now that east London feels like somewhere where people can meet and there’s different places where people can socialise. East London is good; it’s where it’s at. There is something very special about the place.

You have worked with kids a lot – what is it you enjoy about the work?

I really enjoy working with younger people, I feel like sometimes when I was younger I didn’t have the opportunity to meet, or speak or get advice from people who you respect or look up to for what they do. I feel like I can say “I’m from where you’re from” and I can show them that it can be done. I like the connection and the bonding, it’s natural, like that feeling in the air, it can’t be replaced.

If you could give yourself a piece of advice as a kid looking back, what would you say?

I focused on too many different things growing up, I would say to focus on one thing that you love, go with your heart and stick to it. Without the heart there is no you.

What do you think about Chobham Academy, now you’ve seen it yourself?

I was thinking, why didn’t I have schools like this when I was younger? Everything is high tech and I like it. There's a good vibe, a good energy, especially with the kids and the young ones I was working with today, writing music and lyrics with. It's good energy.

They all seem really focused and there wasn’t anyone who was just there for the sake of it. They’ve got plans and they’ve got aims and ambitions and hopefully everyone will fulfil that.

I wanted to see what the school means to them. They told me what different colours mean to them, about healthy competition and working together. They gave me ideas about the melody and rhyming patterns. So I gave them a few ideas and will be back to see how they get on.

I think it is really important for students to get involved with the world of arts. I believe everyone is artistic in one way or another. If you are in the right surroundings where there are loads of people as creative as you are, or maybe even more, it is
