rank_119.title: Leyton Orient could share Olympic Stadium with West Ham as Barry Hearn is cleared to strike rental deal
rank_119.text:
West Ham United may yet be forced to share the Olympic Stadium with Leyton Orient after Barry Hearn was given permission to use the venue by legacy chiefs.

The London Legacy Development Corporation confirmed on Wednesday night that it had no objection to Orient chairman Hearn negotiating a rental agreement with whichever firm ends up operating the London 2012 centrepiece, something that could lead to the club playing all of their home games there.

The revelation followed a meeting between the London Legacy Development Corporation and Hearn, set up in the wake of the House of Lords report last month into the Olympic legacy, which recommended that Orient be allowed “occasional use” of the stadium.

The LLDC reiterated that there was no prospect of West Ham’s sole anchor tenancy being challenged but told Hearn that there was nothing to stop him striking a deal for Orient to play at the venue when it is not being used by their local rivals.

The right to manage the stadium during those periods will be put out to tender next year, with Live Nation and AEG likely to be among the ­bidders. The winner will be charged by the LLDC with eking the maximum possible revenue out of the arena during a contract expected to span between 10 and 20 years.

They will not be able to offer Orient a long-term lease such as the 99-year agreement enjoyed by West Ham but look poised to have the power to grant permission for them to play an entire season at the venue, perhaps several.

Confirming the outcome of the meeting last week, Hearn said: “West Ham won’t want to hear this but the news that came down is they have no problem with me renting the Olympic Stadium and playing my fixtures there. It’s only a question of what rental I agree with the new operators. That’s a major breakthrough for me.”

Hearn claimed that the prospect of Orient using the stadium every other weekend would be attractive to whoever manages it because it would provide the kind of regular guaranteed income a music concert or other one-off event could not.

It remains to be seen whether the new stadium operator will agree with that assessment. “They’ll realise that there is nothing else to go in there during the football season,” Hearn said.

Hearn, who has lost every legal challenge to the LLDC’s refusal to sanction a permanent groundshare, had offered previously to pay £500,000 a year rent, double were Orient promoted from League One.

Revealing that he would ask the new operator to name its price, he said: “If they ask me for £1 million per game, I’m not going to move in.

“But, when push comes to shove, to recoup fixed costs – even partial fixed costs – it is better than having an empty stadium as far as the taxpayer in ­concerned. If they quote me something ridiculous, I will hang them out to dry, in terms of, ‘This is a community club and you’re trying to take liberties’.”

Hearn’s previous plan was to sell Orient’s present home at Brisbane Road if they moved into the Olympic Stadium but he admitted that would now depend on what length of deal was on the table.

An LLDC spokesman said: “We will be appointing an organisation next autumn to manage, maintain and operate the stadium and programme activities and events.

“Once they are appointed, Leyton Orient are free, as are anyone, to approach the operator to discuss using the stadium. If long-term use is proposed, this would be subject to a further competitive process.”

West Ham declined to comment.

rank_10.title: Olympic legacy chiefs attacked by London Assembly over tax-funded conversion of Olympic Stadium
rank_10.text:
A Conservative member of the London Assembly has attacked 2012 legacy chiefs, who include Boris Johnson, over the taxpayer-funded conversion of the Olympic Stadium.

Andrew Boff, the Greater London Authority Conservatives Olympics spokesman, reacted angrily to news that Balfour Beatty had won the £154 million contract to prepare the London 2012 centrepiece for West Ham United ’s arrival as anchor tenants. The Premier League strugglers are expected to pay around 10 per cent of the conversion costs.

Boff, who lost out to Johnson in the battle to become the Tory candidate for London Mayor in 2007, said: “Where is the cash coming from? Who’s paying for it? We still don’t really know, but chances are we’re all contributing. Taxpayers shouldn’t be paying for Premiership football clubs.”

The 55-year-old claimed that the conversion costs would come at the expense of other London Legacy Development Corporation projects at Stratford’s Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park.

He said: “The £154 million has to come from an already stretched LLDC budget and the knock-on effect is that the rest of the transformation of the park – the really important stuff such as housing – will suffer as a result.”

The Olympic Stadium conversion will include retaining London 2012’s athletics track, which will be covered by expensive retractable seating when West Ham play there.

Boff said: “Only by ditching the requirement for the athletics track are we likely to see more bids from the private sector for a proper football stadium rather than the hybrid fudge we currently have.”

Welcoming Monday’s news, Dennis Hone, LLDC chief executive, said: “This is another milestone in the development of Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park. We go into 2014 on track to deliver a world-class venue that, when it fully opens in 2016, can be used year round to host a whole range of sporting, cultural and community events.

“The stadium will be a truly remarkable legacy here in east London.”

rank_83.title: Historic pre-election cross-party manifesto being drawn up by MPs amid fears over Olympic legacy
rank_83.text:
The All-Party Parliamentary Group for Sport, chaired by former sports minister Gerry Sutcliffe, plans to devise a 10-year strategy for sport which it wants every major political party to include in their own election manifestos next year.

A cross-party consensus over sport is thought to be unprecedented, with such formal pre-election agreements on other areas of policy tending to be reserved for wartime or other national emergencies.

But those who champion sport inside Westminster have grown increasingly concerned about the extent to which it has fallen down the list of Government priorities since the Olympics and Paralympics and believe the country risks heading for an irreversible decline in physical activity.

The infighting within the Conservative Party over cuts in school sport funding highlighted how damaging a lack of joined-up thinking could be, while the Prime Minister's last cabinet reshuffle – in which the highly-rated Hugh Robertson was moved to the Foreign Office – sent a message that sport would face even more of a fight for attention in future.

Sport England's most recent Active People Survey, meanwhile, showed participation in sport in England fell by more than 50,000 between December 2012 and December 2013.

Sutcliffe told the Telegraph Sport: "I don't want to see what's happened in other nations post-Olympics and Paralympics, where the bubble has burst and participation rates drop.

"We know that elite athletes are funded to 2016 and that the 'whole sport plans' are there until 2017 but we've got to look beyond that. We've got to have a 10-year plan in my view."

Sutcliffe was confident any cross-party manifesto, which he plans to present to each party at the end of the year, could survive the brutal partisanship of a General Election campaign – even one as close as 2015's is predicted to be.

He said: "There are always competing interests in terms of manifestos. But our aim is to give sufficient time for people to endorse that manifesto.

"We will have to battle but if we don't have anything ready or don't have a view then it will get lost as different priorities compete for Government support."

The manifesto could include a budget and is likely to highlight how investment in sport can ultimately result in huge savings in other Government departments.

Sutcliffe, the Labour MP for Bradford South who was sports minister between 2007-10, added: "Sport can influence policy areas in other departments, whether that's Health – in terms of well-being – Education – in terms of developing individuals – and even the Home Office. After all, the busiest place in a prison is the gym."

The all-party group plans to consult as widely as possible for manifesto ideas, including speaking to sports groups within parliament and sports bodies themselves.

But Sutcliffe said it would also welcome ideas from members of the public, including from readers of the The Telegraph.

"It's important to develop a scale of interest in this, not only from sports bodies.

"I think individuals have got a lot to contribute here and so it'd be great to hear what people think are the priorities and where they think the investment should be."

rank_126.title: Wapping's hockey revolution bears fruits as London club goes business savvy
rank_126.text:
When Stuart Burnside, a Yorkshireman who played hockey for his local factory side, arrived in London a decade ago to work for a top law firm, he was handed a dilemma over where to live.

He decided on the shortest commute and settled on Wapping, close to his work in Canary Wharf. It then conspired that a work colleague played hockey for Wapping, a club founded in 1988 as part of the Olympic legacy project following Britain men’s glittering gold in Seoul.

Ten years later and Burnside is now Wapping Hockey Club’s chairman and admits, when the question is put to him, that there is “something of a revolution” occurring at the club.

It’s nothing to do with the club not having a home identity, that their facility is council-owned, or that they use a local bar as their club house. Far from it, the club has just been savvy in garnering commercial and sponsorship deals at every corner and they are reaping the rewards.

“Historically, Wapping has had limited access to local facilities and they have been pretty dilapidated,” admits Burnside. “As a result, we had been reticent about taking on new members.”

So when Burnside came in as chairman earlier this year, he ripped up the previous template. “My view is that if you have growing participation then you get support in terms of getting facilities. But that’s not to say there are still challenges remaining.”

Numerous talks were held with Tower Hamlets council, with Wapping offering to invest alongside them to improve the facilities, in return for more access.

This has resulted in the club securing over £300,000 of investment to designate a local sports centre, the John Orwell, into a hockey priority facility a stone's throw from London Bridge.

“It means we can put a first-class turf in our home ground,” Burnside says. “Coupled with hopefully getting access to the Olympic legacy facility at Lee Valley, it means we can attract the calibre of players to progress.”

Two years ago, Wapping had 196 members. Now they are currently sitting pretty with over 300 signed up and 20 teams. Training nights have also doubled to four per week. “It is a combination of opening the doors and the Olympic effect which has given us a bump in numbers,” Burnside adds.

Burnside’s business nous has helped in acquiring extra funds. “The core of any subs is match fees, but Wapping have looked at benefits for extra revenue. There are discounts with local restaurants and online commission fee arrangements.”

Wapping have also teamed up with Drambuie, the liquer company, and the deal will help Wapping finance their stadium redevelopment – with extra floodlights, a modern terrace for spectators - and youth programme.

Moreover, the club have also moved to a local bar, Bar Cape in St Katherine Dock, while a funding injection of £6,000 from its owners allowed them to purchase their own club shirts. Sticks and shirts will adorn the bar walls down the line to give it a club feel.

“We have an offering which works for both ends of the spectrum in the council," Burnside explains. "We have pricing which is accessible for everyone. On the back of that, the higher earners are now putting money into the scheme as everyone believes in the structure.

“There are a range of people that we have who are interacting and who are friends as a result of playing sport together. There is no other reason why they would interact, other than sitting on the same tube and not particularly liking each other’s presence. That’s the power of sport, it unifies in a team structure.”

Burnside believes that Wapping can attract players over from more popular sports too. The most recent goalkeeper to join the club has come across from football, though this may have been down to the club deciding to waive subs as they were struggling to attract stoppers.

Burnside now wants to work with 200 local children. His vision is to put satellite clubs and coaches into local schools to nurture the next generation of hockey players in the borough.

Come the 2018 World Cup at Lee Valley, Burnside says, the club's talent will start to be recognised, while he wants his hockey athletes to be part of those England squads in four years' time. It’s a “big plan” but one Burnside could well pull off.

Go to Wapping Hockey Club for more information on how to join.

rank_49.title: London 2012: More than ever before, we need to get our children active
rank_49.text:
It seems barely conceivable that it’s nearly a decade since our bid to bring the Olympic Games to the UK. In the formal presentation, I said that London’s vision is to reach young people all around the world, to connect them with the inspirational power of the Games so that they are inspired to choose sport. I say “is” and not “was” because this vision is as alive today as it was nine years ago.

When we handed the Olympic and Paralympic flames on to the Winter Games in Sochi, I only ever saw it as the first half of Britain’s Olympic and Paralympic journey. Just as it took 10 years to win, plan and deliver our Games, so the next 10 years had to be about capturing everything witnessed in that extraordinary summer of 2012 and converting it into lasting change.

We’ve made a good start – but it’s only a start. For example, all eight permanent venues at the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park have a secure future and 1.5 million more people are playing sport once a week now than in 2005, including 350,000 more people with a disability or impairment.

But there remains much to do to deliver the lasting legacy we all want to see. Today’s children are the least active generation in history. They also might be the first generation to have a shorter life expectancy than their parents. Clearly that’s not progress – and physical inactivity may be a bigger culprit than we think. By the age of 15, European children are half as active as they were aged nine. As a nation, we are currently a fifth less active than we were in 1961, and if things don’t change rapidly, we’re on course to be 35 per cent less active by 2030.

The price we pay is high. Inactive children don’t perform as well in school and are less likely to go to university. As they reach their adult years, they won’t be as happy, healthy or productive as they would be if they had played during childhood. Yes, simply played. All this is why I recently helped launch “Moving more, Living more” – the Government and Mayor of London’s initiative to promote physical activity.

Worldwide, inactivity is closely linked to more than nine million premature deaths. According to the NHS, inactivity costs Britain nearly £10 billion every year for just five conditions (post-menopausal breast cancer, lower gastrointestinal cancer, cerebrovascular disease, cardiovascular disease, and type 2 diabetes).

What, you may ask, does “moving” do? Well, Cycling England estimates that a 20 per cent increase in bike riding would save £246 million in terms of premature deaths, NHS costs, and absenteeism by 2015. These numbers make one thing clear. Our Olympic and Paralympic legacy is about so much more than medals or races won. It is about ensuring those moments, and what we do next, inspire people to participate in sports as a daily priority.

Children have a right to the benefits that participation in sports and physical activity provide. To unlock this potential it is essential that their first experiences of physical activity – particularly sporting – are positive ones. If they are, then there is a better chance that it will become habit-forming. It is crucial that the Government has committed £150 million a year for three years, ring-fenced, for primary school sport and PE. This has sent a clear message to head teachers that developing high quality PE and sport should be a top priority.

But this is not just, nor should it be, a government crusade. Influential actors from across all sectors have recognised the importance of this. Last October, the Lawn Tennis Association, British Heart Foundation, Nike, Premier League, Sustrans, and the Young Foundation joined in support of the All-Party Commission on Physical Activity, a group chaired by MPs from across the political spectrum. The commission’s work seeks to provide key recommendations to get children and young people moving more throughout everyday life.

Today, the commission will launch a report of its recommendations based on input from experts and leaders in a wide range of sectors, alongside charities and key governmental bodies. I gave evidence to the commission and welcome its report, which I am sure will merit serious consideration.

Now it is a matter of mobilising everyone to move more themselves to help our children and young people to be active; to ensure our cities and workplaces encourage activity; and for positive experiences of physical activities to be a national priority. If we do this – move our nation – we will thrive as a population, as an economy, as healthy neighbourhoods. We should be pushing and challenging young people.

If we look at global events like the Olympic and Paralympic Games and the Fifa World Cup, it is clear that a select few countries are shaping the world’s perception of sport and physical activity. We are one of them. We have the chance to ensure that the perception is one that inspires the next generation to move. Their future, our future, depends on it.

Lord Coe was the chairman of the London Organising Committee for the Olympic Games

rank_100.title: Ofsted head's attack on Olympic legacy
rank_100.text:
The head of Ofsted will launch an attack on the Olympic legacy this week, warning that a “disproportionately high number” of medallists were educated in private schools.

Sir Michael Wilshaw will use a major speech to criticise poor standards of PE and claim that millions of state-educated pupils are being failed by the lack of competitive sport.

Proper competition remains optional in the vast majority of state schools and only one-in-five pupils regularly play football, rugby, cricket or hockey outside the school day, it is claimed.

Sir Michael will call on the Government to do more to enable competitive sport to thrive in the state sector, allowing schools to close the gap between the state and private sectors.

In a speech, he will say that the best schools use competition to build self-esteem, confidence, a strong ethos and academic excellence, but too many schools allow pupils to opt out.

The comments come despite a pledge by David Cameron two years ago to put sport at the centre of the school timetable in the wake of the London Olympics.

According to figures, well over a third of British medal winners in the 2012 games were from private schools, even though they educate just seven per cent of the population.

The dominance of private schools was particularly evident in sports such as rowing where more than half of gold medallists were independently-educated.

Lord Moynihan, the former chairman of the British Olympic Association, has branded the dominance of private school pupils in sport “wholly unacceptable”.

Ofsted has also criticised standards, warning last year that a third of state primaries were failing to provide good PE lessons, with no warm-up sessions, little strenuous exercise and able athletes ignored.

Earlier this month, it emerged that PE lessons would be dramatically toughened up amid fears hundreds of thousands of pupils can barely run, jump, throw or catch.

For the first time, a generation of specialist PE teachers will be employed directly by state primaries in England to give pupils advanced exercise sessions, healthy living advice and more competitive sport.

But Ofsted claims that it fails to go far enough and wants a greater emphasis on elite sport.

This week, Sir Michael will release a major report – and make a speech – on the issue.

It will find that a minority of state schools match the sporting success of the best private institutions, saying that competition creates “culture and identity” and helps pupils “achieve well academically”.

But the report says many schools provide “few opportunities to excel in competitive sport because it was not seen as a priority by school leaders, who did not invest in it”.

According to Ofsted, schools that shun sport do less well, on average, in terms of overall inspection judgments than those where competition “flourished”.

Sir Michael will cite the high number of Team GB medallists at the London Olympics – 42 per cent – who were educated privately.

Speaking at a conference at fee-paying Wellington College in Berkshire, he will say that sport “is seen as essential to building self-esteem, confidence, school ethos and academic excellence” in many schools.

rank_108.title: Lord Coe lifted by funding boost for International Inspiration programme
rank_108.text:
One of the biggest legacy successes of the 2012 Olympics gained a funding boost last night after the International Inspiration programme received three more years of government backing.

The global initiative, chaired by London 2012 architect Lord Coe, was rewarded by the Department for International Development after a report found it had reached more than 25 million children and in excess of 250,000 teachers, coaches and leaders in Britain and countries like India, Indonesia and Nigeria.

Establishing such a programme formed part of London’s successful bid to host the Games, Coe making a commitment to reach out to young people around the world and help inspire them to take part in sport and physical activity.

It easily met its target of engaging with 12 million children in 20 countries – as well as influencing policy makers – before London 2012. And, two years on, it has now more than doubled that figure. “I’m not surprised but I’m relieved that, independently, we’ve had our work validated and that’s important,” Coe said.

“The great thing about these programmes is that you always need to refine, you need to really understand what is working and what isn’t working, what is best practice, what isn’t best practice.

rank_154.title: World Equestrian Games: Charlotte Dujardin eyes historic grand slam on her dancing horse
rank_154.text:
The London 2012 Olympics was a time of many surprises, and one of the quirkiest for many sports fans was how much they enjoyed watching the dressage.

The much-vaunted Olympics legacy may have had mixed results for many sports, but for dressage at least the London Games was a major boost.

Those Olympics gave the sport a star, in Charlotte Dujardin, as well as our first medals in the discipline.

“My ultimate dream was to get to the Olympics. I never thought I would come away with two gold medals.

"To be able to do that in your home ground and have all that support was just fantastic.

“Life has been manic since. It is so nice that I’ve inspired so many people to take up the sport.

"I still have loads of mail from fans and the profile of our sport has risen so much since the Olympics.”

The sight of horses strutting their stuff to disco music in Greenwich was, beyond question, one of the unexpected highlights of the Games and it seemed to strike a perfect chord with the British sense of eccentricity and love of animals.

“Before the Olympics people had no idea what the sport was and now they go ‘oh yeah, the dancing horses’.

"The Olympics made a massive difference,” said Dujardin, who was awarded an OBE in the 2013 New Year Honours list.

“There were people that had no idea, and then they watched it in the pub and they started following it.”

Anyone with a passing interest in the prancing equines would know that Dujardin and four-footed partner Valegro stand on the verge of a historic grand slam.

If she can add gold in Normandy to her Olympic 2012 win, European 2013 title and her April 2014 World Cup triumph, she will be the reigning champion in all four of the sport’s major events.

“Individually, a medal here would be fantastic,” she said, perhaps unnecessarily modestly given that she and Valegro will surely be the pair to beat.

They are not resting on their laurels, winning the World Cup Final in Lyon with a new freestyle routine, set to music from the film How To Train Your Dragon.

Schooling a dressage horse might be slightly less daunting than training a giant fire-breathing lizard, but until that day arrives, Dujardin pointed out: “It is a huge challenge to be able to get such a big animal to do what we do with it.

"I remember some people after the Olympics that had no idea about horses would ask: ‘Do you do that with the horse or does the horse do it by itself?’

"I think the fact that you can make it look like you are doing nothing is a real talent. And it is such a massive reward at the end of it.”

There is, however, one note of caution to sound in this tale of British Olympic legacy: a familiar foe lies in wait.

“I would love to win the team event in Normandy but the Germans have got a very strong outfit and I don’t think we can beat them,” she said.

Dujardin, with eyes on yet another gold, and Valegro, who has had the carrot of a carrot dangled in front of him, might yet upset the Germans.

And what better Olympic legacy could there be than that?

rank_114.title: Schools must try harder to find Olympic stars of the future – Ofsted
rank_114.text:
Almost three quarters of primary schools are not doing enough to develop Britain’s sports stars of the future despite receiving in injection of extra cash as part of the London 2012 Olympics legacy, Ofsted has warned.

Only a small minority are also using the £150 million-a-year fund, intended to bring back the spirit of competition into school sports in England, to help get obese children taking part in physical activity, it found.

Ofsted visited a sample of 22 schools already recognised for their sporting initiatives to see how the money from the fund, known as the PE and sport premium for primary schools, was being spent.

While all had devoted the extra cash to improving PE, including hiring special coaches and training existing staff in new sports, inspectors found that planning for the money would be used by “generally poor”.

The fund was set up last year with the joint aims of “re-energising” school sport, particularly reviving a focus on competition, and promoting a “sporting habit for life” in young people.

One school visited had recently recruited 60 children and their parents to take part in a local cross-country race, another had more than doubled the number of children participating in outside competitions. Several had paid for specialists to run after-hours boxing, taekwondo, karate and badminton sessions as well as more unlikely ventures such as cheerleading and street dance.

And many had identified children who did not take part in games at lunchtime and attempted to entice them into after-school sports activities.

But only six of those visited were able to demonstrate that they had specifically targeted new funding to help their most able pupils in hope of helping find the next generation of Olympic stars.

“Very few schools were using their funding to improve pupils’ health and well-being, especially those known to be overweight or obese,” the report added.

“In particular, there was a lack of engagement with parents and local health agencies to develop and implement effective approaches to tackle these issues.”

The inspectors noted: “Most of the head teachers of the schools visited commented on a lack of clear guidance on how the new funding should be spent when it was first allocated.

“This meant that they did not initially feel confident or well prepared to use it effectively.”

The report adds: “Although most of the schools visited were using the premium in effective ways, some common weaknesses were noted.

“Strategic planning was generally poor, monitoring and evaluation of the impact of actions to improve the provision of PE and sports were not rigorous enough.

“A few of the schools had used a small part of the funding to promote pupils’ health and well-being, including providing help for those pupils who were overweight or obese. “However, overall, this was not done well enough in the majority.”

rank_147.title: Alarming fall in school PE lessons casts doubt over government's commitment to tackling obesity crisis
rank_147.text:
The Government has overseen an alarming fall in the amount of PE in schools since coming to power, according to new figures which cast serious doubt on its commitment to an Olympic legacy and to tackling Britain’s obesity crisis.

The biggest survey of its kind during the Coalition’s 4½ years in office found that the average number of minutes of PE offered to children in England had dropped well below two hours per week, in defiance of promises made to use London 2012 to ‘Inspire a Generation’ of ­youngsters to become more active.

Seen by Telegraph Sport ahead of its official publication on Wednesday morning, the Youth Sport Trust’s National PE, School Sport and Physical Activity Survey Report also suggested that there had been a major slump in the number of links between schools and community sports clubs since 2010.

Baroness Campbell, chairman of the charity formed in 1995 to support children’s development through sport, described current physical inactivity levels among the young as “a bleak and worrying picture”.

The YST survey helped to inform its own manifesto for PE and school sport, which is also being launched on Wednesday in an effort to convince whoever wins the General Election in May to develop a joined-up, cross-departmental approach to physical activity.

Campbell also chaired UK Sport for almost a decade, during which the elite funding body bankrolled Britain’s 65 Olympic and 120 Paralympic medals at London 2012.

She said: “Reversing the growing levels of physical inactivity amongst young people is a seismic challenge. With one in three children leaving primary school obese or overweight, and less than one in five meeting the minimum recommended guidelines for physical activity, it is a bleak and worrying picture.”

According to the YST survey, which yielded responses from seven per cent of England’s primary schools (1,392) and 12 per cent of secondary schools (554), in the last school year five-to-seven-year-olds spent an average of only 102 minutes per week taking part in PE. That compared to 126 minutes in 2009-10, the final year of the Government’s annual PE and School Sport Survey, which was controversially scrapped when the Coalition took office.

For children aged seven to 11, the 2009-10 and 2013-14 figures were 127 minutes and 114 minutes, respectively, with a similar drop recorded among those aged 11 to 14. The YST research also found that the average number of links between schools and community sports clubs had almost halved from more than nine to five.

The charity admitted that it was difficult to compare the 2009-10 and 2013-14 surveys on a like-for-like basis as the Government’s had boasted a 99.8 per cent response rate, participation in it having been mandatory. However, it insisted that its own data was “statistically reliable”.

Its findings also supported other more limited research conducted since London 2012, during which it emerged that the Department for Education had scrapped a target for state schools to provide two hours a week of PE.

That was after it also abolished £162 million of ring-fenced funding for national School Sport Partnerships, the outcry over which prompted a partial about-turn in 2013 and a commitment by the Prime Minister last year to extend a £150 million-per-year primary school pot until 2020 should the Conservatives remain in office.

However, the YST believes more needs to be done to tackle obesity and will launch its manifesto, Unlocking Potential: A Manifesto for PE and School Sport, at the House of Lords this afternoon.

That manifesto cites figures from recent research which found only 21 per cent of boys and 16 per cent of girls met recommended guidelines for one hour’s moderate exercise per day and that British children born today were on course to be 35 per cent less active by 2035.

The document calls for every child to receive at least two hours of “high-quality” PE per week and an additional three of other physical activity.

Campbell said: “Our manifesto demonstrates how PE, school sport and physical activity: improves physical health; boosts mental health and builds resilience; creates active habits for life and boosts academic achievement. We have set out where we believe any future Government should focus its efforts if we are to stand any real chance of reversing the worrying trends that are leading to increasing sedentary lifestyles amongst young people.”

The YST manifesto is being published in the week the grassroots funding body Sport England launched its “This Girl Can” campaign to address the disparity in physical activity between the genders.

The DfE last year commissioned its own survey of 586 primary schools which showed their pupils spent an average of 122 minutes each week doing PE, up 13 minutes on 2013. A DfE spokesman said last night: “As part of our plan for education, we want children to get into the habit of playing and enjoying sport – both in lessons and after school. That’s why we are giving primary school headteachers over £450 million of funding to spend on improving PE – and our own research shows they are using it to deliver more and better sport.

“Our findings show that primary schools are delivering more than two hours of PE each week, and it has increased by an average of 13 minutes in the last year; 83 per cent of schools also reported an increase in participation in after-hours sports since the introduction of the funding. We are pleased that the Youth Sport Trust’s own figures show that PE lesson time has actually increased for pupils in years 10 to 13.”

Clive Efford, the Shadow sports minister, accused the Coalition of undoing Labour’s work in increasing from 25 per cent to 90 per cent the number of children taking part in two hours of PE and sport each week. He said: “This Government was handed a golden legacy on sport and they have totally failed to build on the success of the Olympics and inspire a generation.”

rank_75.title: Sporting events leave a lasting legacy
rank_75.text:
A global sporting event, such as the Olympic and Paralympic Games, can these days be an economic boon to its host

The UK economy enjoyed a trade and industry boost of £14.2bn in the two years after the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games, according to the UK Government, beating the four-year target of £11bn in less than half the time. By 2017, the Games will have injected £16.5bn.

The second annual report on the legacy from the 2012 Games showed the economic benefits came from businesses securing contract wins, additional sales and new foreign investment.

For example, British companies Bluecube and International Stadia Group have won deals to provide stadiums around the world since 2012.

Oxford Economics says that, by 2020, the gross value added economic impact of the Games will be £28-£41bn.

Source: UK Government, Mayor of London

rank_28.title: Olympic Stadium cost rises to £702 million ahead of West Ham hand over - and tax payer will pay for most of it
rank_28.text:
The public will end up paying at least £100 million more than first thought towards converting the Olympic Stadium into West Ham United’s new home.

The cost of redeveloping the London 2012 centrepiece into a Premier League ground was announced to be £272m by the London Legacy Development Corporation, taking the overall bill for the venue to £702m.

That is a whopping £118m more than had previously been revealed , almost all of which will be paid for by the public purse.

To compound matters, West Ham will still contribute a grand total of just £15m under the terms of its 99-year anchor tenancy of the stadium, which was originally built for £430m.

An artist impression of what stadium will look like when West Ham move in

It was already forced to increase the budget for Balfour Beatty to construct a new roof from £154m to £189.9m following complications.

The LLDC defended the costs by claiming it was part of a regeneration programme that would deliver and additional economic benefit to east London of “well over £3 billion”.

It added: “The stadium work included the removal of the original roof and light paddles and installation of a new permanent roof, the largest of its kind in the world. The 45,000sqm cantilevered roof needed significant strengthening of the superstructure to support the 8km of cable net, 112 steel rafters, 9,900 roof panels and 14 light paddles each weighing 45 tonnes. The new roof covers every seat in the venue, improving the acoustics and spectator experience.

Image A: Post-conversion Olympic Stadium in athletics mode

Image B: Post-conversion Olympic Stadium in football mode

“An innovative retractable seating system required the removal of the lower seating bowl. The 21,000 movable seats bring the fans close to the pitch for football and rugby ensuring the stadium has a long-term legacy. Other works included installing catering facilities, toilets and turnstiles, all of which were only temporary during the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games.”

As well as being the new home of West Ham, the stadium will stage a range of other sporting events and become the new home of British Athletics.

Even before re-opening permanently, it will host the Sainsbury’s Anniversary Games, a Barbarians v Samoa rugby union fixture, five matches in the Rugby World Cup and an England v New Zealand rugby league international.



Boris Johnson blames Labour Government of mid-2000s for the additional costs

LLDC chief executive David Goldstone said: “We have invested in transforming a temporary athletics venue into a permanent world class multi-use arena that has a secure and long-term sustainable future. This has required a significant amount of work and innovative engineering solutions.

“Alongside the transformation workm the deals signed with British Athletics and West Ham United and the appointment of a stadium operator ensures the stadium will pay its way and not require any continuing subsidy from the taxpayer.”

Boris Johnson, the Mayor of London and LLDC chairman, blamed the Labour Government of the mid-2000s for the additional costs.

“A very bad call was made when those in charge at the time backed a stadium construction plan that would leave the Olympic Park with a much smaller, mouldering and tumbleweed ridden arena following the Games,” he said.

“Following that plan would have literally torn the heart out of the park and put at risk the incredible economic regeneration we are now seeing in east London.

“Our remedy offered long term sustainable investment in order to protect an iconic stadium that Londoners took to their hearts, and which is now set to be home to almost every conceivable sport, concert or community event for decades to come. We’ve created a knockout venue that will drive and sustain thousands of jobs, where we’ve ensured that a hefty share of the profits will be paid back into taxpayer coffers and which provides a genuine Olympic legacy for our city.”

rank_169.title: The truth about cycling safety
rank_169.text:
Last week, Ying Tao, a 26-year-old Cambridge graduate, recently married and with a great job in the City, was crushed to death under the wheels of a tipper truck.

She became the eighth cyclist to die on London’s roads since the start of this year. Six of the fatallities were women, all of whom died in a collision with a lorry.

Her death, and those of fellow women in very similar circumstances, has once again ignited the debate about cycling safety in Britain.

A protest was organised the next day at the place where she was killed, one of London’s most prominent landmarks: the junction of the Bank of England and the Royal Exchange.

“This is gendered,” said Dr Sarah Wollaston, the Conservative MP. “I don’t think the Secretary of State can ignore this any longer: there are specific dangers to women from HGVs in London – and there’s something he could do about it tomorrow.”

Is the Olympic legacy in danger of being crushed? According to British Cycling, the gold-medal performances of Victoria Pendleton and Laura Trott helped encourage 250,000 more women to start regularly cycling since the 2012 Games. But anyone reading the headlines this week might understandably refuse to join them.

However, the tragedy of Ying Tao’s death, and all the other women on London’s roads, do not fit the long-term picture.

On Thursday, the Department for Transport published its annual road safety statistics. They showed that last year, 113 cyclists died in Britain. This was a touch above the year before, when 109 were killed, but considerably lower than the 134 a decade ago – and just a fraction of the 1,536 killed in 1934.

The long-term trend is that cycling deaths are falling.

So far in 2015, according to the Beyond the Kerb blog which unofficially monitors casualties, there have been 53 fatalities – which would suggest that, if anything, we may see fewer deaths than usual this year.

There is, undoubtedly, a specific problem with women cyclists and heavy lorries in London. Most experts suggest that women are more likely to be cautious at junctions and, as a result, be left in a lorry’s blind spot as the vehicle turns left. And London’s construction boom has seen more tipper trucks on the roads, many with poor safety features.

Big, articulated trucks pose a danger to cyclists (Photo: Alamy)

• Should we ban HGVs from our rush-hour roads?

• Four outlandish ideas to fix London's cycling problem

But, overall, women, are less likely to be killed than men. The DfT says that women make up 21 per cent of all the distance travelled in the UK on bicycles, but only 18 per cent of the deaths.

Indeed, as a cyclist – male or female – you are less likely to die than at any time since the motorcar was first seen on Britain’s roads.

But it would be wrong to be complacent, because buried within the official statistics were two very worrying phenomena, which get talked about less frequently.

Namely, that far more deaths occur on rural roads than on urban ones – despite the London headlines. Secondly, though deaths are falling, serious injuries are increasing – and increasing at an alarming rate.

Indeed, 3,401 cyclists were seriously injured last year on Britain’s roads, a jump of 8.2 per cent on the year before. This was not a blip. They have increased in nine out of the last 10 years, and are up significantly from 2,174 serious injuries in 2004.

Dr Rachel Aldred, senior transport lecturer at the University of Westminster, says: “Yes, deaths often rightly hit the headlines. But serious injuries can involve lives being cut short and serious disabilities.

“It is concerning. Safety in numbers is not naturally following on.”

Ed Morrow, at Brake, the road safety charity, says: “There are more incidents happening where people’s lives are being put at risk. This isn’t just a statistical blip. This is a serious a long-term trend.”

There was a hope that the sheer weight of cyclists on the roads would force both drivers and local authorities to create a safer environment. But this has not happened.

One who knows to his cost is John Whiteley, 71, who has been cycling seriously for 55 years – much of it in the dramatic hills surrounding his Halifax home.

John Whiteley, 71, near his Halifax home (Photo: Paul Macnamara/Guzelian)

On January 2 this year, a clear day, he was out with a friend for a pleasure ride on the B6118, a country road that runs around Huddersfield up to the Emley Moor television aerial. As usual, he was wearing his fluorescent orange vest.

“It was about midday. And this Volvo estate came up from behind and the corner of his car hit me.” The impact broke his leg, and he went flying into the grass verge, spraining his ankle into the bargain.

What did he think? “Bloody hell, what a terrible way to start the year.” He has yet to fully recover his mobility, and still feels “rusty”.

John Whiteley wearing his orange jersey that he was wearing the day he was hit

There are no conclusive answers why fatalities are falling as a long term trend, and serious injuries are increasing. The obvious answer is that there are more cyclists on the road – but accidents are increasing at a faster rate than the number of two-wheels. Morrow says: “The fact it’s going up faster than cycle traffic means we can’t just blame more cyclists on the road. It’s a very complex issue, but there are various factors.

“Our urban road environment is still designed with the car as king. There is money starting to go into cycle infrastructure, but it has been so piecemeal so far.”

Other cyclists suggest that the cuts to road policing mean poor and drunk drivers are not being deterred.

• Why motorists should thank cyclists for the car

• Cycle safety: why Chris Boardman is wrong about high-vis jackets

Whiteley himself has his own theory. “Hospitals are far better now,” he says. Ten years ago, he was involved in another cycling accident, far more serious than the one that broke his leg. “I was in a really bad way, and if it had happened 15 years before that, I’m not sure I would have survived. But the doctors are so good now.”

One thing that medicine cannot do, however, is help the disproportionate number of cyclists dying on rural roads. Country roads only account for 32 per cent of cycle traffic, but 58 per cent of all the cycling deaths.

The main reason is obvious: speed. David Murray, at CTC, the cycling advice group, says: “If you get hit on a rural road, you are more likely to be hit at speed, and you are more likely to be killed.”

As rural drivers are less accustomed to sharing the road with cyclists, they can be taken by surprise. “In London, Bristol and Newcastle, you do expect to see lots of cycling traffic in small confined spaces as part of the traffic mix. As a motorist, you are likely to be aware of cycling and hopefully less likely to cause an incident and accident. In a rural space, motorists are often caught unawares.

“And those rural roads are just not good enough. There are very few cycle lanes.” Netherlands is invariably held up as the shining example: high-quality cycling infrastructure can be found both in cities and in the countryside, where separate cycle lanes are common. There, 37 per cent of short journeys (of less than two miles or so) are taken on a bike. In Britain, it is about 3 per cent.

Amsterdam was not always the ideal cycling city

It is easy to dismiss the Netherlands – with its endless flat countryside and culture of two wheels, as something we can not replicate. But as Melissa Henry, director at Sustrans, the charity that promotes safer, healthier travelling, says: “In the Netherlands and other European nations renowned for their bike use, they were pretty much following the same path as us up until the mid-1970s.” Bike use was falling at the same rate as Britain, and car use was increasing. “But they made a conscious decision to invest more in infrastructure.”

Henry adds that better, and separated, cycle lanes – both in cities and the countryside – are crucial to increasing the take-up as well as the safety of cycling in Britain. “The reason why so many women, children and old people, don’t get on their bikes is that they just don’t feel safe. The perception is the reality. And to change the perception, we have to change the physical environment.”

Segregated cycling lanes in central London. Rarely seen in rural areas

Whiteley’s accident is only one of many that will happen on country roads this year. As he says: “Rural roads are many, many times worse than when I started cycling.”

Not only are they busier with cars, they are increasingly full of lorries avoiding congested A-roads: “Motorists used to be so much more considerate. They’d all mostly been cyclists, too. Families used to cycle together back then. They understood what it meant to be a cyclist. People drive faster now, and there’s been a general downturn in manners. People don’t give a damn.”

Undoubtedly, millions more needs to be spent on infrastructure to improve cycle safety – be it the increase in serious injuries or the deaths on rural roads, or under the wheels of an HGV in a city. But an increase in old-fashioned courtesy might start to make a difference, too.
