As rural drivers are less accustomed to sharing the road with cyclists, they can be taken by surprise. “In London, Bristol and Newcastle, you do expect to see lots of cycling traffic in small confined spaces as part of the traffic mix. As a motorist, you are likely to be aware of cycling and hopefully less likely to cause an incident and accident. In a rural space, motorists are often caught unawares.

“And those rural roads are just not good enough. There are very few cycle lanes.” Netherlands is invariably held up as the shining example: high-quality cycling infrastructure can be found both in cities and in the countryside, where separate cycle lanes are common. There, 37 per cent of short journeys (of less than two miles or so) are taken on a bike. In Britain, it is about 3 per cent.

Amsterdam was not always the ideal cycling city

It is easy to dismiss the Netherlands – with its endless flat countryside and culture of two wheels, as something we can not replicate. But as Melissa Henry, director at Sustrans, the charity that promotes safer, healthier travelling, says: “In the Netherlands and other European nations renowned for their bike use, they were pretty much following the same path as us up until the mid-1970s.” Bike use was falling at the same rate as Britain, and car use was increasing. “But they made a conscious decision to invest more in infrastructure.”

Henry adds that better, and separated, cycle lanes – both in cities and the countryside – are crucial to increasing the take-up as well as the safety of cycling in Britain. “The reason why so many women, children and old people, don’t get on their bikes is that they just don’t feel safe. The perception is the reality. And to change the perception, we have to change the physical environment.”

Segregated cycling lanes in central London. Rarely seen in rural areas

Whiteley’s accident is only one of many that will happen on country roads this year. As he says: “Rural roads are many, many times worse than when I started cycling.”

Not only are they busier with cars, they are increasingly full of lorries avoiding congested A-roads: “Motorists used to be so much more considerate. They’d all mostly been cyclists, too. Families used to cycle together back then. They understood what it meant to be a cyclist. People drive faster now, and there’s been a general downturn in manners. People don’t give a damn.”

Undoubtedly, millions more needs to be spent on infrastructure to improve cycle safety – be it the increase in serious injuries or the deaths on rural roads, or under the wheels of an HGV in a city. But an increase in old-fashioned courtesy might start to make a difference, too.

rank_164.title: Letters: There simply isn’t room in west London for Heathrow expansion
rank_164.text:
SIR – While it might be desirable from a commercial point of view to expand Heathrow, from a social perspective it will be a disaster.

The proponents claim it will create 70,000 new jobs, but where are the employees going to live? Houses in west London and the outer suburbs already cost upwards of £200,000 and prices are rising. There is very little building land available in these places, without encroaching on the green belt, and immigration has led to a growing number of “beds in sheds” in areas such as Southall and Slough.

Probably every school within 20 miles of Heathrow is full, with no room for expansion.

Traffic congestion will also increase with concomitant air pollution – which, in a lot of the London area, already exceeds EU recommended limits.

With a little foresight, Greenham Common airbase, which was suitable for large jet aircraft, could easily have been connected to the main rail line from London to the West and to the M4. There are other military airfields along this route which should also have been considered as possible sites for a new major civil airport.

As Britain does not just consist of London, “Boris Island” is too far east to be of any value to the Midlands, the North or the West.

Enid Hope

Slough, Berkshire

SIR – My company employs about 140 people at offices in Newcastle, Glasgow, London and Hong Kong. It has partners in Barcelona, Paris, Sydney and Melbourne. Clearly, ease of international travel is of vital importance to our development, and this is the case for many British-based international consultants in the construction sector.

Therefore, delays in the development of increased capacity at Heathrow have a detrimental effect on our international ambitions.

David Cameron has committed himself to “get Britain building”. We urge the Government to embrace the findings of the Davies commission and start the project at Heathrow.

Mark Thompson

Newcastle upon Tyne

SIR – As Boris Johnson, the Mayor of London, points out, Britain needs a long-term, sensible solution for a competitive airport hub. Neither Heathrow nor Gatwick meets this key objective.

The Government must set the commission’s report aside and not allow lobbyists to hijack the agenda.

As Mr Johnson says, the “truly long- term solution” is a four-runway hub in the Thames Estuary.

Joe Seet

London EC1

SIR – Boris Island is the obvious solution for an international airport for the 21st century.

Get on with it, sell Heathrow for housing and relieve the demand for building land elsewhere.

R G Hopgood

Kirby-le-Soken, Essex

Price of atomic war

Photo: EPA

SIR – As a Londoner who survived the Blitz, as well as the V1 and V2 rocket attacks, I well remember the joy with which we greeted the news that Japan had finally surrendered.

At the age of 11, I gave no thought to the cost: the thousands of innocent Japanese lives sacrificed.

Many times since becoming a father and then a grandfather I have wondered if it was necessary. Why could the Allies not have shown the Japanese the power of these weapons by inviting them to a demonstration – the obliteration of some small atoll in the Pacific Ocean, for instance?

I’ve always wondered if another approach might not have achieved a more honourable victory.

S T Hedges

Cheveley, Cambridgeshire

SIR – I will never forget the silence between adults the day it was announced that the atomic bomb had been dropped on Hiroshima.

Tim Kinross

Selsey, West Sussex

Cold callers

SIR – My landline number is registered with the Telephone Preference Service (TPS), but I receive an average of 35 nuisance calls per month to my mobile phone, not to mention at least three text messages a day.

Each time I block a number, the same message comes from another number. As I never give out my mobile details, have never had payment protection insurance, nor have I been involved in any accident over which I might hope to claim compensation, I am perplexed as to how these people got my number and what they hope to achieve by persistently contacting me.

Linda Bos

Midhurst, West Sussex

Give a gull a bad name

SIR – I recently visited Sidmouth, Devon, which was hugely crowded because of the annual folk festival.

Every day, thousands of people were wandering along the sea front, eating fish and chips and ice creams. Not once did I see one of the many gulls hovering overhead swoop in to steal a meal.

They were noisy, and one scored a direct hit on me, but that is the worst they could be accused of. Where did the gulls in other seaside towns learn their aggressive behaviour?

Lorimer Burn

Guildford, Surrey

Sunday trading laws

SIR – It is extremely disappointing that the Government is seeking to make changes to Sunday trading laws, particularly after promising before the election it had no plans to relax them.

Devolving powers to vary opening times to local authorities and elected mayors amounts to deregulation by the back door. It is a recipe for chaos in the retail sector, with each area of the country having different regulatory regimes. That is hardly “cutting red tape” – a stated aim of this Government.

The Sunday Trading Act is a valued British compromise that has worked well for more than 20 years. Retailers can trade, customers can shop and staff can work, while Sunday remains a day of communal rest. This allows shop workers to spend time with their families and it respects the views of those who want to keep Sunday special for religious reasons.

Relaxing Sunday trading laws will simply spread the same customer expenditure over a longer period. The trial of abolishing Sunday trading hours during the London Olympics proved to be a flop: small shops lost trade, sales declined overall and staff came under pressure to work longer.

Keeping Sunday special is essential to the fabric of our society. Longer Sunday opening will have a dramatic effect on family life for no economic gain. We urge the public to participate in the Government’s consultation.

John Hannett

General Secretary, Union of Shop, Distributive and Allied Workers

Rev Dr Malcolm Brown

Director of Mission and Public Affairs, Church of England

James Lowman

Chief Executive, Association of Convenience Stores

Michael Trend

Spokesman, Keep Sunday Special

Impressive results belie grammar school failings

SIR – Richard Tuck is wrong to justify the re-introduction of grammar schools by comparing their examination results with those of comprehensives. Grammar schools select on ability and usually enrol the top 35 per cent of the ability range. Comprehensives take the full spectrum of ability.

The only realistic and fair comparison is between the results of the top 35 per cent of comprehensive students and the performance of all pupils from selective schools. In many areas, this simple comparison destroys the myth of comprehensive school failure and the academic superiority of grammar schools.

I was the headmaster of a comprehensive school where the top third invariably achieved a 100 per cent pass rate, the majority with As or A*s. I find it scandalous that, with such an overwhelming advantage due to the ability of their intake, a majority of selective schools regularly fail to ensure that all of their pupils achieve at least five GCSEs at A*-C.

Paul Strong

Claxby, Lincolnshire

SIR – I agree with Mr Tuck that, with some exceptions, comprehensive schools have failed. However, I do not agree that grammar schools should be brought back, as this would mean the return of the Eleven Plus and of secondary modern schools – which were themselves failures, because their pupils were, in effect, rejects.

We need of a new kind of selective education, without examinations. Why not have a system where every primary school nominates at least 30 per cent of its pupils to proceed to an academic type of school, with the remainder going on to a well resourced technical school, with links to industry?

Ivor Arnold

Barry, Glamorgan

The Olympic legacy should be sports for all

Photo: Paul Doyle / Alamy

SIR – Tracey Crouch, the minister for sport, makes some excellent points (“Don’t lose the impetus of London 2012”).

However, her nine-week public consultation must start with scrutiny of schools in the state sector and a resolution to offer all young children the opportunity to become more athletic, regardless of age or ability.

The basics of learning to run and hand-eye coordination, coupled with an understanding of how good it feels to be fit and active, are vital if we want children to choose to take part in sport. Otherwise, declining numbers of those engaged in sport will see us become a spectator-based sporting nation rather than a participating one.

The legacy of the London Olympics should also have seen the minister for sport elevated to an independent Cabinet post rather than sitting within a shared department.

Jamie Salmon

Crowthorne, Berkshire

Driverless night trains

SIR – London’s Underground drivers went on strike last week because they were unhappy with the pay and conditions being offered to extend the service overnight.

Would this not be a good opportunity to extend the use of automatic driverless train technology on the Underground?

Late-night workers and revellers would benefit from a 24-hour service, and the train drivers need not disturb their beauty sleep.

Brendan Barker

Manchester

Cooperative banking

SIR – With the wholesale closure of many bank branches in towns all over the country, is it beyond the wit of directors to join forces and run several banks from the same premises? That way, they could reduce costs but maintain a service to their customers.

My own small town is losing its only bank in October and the nearest alternative is more than 15 miles away.

Stephen Rees-Jones

Dulverton, Somerset

Verbosity pomposity

SIR – Celia Walden’s feature about the use of gobbledegook (“The perils of jargon: a plea to speak in plain English”) reminds me of attending lectures in the Sixties.

If a student became too verbose, others would chant: “To overawe your audience, simplicity eschew. / Never use a simple word, when a complex word will do.”

Robin Watson

Rookley, Isle of Wight

rank_199.title: England try to break new ground in Olympic arena
rank_199.text:
The stakes could not be ­higher as England aim to go 2-0 up in their three-Test ­series against New Zealand at the Olympic Stadium on Saturday afternoon.

After winning the opening Test 26-12 last week, Steve McNamara’s team are one victory from a first series triumph over southern­hemisphere opposition since 2007. Yet more than just the series will be on the line.

In the stadium that ­captivated a nation and made heroes of Mo Farah, Greg Rutherford and Jessica Ennis, rugby league gets to stage its own Super Saturday. Most encouragingly from the

organisers’ perspective, two-thirds of the tickets bought have been sold in London or the South East – a territory far removed from the sport’s traditional strongholds.

That opportunity to convert a new generation to the charms of the 13-man code is not lost on Tom Burgess, who was instrumental in that first Test victory, in Hull.

“I loved watching the ­Olympics and I remember seeing Mo Farah and Jess Ennis win. It was unbelievable,” he said. “The turf is hallowed with the amount of stars that were there in 2012, so to be walking through the same changing rooms and tunnels as they walked through is going to be a great experience. I can’t wait.

“I love that word, 'legacy’. It is probably one of the main things as a sports player. You get trophies and things like that, but if you can leave a legacy that is probably the biggest thing you can do. To think that you could inspire someone to play league in the South by putting on a good show this weekend is amazing. It shows what the main focus is about.”

McNamara, the England coach, has a direct experience of that Olympic legacy in action. “My daughter was not really fully engrossed in sport at that stage,” McNamara said. “But I ­remember my wife ringing me and saying, 'You won’t believe this. Grace has got up at 8am, put the Olympics on and sat there 12 hours a day watching it’.

“You hear these stories about inspiring a generation, and that was it for her – she joined a rowing club and is a rower now. That was my overriding memory from the Olympics.”

It is not just those in the crowd who need to be won over, but the players too. McNamara has no doubt that there will be a sizeable contingent of union scouts in the stands. Kallum Watkins, the centre, would be on many clubs’ shopping lists.

The threat no longer just comes from the 15-man code. Burgess has been following Jarryd Hayne’s transition to American football with interest, while Daniel Vidot, an Australian player with the Brisbane Broncos, has just signed for WWE, the wrestling organisation.

“Our players are tremendous athletes who can turn their hands to other things,” McNamara said. “There is a great awareness of the qual-ity and skill of the players within rugby league.”

While the Sam Burgess saga will be used as a case study in proving that the grass is not always greener, McNamara says it is incumbent upon the whole sport to put on more internationals to packed crowds.

“Ultimately these players want to play at the highest level and internationals are the highest level,” McNamara said. “The more we can create space within our calendar to play meaningful games in front of full houses is really important to convince ­players to stay.

“We need to retain our best players, but our longer-term goal is to increase the participants, which means it is hugely important that this game is a success for us.”

rank_44.title: American takeover of St Andrews shows Olympic legacy is alive and well
rank_44.text:
St Andrews is currently full of Americans. The happy coincidence of the Open being staged at the spectacular home of golf has brought them across the Atlantic in their thousands. They are everywhere you go, in their stars-and-stripes trousers, in the evening thronging the pubs, lubricating their throats in preparation for shouting, “It’s in the hole”, from the first tee.

At Wimbledon this year, too, the sound of foreign tones was far more noticeable. Drawn by the tradition of the event, relishing its arcane strictures, certain there was no other tennis gathering like it, the rest of the world converged on the south London lawns.

Everything about the tournament appeared to turn attractive when viewed from a distance: I was even told by a couple from Sweden who had lined up for more than eight hours and still not seen any tennis, that queuing was all part of the unique fun to be had there. Selling the queue overseas: that is some marketing skill.

rank_52.title: Desiree Henry: from lighting London's Olympic flame to competing in Rio
rank_52.text:
One of them has not competed since 2014, two are focused on becoming doctors and another has turned her back on representing Britain altogether.

If proof was ever required of the complexities of turning a talented junior career into a successful life in the senior ranks, you need look no further than the teenagers dubbed the “Secret Seven” after they were given the honour of lighting the London 2012 Olympic torch.

Their presence was a novel answer to a question that had kept the entire nation on tenterhooks for weeks. Conventionally befitting of a host nation’s sporting superstar, the most prestigious of Olympic roles was not given to Sir Steve Redgrave or David Beckham but seven complete unknowns selected by some of Britain’s most successful Olympians.

It was all part of a master plan to stress the London 2012 legacy narrative by focusing attention on those primed to be the stars of tomorrow.

Four years on, it has not quite turned out the way that was envisaged. But for every hard luck story there is a tale of triumph, and in this case there is Desiree Henry – at that point a world youth 200 metres champion chosen for the role by Daley Thompson and now, aged 20, the third fastest female sprinter this country has ever produced.

rank_6.title: The Olympic legacy: which housing areas have won gold?
rank_6.text:
Four years ago the eyes of the world were fixed on east London. Danny Boyle’s opening ceremony had fired the starting gun on the 2012 Olympic Games, the cycling was under way in the velodrome, and the swimming heats were in full flow in the new aquatic centre.

All these crowd-pleasing events, including the athletics held in the main stadium, took place within the grounds of the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park in Stratford, in the borough of Newham.

Historically Stratford had been considered an unglamorous location, overlooked by tourists, investors and home buyers, and overshadowed in the wider context of the capital. It was the London Olympics and the Olympic-driven regeneration that put the suburb on the map as a tourist destination and a great place to live and work.

rank_3.title: London's Olympic legacy - and why Rio should follow suit
rank_3.text:
Visiting the park today, the former industrial site is unrecognisable. The park officially reopened in April 2014 after work was done to remove the temporary facilities and change others for public use, and since then has welcomed 11 million visitors. Since the end of the sporting events, the focus has turned to providing jobs and housing, and there are currently two enormous office blocks being built as part of a new district called The International Quarter, which will eventually be home to 4m sq ft of commercial property space.

It is Kevin Chapman’s job to make sure the new office buildings don’t stand empty. He is the head of offices at Australian development company Lend Lease, which is behind the International Quarter, and says Lend Lease is already in discussions with occupiers about future office space.

“It’s been really good, particularly in the last six months, to see the park coming to life,” he says.

But critics have suggested that the area was on the up anyway as London expanded outside of its traditional core. Chapman says that it is likely that Stratford would have eventually been regenerated, but that the Olympics “meant it happened more quickly”.

“Ultimately I think it would have happened anyway because Stratford has always been so well connected,” he concedes.

rank_4.title: How the London 2012 Olympic legacy could turn the energy business on its head
rank_4.text:
"It was essentially a swamp, a complete wasteland,” says Wilfrid Petrie as he walks through the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park in East London.

It has been four years since the Stratford site’s transformation from East London wilderness to the host of London’s 2012 Olympic triumph was complete. But for the UK chief executive of the energy company which powered the Games, the area is a blueprint for a new kind of energy system which is only just beginning to emerge.

Engie is not a household name but the £32bn French company, formerly known as GDF Suez, is one of the largest power generators in the UK and stands shoulder to shoulder with the Big Six in the business energy supply market.

In winning the bid to power the London Olympic Park the company grasped the opportunity to turn its energy supply business on its head and create a model which is being quietly rolled out across the UK from Whitehall to Leeds.

Engie’s £100m Olympic scheme remains its most impressive example.

rank_99.title: Meet Zamzam Farah: Olympian, refugee and the most extraordinary athlete at this year's London Marathon
rank_99.text:
Less than a year after running round the Olympic Stadium in August 2012, the cheers of 80,000 spectators ringing in her ears, the Somalian 400 metres runner Zamzam Farah was living on the streets of London. Unable to return to her home country because of threats to her life, barely able to speak the language, hungry, cold and terrified, at just 21 years old she was adrift in the capital. This was not the Olympic legacy we had imagined.

“I was so scared,” she says, the tears falling as she remembers the gathering panic of being alone and lost in a foreign city. “So, so scared.”

Four years on and things are looking altogether brighter. Thanks to the intervention of a small, fleet-footed organisation called the Running Charity, she is now a legal resident in Britain, has a job and a roof over her head. And on Sunday she is joining 36,000 others on the start line of the London Marathon.

“I feel so happy to run again,” she says. “Whatever sport I’m doing I feel happy. If I get a chance to do sport 24/7 I would. It was hard, so hard. But not now, now that I have support from people who are really nice.”

Farah’s extraordinary story began in Mogadishu. Growing up in the war-scarred city, gunfire an ever-present soundtrack, she found comfort and release in sport. She was very good at it, too, joining in neighbourhood games of football. But as she grew into a teenager, she found herself the centre of a local storm. This is a country where growing Islamic fundamentalism insists on restrictive rules for women, which she was challenging every time she kicked a ball.

rank_176.title: How Prince Harry is creating the next generation of coaches
rank_176.text:
Five years after he had watched the Olympic closing ceremony there, Prince Harry was back at the London Stadium. This time he and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge were at the graduation ceremony of the latest bunch of apprentices from Coach Core, the organisation the Princes had established to create a whole new generation of sports coaches. It was, Harry said, the most appropriate place he could be. Because it was on that occasion, watching the end of London 2012, that he and his brother had come up with an idea that they felt would provide a tangible, lasting Olympic legacy.

“We believe our graduates are the future of coaching,” he said in a speech delivered from a podium which had been built roughly where Usain Bolt crossed the line to win the 100 metres in 2012. “We believe they are not just great coaches, but great mentors and great leaders of their community.”

Watching him speak were some of the 250 young people who have gone through the intensive, year-long apprenticeship programme. People like 18-year-old Alisha Wilson, now working as a full-time swimming coach in Glasgow after graduating in June. Or 19-year-old Muhammed Mumin, who spent a year on Coach Core before heading off to college to study business. Or Andre Nathaniel-George, an 18-year-old from Harrow, who is now working as a tennis coach for the London school sports charity Greenhouse.

rank_144.title: Holidays, heatwaves and hydrospeeding: Lee Valley legacy is a wild ride
rank_144.text:
Holidays and heatwaves. That is the double-whammy of a predicament facing working parents at the moment. How does one employ one’s sportingly active children to help ensure that the only screen they spend any amount of time with is sunscreen?

Before London 2012 was sold to the International Olympic Committee, a big part of their selling point was their “legacy” for the British public. Of course, we knew a lot of that was political guff and that by the time the Olympics had come and gone so would most of the politicians so there would be very little comeback on the subject.

But West Ham, eventually, moved into the Olympic stadium. It hosts a few high-profile athletics meetings and, in catering for something other than elite footballers and runners, the Prudential RideLondon-Surrey 100 will start in the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park on Sunday.

To prove just how non-elite this event is, when I turned up to the first London 100 in baggy shorts and with lights on my bicycle (unnecessary wind resistance and extra weight, apparently, in the world of stripped-down carbon road bikes), it prompted fellow Telegraph team member James Cracknell to ask if I was intent on finishing after dark.

rank_58.title: Beloved 'Blackheath Donkey' stabbed in suspected 'gang initiation' attack
rank_58.text:
A popular one-time Blackheath donkey was found stabbed in what his owner believes was a suspected "gang initiation" attack.

Bimbo, a 28-year-old donkey, was found bleeding from his side on Friday by one of the animal's minders and has since taken a "turn for the worse" after the wound became infected.

Owner Lorayne Ahmet said Bimbo had contracted laminitis, a disease similar to thrombosis in humans which can lead to animals being put down.

Ms Ahmet said she believed the attack on Bimbo may have been perpetrated as part of a "gang initiation".

"There have been a few stabbings in Eltham of late and I have seen youths messing around with the donkeys," she said.

"I think one of them could have stabbed Bimbo as a gang initiation task.

"I'd like to get my hands on them, put them in a field and let the general public do what they want with them."

The donkey is one of several owned by Ms Ahmet, whose father Len Thorne ran donkey rides in Blackheath, near Greenwich Park, London, for more than 60 years before he died in 2012.

The herd had lived for nearly 30 years in a field surrounded by six foot fences.

But in 2012 they were moved on after then Mayor of London Boris Johnson decided to build the Greenwich Equestrian Centre on the spot as an Olympic legacy.

rank_242.title: Sajid Javid was first British-Asian chancellor but may now be remembered as the second to never deliver a Budget
rank_242.text:
Sajid Javid made history as the first British-Asian chancellor - but may now be remembered as the second to never deliver a Budget. The former Home Secretary was in the Treasury for barely more than six months, the shortest-serving Chancellor since Iain Macleod, who died shortly after taking office in 1970. Mr Javid, who last year ran for the Tory leadership to succeed Theresa May, had his time in Number 11 coloured by tensions with Downing Street, namely Boris Johnson’s chief adviser Dominic Cummings. One MP told The Telegraph on Thursday: “A lot of this goes back to Vote Leave. Sajid is seen as one who betrayed him. He was seen as quite Eurosceptic, then came out for Remain.” One an outspoken Eurosceptic, Mr Javid embraced Remain under Mrs May, arguing about the effects of Brexit on business. When he took over as Chancellor on July 24, he focused his energy on stepping up no deal planning and was keen to change the Treasury image away from Philip Hammond’s “Beating heart of Remain” department. However the source said this did not convince the Vote Leave crowd which populated Number 10. “They still see him as a traitor,” the MP said. “Some of this is payback.”

Mr Javid was born in Rochdale. His father, Abdul Ghani-Javid, arrived in the UK in 1961 from Pakistan with a £1 note in his pocket and worked as a bus driver and cotton-mill worker before opening a shop selling clothes made by Javid’s grandmother. Mr Javid was one of five brothers growing up packed into a two-bed flat in Bristol, living above the family shop, which, he has said, became the target of racist attacks. He was the first in his family to go to university, studying economics and politics at Exeter. From there he pursued a career in finance, first at Chase Manhattan Bank, then Deutsche Bank, where he ran credit trading in Asia – a job that required regular flights to and from Singapore. In 2010, he was elected as an MP, reportedly giving up a rumoured £3 million salary for just under £66,000 a year. His first ministerial job, as Economic Secretary to the Treasury, came in 2012, and his second, as the Treasury’s Financial Secretary, in 2013. Mr Javid’s first Cabinet job was as Culture Secretary in 2014, moving to Business a year later, Housing in 2016 and then Home Secretary in 2018. One Tory MP said Mr Javid “represents graft, hard work. We need these kind of people inside the party.” From day one as Chancellor, Mr Javid was keen to dispel rumours of rifts with Number 10. He told allies he did not want there to be a “cigarette paper” of distance between him and the Prime Minister. He had known Mr Johnson since the Prime Minister’s days as Mayor of London, working with him on the Olympic legacy while serving as Culture Secretary. The former Chancellor is also close to Mr Johnson’s girlfriend, Carrie Symonds.

Mr Javid’s media advisor Sonia Khan was sacked by Dominic Cummings Credit : PA

rank_125.title: Youth Sport Trust: we must not fail in our London 2012 Olympics legacy
rank_125.text:
The Olympic and Paralympic Games are a once in a lifetime event that will get young people excited about sport.

Mr Steele said it is vital that schools are able to maintain this momentum and help young people develop sport and exercise as a habit that will keep them healthy and fit for the rest of their lives.

Amid continuing debate over the Olympic legacy, it was revealed that the Department for Education is no longer forcing state schools to provide 120 minutes of PE and sport. The Coalition insisted that head teachers should be given the freedom to organise physical activity themselves instead of following a “bureaucratic system”.

rank_173.title: £9 billion Olympics 'good value', says spending watchdog
rank_173.text:
The public sector funding package of just under £9.3 billion was more than three times the £2.4 billion cost estimated during the bid phase.

But the total is now expected to come in at just over £8.9 billion, saving £377 million, although the final figure will not be known until 2014.

The National Audit Office said: “By any reasonable measure the Games were a success and the big picture is that they have delivered value for money.

“The contribution of the ceremonies and the volunteers was a huge part of the success and we do not underestimate the work involved.

“Crucially, the Games passed off without major transport disruption or security incident. The scale of the construction programme and the fact that it was completed on time and within budget is impressive.”

Fireworks explode over the Olympic Stadium during a rehearsal for the opening ceremony (AP)

Boris Johnson hailed the report, saying: “The doomsters and Olymposceptics have been confounded yet again.”

The National Lottery stands to be reimbursed for much of its contribution, which will be available to distribute to good causes. This includes a share in the proceeds of the future sale of the Olympic Park.

Also in the report, the NAO warned that the Cabinet Office would have to show strong leadership in bringing together the various organisations responsible for coordinating the legacy of the Games.

Bradley Wiggins on his way to winning the gold medal in the men's individual time trial (AP)

The cost of the Olympic Delivery Authority’s programme to build venues and infrastructure is expected to be £6.7 billion, compared to the £8.1 billion that had been made available in the 2007 budget.

The NAO said success of the Games spanned from the opening and closing ceremonies through to the 11 million tickets sold for the Olympics and Paralympics, while meeting the huge challenge of recruiting and deploying 70,000 volunteers.

British athletes won 65 medals, including 29 gold, at the Olympics, and 120, including 34 gold, at the Paralympics.

Hannah Cockroft stormed away from the field to win GB's first athletics medal at the Paralympic Games (Getty Images)

Amyas Morse, head of the NAO, said: “Few could have envisaged how successful the London 2012 Games would turn out to be.”

But the Games had faced an added £514 million bill to cover venue security costs.

This included payment for extra troops and police that were deployed to plug the gap after contractor G4S fell short in supplying the agreed number of security guards.

The NAO’s post-games review said that 135,000 additional days of military personnel time had been provided, at a cost of £36 million, according to figures supplied by the Ministry of Defence.

(AFP/Getty Images)

It said the Home Office had calculated that the police service provided 12,000 shifts at an estimated cost of £6 million.

Margaret Hodge, chairman of Parliament’s Public Accounts Committee, said the exception to the smooth build-up and delivery of the Games was G4S's "unacceptable failure" to fulfil its contract.

Boris Johnson said: “This report puts into black and white the scale of the achievement in organising such a successful festival of sport, and pays tribute to the many different players who helped make the Games the greatest show on earth.”

Sports minister Hugh Robertson said the UK can look back with pride “on an outstanding Olympics and a groundbreaking Paralympics, which showed Britain at its best".

rank_136.title: London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games success brings record sport participation around England
rank_136.text:
The agency’s survey has revealed that 15.5 million people in England aged 16 and over took part in sport at least once a week over the past 12 months – a 750,000 rise on last year’s figure. The results showed an especially marked increase in enthusiasm since London hosted the Olympics over the summer.

Cycling has enjoyed the biggest benefit. Compared to last year, 200,000 more people in England are cycling at least once a week, bringing the number of regular cyclists in the country to just under two million.

Other Olympic sports have also benefited from London 2012, with a substantial rise in the numbers of people running, swimming and sailing at least once a week.

Jennie Price, the chief executive of Sport England, said: “During the spring and early summer before the Games started, when there was a lot of pretty disgusting weather, some of the pitch sports and other sports had a lot of things cancelled.

“This included cycling, whose figures went down, but they got a real boost in the three months around the Games. We’re also seeing some specific Olympic sports that have done really well this time. Sports like swimming, for example, that have struggled in the past have started to increase their numbers.”

The figures appeared to reverse the trend of recent years in which participation levels have either flatlined or shown only minor increases. Last year, the Government was forced to abandon the previous Labour government’s Olympic legacy target of an extra one million people playing sport three times a week, though the latest figures suggest that retreat might have been overstated.

According to Price, the number of people playing sport three times a week is now 7.4 million, compared to 6.1 million when London won the Olympic bid in 2005.

The one blot on the sporting landscape is the failure to achieve a substantial increase in sports participation among 16 to 25 year-olds, with only a 0.1 per cent rise over the past year.

The news is better for female sport, with the survey revealing that 500,000 more women are now taking part in sport or visiting the gym compared to last year.

Price said that, while there was no doubt that London 2012 had created a grassroots “bounce”, Sport England had been working closely with the governing bodies since 2009 to increase participation levels, with funding levels being set accordingly.

Last year, tennis and cricket had their funding cut after failing to meet their participation targets. Tennis has had an increase in numbers this year, though cricket participation has continued to fall.

Price said: “Cricket suffered from the weather. An awful lot of fixtures were cancelled and some teams had to abandon their seasons because their pitches were in such a state after all the rain. The underlying picture for cricket is actually quite strong.”

Sport England is due to announce its funding levels for the next four-year cycle this month. Price admitted the challenge would be to translate this year’s increase in participation into long-term growth. “When it comes to judging the Olympic legacy, we need to take a long-term view, but this does show that we’re on the right track,” she said.

rank_39.title: Fans recapture the magic of London 2012 Olympics at Anniversary Games
rank_39.text:
It all came packaged with the fantastically unappetising title of the Sainsbury’s Anniversary Games 2013 and, instead of athletes hanging desperately on the five rings at the absolute limits of their ambition and performing as if their very lives depended on it, we had a bunch simply enjoying a decent pay day en route to far more significant dates at the World Championships in Moscow next month.

So what? Who the heck cared? This was a moment for 65,000 to relive the time of their lives. Either that, or to enjoy the time of their lives they felt deprived of missing the previous year when they could not land tickets.

All sequels are inferior – apart from Godfather II, naturally – and Olympic sequels are bound to be more inferior than most but here was an illustration of the enduring power of last year’s national celebration.

Naturally, a year on, this has been a week for largely unwinnable arguments about the efficacy of the Olympic legacy or otherwise. For instance, the BBC today produced the results of a survey, suggesting two-thirds of the UK public felt the cost of the Games was worth the money.

What? As if they needed a survey to determine that. This night might have saved them the bother of all those polls. Of course, the Olympics were monstrously expensive and the legacy benefits highly debatable but what has never been in dispute is that they provided a taste of incredible theatre that proved wholly addictive.

What else could explain the extraordinary scenes here at the Olympic Stadium tonight? People forming vast queues for tickets even though both days and all 130,000 tickets had been sold out for this Diamond League fare in 75 minutes in the spring.

It was not the athletics factor at play, here; it was the Olympic factor, it was pure nostalgia.

So it was that they came on this lovely night in their thousands to rekindle the magic. Even the stewards were trying to recapture a touch of the old ‘Games makers’ bonhomie, letting kids use the megaphones to belt out directions to the punters.

Thus, there were the daft souls in their Mo Farah masks, or their Boadicea dresses, waving their “Go GB!” placards and posing, Usain Bolt-lightning style, over panoramas of bulldozers and ugly building sites. It was all slightly surreal, this attempt to recapture the spirit of 2012 amid the wasteland of 2013, but nobody seemed to mind one hoot.

The organisers did their best to recall the fun of 2012 but their choice of the woeful Colin Murray as an early master of ceremonies did not help. Did we really hear him try to get laughs by saying the identikit athlete would have “the stamina of Mo, the speed of Bolt and the bottom of Jess Ennis?”

Good grief. Truly pathetic.

Once inside the stadium, how the athletes must have savoured the night, though. The mind flashed back to that first Friday of the Olympic track programme when 80,000 were all neatly in place, ready to raise the roof for Ennis at 9am, a morning when every journeyman had his day and was cheered to the echo.

You felt for Sally Peake, a Welsh pole vaulter of no great pedigree who must suddenly have felt like Yelena Isinbayeva for a night.

When she cleared four metres, the sort of occurrence which might have engendered a brief round of applause and a bark from one man and his dog at a league meet for Birchfield Harriers, it was greeted with a roar which must have made her feel she had just struck Olympic gold.

International athletics bosses were sitting here, doubtless purring. Look at the sort of crowds the best athletes in the world attract at their other Diamond League meets. Not bad but no way could they sustain two days of extraordinary interest like this.

How the International Association of Athletics Federations must rub its hands in absolute glee at the prospect of being able to thin out the programme over two days yet still have 80,000 sell-outs.

Athletics comes over as a sport on the ropes, struggling desperately in the face of major doping scandals which just gnaw away relentlessly at its credibility.

Yet here was a night to forget all that and just savour the sight of the man who has sailed through all the controversy and keeps declaring to everyone: “I was made to inspire people and made to run. I was given a gift and that’s what I do. I am clean.”

Yes, another night to remember just what Usain Bolt means to athletics.

They wheeled him out on a motorised spaceship before the action got under way just for the crowd to be able to pay homage. For years, old rocket man has been doing this, carrying the sport on his back like Atlas, not just athletics’ main draw but its main hope.

Now, as he acknowledged his disciples while making his lap of honour, you could not help wondering if he is the sport’s last hope too.

rank_89.title: Sebastian Coe’s going for gold again – £2 million to be precise
rank_89.text:
Sebastian Coe wears his hard hat at a jaunty angle. He seems relaxed, as befits the man who masterminded the London Olympic Games . Compared with years of tours with builders he undertook as the 560-acre Olympic Park took shape, a look around a rather more modest project, covering only three-and-a-half acres, can hardly be taxing.

Yet he takes charge within minutes of arriving at the building on Euston Road, just along from the British Library in north London. When it is finished in 2015, it will house the Francis Crick Institute, Europe’s largest centre for biomedical research, where scientists will tackle Britain’s four biggest killers: cancer, neuro-degenerative illnesses, cardiovascular conditions and infectious diseases.

“I’m going to criticise your ducting,” he joshes with the construction manager, as we don high-vis jackets before going inside. “I had my own boots and a hard hat with my name on at the Olympic Park, so I know exactly what to do.”

Five minutes later, he interrupts as the manager is talking us through a scale model of the building. “On time and on budget!” he chants, drumming his knuckles on the glass cabinet around the model.

Lord Coe has already had three careers. First, he was a champion Olympic double gold medallist, then a politician and, latterly, he worked 19-hour days chairing the London Organising Committee for the Olympics, wresting the 2012 Games from Paris’s grasp and then staging them to worldwide acclaim. In his time off, he is father to four children, three of whom are teenagers. The latest addition to the family, a lurcher called George, is 11 weeks old.

Since the Olympic closing ceremony, he has taken on even more roles, chairing the British Olympic Association, advising the Prime Minister on the legacy of the Olympics, and serving as a trustee for half a dozen charities.

Now he is ready for yet another challenge, running the Sebastian Coe Charitable Foundation, which launches officially today. The fund aims to raise £2 million for the Crick building, among other projects, and I am joining him for his first tour.

Wasn’t he tempted to put his feet up instead? “I don’t think I’ll ever do that,” he bridles, as we descend to one of the Crick’s four basement levels in a rudimentary metal lift. “Why would I want to? As long as I find the world an interesting place I’ll wake up and do things I like doing.

“We’ve all talked about the Olympic legacy. So what’s my personal commitment? I thought this was somewhere I could actually make a difference.”

Named after Sir Francis Crick, the physicist who co-discovered the structure of DNA with the biologist James Watson, the institute is being built on the site of a former goods yard for St Pancras Station, which was heavily bombed in the Second World War and finally demolished in the Sixties.

The £650 million project is a partnership between Cancer Research UK, the Wellcome Trust, the Medical Research Council, University College London, King’s College and Imperial College. Around 1,500 scientists will be based in a “centre of excellence”, with computer scientists, mathematicians and engineers working alongside biologists, chemists and physicists.

It will replace separate laboratories researching the biggest killers, with the best scientific minds working alongside each other instead. By pooling their talents, the researchers hope to discover treatments and cures faster.

The building’s outer shell has taken shape rapidly and some of its terracotta stonework is now visible, blending in with the red brick façade of St Pancras. Inside, however, it is empty, aside from a few boilers. In fact, Cancer Research UK must still raise millions of pounds to build the laboratories.

Lord Coe has a personal motive for helping with fundraising. His mother, Angela, died from the degenerative brain disease known as progressive supranuclear palsy, or PSP, in 2005 (the disease that killed Dudley Moore). Only 10,000 people in Britain are thought to suffer from the disease, which slowly destroys nerve endings in the brain. Sufferers produce a surfeit of tau, a brain protein, which becomes tangled and damages nerve cells.

Little is known about what causes the disease. It is rarely passed down in families, but sufferers are thought to have a genetic disposition that makes them more susceptible. Other researchers have suggested it could be caused by environmental factors, including an unidentified poison that affects brain and nerve cells.

Lord Coe first noticed something was wrong in 1996, when his mother, a Rada‑trained actress, seemed less energetic than usual on a visit to Cornwall. But she was not diagnosed with PSP for another five years.

“At first you think, 'Is this just the ageing process?’ We all slow down at different rates. Then we thought she’d had a minor stroke. She started to lose her balance and then her eyesight started to fade, so we went to ophthalmologists and optometrists.” It was not until 2001, after a string of neurological tests, that doctors connected the different symptoms and diagnosed her.

“This is the most frustrating thing for PSP sufferers,” he says. “You want to get somebody who says, 'I’m seeing the big picture here: your eyesight is failing, and you’re having problems with your balance and swallowing because of the onset of this disease.’ ”

PSP, which generally begins to affect people at 62, is incurable, and there was little doctors could do to prevent Angela’s condition from worsening. “It is an unspeakably horrible disease,” says Lord Coe. “She was very active in her early seventies and would regularly beat her grandchildren at football in the garden. Suddenly, she started to slow down. My mother read voraciously and would have five books on the go at any one time, but she was trapped in a body that just did not do anything.

“She was mentally all there, but by the end she couldn’t read, couldn’t speak and could barely swallow her food. My dad [Peter, Coe’s former running coach] described it as watching somebody die millimetre by millimetre.”

Angela bravely allowed the National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery in London to study her degeneration. “She knew that it was not going to come to her rescue, but she often went in there for two or three days, to allow them to understand a little bit more about it,” says Lord Coe.

His mother died at the age of 75, just a few weeks before Britain was awarded the 2012 Games. Her drive to find out more about the disease inspires his support of the Crick. “She would have been fascinated by this place. I’m naturally cautious about talking about cures. But if we could get to the point where it was manageable, I would love that.”

He becomes even more enthused as we walk around the cavernous fourth floor of the building, where the laboratories will be located. “As a sprinter, all my training was interdisciplinary. I had physiologists, anatomists and nutritionists who were all working to get me to run quicker. So I’ve always felt that big breakthroughs come about when people talk to others about their own areas of interest.

“If you’ve got people understanding, for example, the nature of hepatitis as an illness, they can help with cancer because it is one of the leading reasons for liver cancer. These people will nominally be focusing on different pathologies, but all working together.”

We climb the fire escape stairs back to ground level and I leave Coe talking to the builders as they clock off for the day. “When it opens, they will get the biggest buzz,” he says.

“I have only been here for an hour but I get the same excitement I got talking to the builders on the Olympic Park. They are not just creating a building. This place can make history.”

For more information about the Sebastian Coe Charitable Foundation, visit sebcoe.co.uk/foundation

rank_7.title: Olympic Park legacy starting to fulfil its huge expectations
rank_7.text:
It may be three years since the Thomas Heatherwick-designed cauldron was lit by seven young athletes in front of 80,000 dignitaries and spectators and thousands more athletes to mark the start of 17 amazing days of sporting achievement, but the Olympic legacy lives on in east London.

Aside from this weekend’s Anniversary Games – timed to coincide with tomorrow’s anniversary of the London 2012 opening ceremony – memories of the Games continue.

As well as delivering a celebration of sport, a key pledge of those who brought the Olympics to London was that they would be a catalyst for regeneration in the Stratford area and beyond.

Three years on, is it too soon to judge whether the social and financial legacy of the London 2012 Olympics will be a lasting one? Or have the seeds of revival been sown? And how has the capital fared compared to other former hosts?

Legacy is often judged on the reuse of the landmark stadia – the most fundamentally unsustainable asset within the whole of an Olympic Park – according to Nigel Hugill, the executive chairman of developer Urban & Civic.

“Let’s start with the proposition that the least regenerative asset in an Olympic Park is the stadium,” he says.

Not so in London. Premier League football club West Ham is moving in – albeit with dedicated funds from Government and a significant capital investment from the club itself, which will also pay an annual usage fee for the duration of its lease. The club’s commercial activities will be run from there and players will train on the pitch as well as play all home games from the start of the 2016-17 season.



What West Ham's new stadium will look like

The redesigned venue will also host music concerts and house small businesses, as well as some Rugby World Cup matches this autumn.

Some of the other, small arena assets are also being reused. The Copper Box Arena which hosted handball, parts of the modern pentathlon and goalball in 2012 has attracted more than 60,000 visitors since it reopened in July 2013 as home to the London Lions basketball team and others. The London Aquatics Centre has received more than 1m visitors since it opened in April 2014 with more than 2,000 local schoolchildren accessing it through school swimming sessions every week.

Hugill says one of the reasons the assets are still under considerable use is because the London Organising Committee for the Olympic Games (LOCOG) played to a social need.

In the lengthy build-up to the Games the promise of reasonably priced homes for Londoners was a key part of the delivery strategy.

As the price of the average London home passes the £500,000 mark, according to recent figures from Nationwide, the former Athletes’ Village and now a sprawling housing scheme, is filling up.

The whole site – accounting for nearly 3,000 homes – was bought by Qatari Diar, the oil-rich state’s investment arm, and UK property developer Delancey Estates for £557m.

Now known as East Village, the development site contains a mix of social accommodation, “affordable” housing where residents are paying around 80pc to 90pc of the market rate to live there, and normally priced homes.

For Neil Young, the chief executive of Get Living London, it was important to get the balance right between using the Olympic brand and putting some distance between it and everyday life.

“When we first marketed the village we wanted to create a new place and new community without always looking to the past – although we are very proud of the Olympics and buyers are still genuinely excited by it.”

Plaques are going up across the site to show where athletes such as Usain Bolt or Jessica Ennis-Hill stayed.

“But more importantly we can see that the village is serving its local population,” Young says. “Half of our residents lived within a London postcode and within that number, half were from east London.” East Village along with all the other, smaller schemes, spread across the Olympic Park should bring 11,000 homes to London.

The Olympic legacy is not simply judged on sporting culture and housing need alone, however. Office and commercial space is the third piece of the jigsaw to create a vibrant Stratford.



Aerial view of the Olympic site in East London

“We are now bringing an office workforce to Stratford which it has not had so far,” said Kevin Chapman, head of commercial property at Lendlease.

The developer has planning consent for 4m sq ft of commercial buildings, of which 25pc is already pre-let to the Financial Conduct Authority and Transport for London. But a school of thought exists that suggests that the Olympic legacy will only be deemed a success because of the regeneration of Stratford that predated it.

“There is a myth that the Olympics in itself is extremely regenerative of an area – a myth that is picked up by those people who want to see the Games hosted in a certain area,” says Hugill.

“Let’s compare the relatives. Montreal has only just paid off its debts. Athens was palpably not regenerative and the Sydney Games was held in an out of town suburb and had little impact.”

The two examples that are held up as legacy successes are London and Barcelona, he adds, but in both instances regeneration around the site was already well under way.

“The notion that the Westfield shopping centre, already planned before London was awarded the Olympics, would not have been built otherwise is clearly ridiculous,” he says.



Westfield shopping centre, Stratford

But it seems that what the Olympics does do, on occasion, and in the right place, is reinforce the regenerative process if it is already in full swing.

“In London it accelerated private initiatives and turned them into political imperatives,” says Hugill. “I tried to persuade [the energy company] EDF and the National Grid to bury pylons in Lower Lea Marshes in order to clear the Westfield Stratford site for building. I had little success until after the Olympics was won and the contract was awarded to bury the pylons.”

In his view the long-term impact of the Olympics is not as strong as it is from a project such as Crossrail, which will fundamentally change more people’s lives on a daily basis – but there are softer effects. “What is the price you are prepared to pay to make the country feel good about itself?”

At the heart of the 2012 legacy success is the money committed by the Government, private businesses such as West Ham, developers and overseas investors. In fact, London is not the beneficiary of the regenerative powers of the Olympics – the Olympic legacy will be seen as a success because the Games were held in London.
